An idea is taken up antithetically: i. 97-98 lugicei=n…e)lugi/xqhs, especially in dialogue, v. 2-4; v. 14-17; v. 112-114. v. 124-126; v. 80, 82 fileu=nti…file/ei. xv. 60, 61 parenqei=n…h)=nqon: or the word runs through a passage; with loving repetition as--*nu/mfai, vii. 137, 148, 154. )*agea/nac, )*agea/nakti, )*agea/naktos, vii. 52, 61, 69. *moi=sai, xvi. 58, 69, 107. *ti/turos, iii. 2-4; *koma/tas, vii. 83-89, cf. xv. 143-4, especially the running repetition of a)oidh/, a)oido/s. xvi. 1, 19, 21, 24, 44, 50, 57. So parallelism between two periods is obtained: xii. 28, 34 o)/lbioi, o)/lbios; iii. 49, 50 zalwto/s, zalw=, and see note on i. 82 ta/ketai. Note i. 1 a(du/; 2 a(du/; 7 a(/dion; 65 a(de/a; 148 a(dei=an. So xvi. 5 ti/s ga/r is taken up in xvi. 13. a)/mnastoi, xvi. 42, is taken up antithetically xvi. 45. xvii. 26, repeated, xvii. 27; xviii. 44=xviii. 46; xxvi. 16, 18 *penqeu/s.
(k)
Simple verbal antithesis is used to produce this same symmetry of expression: xvi. 3, 4; xvi. 87:
a)riqmh/tous a)po\ pollw=n.
xvi. 105:
)*orxomeno\n file/oisai a)pexqo/meno/n pote *qh/bais.
xxv. 41; xv. 25; xvi. 101; xxviii. 24. Paronomasia, ix. 31; i. 34; xvi. 3; xxii. 65 ei(=s e(ni/; xiv. 63 polloi=s polla\ didou/s. xviii. 53. xvii. 42; ix. 32. vi. 23; xv. 93; xxix. 32.
(l)
Phrases are repeated (changed in form or not) in the same idyll. ii. 8=ii. 97; ii. 4=ii. 157. ii. 116=132. vii. 28=94; xvi. 7=28, 31-41. Either as above (i) setting out the leading idea in a new light, or returning as in ii. 157 sadly to the original sorrow.
(m)
Rhyme is used with considerable frequency:
(1)
The end of the hexameter rhymes with a word forming the weak caesura of the same line, xxvi. 30:
au)to\s d' eu)age/oimi kai\ eu)age/essin a(/doimi.
i. 96; vii. 62.
(2)
Mascul. caesura and end, i. 64, etc.; viii. 31; xxiv. 89. (3)
Each half of pentameter, Epig. ix. 4; xv. 4; xvi. 4. (4)
Second and fourth arsis, viii. 30, 61; xxv. 1, etc.
In the first and third case the effect is to round off and balance the two halves of the line; the ear is prepared for the cadence of the end of the line. This is not peculiar to Theocritus: graceful examples can be found both in Greek and Latin. Philetas:
kai\ ga/r tis meleoi=o koressa/menos klauqmoi=o.
Anacr. 75:
i)/sqi toi kalw=s me\n a)/n toi to\n xalino\n e)mba/loimi
h(ni/as d' e)/xwn stre/foimi/ s' a)mfi\ te/rmata dro/mon.
Propertius has a pretty triple rhyme, i. 8:
'Illa vel angustó mecum requiescere lectó
Et quocunque modó maluit esse mea.'
(n)
Lastly we may notice here the not infrequent repetition of a word immediately: xi. 72 w)= *ku/klwy *ku/klwy. i. 123 w)= *pa\n *pa/n. vi. 8 ta/lan ta/lan. Epig. iii. 6 feu=ge, feu=ge (cf. Epig. ix. 4, 9), generally for the sake of pathos. Instances might be multiplied from any language: it will be sufficient to remember Shakespeare's
'O Romeo, Romeo! wherefore art thou Romeo?'
M. Arnold's
'Strew on her roses, roses!'

Add to these points the fact that Theocritus writes generally in short rounded periods, often by the single line, with the daintiness but not the monotony of Catullus' hexameter, and it will be seen how widely his verse differs from the old Homeric e)/pos. We get melody in each separate phrase, not a sonorous march of the whole: the verse dwells affectionately on each detail and often looks back at what it has left, whatever be the feeling it would keep before us: effective for nature's sights, sounds, or a fondly remembered name; indignation at the greed of men; sarcasm directed at another (i. 97) or envy of good fortune (xii. 28).
The loud lyre of Homer is changed for the pipe of Pan.
The same characteristic appear in some degree in Vergil's Eclogues, distinguishing their metre from the 'ocean roll of rhythm' of the Aeneid.

div1.head: C.--The Authenticity of the Poems attributed to Theocritus.

div2.p:
In dealing with the question of authorship we have to follow three lines of evidence, (a) the testimony of MSS. existing or inferred; (b) the testimony of ancient writers,
scholiasts, grammarians who cite passages of Theocritus, imitations by Greek and Latin poets where such can be definitely traced to Theocritus; (c) internal evidence of style, grammar, vocabulary, versification.

An examination of this evidence leads to an unqualified rejection of the poems numbered in the traditional text xix, xx, xxi, xxiii, xxvii, and the ei)s *nekro\n )/*adwnin. xxv and the Megara must be accepted or rejected together. I have therefore included the Megara in the collection.

We must in the first place clear our minds from any prejudice arising from the new traditional orderDeparted from only by Ahrens and Brunck., which dates only from the edition of Stephanus (1566 and 1579). This arrangement has no support in the MSS. or early editions, but poems of Theocritus, Bion, and Moschus, are mingled together without clear assignment of author.

Setting aside the editio princeps (Mediolana, 1481) which contains i-xviii only we have to take into account four printed versionsA full account of the editions is given by Ahrens, Poet. Bucol. i. The whole question is discussed by Ahrens in Philologus, xxxiii; and Hiller, Beiträge zur Textgeschichte, Leipzig, 1888.:
(1) Aldine a (1495) i-xviii, Epit. Bionis, Europa, )/*erws *drape/ths, xix, Epit. Adonid. 20, 21, Megara, 1-13, Epit. Adonid. 35-fin., xxii. 1-44, 92-185, xviii. 52-59, xxiii, Syrinx, *nek. )/*adwn.
(2) Aldine b (1495), a correction and supplement of above.

(3) Juntine (1515) i, vii, iii-vi, viii-xiii, ii, xiv-xviii, xxii, xxiv, Europa, xxix. 1-25, xxvi, xxvii, xxviii, Megara, xxv, xxi, xxiii, xx, Epit. Adonidis, *nek. )/*adwn., Epit. Bionis, )/*erws *drap. xix, Epigrams, Syrinx, etc.
(4) Callierges (1516). The same contents, different order, xxvii standing last, before epigrams.
These two are practically one authority, being both prepared from a copy supplied by M. Musurus derived from a lost Codex Patavinus.
The MSS. vary enormously in contents and order of poems (see the descriptions of them in Ahrens' and Ziegler's editions, and in Hiller's Beiträge).

Of the editions above mentioned the Aldines go back to two Vatican MSS.--Vat. 1311 (11) and Vat. 1379 (18). Of these 11 is derived from a now mutilated MS., Vat. 1824 (23); 18 and the Ambros. 75 (c)--in its central portion--are derived from the Paris MS. 2832 (*m).

From a comparison of 23 (or its representatives) and *m, Hiller infers an archetype f containing i, v, vi, iv, vii, iii, viii-xiii, ii, xiv, xv, xvi, xxv, Megara, xvii, Epit. Bionis, xxii, xviii, xx, xxi, *erws, xix, Epit. Adonid. *nek. )/*adwn., xxiii; Epit. Achillis (Beiträge, p. 57 sqq.). Beyond this, in turn, can be reconstructed an older archetype *fm.From a comparison of *f with the MSS. m and p. This was smaller, and included i-xvi, xvii, xviii, Epit. Bionis, xxii, xxv, Megara.
What is added to this by *f is added from a new source, and, to judge from the condition of the text, an exceedingly bad source.
On this line then our MSS. are gradually reduced till we get to the respectable *fm. The suspected poems have no good tradition. They belong to the *f group only, and do not go back to *fm.
A. The second line to follow is that represented by Juntine and the Paris MS. D.

This MS. is divided into three parts--D1 i-iii, viii-xiii, iv-vii, xiv, xvi, xxix, Epigrams; D2 xvii, xviii, xv; D1 xxiv, xxii. 69-fin., xxvi, xxviii, Megara, xxv. 85-fin., 1-84, Epit. Bionis, finally, after three and a half blank pages, xxvii, Securis.
This adds to the *f group, xxiv, xxvi, xxviii, xxvii (D3), xxix, Epigrams (D1); of suspected poems it contains, xxvii, Megara, xxv.
Other MSS. to be taken into account are:--
(1) k (Ambros. 222, our best MS.), i, vii, iii-vi, viii-xiii, ii, xiv, xv, xvii, xvi, xxix, Epigrams.
(2) The corrections of D (Db in Ahrens).
(3) Ambros. 75 (c), first and fourth parts (Ziegler, p. vii).
(4) Vat. 1311--third part--11c, for xxiv. 1-87.
(5) Vat. 1311--first part--11a for xxviii, xxix. 1-8.

From D and the Juntine can be reconstructed, (1) Codex
Patavinus of Musurus, (2) archetype of Patavinus and D (*p, see Hiller, p. 4).
Db is better than D, akin to k, and must have been used by Musurus here and there (e. g. xxiv. 66). The origin of these corrections may be called *p2.
Now we get Db evidence in xxiv. 109, 45; xviii. 36, 20; xxv. 92, 114; Megara, 49; not in xxii, xxvi, xxvii; therefore the double tradition of *p *p2 attests xxiv, xviii, xxv, Megara.
For xxiv we have also 11c, a MS. showing marked peculiarities, and not derived from *f or *p or *p2.
Ambros. 75 (c)--first part--contains, Epigrams, xxiv, xxvi, xxvii, agreeing with D in almost every respect and forming no new authority:
e.g. xxiv. 66 xre/os Db om. D c.
xxiv. 26 ei(/leto Db: ei)/xeto D c.
xxvi. 34 ka/tqeto D c: qh/kato Junt.
xxvii. 8. om. D c, etc.
xxiv. 91 dra/konte c Db: dra/kontesas, D by copyists error and false correction.
The difference of arrangement in c and D is easy of explanation.
The MSS. evidence for the idylls included in D is therefore--
For xviii, xxv, Megara--*p *p2 *f *fm.
For xxii--*fm *p.
For xxiv--*p *p2 11c.
For xxvi, xxvii, *p (represented by D c Junt.).
For Epit. Bionis, *fm *f *p.
The last is obviously untheocritean; its exclusion from *p2 is a testimony to the superiority of that collection.
xxvi has only the support of *p, but has external authority, and is placed among pieces undoubtedly genuine in D.

xxvii is placed apart from the rest in D, is not in *p2, and that it came into *p from a new and bad source is shown by the striking deterioration in D's text. The differences of Juntine are due to conjecture only as in Id. xxi.
xxii has explicit external authority.
xxvii may therefore be rejected, and we get as undoubtedly genuine, xviii, xxii, xxiv, xxvi, possibly Megara and xxv.
Idylls i-xvii are contained in nearly all the good MSS., and, so far as such evidence goes, cannot be impugned.
There remain xxviii, xxix, xxviii, and the Epigrams.

Only one MS.--c--contains the three Aeolic poems. D has xxviii, xxix. Juntine has xxviii, xxix. 1-25. 11a has xxviii, xxix. 1-6. k has xxix, with Argument and Scholia. In character D resembles k; c differs from both and resembles 11a (Db does not appear).
The genealogy of the MSS. must be somewhat as follows:

[D places xxix in first part as in k. xxviii in Dc; the connexion of D with *p is very doubtful here. d probably *p2. ai)ol. g suffered two mutilations losing (1) xxix. 26-end and 30; (2) xxix. 7-24. c was copied before mutilation; 11 (with Ahrens' MSS. G. 6. c) after second mutilation, Patavinus after first.

Ahrens--Philol. xxxiii. p. 589--holds that xxx came into c from a new source, arguing from absence of argument and corruption of text. But c has all three poems in one hand; and continuously written; and the corruptions in xxx are nearly all at the end of lines--an indication that it was copied from a torn MS.]

The name of Theocritus is not attached to these poems in the MSS., but c and vi have arguments to xxviii; k to
xxix. These arguments come from one archetype, and that of xxviii assumes Theocritean authorship. The Epigrams probably came from same source as xxviii-xxx. They have the authority of k, D, and Juntine (hence *p), and independently that of the Anthology.
Hence, in conclusion, our good MSS. accept as genuine i-xvii, xxii, xxiv, xxvi, xxviii-xxx, Epigrams, xxv, Megara; the last two always placed together.

None of our MSS. are older than the twelfth century, the majority belong to the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries; they represent therefore only Byzantine tradition. A study of the MSS. shows further that in Byzantine times the poems of Theocritus had to be collected from scattered sources, all our fuller MSS. are compilations. Ahrens (in Philol. xxxiii) has attempted to show what collections of Theocritus' poems were made at various times, and argues for the existence of three of importance:

(1) i-ix, made by Artemidorus a scholar of Augustan times. He argues from the fact that many MSS. have only i-ix: that Scholia to i-ix are found in some MSS. drawn from a different source to the rest. That the collection existed is clear; but the MSS. containing it are only bad MSS. Artemidorus certainly made a collection, but it certainly included more than i-ix as his epigram shows:--(A. Pal. ix. 205)
boukolikai\ *moi=sai, spora/des poka/, nu=n d' a(/ma pa=sai
e)nti\ mia=s ma/ndras, e)nti\ mia=s a)ge/las.
(2) i, v, vi, iv, vii, iii, viii-xiii (as in MSS. Q p w). This was undoubtedly an early collection.
(3) i, vii, iii-vi, viii-xiii, ii, xiv, xv, xvii, xvi, xxiv, xxii, xviii, xxvi, xxviii-xxx, xxvii, Epigram, xxv, Megara. This Ahrens attributes to Eratosthenes.

This collection is too wide. As appears from the foregoing examination of the *p and D line of MSS., D is a composite MS., and of its tributaries that which represents the best tradition (*p2) did not include xxii, xxvi, or xxvii. The assignment of the collection to Eratosthenes is merely hypothesis.

The acope of this edition makes a full examination of
these points impossible. I can give only a summary of the results, as they appear trustworthy, and must reserve a more minute discussion for another place:--

The Scholia afford a base of discussion. We have pre-Byzantine Scholia and Arguments only to i-xviii, xxviii-xxx. Scholiasts are cited by name in Idylls i, ii, iii, iv, v vii. Arg. xii is from Eratosthenes. Munatios is mentioned in Arg. iii, vii, xvii; Schol. ii. 100, vii. 106, 138.

(1) This Eratosthenes lived in the time of Justinian (see Ahrens, Poet. Bucol. ii, p. 33); he is the author of an epigram, A. Pal. vi. 78, showing marked imitation of Theocritus, and may unhesitatingly be regarded as an editor of our poet, and author of part of the Scholia. It is remarkable that Arg. xii and no other is attributed to him; moreover this argument differs from all the rest in form. It is a probable conclusion that Eratosthenes added Id. xii to a collection already existing, with Scholia. This cannot have been Ahrens' third collection, since, of the poems therein, many have no Scholia at all; and it is hardly conceivable that they should have been entirely lost. Note further: Eratosthenes is never mentioned as a commentator. Is this because he is the author of our Scholia in their final form? Eratosthenes' Theocritus contained therefore:
i, vii, iii-vi, viii-xiii, ii, xiv, xv, xvii, xvi, xviii, xxviii-xxx (the order of i-xvii appearing in k).

(2) We shall have Munatius' edition, appearing shortly before Eratosthenes', and of the same contents, save that xii is not included. Munatius introduced with his commentary several notices concerning Theocritus' parentage (Arg. Id. iii, vii, xvii). It was to his edition in all probability that the epigram was affixed--
a)/llos o( *xi=os: e)gw\ de\ *qeo/kritos o(\s ta/d' e)/graya
ei(=s a)po\ tw=n pollw=n ei)mi\ *surakosi/wn,
ui(o\s *pracago/rao, perikleith=s te *fili/nhs:
mou=san d' o)qnei/hn ou)/tin' e)feilkusa/mhn.
The last line meaning 'I have introduced no alien Muse,' i. e. no song from another hand; and distinguishing Munatius' edition of Theocritus only from

(3) an earlier edition of the bucolic poets. This early
Corpus bucolicorum may be taken to have included Theocr. i, iii-xi, Bion, Moschus, perhaps Philetas, and others.

(4) There are left over from these three editions, Idylls xxii, xxiv, xxvi (the Berenice), xxv, Megara. These would together form a convenient biblion, and could be classed roughly as e)/ph h(rwika/. They must have existed without Scholia, if they existed together, and that they did exist together is rendered probable by their conjunction in D3.
It is uncertain whether the Epigrams ever existed in separate form after the compilation of the Anthology of Meleager.
On this line of argument therefore we are led to accept and reject just the same poems as by the argument from our existing or demonstrable MSS.
B. External evidence: citation and imitation.
Citations are made by grammarians from xviii. 49; viii. 66; xxiv. 138; xxii. 72, 137; xxvi. 1; xxviii. 1; xxv (Hiller, Beiträge, p. 65). These can be seen in full in Ahrens' edition at foot of text.
Arguments from imitation have little weight owing to the impossibility of proving that the imitation must be from Theocritus.

There is certain evidence that Theocritus wrote poems which have not been preserved. A fragment of the Berenice has come down to us; and Eustathius and Servius quote or allude to others (see Meineke, p. 397). Suidas has a curious note: *qeo/kritos e)/graye ta\ kalou/mena bouko*lika\ e)/ph *dwri/di diale/ktw|: tine\s de\ a)nafe/rousin ei)s au)to\n kai\ tau=ta: *proiti/das: e)lpi/das: u(/mnous: h(rwi/nas: e)pikh/deia me/lh (so Bekker, e)pikh/deia, me/lh, Birt): e)legei/as: i)a/mbous e)pigra/mmata. We do not know the origin of the above statement, nor who the tine/s were; nor whether Suidas means isolated poems or bibli/a bearing the above titles. Attempts have been made to identify the names with the poems in our TheocritusNotably by Birt, Antikes Buchwesen.: boukolika\ e)/ph, i-xi, xxvii, etc.; e)lpi/des, xxi; u(/mnoi, xvii, xvi, xxii; h(rwi=nai, xxvi, xviii; e)pikh/deia, Epit. Adonidis, Epit. Bionis; me/lh, xxviii, xxix, xxx; e)legei=ai, viii; i)/amboi and
e)pigra/mmata, Epigrams. Even if this is the right method the identification of e)legei=ai and i)/amboi is unlikely. By the first is more likely meant some of the epigrams, if not poems, altogether lost: for i)/amboi we might read mimi/amboi a confused description of xv and the mimes. The *proiti/des are left out of account. J. A. Hartung thinks that Vergil may betray knowledge of the poem in Ecl. vi. 48:
'Proetides implerunt falsis mugitibus agros.'
The story is certainly current in Alexandrian literature (Call. Dian. 233 sqq.), and was dealt with by Bacchylides (xi), a poem which Callimachus obviously knows. It is possible enough that Theocritus wrote such a poem (on the model of xxvi), but no proof for or against can be adduced.
Not much importance attaches to the statement that one Marianus (400 a. d.) paraphrased Theocritus in 3150 iambic verses. He probably included the other pastoral poets.
C. Internal evidence.
In Id. xx we notice as untheocritean:--
(1) The large proportion of uncontracted forms--file/ein (4), lale/eis (7), nose/onti (9) etc.
(2) The forms--e)mei=o, sunexe/s, a)/far, stoma/twn, a(de/a, kre/sswn, e)mmi/, h)de/, pollo/n.
(3) The words--bohno/mon, a)/groikos, done/w, dw/naki, plagiau/lw|, a)na/ (of time), a)ne/ri bou/ta| separated. Contrast i. 86; vi. 7; vii. 32.
The poem is full of reminiscences of Theocritus--xxvii=xi. 38; xxi sqq.=vi. 34; xxvi=xi. 19; xxx=xi. 76 (see Meineke, p. 328). [krh/guon='true,' see ad loc.]

(4) In metre the poem is far more dactylic than the genuine pieces, the proportion of dactyls to spondees in the first five feet being 5.08:1 as against 3.5:1 in Theocr. Id. iii. In Theocr. iv it is 2.33:1 (cf. Kunst, De versu Theocr., p. 10; Legrand, Étude, p. 329).
Still more decisive is the general tone of the poem. The contrast of town and country manners is not a Theocritean motive. There is no setting, or localization. To whom is it addressed?

The piece is obviously of later authorship, but who wrote
it has mercifully been forgotten (see further, Hiller, Beiträge, p. 70).

xxiii was apparently known to Ovid (see note on v. 16), but this proves nothing for authorship. The motive becomes a commonplace in the writers of so-called romance (Charito, E. 10; Ovid, Met. xiv. 701). The evidence of style and metre is the same as for xx. The tone is maudlin and namby-pamby. In language note untheocritean: a)phne/os, a)teirh/s, to\n broto/n (11), e)qe/lw with accus., sbe/ssw (Theocr. uses the ss only in aorist), ou)de\ e(/n, pw=s (for o(/pws), u(popteu/h|si.
xix resembles Bion iv (Meineke) in conception, and may be with probability ascribed to that poet (so Valck., Hermann, and others).

xxvii is condemned by style, and by the coarseness of its tone. The language also obviously belongs to a late writer i)de\ pw=s, di/dou o)/fra fila/sw for di/dou fila=sai, mi/tra^n. Untheocritean are sei=o, nai\ ma/n, *pafi/a.

xxi is a far more important poem, and has been thought fully worthy of Theocritus. 'There is nothing in Wordsworth,' writes Mr. Lang, 'more real, more full of the incommunicable sense of nature, rounding and softening the toilsome days of the aged and the poor, than the Theocritean poem of the Fisherman's Dream.'
But a piece worthy of Theocritus is not necessarily a Theocritean piece, and the 'nature' of xxi is not the nature of Theocritus.

The evidence of language is strong: ai)fni/dion, meledw/nh, e)ggu/qi, a)qlh/mata (new sense), qlibome/nan ('narrow'), trufero/n (new sense), prose/naxe, fi/los po/nos, h)/reqon, minu/qein, sida/rois (pl.), traferw=n, h)re/??a, w)/mosa d' ou), tarbw=, e)pi_mu/ssh|si, fukio/eis, *poseida/wni, i)xqu/a, i)xqo^n--all these are untheocritean. The rhythm of v. 15 is unparalleled. The long list of implements in v. 10 sqq. is foreign to our poet's style.
Still less than Theocritus is Bion the author: the spondaic character of the verse alone proves this; and there is no evidence that Bion or Moschus ever wrote realistic poems.
A much stronger case could be made out for assigning the poem to Leonidas of Tarentum, or at any rate to a close imitator of that writer:--

i)xqu/os (6) sing., cf. A. Pal. vii. 504 ki/xlhs kai\ ska/rou i)xquboleu/s. fukio/enta de/lhta, cf. A. Pal. vii. 504 petrh/essan (living under rocks); vii. 273 ai)ph/essa kataigi/s (from the heights). qlibome/nan (pres. part.), cf. A. Pal. vii. 665 peptame/nous ai)gialou/s. u(/pnon a)pwsa/menoi, cf. A. Pal. vii. 726 a)pw/sato polla/kis u(/pnon.

Leonidas' epigrams, A. Pal. vi. 4; vii. 295; vii. 504, are 'fisher epigrams.' The first is a dedication from the fisher Diophantus. xxi is addressed to Diophantus. The second is on the death of Theris who e)/qan' e)n kalu/bh| sxoini/tidi lu/xnos o(poi=a, cf. xxi. 7. The list of implements in xxi is thoroughly Leonidean (A. Pal. vi. 4, 205, 204, 296, 35).

Leonidas is essentially a poet of humble life and workers (cf. A. Pal. vi. 288; vii. 726). He is remarkable for his bold use of new words, or old words in new senses. True, we know Leonidas only as an epigrammatist, and one of no great note; but A. Pal. vii. 736, 295, 472; vi. 300, show a certain pathos and poetic power; and though xxi shows a humour not found in Leonidas, yet the elaboration and conception of the poem are of the simplest and not beyond the power of the Tarentine. There is evidence, finally, that even before Meleager's time the poems of Leonidas and Theocritus had been confused (cf. note prefatory to Epigrams).

The only objections to recognizing Leonidas as author are (1) the form of such lines as 16, 56, 60--not paralleled from Leonidas (cf. Geffcken, Leonidas von Tarent, p. 142); (2) the representation of humble life is a common motive both in New Comedy and afterwards (Plaut. Rudens; Herondas; Geffcken, op. cit., p. 137); (3) that we do not know of Leonidas as an author of anything but epigrams.

Reitzenstein's judgement is worth quoting (Epigram und Skolion, p. 152): 'Anders ist der Stil der (*aliei=s, sie können nicht dem Leonidas gehören, trotz der weiten Aufzählung der Fischergeräte, einzelner kühner Wörter, ja einer direkten Entlehnung aus Leonidas. Dann sind die (*aliei=s aber von einem Nachahmer des Tarentiners, welcher seinerseits die pomphafte Sprache desselben herabgestimmt und gemildert hat.' But it is not impossible that Leonidas himself modified
his style under the direct influence of Theocritus in Cos.

The question of xxv and Megara is much more difficult. That they are by the same author is now generally accepted; who this author was is still sub judiceSee Hiller, Beiträge, p. 66; L. Genther, Über Theocr. xxv und Moschus iv, Luckau, 1898. Legrand, Étude, p. 17, accepts xxv, says nothing about Megara..
(1) The two poems are conjoined in the MSS. (*p *p2 *f *fm); community of authorship being obviously assumed.

(2) Internal evidence: the two poems have a large number of words in common which do not occur elsewhere in the Corpus bucolicorum, e. g. a)qe/sfatos, a)/motos (as adj.), go/nos, dedegme/nos, e)kpa/glous, bi/h (*hraklhei/h, kla/zein, k.t.l.; cf. ai)nole/onta, xxv; ai)noto/keia, Meg. (Legrand, Étude, p. 264). The metrical structure of the two is much the same, allowance being made for the difference of the character of the persons (Hiller, Beitr., p 63). The vocabulary of both is partly Homeric, partly that of the new epic, though xxv contains the more unhomeric words.

The evidence of metre is instructive. There are four general 'laws' of the hexameter observed in Alexandrian writersSee Meyer, Zur Geschichte des griech. und latein. Hexam.; cf. Geffcken, op. cit., p. 141 sqq.:--
(1) A trochee or dactyl in the second foot must not be formed by a word commencing in first foot.
(2) The masculine caesura in third foot must not be preceded by an iambic word.
(3) Masculine caesura and diaeresis in both third and fifth foot of same line is forbidden.
(4) Diaeresis in fifth arsis is only allowed when the verse contains weak caesura and third foot is followed by a long word.
Theocritus neglects these laws entirely in his pastorals and mimes, e. g. first law, vii. 14, 38, 65, etc.; second law, ii. 76, 126, 130, etc.; third law, x. 11, 39, etc.; fourth law, xi. 7, 71, etc.

In the epic idylls (among which reckon xiii, xvii, xxii,
xxiv, xxv, Megara) the number of places where the laws are neglected are (if my counting is correct):
xiii xvii xxii xxiv xxv Megara
First law 4 5 8 5 14 7
Second law 3 2 5 1 13 2
Third law 1 1 (?) 5 0 2 0
Fourth law 2 6 11 5 11 6

Enclitics are counted as forming one word with the preceding. In fourth law if preposition + noun is counted as one word, xvii will lose one extra, xxii will lose six extra, xxiv will lose three extra, xxv will lose two extra, Megara will lose two extra.

The Megara resembles xxiv and xvii most nearly. xxii is especially lax in third, xxv in second, but all six poems agree pretty closely, but differ from the practice of other writers. Moschus, to whom the Megara was assigned by Stephanus, neglects in the Europa the first law four times, second twice, third twice, but fourth never.

In structure there are striking resemblances. Both begin and end with striking abruptness. Both narrate an episode in Heracles' life through the speech of persons in the poem, not directly from the poet. And while the tone of the two differs widely it differs no more than is necessitated by the difference of characters. The strong virility of xxv suits Heracles and his manly companion; the complaining frightened tone of the Megara suits the unhappy womenfolk. More might perhaps be made of the absence of any 'setting' in 'Megara,' but if we have been right in concluding that Theocritus not seldom follows Bacchylides as a model, here again we might see a trace of the lyric poet's influence. The Megara bears a most striking resemblance to Bacchylides' Ode xviii (dialogue of Aegeus and Medea), in which an exploit of Theseus is told of.
There seems then good reason to go back on the judgement of Stephanus, and to assign xxv and Megara to the same author.
For making this author Theocritus we have--

(1) MSS. evidence of *fm, *p, *p2 in all of which good
archetypes the two poems are put among undoubtedly Theocritean pieces. The Florentine MS. S has the Megara alone after pieces by Moschus, but without name of author, while the preceding are all entitled *mo/sxou.

(2) Internal evidence of style, metre, and language; for while many words occur in these poems which do not occur elsewhere in Theocritus, the same is true of xxii and xxiv, and the general use of language and idiom is Theocritean. For Theocritus tells strongly the method of handling the myths. 'Theocritus takes pleasure in surrounding the events of fable with minute familiar details; in showing that the ancient heroes had not always a heroic gait, and that their exploits do not stand altogether apart from the actions of daily life' (Legrand, p. 184). This is true of xiii, xxii, xxiv, xxv, equally; to a rather less extent of Megara. It is characteristic of the school of Philetas, and Hermesianax (supra, p. 29), to which Theocritus belongs. Further, xxv shows the rapid narrative power which marks xxii and the first part of xxiv. On the whole the argument for accepting the poems as genuine is considerably stronger than that for rejecting them.

'The history of the pastoral,' writes Prof. Conington, 'shows how easily the most natural form of composition may pass into the most artificial.' The reason of this is that practically all pastoral poetry subsequent to Theocritus is an imitation of an imitation, and becomes, as Plato would say, three degrees removed from truth. The name moreover has been grossly misused, and while it covers a multitude of sins against good taste, much poetry that is really pastoral in the Theocritean sense is excluded.

Strictly understood pastoral poetry must be defined not by its form so much as by its contents. It is a comedy of rustic character and speech, brief, written to please not to instruct, in dialogue or monologue drawn from the life.
Theoc. Id. iii iv, v, x, are the most perfect examples. Song has nothing essential to do with the pastoral. Theoc. iv lacks it, but is most truly a pastoral. But song is generally introduced because one of the most salient features of Greek peasant life was the singing-match, and this afforded at once both an easy and a graceful subject for composition. Hence Id. v, vi, viii, ix, contain singing-matches; Id. i repeats one well-known song; Id. iii, xi, x, contain monodies, yet always such as might be heard in Greece.

The result was fatal for the pastoral; the charm of form became the essential; the truth of the representation to country life became of secondary importance, and finally was left altogether out of sight. Theocritus himself must be held responsible in part for the change.

The shepherds of the beautiful first idyll are shepherds in name rather than in vocation; in Id. vii we have, as before noted, an imitation of the country singing-match, in two poets who disguise their names but not their personality. Yet here there is nothing to offend: nothing to disgust us by its hopeless unreality. It is only when we come to the imitators of Theocritus that we see that the pastoral has become merely a fashionable setting for any incongruous thought. There is no trace of any study of the country in Bion and Moschus; Vergil's Eclogues are echoes of Theocritus, exquisite in sound, but signifying anything rather than Italian peasant life: the story of Vergil's farm; of Julius Caesar's deification, of Gallus' love-story. Kings, statesmen, and poets must all be shepherds, and sing songs, whether the shepherds of their country sang or no; in their shepherd dress and under their shepherd names they must discourse of affairs of state or church, as in Milton's Lycidas and in the Shepheardes Calender. Each step taken is but slight. The plaint for Daphnis leads easily to the plaint for Bion; that to Vergil's 'Gallus,' to 'Lycidas,' to 'Thyrsis.' The form developes, but does not change materially; but the matter changes from the simple 'rural ditty' to the 'strain of higher mood.' Meanwhile real pastoral poetry as Theocritus made it--the mirror held up to country life--found but little favour. The trammels of classical form prevented it. If one wrote in the style of Theocritus he
did not represent life as it was in other lands than Greece; if he wrote of life as he saw it, he had to desert the sacred classical form and still more sacred diction. Consequently the most of so-called pastoral is imitation of an imitation--fit for a boyish exercise alone.

The sketch of rustic manners passes to prose. In verse the spirit of Theocritus breathes--because the form is dropped--in the German Hebel, in some of Burns' narrative poems, and in Lord Tennyson's Northern Farmer.

div1.head: E.--The dialect of Theocritus
div1.p: In idylls i.-xi., xiii.-xviii., xxiv. xxvi, and in the epigrams. Theocritus uses the Doric dialect. On xii. see ad loc. In xxii., xxv., and Megara, he follows Homeric usage. The dialect for the spurious poems is a less correct Doric: that of xxviii., xxix., xxx. is Aeolic (vid. preface to xxviii.).
The following sections will deal with the Doric as used in the above-named poems.

In the first place we must note that the dialect is nowhere pure DoricThe chief authority for the Doric dialect remains Ahrens' great work De linguae graecae dialectis, Göttingen, 1839, to which should be added Morsbach, De dialecto Theocritea, Bonn, 1874, and Curtius, Studien, x. 1. There is an excellent summary of the Theocritean usages in the Fritzsche-Hiller edition (Leipzig, 1881); cf. Legrand, Étude, p. 234 sqq. A useful collection of Doric inscriptions is published by Drs. Collitz and Bechtel, Göttingen, 1898 (Band 3, 2te Hälfte, ed. R. Meister).; Epic and Aeolic forms are intermixed, and local peculiarities are brought together, so that even the Doric is not a Doric of a single district.
Probably in Cos, where we have seen that Theocritus passed his youth, Aeolic forms might be heard; but the fact remains that Theocritus' dialect is a literary rather than a spoken form of speech.

div2.head: Declensions.
div2.p: (a) First declension. Nouns in -a, -h, -hs.

h always becomes a_ in terminations.
Thus: Nom. Acc. Gen. Dat.
fwna/ u(/lan a)oida=s knu/za|.
*simixi/das )*ai/dan *lampria/da *eu)ma/ra|.
Plural nominative -ai, accusative -a^s (v. 103), and so in adjectives au)ta^s (v. 33), kala^s (vii. 86).
The dative plural is properly -ais (i. 2), but the Homeric -aisi or -h|si are often used.
Genitive plural -a=n (i. 12).
Homeric is genitive singular. -ao from nominative -hs (i. 126).
(b) Second declension. Genitive singular -w for -ou (ii. 95), etc.
Homeric -oio (ii. 134), etc.
Accusative plural usually -ws (i. 121). Sometimes -os (i. 90).
Dative plural -ois. Homeric -oisi (iv. 7), etc.
(c) Third declension.
(i) Type ge/nos. Genitive singular qe/reos (ii. 58). xei/leos (vii. 20). Nominative plural xei/lh (i. 29), and th/qea (ii. 79).
(ii) In other types the chief variation is in dative plural; -ssi or -si are both used. The latter only is true Doric (vii. 17, vii. 153, viii. 43).
So we have porqmh=a (xvii. 49), *phlh=i (xvii. 56), but in pastorals only -ei (i. 58), a)riste/es (xviii. 17), a)risth=es (xiii. 17).
(d) Adjectives in -us.
These appear both in the Ionic form in feminine a(de/a (i. 65), and Doric a(dei=a (i. 95).

div2.head: Pronouns.
div2.p: The Doric forms are: e)gw/n, meu (mou), e)mi/n (e)moi/). a)/mmes (h(mei=s), a)/mme (h(ma=s), are Aeolic.
2nd person tu/ (su/), tu/ or te/ (se), teu or teu=s (sou, sou=), tin or toi (dative).
Here, as elsewhere, Doric shows the older form, retaining the original t (Lat. tu, etc.). A rare form, teou=s (genitive singular), appears (xviii. 41; xi. 25).

div2.head: Verbs.
div2.p: (a) In -w.

2nd person singular present indicative -es for -eis occasionally (i. 3). 1st plural -es for -en (i. 16) dedoi/kames, etc. 3rd plural -onti for -ousi, the older form appearing (Lat. -ant, etc.) (i. 38) moxqi/zonti. So in contracted verbs fileu=nti = file/onti = file/ousi (v. 80, etc.): subjunctive, -wnti (viii. 70); infinitive, -en for -ein occasionally (i. 14) suri/sden.
Participle: -oisa for -ousa (Aeolic rather than Doric) constantly (ii. 137 lipoi=san). In verbs in -ew, -eu=sa for -ou=sa (v. 56).
In the future verbs in -zw make -cw= instead of -sw: in all verbs the future is contracted -w= for -w (viii. 86 dwsw=; vii. 71 au)lhseu=nti; v. 142 kaxacw=).
Similarly in aorist: e)ch/taca (xiv. 28) = e)ch/tasa; cf. e)lugi/xqhs (i. 98).
A new present is formed from the perfect stem in many words. dedoi/kw (xv. 58), vid. note on i. 63.

Many verbs pass from the -aw conjugation into the -ew, poqoreu=sa (iii. 18), etc., and many, ordinarily conjugated in -w, appear in the -mi form (these are strictly Aeolisms): cf. i. 36 note, vi. 8, and preface to idyll 28. (nike/w, Herondas, i. 51.)
(b) In -mi:
3rd singular present has -ti for -si (cf. tu/ for su/ and -onti for -ousi). fati/ (i. 51), u(fi/hti (iv. 4).
3rd plural, -anti, -enti, -onti for -asi, etc. i)/santi (xv. 64) = i)/sasi.
In vi. 8 poqo/rhsqa shows the Aeolic addition of -qa to the termination: cf. xxix. 4.

ei)mi/ shows the following peculiarities:--2nd singular present, e)ssi/; 1st plural present indicative, ei)me/s (ii. 5); 3rd plural, e)nti/; imperfect, h)=s for h)=n, h)=mes for h)=men; infinitive, ei)=men, h)=men (an older form), ii. 116; participle, e)w/n (w)/n once in idylls viii. and ix.), e)oi=sa or eu)=sa (v. 26), e)o/nta or eu)=nta (ii. 3, Herondas v. 16); future, e)ssei=tai.

div2.head: Form of Words in general.
div2.p: In stems of words a appears for h in many cases, but by no means universally. poimh/n, not poima/n; a)pexqh/s, not a)pexqa/s, etc.
t appears for Attic s in ei)/kati (ei)/kosi). poti/ (pro/s), plati/on = plhsi/on (v. 28).
oi for ou in *moi=sa (Aeolic).
a for e in e)/traxon (e)/trexon): ga = ge, and others.
k for t in o(/ka, po/ka (po/te).
The chief peculiarities in contraction are:--
a_ for ou (= ao) in genitive 1st declension.
a_ = ao; peina=nti = peinw=nti (but gela=nti = gela/ousi, i. 90, is from ge/lhmi: cf. i. 38).
a_ = w; e)pa/ca = e)ph/cw.
h for Attic a_ in verbs in -aw; o(/rh, vii. 50. So e)sorh=|s, i. 90.
w for ou in nw=n, xi. 74.
eu for ou in fileu=sa, xei/leus, w)qeu=ntai, e)/rreun.
Note the following individual forms:--
ka_ = ken = a)/n; thnei= = e)kei=; th=nos = e)kei=nos; w(s = e)/nqa; a(=s = e(/ws; pra=n or pro/an = prw/hn; toutei= = thnei= (v. 45); a(ma=| = o(mou= (xi. 39); ai) for ei); poti/ (po/t) for pro/s.

5. The accent varies from the Attic in ou(tw=s, a)lla=|. According to the grammarians the Dorians sounded pai/das as pai/das. And similarly gunai/kas, ai)/gas, fw/tas (see R. Meister, Bemerkungen zur griech. Accentuation). It would hardly be a right course to foist these into our text of Theocritus.

div1.p: The first half of this idyll forms but a setting for the shepherd Thyrsis' song on the death of Daphnis (i. 65 sqq.). Thyrsis is invited to while away the noon-day by singing, 'as once he sang in rivalry with Chromis,' and is promised as reward a goat for the milking and a carved bowl. He assents and sings the monody.

Various forms of the legend are preserved, and no reconcilement between them is possible; the story as adopted by Theocritus in this idyll and the seventh seems to be as follows: Daphnis had vowed that he would be stronger than Love (i. 97), and that his heart would never be subdued. Aphrodite half offended, half in jest, inspired him with a strong passion for a maid (Xenea in vii. 73), but Daphnis would not confess his love, but suppressing it slowly pined away. The shepherds and the gods try to draw his secret from him: Pan reviles him for a fool. Aphrodite boasts her victory, and stings Daphnis into violent reproach and final confession of defeat when death is already at hand. It is enough; and Aphrodite would save him but it is too late, and Daphnis passes down to the stream of death.

The song, as appears from 19 and 61, is not an impromptu, but, as in Id. vii, a piece already conned. The setting and the characters are somewhat ideal, so much so that it is possible--although not necessary--to regard the poem as of the same class as Id. vii. (See Introd.)

div2.p: 1, 2 a(du/ ti taken up by a(du\ de/ (2), a(/dion (7), a(de/a (65), a(/dion (145), for 'sweet is every sound, sweeter thy voice, but every sound is sweet.' The construction of the lines is rendered clear if we attend to the balance of the words: a(du/ ti is answered by a(du/ de/: kai\ a( pi/tus by kai\ tu/. suri/sdes (3) belongs to both clauses. kai\ a( pi/tus (a(\ poti\ tai=s pagai=si meli/sdetai) a(du/ ti to\ yiqu/risma suri/sdei kai\ tu\ a(du/ ti suri/sdes.

[To read a( and make meli/sdetai verb to pi/tus impairs the rhythm.] 'Sweet is the whispered music of yon pine which sings beside the water, and sweet thy music, herdsman.' Cf. Terent. Maurus, l. 129:
'Dulce tibi pinus submurmurat, en tibi pastor,
Proxima fonticulis, et tu quoque dulcia pangis.'

a=du/ ti to\ yiqu/risma suri/sdes = a(du/ ti e)sti\ to\ yiqu/risma o(\ suri/sdes. tis is not often added to a predicative adjective referring to the object when the object has the article, but cf. Lycurgus, § 101 a)nupe/rblhton tina\ dei= th\n eu)/noian e)/xein.

suri/sdes = suri/sdeis. For the application of the word to wind in trees, cf. Longus, iii. 24 o( me\n e)su/rizen a(millw/menos pro\s ta\s pi/tus. 'The pines sing overhead' (Kingsley) Lucian, V. H. ii. § 5 a)po\ tw=n kla/dwn kinoume/nwn terpna\ me/lh a)pesuri/zeto e)oiko/ta toi=s au)lh/masi tw=n plagi/wn au)lw=n.

meta\ *pa=na, 'second to Pan alone.' Eurip. Troad. 218
ta/de deu/tera/ moi meta\ ta\n i(era\n
*qhse/ws zaqe/an e)lqei=n xw/ran:
Propert. ii. 3. 32 'post Helenam forma secunda.'
te/ = se a form known elsewhere only in grammarians, but restored by conjecture in v. 14.
katarrei= comes over to thee (from what he leaves). The three prizes are arranged in order of value.

e(/ste/ k' a)me/lch|s cf. Hesiod. Op. 591
kai\ boo\s u(lofa/goio kre/as mh/pw tetokui/hs
prwtogo/nwn t' e)ri/fwn.

Note the careful correspondence of these five lines to the preceding. a(/dion to a(du/ ti: me/los to meli/sdetai: u(/dwr to pagai=si: *moi=sai to *pa=na: ge/ras to ge/ras and the arrangement of the prizes (l. 9, note).
a(/dion sc. katalei/betai, cf. xx. 27. The proposed explanation a(/dio/n e)sti h)\ to\ u(/dwr a(du\ o)\n katalei/betai is highly artificial and awkward.

oi)i/da diminutive of oi)=s, not the same as o)/i+s of l. 11, but as in 4-6 we had a descending scale of age, here we have an ascending order; 'the little ewe lamb--the stall-fed lamb--the sheep.' For the formation cf. a)mni/s, e)rwti/s, o)rodamni/s. The winners chose their prize, the next best left goes to the second competitor.
w(s, 'where.'
ta\s d' ai)=gas parataxis = 'while I tend thy goats'; cf. vii. 86.

ou) qe/mis…ou) qe/mis, see Introd. 2. qe/mis --fas--law relative to heaven (Soph. O. C. 1556). The gods themselves rest at noon-day, and man may not break their repose; cf. Verg. Georg. iv. 402; Ecl. vi. 14; 1 Kings xviii.
kekmakw/s, 'wearied.'
poti\ r(ini/. Herondas, vi. 37 mh\ th\n xolh\n e)pi\ r(ino\s e)/x' eu)qu/s: Iliad xviii. 322 drimu\s xo/los.
a)ei/des = a)ei/deis: 'Thou dost sing the "Sorrows of Daphnis," and surpass all others in the woodland song.'

e)pi\ to\ ple/on is not equivalent to ei)s a)/kron (as Haupt, Opusc. ii. 312, and editors take it), but expresses simply a degree definitely higher than that reached by others (distinguish e)pi\ ple/on--a vaguer comparison). Cf. viii. 17 note; Xenoph. Hellen. iv. 7. 6 w(/sper pe/ntaqlos pa/nth| e)pi\ to\ ple/on u(perba/llein e)peira=to.

i(/keo, 'reached,' cf. Odyss. viii. 198 ou)/tis *faih/kwn to/de g' i(/cetai ou)d' u(perh/sei. The aorist is 'momentary'--an action present or habitual being vividly represented as completed at once and already passed. Cf. Aesch. Eumenid. 321:
ma/rtures o)rqai\ toi=si qanou=sin
paragigno/menai pra/ktores ai(/matos
au)tw=| tele/ws e)fa/nhmen.

*kranaia=n, 'Nymphs of the spring,' i. e. statues of them. Cf. Leonidas in A. Pal. ix. 326:
*pe/trhs e)k dissh=s yuxro\n katapa/lmenon u(/dwrCf. Theocr. i. 7.,
xai=rois, kai\ *numfe/wn poimenika\ co/ana,
and A. Pal. vi. 334:
au)/lia, kai\ *numfe/wn i(ero\s pa/gos, ai(/ q' u(po\ pe/trh|
pi/dakes, h(/ q' u(/dasin geitone/ousa pi/tus.
to\n *libu/aqe cf. xxiv. 109; Demosth. Meidias 121 *lusi/maxos )*alwpekh=qen.

e)s tri/s cf. ii. 43. In the following line e)s du/o pe/llas = 'as much as two pails full' (not 'into two pails')--accusative of amount. Plato, Laws 704 b a)pe/xei qala/sshs ge h( po/lis ei)/s tinas p' stadi/ous.
a)mfw=es 'with two handles.'
poto/sdon, 'fresh from the graving chisel,' still possessing the scent of fresh cut wood. The bowl is a drinking-bowl (see Odyss. ix. 346) not a milking-bowl.
, sqq. 'Above, about the lip twines ivy, ivy painted o'er with helichryse, and opposite (kat' au)to/n ) the tendrils twist gay in their golden berries.'

kekonime/nos lit. 'dusted.' Does Theocritus mean that the 'dust' of the flower is scattered over the ivy ('the yellow lotus dust is blown'), or use the verb in a somewhat new sense? The general meaning is clear that ivy and helichryse are mingled.

kat' au)to/n, 'in a line with,' or 'opposite to.' Cf. xxiv. 12 (note): a second band of floral decoration round the base of the cup is meant. Those who change kat' au)to/n or take it in another sense than this leave u(yo/qi (29) pointless. Cf. Vergil's description, Ecl. iii. 39; Nonnus, xix. 25:
tou= peri\ xei/leos a)/kron e)p' a)mpelo/enti karh/nw|
kisso\s e(/lic xruse/w| de\ pe/ric daida/lleto ko/smw|.

e)/ntosqen. Inside these bands (i. e. between) not 'inside the cup.' See two notes of Hiller and J. A. Hartung. The outside of the cup between the bands is divided into three fields:--the carving of the first represents a coquette, with two admirers; that of the second an old fisherman at his work; the third shows a vineyard tended by a little lad who, intent on his own pursuits, is robbed of his breakfast by a fox.
For the meaning of e)/ntosqen cf. xvi. 95; Ap. Rhod. ii. 679 ei)/sw petra/wn, 'in between the rocks.'
ti/ proclitic. For position cf. Soph. Antig. 159; Lysias, xxx. § 1 h)/dh w)= a)/ndres dikastai/, tine/s.
qew=n dai/dalma, 'a work as of the gods.' Callim. v. 94 goera=n oi)=ton a)hdoni/dwn a(/ge baru\ klai/ousa.

a)/lloqen a)/llos, 'this side and that.' Ap. Rhod. iv. 951
w(\s ai(\ nh=a qe/ousan a)moibadi\s a)/lloqen a)/llh
pe/mpe di' h)eri/hn e)pi\ ku/masi.

a(/ptetai. Eurip. Medea 55 frenw=n a)nqa/ptetai. There is a similar picture in Naevius (Cruttwell, Specimens of Rom. Lit. ii. 1. 1):
'Quasi pila
In choro ludens datatim dat se, ac communem facit,
Alii adnutat, alii adnictat, alium amat, alium tenet,
Alibi manus est occupata, alii percellit pedem,
Anulum alii dat spectandum, a labris alium invocat,
Cum alio cantat, attamen alii suo dat digito literas.'

gela=sa = gelw=sa. The former may be explained as due to an erroneous change of w to a on the analogy of pra=tos…gla=ssa (= glw=ssa, Herondas); but is more probably to be derived from a collateral form of the present ge/lhmi or ge/lami. So we have i)/sami, 'I know' (hence i)/sasi, cf. xiv. 34), with a participle i)sa/s (Ahrens, Dial. Dor. p. 345). The masculine of gela=sa would therefore be gela/s not gelw=n.
kuloidio/wntes, 'with hollow eyes.' Oppian, Hal. iv. 18 'love delights xrwto/s te para/tropon a)/nqos a)/mersai o)/sse te koilh=nai."

toi=s de\ meta/, 'next after them.' For this use of meta/ with the dative cf. Odyss. ix. 369 *ou)=tin e)gw\ pu/maton e)/domai meta\ oi(=s e(ta/roisin: Theocr. xxv. 93; Quint. Smyrn. v. 64 toi\ d' e)fe/ponto ai)zhoi\ meta\ toi=si.
te/tuktai singular, because the two nouns joined by te…te form but one notion cf. ii. 7. Xen. Symp. iii. 4 a)ndrei/a kai\ sofi/a e)/stin o(/te blabera\ dokei= ei)=nai.

e)s bo/lon e(/lkei is 'hauling in his net for a catch.' Theocritus imitates (Hesiod) Scut. Her. 213:
au)ta\r e)p' a)ktai=s
h(=sto a)nh\r a(lieu\s dedokhme/nos: ei)=xe de\ xersi\n
i)xqu/sin a)mfi/blhstron, a)porri/yonti e)oikw/s.
to\ kartero/n, 'with a man's whole strength,' see iii. 3 note. For e)s cf. v. 98; St. Luke v. 4 xala/sate ta\ di/ktua u(mw=n ei)s a)/gran.
o(/son sqe/nos…gui/wn, 'with all the strength of his limbs.' Ap. Rhod. ii. 591 e)mbale/ein kw/ph|sin o(/son sqe/nos: and with verb expressed, Ap. Rhod. iii. 716 o(/sson sqe/nos e)sti\n e)mei=o.

tutqo
 d' o(/sson, 'a little way.' The construction is like the Platonic a)mhxa/nws w(s, etc., Phaedrus 263 d. Polit. 308 e ou)damw=s w(s ou) fh/somen: Laws 782 a a)mh/xanon a)
 o(/son gegono\s a)
 ei)/h: Arist. Eccles. 386 u(perfuw=s w(s leukoplhqh\s h)=n i)dei=n h(kklhsi/a. The full construction would be tutqo/n e)stin o(/son a)pe/xei. The verb is omitted and wherever possible the antecedent is attracted to the form of the relative. Cf. Herod. iv. 194 a)/fqonoi o(/soi: Lucian, Alex. i. o)li/gous o(/sous: A. Pal. xii. 227 baio
 o(/son paraba/s. Exactly similar is the use of ou)dei\s o(/stis ou): ou)de/na o(/ntina ou), etc.

Cf. Iliad xviii. 561. purnai/ais vid. Liddell and Scott; the word is very doubtful here, even if it does bear the meaning of 'eating' or 'fit for eating.' We want some word descriptive of colour. perknai=si (Briggs) is unlikely to have been displaced; it is a common word cf. Odyss. vii. 126. perknai/ais (Ribbeck) is possible, as a collateral form, cf. e)ruqro/s, e)ruqrai=os, pello/s, pellai=os. Ahrens (Philol. vii. 410) favours purrai/ois.

du/' a)lw/pekes a( me/n… For the construction cf. Odyss. vii. 129:
e)n de\ du/w krh=nai h( me/n t' a)na\ kh=pon a(/panta
ski/dnatai, h( d' e(te/rwqen u(p' au)lh=s ou)do\n i(/hsi.
Odyss. xii. 73; Achill. Tat. i. 3. 1 ai( ga\r mhte/res tw=| me\n h)=n *buzanti/a tw=| de\ e)mw=| patri\ *turi/a: Caesar, Bell. Gall. i. 53 'duae filiae: harum altera occisa, altera capta est.'
e)pi\ ph/ra|, 'with designs on the wallet.'

ou) pri
 a)nhsei=n fati/ (= fhsi/), 'says she will not let the lad go.' Xen. Hellen. v. 2. 38 o(/ti oi( )*olu/nqioi katestramme/noi th
 mei/zw du/namin *makedoni/as ei)=en kai\ ou)k a)nh/sousi th
 e)la/ttw ei) mh/. Commoner is a)fh/sein.

fati/ of speechless things; Xenophanes, i. 5 oi)=nos o(\s ou)/pote fhsi\ prodw/sein: Catull. iv. 2 'Phaselus ille ... ait fuisse navium celerrimus.' But in this picture, as in the first, the description reads more into the carving than can strictly be expressed. Cf. Verg. Aen. viii. 634 sqq.; Martial, viii. 51. 14 'Palladius tenero lotus ab ore sonat.'

pri
 h)\ a)kra/tiston, k.t.l. is the MS. reading. In this a)kra/tiston cannot be the verbal adjective from a)krati/zomai or the accent would be oxytone, but must be a substantive--'breakfast'--cf. a)/mhtos, trughto/s (? tru/ghtos): (1) Ahrens (Philol. vii. 410) takes it thus as a substantive, and explains the phrase as a metaphor from navigation, 'before the breakfast has been wrecked.' He supports this by Polyb. xx. 5. 7 e)ka/qisan pro\s to\ chro
 ai( nh=es ('the ships grounded'); Diodorus, xi. 77 tw=n new=n a)/fnw kaqizousw=n e)pi\ chra
 th
 gh=n. This explanation is rendered improbable by the weakness of the phrase, even if e)pi\ chroi=si can have this meaning. To say 'the breakfast has touched bottom' is far from saying 'the breakfast has been totally wrecked.'

(2) J. A. Hartung (reading a)kratismo/n) takes the metaphor to mean 'before she has safely docked the breakfast'--kaqi/zein, active. This is a good sense, but there is no evidence for
the phrase. (We might also change the metaphor and say, 'before she has safely landed the breakfast.') The question is whether e)pi\ chroi=si can possibly mean 'on dry land' in face of the fact that chra/ (fem. sing.) and to\ chro/n (sing.) are the standing phrases. Cf. also Thucyd. i. 109; viii. 105.

(3) Changing the accent to a)kratisto/n, verb. adj., the only explanation possible is 'before she set him down to starveling fare to get his breakfast.' chro/s = 'wasted,' 'used up'; see Eurip. Androm. 637; Callim. vi. 113 oi)=kon a)nech/ranen. The use of the verb. adj. is then strangely and scarcely parallel even to Thucydides' menetoi\ kairoi/ ('inclined to wait') bk. i. 142. 1.

(4) Interpreting e)pi\ chroi=si as in (3), we should get a good sense by substituting for a)kra/tiston a verbal in -tos formed with a)- privativum. Nearest would be a)kra/stiston, a nonexisting word but formed regularly from krasti/zomai, 'to eat green stuff.' Tr., 'Before she set him down to a starveling fare with not a bite of green stuff.'

[The explanation recorded in Liddell and Scott, 'having breakfasted on dry stuff,' i. e. 'having made no breakfast,' joins a)kratisto/n and e)pi\ chroi=si in a way that is hardly Greek; we should at least have a)po\ chrw=n.]
me/letai for me/lei. So in Soph. Elect. 74; Oppian, Pisc. i. 117 me/letai de/ oi( ou)/ti mo/roio to/sson. Late authors play havoc with the forms and constructions of this verb.
peri\ ple/gmati. Verbs of rejoicing take e)pi/ not peri/, with dative, in Classical Greek. peri/ here expresses not only joy at his work, but 'joy engrossed in his work.'

ai)oliko/n ti qe/ama, 'a dazzling sight.' ai)oliko/n is a collateral form of ai)o/lon (see a note by the editor in Classical Review, July, 1896); cf. Schol. k ai)oliko/n, a)pathtiko/n, poiki/lon, *ai)oli/zein ga\r to\ a)pata=n. So Ap. Rhod. i. 765, perhaps in imitation of this:
kei/nous k' ei)soro/wn a)ke/ois, yeu/doio/ te qumo/n,
e)lpo/menos pukinh/n tin' a)po\ sfei/wn e)sakou=sai
ba/cin, o(\ kai\ dhro/n per' e)p' e)lpi/di qhh/saio.

porqmei= *kaludwni/w| a coaster from Calydon to Sicily; not from Calydon to Peloponnesus. porqmeu/s is used of one making a long voyage in Herod. i. 24 (Sicily to Corinth); in Lucian, V. H. ii. 29, of the pilot who brought Lucian home from the maka/rwn nh=soi. The objection should not have been raised that the word is only used of a ferryman across a strait. The v. l. of the Scholiast, porqmh=i *kaludni/w|, is interesting. Calydnae is the name of a group of islands near Cos. The reading is apparently due to some critic who wished to fix the scene of the poem in Cos, not Sicily. porqmh=i is however not a Theocritean form, and ll. 24 and 65 speak emphatically for Sicily.
pro/frwn, 'with all my heart.'
a)resai/man, 'would fain please thee'; cf. xvi. 67, note.

to\n e)klela/qonta accent and sense mark this as a present, not an aorist form. Homer has a causal reduplicated aorist; cf. In Aphrod. 40 (/*hrhs e)klelaqou=sa, 'making to forget Hera.' The form used here would seem to belong to the number of presents formed from the perfect stem, of which Theocritus has several: pepo/nqw (x. 1), dedoi/kw (xv. 58). So keklh/gontes, e)me/mhkon, Odyss. ix. 438; tetu/pontes, Callim.; e)pe/fukon, Hesiod. Naturally we should have lelh/qw: the stem is shortened as in lelakui=a (lelhkw/s), e)i+kui=a (e)oikw/s), sesarui=a (seshrw/s), etc. It is immaterial whether we take the verb as causal or neuter. If the latter, cf. Horace's 'oblivioso Massico'; Ovid, Fast. iv. 341 'furiosa tibia.'

The refrain as used here and in Idyll ii is said to be specially characteristic of Sicilian poetry. So in the drama it is frequent in Aeschylus (Agam. 117 sqq.; Choeph. 955; Eumenid. 1016; Persae 665, etc.). But it is found in all ages and all languages in varying forms, cf. Aristoph. Birds 1731; Peace 1334. In Hebrew, in the Psalms, 'For His mercy endureth for ever.' In Latin, Verg. Ecl. viii. 21; the Pervigilium Veneris, 'Cras amet qui numquam amavit, quique amavit cras amet'; Catull. 61, 62; and in direct imitation of Theocritus, Bion, Epit. Adon. ai)a/zw to\n )/*adwnin…e)paia/zousin e)/rwtes: Auctor, Epit. Bion. )/*arxete *sikelikai\ tw= pe/nqeos a)/rxete *moi=sai. In English it appears especially in the ballad.
a(de/a = h(dei=a, the Ionic form, cf. Odyss. xii. 374. The variant a(/d' a( besides lacking good MS. support spoils the rhythm and is weak.

Cf. Verg. Ecl. x. 9; Milton's Lycidas:
'Where were ye, Nymphs, when the remorseless deep
Closed o'er the head of your loved Lycidas?'
*pi/ndw sc. kala\ te/mpea, the last word being used in the general sense of valleys.

ei(/xete, 'were ye dwelling in.' Aesch. Eumenid. 24 *bro/mios d' e)/xei to\n xw=ron. So teneo in Latin, Verg. Aen. vi. 788 'omnes supera alta tenentes.'
'For neither were ye playing on the steep,
Where your old bards, the famous Druids, lie;
Nor on the shaggy top of Mona high,
Nor yet where Deva spreads her wizard stream.'

xw(k drumoi=o = kai\ o( e)k, 'the lion in the thicket'; the double crasis as in 109 xw(/dwnis. The Scholiast has a delightful variant a)\n e)/klause, and note: 'There were no lions in Sicily. If there had been they would have wept!'

Hermes first, who according to the legend was father of Daphnis, then the herdsmen, seeing Daphnis' misery, come in pity to know the cause. a)p' w)/reos, 'from the hill.' The article is omitted as in ii. 36; vii. 74; i. 140.

e)ra=sai from e)ra/smai a rare middle form of e)ra/w cf. ii. 149; Bion x. 9 a)ll' e)ra/w: kalo\n de/ t' e)rassame/nw| sunera=sqai (al. sune/rasqai); Constant. Anacreont. i. 75 para\ qi=n' a(lo\s badi/zein
polih=s tanu=n e)rw=mai (Hiller). The use of the middle for the active is common in Alexandrian Greek. Theocritus himself has skopia/zetai (iii. 26). a)rti/zonto (xiii. 43), potele/cato (i. 92), e)tina/cato (xxii. 185), and others; see Legrand, Étude, p. 229.
ti/ pa/qoi. Note that while the use of the optative in dependent statements is confined to Attic Greek and Herodotus, the use of this mood in dependent questions is universal.
*pri/hpos. Priapus comes in a different mood; knowing the reason of Daphnis' misery, and the object of his love, he taunts him for not giving himself up to the love which might be his.

ti/ tu\ ta/keai, a( de/ te, k.t.l. 'why dost thou sit pining while the maid hastens through all the springs and all the groves'--begin dear Muse, begin the woodland song--'seeking thee. Ah! thou art feckless and a fool in love. Thou art no neatherd as thou wast called, but a sorry goatherd, who can do no better than mope and pine for what he is not; thou hast the girls gay before thee, and all thou dost is to mope and pine.' The key to this difficult passage is right understanding of (1) du/serws, not 'perdite amans,' as most translate, but, as the Scholiast explains, ou)k ei)dw\s e)ra=n: cf. du/squmos. (2) ta/ketai o)fqalmw/s = 'you pine and hold aloof from the pleasure you might have, because you are too mawkish or prudish to go and enjoy yourself,' i.e. here you are in love, the girl is seeking you, and for a silly vow you waste your life away instead of taking the good things offered.

de/ te joins the sentence closely to the preceding, so that here ti/ tu\…a( de/ te is equivalent to the Attic ti/ su\ me\n th/kei h( de\ ko/rh…forei=tai cf. xxiv. 38; xv. 120; Odyss. vi. 108 r(ei=a/ t' a)rignw/th pe/letai, kalai\ de/ te pa=sai. The ordinary punctuation of these lines would make de/ te couple two sentences of dissimilar form contrary to the right use of the particles.
za/teis' an Aeolic form = zatou=sa. The interposition of the refrain verse adds to the emphasis of the word.
ai)po/lw| a)ndri/ cf. vi. 7; Longus, iii. 18 a)/groikos kai\ ai)po/los. The word is used contemptuously.
e)/gento, 'that he was not born.' Odyss. viii. 311 ou(/nek' e)/gwge h)pedano\s geno/mhn. This syncopated form occurs first in Hesiod; then frequently.
a)lla\ to\n au)tw=. 'But continued on his bitter way of love, and continued thereon to the end of fate--begin ye Muses--but Aphrodite came.'
au)tw= (not au(tw=) according to the Epic use. Monro, Hom. Gram. § 252; Tyrtaeus, x. 3 th\n au)tou= prolipo/nta po/lin.
a)/nue note the tense. It is not finished but 'journeyed along'; cf. A. Pal. vii. 316 h)\ mh\ th\n a)nu/seis tele/sais o(do/n.
kai/ Herod. i. 124 poi/ee tau=ta, kai\ poi/ee kata\ ta/xos.

ge ma/n strongly adversative. 'But ere he reached the end Aphrodite also came, smiling with kindly heart, hiding her smile, but feigning dire wrath.' Much unnecessary trouble has been caused here by a misunderstanding of the situation. Venus has tormented Daphnis rather in jest than earnest of revenge; she makes pretence of anger and is in heart kind to
him and would save him from destruction if only he will confess his love (cf. 139). a(dei=a is therefore not 'glad at Daphnis' plight,' but 'kind' as in Soph. O. T. 82. For la/qria cf. Soph. Philoct. 1272 pisto/s, a)thro\s la/qra. a)ne/xoisa not 'restraining' as most editors translate, ruining the sense, but 'keeping up'; cf. Eurip. Medea 482. With the whole cf. Nonnus, Dion. xxxiv. 303 ei)=xe no/on gelo/wnta, xo/lon d' a)ne/fhne prosw/pw|. In 95 a(dei=a is to be construed closely with gela/oisa: cf. Pindar, Pyth. viii. 12 traxei=a u(pantia/caisa and Aesch. Eumenid. 223 pra/ssousan h(suxaite/ran as if it were an adverb. To construe a( *ku/pris a(dei=a kai\ gela/oisa is unnatural.
kateu/xeo, 'vowed.' lugicei=n a metaphor from wrestling; cf. Lucian, i. 249 tou\s me\n a)/llous qeou\s kathgwni/sw a(/pantas.
nemessata/ probably 'revengeful.' In Homer of persons = 'revered.'
'Sith thou dost mark that all my suns are set, Daphnis shall be a bane to Love even in death.'

Daphnis feels that the struggle is over for him, and that death is the price of his resistance. He takes Venus' words in l. 98 as spoken in earnest; hence his bitter cry against her cruelty, and vow of further battle.
dedu/kein infin. from dedu/kw cf. 63. For the metaphor cf. Livy, xxxix. 26 'elatus deinde ira adiecit, "nondum omnium dierum solem occidisse."'

sqq. w(= le/getai. 'When the herdsman is said to have won Cypris, get thee to Ida, get thee to Anchises; there are pleasant spots enough; Adonis too is ripe for thy love, for he too is a herdsman and hunts the beasts of the field. Then hie thee and stand before Diomede and say, I have conquered the herdsman, Daphnis; fight thou with me.' The italicized words give the key to the sense. Venus has, thinks Daphnis, boasted of her unbroken victories. He retorts in bitter scorn, 'Thy victories have been gained over poor shepherd folk in soft places--over Anchises, Adonis, Daphnis; but remember that thou art not invincible, but fled from Diomede. Go then and win thy easy triumphs; then in the strength of them challenge a stronger foe on the battlefield and be disgraced, and boast no more.'

There are many difficulties in the detail of the lines; in line 106 thnei= dru/es, w(=de ku/peiros (the MS. reading) gives a pointless antithesis. In the parallel passage v. 45 toutei= dru/es, w(=de ku/peiros the two together form a pleasant spot. There is no comparison of the merits of the two. As therefore thnei= appears here in place of toutei= of v. 45 it is probable that w(=de has wrongly displaced the real word. I have accordingly substituted e)/nqa. This is supported by a passage in Plutarch, Quaest. Nat. 36, quoted in Ahrens' edition.
l. 107 is probably merely interpolated from Id. v. loc. cit. So arranged the text will fall into pairs of verses, divided by the refrain.
l. 110 is rejected by many editors, but without need. It is partly repeated from v. 107, but such partial repetitions are common in Theocritus.

In l. 112 au)=qis = not 'a second time,' but 'after that'; cf.
Demosth. Phil. i. 13 meta\ tau=ta *pu/dnan, pa/lin *potei/daian, *meqw/nhn au)=qis: Soph. O. T. 1403. See further Class. Review, July, 1896.

qw=es the lengthening of the syllable is justified by the pause and stress of the verse, cf. viii. 65; vi. 22, etc. With this farewell of Daphnis cf. Soph. Phil. 936-939:
w)= lime/nes, w)= problh=tes, w)= cunousi/ai
qhrw=n o)rei/wn, w)= katarrw=ges pe/trai,
u(mi=n ta/d', ou) ga\r a)/llon oi)=d' o(/tw| le/gw,
a)naklai/omai parou=si toi=s ei)wqo/sin,
and ib. 1453.

*qu/mbridos. The spelling is uncertain in the MSS. both here and in Servius on Aen. iii. 500 who mentions this as 'fossam circa Syracusas' (k has du/bridos, p qu/bridos, Serv. loc. cit. Thibrin or Ybrin). It is doubtful whether Servius' description of the place as 'fossa' is correct. The context does not favour it, but points rather to a well-watered valley. Whatever it was it seems to take its name from Apollo Thymbraeus.

Daphnis in these two lines merely proclaims himself aloud to the Nature to which he has bidden farewell. The couplet is not a sepulchral inscription as is Vergil's adaptation, Ecl. v. 43, for if so to whom would Daphnis commend the duty of writing the epitaph? He has refused communication with his fellow men.
sqq. Daphnis calls finally on Pan, the herdsmen's god, and delivers to him his shepherd's pipe.
*lukai/w Mount Lycaeus in south-west Arcadia, on the boundaries of Elis.

tu ge. The pronoun is used thus in either of two alternative clauses, without special emphasis; cf. Herod. ii. 173 la/qoi a)\n h)/toi manei\s h)\ o(/ ge a)po/plhktos geno/menos. Conversely in first clause, Odyss. iv. 821; in both, Odyss. viii. 488.
e)/nq' = e)/nqe = e)lqe/.

(*eli/kas, 'and leave the tomb of Helice and the high cairn of Arcas.' Arcas was son of Callisto, translated to the heavens, and made into the constellation (*eli/kh (The Bear). Callisto was daughter of Lycaon. *lukaoni/das therefore = 'grandson of Lycaon,' not 'son of.' These tombs are described by Pausanias viii. 35 ta/fos *kallistou=s xw=ma gh=s u(yhlo/n, de/ndra e)/xon polla/: cf. viii. 9. 2 pro\s de\ th=s (/*hrhs bwmw=| kai\ )*arka/dos ta/fos tou= *kallistou=s e)sti/. Meineke maintains that the name Helice is only used when the constellation is meant. If it were necessary to find two instances of every usage in Greek a parallel might be quoted from Callim. i. 41 ui(wnoi\ *lukaoni/hs a)/rktoio.
e)k khrw= join with meli/pnoun honey sweet with its fragrant wax.
e(likta/n has gerundival force; 'that can be moved across the lip,' not 'curved to fit round the lip.' See Jebb, Appendix to Oed. Tyr. p. 298; cf. gnwto/s, r(hkto/s, etc., Monro, Hom. Gram. § 246. 2.
(/*aidan one of the few instances of a neglect of the 'rule' of the bucolic caesura in the pastoral idylls. The effect is to give the line a sudden heavy cadence, suited to the sense.
Daphnis is dead; let all nature change and go awry to show his loss. Conington (on Ecl. iii. 89) is hardly right in regarding the lines as a curse invoked by Daphnis.

e)/nalla, 'and let all change'; cf. Ovid. Trist. i. 8. 5 'Omnia naturae praepostera legibus ibunt.' Vergil seems to have mistranslated the line: Ecl. viii. 58 'omnia vel medium fiant mare,' taking e)/nalla as = e)na/lia. The line is however of doubtful authenticity. It breaks the here regular arrangement of four-line strophes; and among the specified changes the general pa/nta e)/nalla is weak.
e(/lkoi, 'worry.' Herod. i. 140 e(lkusqh=nai u(po\ kunw=n: cf. the proverb o( nebro\s to\n le/onta, Lucian, Dial. Mort. viii. 1.
kh)c o)re/wn, 'and let the owls cry to the nightingales upon the hills,' i.e. cry in rivalry.
e)/ba r(o/on, 'went down to the stream of death.' r(o/on is accus. of motion to; cf. xiii. 29; xxv. 141.
A favourite form of 'closing line' in Theocritus, divided into two rhythmic parts, balanced, and antithetical; see Introd., and cf. i. 126; xv. 86; xiii. 7, etc.
e)s u(/steron…a)|sw= an echo of the ending of the Homeric hymns; e.g. h. Demet. 495 au)ta\r e)gw\ kai\ sei=o kai\ a)/llhs mnh/som' a)oidh=s.
a)p' *ai)gi/lw i)sxa/da, 'figs from Aegilus.' For construction cf. xxiv. 111; ix. 34; Aesch. Eumenid. 183; Arist. Acharn. 146 a)lla=ntas e)c )*apatouri/wn: ib. 192 presbe/wn e)s ta\s po/leis.
*ai)gi/lw. Theocritus probably means Aegilia in Attica, where figs of special excellence were grown, and calls the place by the name of its eponymous hero Aegilus (Hiller).

(*wra=n. The Hours are the givers of all beauty and fragrance, cf. xv. 104; cf. a fragment of the Cypria quoted by Athenaeus (xv. 682 d)
ei(/mata me\n xroi+\ e(/sto ta\ oi( *xa/rite/s te kai\ =(*wrai
poi/hsan kai\ e)/bayan e)n a)/nqesin ei)arinoi=sin,
oi(=a fe/rous' w(=rai, k.t.l.:
Pindar, Nem. viii. 1.
*kissai/qa name of a goat.

ai( xi/mairai. The article with the nom. plural is not uncommon in place of vocative; cf. v. 100; Arist. Clouds 601. With singular, iv. 45, note. So in Shakespeare:
'The jewels of our father, with washed eyes
Cordelia leaves you.'--King Lear, i. 1. 263.

div1.p: I have discussed the literary aspects of this poem in the Introduction, p. 32.

Vergil imitates it in the eighth eclogue, but with singular lack of taste makes of it merely an 'amoebean exercise' put into the mouth of a shepherd, Alphesiboeus, thereby destroying all the pathos of the original! Horace (Epode 5) has a few
verbal resemblances, but the spirit of his work is utterly different, as presumably was that of Sophron's mime, from which Theocritus is said by the Scholiast to have borrowed the form of the poem.

Nearer to Simaetha in the pathos of loneliness, than any previous creation of Greek literature, is the nameless speaker in Mr. Grenfell's 'Erotic Fragment.' Cf. the following fragments: o)du/nh m' e)/xei o(/tan a)namnhsqw= w(/s me katefi/lei e)pibou/lws me/llwn me katalimpa/nein…a)/stra fi/la kai\ sunerw=sa po/tnia nu/c moi para/pemyon e)/ti me nu=n pro\s o(\n h( *ku/pris e)/gdoton a)/gei me kai\ o( polu\s e)/rws paralabw/n: sunodhgo\n e)/xw to\ polu\ pu=r to\ e)n th=| yuxh=| mou kaio/menon… Nearer still in spirit is a modern Greek love chant which Mr. Andrew Lang quotes (Intr. to Trans. p. xvi): 'Bright golden Moon that now art near thy setting, go thou and salute my lover, that stole my love and kissed me, and said, "never will I leave thee." And lo, he has left me like a field reaped and gleaned, like a church where no man comes to pray; like a city desolate. Therefore I would curse him, and yet again my heart fails me for tenderness. Nay even so I will lay my curse upon him, and let God do even as he will, with my pain and with my crying, with my flame and mine imprecations.'

The date of the idyll is before 264, as is to be gathered from line 115. The Philinos there mentioned is no doubt Philinos of Cos, winner of the Stadium at Olympia in 264, 260. From the manner in which Philinos is spoken of it is obvious that he had not attained pan-Hellenic fame (cf. Wilamowitz-Moellendorff, Aratos von Kos, p. 184).
From this and from the mention of the Myndian Delphis, i.e. from Mynda in Caria, the scene of the idyll is determined as Coan.

div2.p: da/fnai see on l. 11.

Thestylis. The writer of the Greek argument says that Theocritus th\n *qestuli/da a)peiroka/lws e)k tw=n *sw/fronos meth/negke *mi/mwn, apparently meaning that while in Sophron there was dialogue between women in Theocritus Thestylis is a mute, and that this is a)peiro/kalon (see Jahn. Hermes 2). The literary criticisms of the Scholiasts are not as a rule very acute; this one is no exception. Thestylis is needed to make the opening of the poem more than idle talk; what place there could be for speech on her part let the Scholiast see.
ta\n kele/ban. The cauldron in which the magic brew was made; cf. Macbeth, iv. 1. 11.

foinike/w|. Crimson was especially associated with magical rites; cf. Lysias, vi. 52 kai\ e)pi\ tou/tois i(e/reiai kai\ i(erei=s sta/ntes kathra/santo pro\s e(spe/ran kai\ foiniki/das a)ne/seisan kata\ to\ no/mimon to\ palaio\n kai\ a)rxai=on.
oi)o\s a)w/tw| fine wool (the original Homeric sense, Iliad xiii. 599; of linen, Iliad ix. 661; contra, Theocr. xiii. 27).

to
 e)mo
 baru
 eu)=nta fi/lon…a)/ndra, 'my cruel sweet lover.' The pathos is spoilt by making fi/lon predicate; cf. Eurip. Phoeniss. 1446 fi(los ga e)xqro\s e)ge/net', a)ll' o(/mws fi/los: and Catullus' 'Odi et amo.'
w(s, 'since,' not 'in order that'; cf. l. 9 note.

kataqu/somai cf. ll. 10, 159. There is no variant in the MSS., and on l. 159 Schol. k has katadh/sw fhsi\n au)to\n toi=s farma/kois (a clear proof that he did not read kataqh/sw). kataqh/somai is generally read in all three places from a 'restoration' of the Scholiast here by Toup -- falsely. katade/w is the usual word for 'binding by magic' (cf. kata/desmos, kata/desis), and would never be changed to the unusual kataqu/esqai. The word must = e)k que/wn katamageu/ein, 'charm by fire magic,' and is supported by Aesch. Eumenid. 328:
e)pi\ de\ tw=| tequme/nw|
to/de me/los…
u(/mnos e)c )*erinu/wn
de/smios frenw=n.

dwdekatai=os a)f' w(= ta/las. The twelfth day is frequently mentioned as critical; Odyss. ii. 374, iii. 391; Ap. Rhod. i. 1079. Tr., 'Who hath not been near me, for twelve days since'; cf. l. 157. The full construction would be o(/s moi ou)de/poq' i(/kei--dwdekatai=o/s (e)stin) a)f' w(= i(/kei. In l. 157 nu=n de/ te/ nin ou)de/pot' ei)=don--dwdekatai=o/s (e)stin) a)f' w(=te ei)=don. For a)f' ou(= added to these adjectives in -ai=os, cf. Xen. Hellen. v. 3. 19 e(bdomai=os a)f' ou(= e)/kamen e)teleu/thse: Lucian, Halcyon 5 ta\ pemptai=a e)k geneth=s bre/fh. 'Time since which' is constantly expressed in Greek by a parenthetical polu\s xro/nos e)c ou(=, cf. Isocrates, 91 d ou(=toi ga\r a)/rxontes tw=n (*ellh/nwn ou) polu\s xro/nos e)c ou(= kata\ gh\n kai\ kata\ qa/lassan: Soph. Ajax 600 (Lobeck, ad loc.). Here that form of expression is personalized; Eurip. I. T. (e conj. Heath):
xro/nioi ga\r h(/kous' oi(/d' e)pei\ bwmo\s qea=s
(*ellhnikai=sin e)cefoini/xqh r(oai=s.
For tala^s see Ahrens, Dial. ii. 174.

zooi/. The plural masculine is used by a woman referring to herself. Eurip. Androm. 357:
e(ko/ntes ou)k a)/kontes, ou)de\ bw/mioi
pi/tnontes au)toi\ th\n di/khn u(fe/comen.

qu/ras. The -a^s (Doric acc. plural) is lengthened in arsis cf. viii. 65, vii. 104. The plural would not be used in Classical Greek of a house door; but cf. Lucian, Dial. Mort. ix. 2. (Cobet reads qu/ran.)

a)na/rsios, emphatic by its position, and almost amounting to a curse. Cf. the Homeric nh/pios…sxe/tlioi: Ap. Rhod. i. 1303:
ei) mh\ *qrhiki/oio du/w ui(=es *bore/ao
…e)rhtu/eskon e)/pessin
sxe/tlioi: h)= te/ sfin stugerh\ ti/sis e)/plet' o)pi/ssw.
See on iv. 6; cf. xxii. 168 and Demosth. De Fals. Leg. § 21 ei(=pe de\ toiou/tous lo/gous w(/sq' a(/pantas u(ma=s labw\n w)/|xeto, 'he carried you away with him.'

w(/s nin i)/dw, kai\ me/myomai. me/myomai is parallel with baseu=mai it cannot be taken as dependent on w(s, 'in order
that I may blame,' since there is no instance of w(s with the fut. ind. in a purely final--adverbial--sentence. The apparent instances are all to be taken as noun clauses (as o(/pws and fut. indic.) dependent on the main verb. Lucian, *bi/wn *pra=sis 1 kosmh/sas w(s fanou=ntai: Lysias, xx. 23 pareskeu/asan w(s a)\n ei)/hmen: Arist. Frogs 1121:
kai\ mh\n e)p' au)tou\s tou\s prolo/gous sou tre/yomai
o(/pws…basaniw=.
In all there is expressed or implied a notion of 'striving' or 'precaution' (see Sonnenschein, Syntax, 369 a, and additional examples in Liddell and Scott, o(/pws, B. 2. b).

e)k que/wn, will enchant him by fire magic; Ap. Rhod. iii. 845. e)k expresses the source of the spell, and is more graphic than would be the dative (of instrument). Soph. O. C. 848:
ou)/koun pot' e)k tou/toin ge mh\ skh/ptroin e)/ti
o(doiporh/seis.

potaei/somai a(/suxa, dai=mon altered by Kiessling and subsequent editors to a(/suxe dai=mon. But the sense is not 'submissa voce tibi, Luna, dolores meos conquerar' (Meineke); but 'I will sing my invocation in a hushed voice of awe.'

Nor has dai=mon been rightly understood. Simaetha is not addressing the moon as the peaceful goddess of night but the daemon of magic; the counterpart in heaven of Hecatè in hell. Lines 14-16 are this very incantation addressed to the 'diva triformis,' Hecatè. Cf. Lucian, *nekuomant. 465 r(h=si/n tina makra
 e)pile/gwn h(
 ou) sfo/dra kath/kouon: e)pi/troxon ga/r ti kai\ a)safe\s e)fqe/ggeto plh
 e)w/|kei ge/ tinas e)pikalei=sqai dai/monas: ib. 466 th
 e)pw|dh
 e)kei/nhn u(potonqoru/sas: cf. ib. 469.

In the magic formulae preserved to us we have constant invocations of the nekudai/mwn, 'demon of the dead' (Brit. Mus. Papyrus XLVI) nekudai=mon o(/stis ei)=, paradi/dwmi soi\ to\n dei=na o(/pws mh\ poih/sh| to\ dei=na pra=gma: Paris Pap. Z. 1496 (see E. Kuhnest, Rhein. Mus. 1894, p. 37) o(rki/zw se nekudai=mon kata/dhson th\n dei=na filou=san, e)rw=san.

Throughout the first part of the poem Theocritus reproduces accurately the rites and symbolisms of the two branches of 'Fire magic' and 'Philtro-Witchcraft' (classed generally in l. 1 under (a) da/fnai, (b) fi/ltra).

(1) In 'fire magic' some quickly burning substance (a)/lfita, 18; da/fna, 23; khro/s, 28; pi/tura, 33) or some relic (kra/spedon, 53) was taken as a symbol of the object of the charm, and consumed in the fire while a charm or curse was pronounced, that as the symbol consumed so might the person consume (see ll. 21, 26, 31). So the Paris Pap. Z. 1496 foll. gives a form of charm to be used with zmu/rna--myrrh--and fire. )*agwgh\ e)pi\ zmu/rnhs e)piquome/nhs…pe/mpw se pro\s th
 dei=na th=s dei=na…i(/na moi a)/ch|s au)th
…ei) koima=tai mh\ koima/sqw a)ll' e)me\ mo/non to
 dei=na kata\
nou=n e)xe/tw, e)mou= mo/non e)piqumei=tw, e)me\ mo/non sterge/tw (cf. Theocr. ii. 44-46) e)corki/zw se zmu/rna kata\ tw=n triw=n o)noma/twn a)no/xw a)bra/sac trw-- w(s e)gw/ se kataka/w kai\ dunath\ ei)= ou(/tw h(=s filw= kata/kwson to
 e)gke/falon (ll. 26, 29) e)/kkauson kai\ e)/kstreyon au)th=s ta\ spla/gxna, e)/kstacon au)th=s to\ ai(=ma e(/ws a)
 e)/lqh| pro\s e)me/. Or an old German charm: 'Schrieb auff ein weyss glas dyse wartt ... und leg das glas zu dem feure, und sprich dise wartt: Als hayss das glas ist als hayss sy der N nach mir' (quoted by Kuhnert loc. cit.).

The object burned might be made into a rough image of the person, but there was no need for this. Althaea wrought the doom of Meleager by burning a log of wood identified with him.
kai=e/ te daidale/as
e)k la/rnakos w)ku/moron
fitro\n a)gklau/sasa: to\n dh\
moi=r' e)pe/klwsen to/te
zwa=s o(/ron a(mete/ras e)/mmen.--Bacchyl. v. 140.

(2) Charms without fire were (1) potions (l. 58); (2) spells wrought by herbs possessing occult virtues (qro/na, 59: i(ppomane/s, 48), or by representative objects acting by sympathy, Brit. Mus. Papyrus XLVI = Cambr. Antiq. Soc. Publication, ii. § 3 parado\s to
 kle/pthn to
 kle/yanta/ ti: o(/son krou/w to\ ou)a/tion (a rough drawing) sfu/rh| tau/th| o( tou= kle/ptou o)fqalmo\s kai\ flegmaine/sqw a)/xri ou(= a)
 au)to
 mhnu/sh|: cf. the use of the r(o/mbos, Theocr. ii. 30.
Cf. Ap. Rhod. iii. 1210 *brimw\ kiklh/skwn (*eka/thn e)parwgo\n a)e/qlwn: cf. ib. 860.
'Making these spells as potent as those of Circe'; brachylogical comparison. Herod. ii. 134 purami/da de\ ou(=tos a)peli/peto pollo\n e)lattw tou= patro/s.

Perimedè: Propert. ii. 4. 18 (if reading there is sound) 'Perimedeae gramina cocta manus.' Apparently the same as Agamede of Iliad xi. 740:
canqh\n )*agamh/dhn
h(\ to/sa fa/rmaka h)/|dh o(/sa tre/fei eu)rei=a xqw/n.

=)*iugc the 'wryneck,' which was bound by the sorceress to a wheel, and spun rapidly in one direction (ai( tai=s farmaki/si gunsici\n prosfilei=s i)/ugges, Dionys. Paraph. de Avibus, i. 23); then used of the wheel itself, A. Pal. v. 204 (Asclepiades?)
i)/ugc h( *nikou=s, h( kai\ diapo/ntion e(/lkein
a)/ndra, kai\ e)k qala/mwn pai=das e)pistame/nh,
………
porfure/hs a)mnou= malakh=| trixi\ me/ssa deqei=sa
th=s *larisai/hs cei/nia farmaki/dos.
Lastly of any charm, Pind. Ol. iv. 35; Verg. Ecl. viii. 68 rather tamely 'ducite ab urbe domum, mea carmina, ducite Daphnim.'

a)/lfita…ta/ketai. Here begins the use of the fire magic. ta/ketai is rather strange with a)/lfita, but cf. Hesiod, Theog. 867 w(\s a)/ra th/keto gai=a se/la| puro\s ai)qome/noio: cf. 861 kai/eto
gai=a (ka/etai is given as v. l. in Scholiast, but is probably a mere gloss: tu/fetai, Meineke, Frit. Hill.).
'Whither are thy wits flown'; cf. xi. 72; Arist. Eccl. 156 ta/laina, pou= to\n nou=n e)/xeis;
h)= r(a/ ge/…te/tugmai; a question suits the context better than an (aside) statement; but h)= r(a/ ge/ toi (MS.) is not used in interrogations.
ti/n = soi/.
e)pi/xarma (an object of) scorn; cf. xii. 11, note.
pa/ss' a(/ma, not pa/ss', a(/ma kai/: cf. A. Pal. vi. 202 zw/nhn toi o(mou= kai\ to/nde ku/passin.
ta\ *de/lfidos o)sti/a. The meal is taken as a symbolical representation of Delphis, as the laurel and wax in 23, 28.

Verg. Ecl. viii. 83. For the chiasmus cf. v. 145. e)pi\ *de/lfidi, 'against Delphis'; cf. xxii. 134, 142; Propert. ii. 28. 35:
'Deficiunt magico torti sub carmine rhombi,
Et tacet extincto laurus adusta foco.'
lakei= me/ga, 'crackles loud.'
kappuri/sasa = katapuri/sasa: intransitive 'catching fire.'
ou)de\…ei)/domes. There is no stumbling-block in the use of the aorist here; 'the laurel burnt so quickly that we saw not even the ashes.'
