sa/rk' a)maqu/noi 'so may Delphis waste his body in the flame (of love).' For the active form of expression cf. xxiv. 124; xv. 85, note.
khro/n not necessarily an image of Delphis in wax, as Horace, Ep. xvii. 76 'cereas imagines'; Ovid, Heroid. vi. 91 'Devovet absentes simulacraque cerea fingit.'

su
 dai/moni, 'with the aid of the daemon'; vid. supra on ll. 11, 14. For su/n cf. vii. 12; Iliad xi. 792 ti/s d' oi)=d' ei)/ ke/n oi( su
 dai/moni qumo
 o)ri/nais, 'whether you would with the favour of God.'
r(o/mbos o( xa/lkeos see note on l. 17; Horace, Ep. xvii. 7 'retro solve turbinem'; Ovid, Fasti ii. 575 'tum cantata ligat cum fusco licia rhombo' (Fritzsche).
e)c )*afrodi/tas cf. vii. 112; vii. 55 o)pteu/menon e)c )*afrodi/tas The preposition here expresses the agent, as in l. 7 the means.

pi/tura, 'bran' is mentioned as used in mystic rights, though differently to this ceremonial, Demosth. De Cor. § 313. qusw=, not 'sacrifice' but 'burn'; cf. Excursus on l. 11 (first extract). The sense of the passage is well given by Wuestemann, 'furfures in ignem coniiciam ut ad me revocem illum, te adiuvante, Hecate; tu enim firmissimum quodvis movere possis.'
to\n e)n (/*aida kinh/sais a)da/manta: e)n (/*aida, cf. i. 103. The dative a(/|da| has no good MS. authority.

kinh/sais (k), 'thou could'st move.' The bare optative to express possibility in a main clause is common enough in Homer and all but Attic Greek; cf. Odyss. iii. 231 r(ei=a qeo/s g' e)qe/lwn kai\ thlo/qen a)/ndra saw/sai: Ap. Rhod. i. 767 o(\ kai\ dhro\n e)p' e)lpi/di qhh/saio, vid. Index, s. v. Optative.

to\n e)n (/*aida was altered to a)naidh= by Taylor, whom most
of the modern editors follow. MSS., Scholia, and sense are against this.

to\n e)n (/*aida a)da/manta = the adamant in hell = the gates of hell; cf. Propert. v. 11. 4 'non exorato stant adamante viae'; Verg. Aen. vi. 552; Ovid, Metam. iv. 452 'carceris ante fores clausas adamante'; cf. v. 160. These are appropriately mentioned as yielding to the power of Hecate, queen of hell. Cf. also Lucian, *nekuomant. 6 h)/kouon de\ au)tou\s (the Zoroastrians) e)pw|dai=s te kai\ teletai=s tisi\ a)noi/gein tou= (/*aidou ta\s pu/las.
ei)/ ti/ per cf. vii. 4.
35, 36 A sign that the invocation is answered is given by the barking of the dogs through the town; 'the goddess is at the cross-roads: sound the brass cymbal quickly.'
a)na\ pto/lin, 'up through the town'; one dog starts barking, and the rest take it up in turn. kata\ pto/lin would = about the town.

a)/xei is not used elsewhere with an accusative of the thing struck (a cognate acc. of the sound made is common enough with all verbs of the kind, e.g. Soph. Trach. 871), but cf. Pind. Ol. x. 93:
a)ei/deto de\ pa=n te/menos terpnai=si
qali/ais.
The custom of striking gongs, etc. at eclipses still prevails as in ancient times (Tacitus, Annals i. 28); at Athens this tom-tom music was used in connexion with the rites of Persephone.

39, 40 Vid. Introd. The lines express beautifully the contrast between the calm of sea and air, and the wild unrest of the girl's heart; cf. Tennyson, In Mem. xi:
'Calm and deep peace in this wide air,
These leaves that redden to the fall;
And in my heart, if calm at all,
If any calm, a calm despair.'
And in Greek where such contrasts are rare (though there is no lack of deep felt descriptions of nature's moods, Alcman 60, Aesch. Agam. 565) read Simonides' Danae (fr. 37, Bergk); cf. Statius, Silv. v. 4; Verg. Aen. iv. 522.
e)pi\ th/nw| cf. x. 31.
e)s…tri/s i. 25, note. A triple call was used in all ritual, Verg. Ecl. viii. 76; Pind. Pyth. iv. 109 e)s tri\s au)da/saisa. Dia = Naxos. The magic is here exchanged for prayer and curse.
to/sson e)/xoi la/qas sc. au)to/n. Greek says: e)/xei me u(/pnos: fluari/a (Plato, Rep. 336 c), e)/rws (Pind. Isth. viii. 64, etc.); so Latin 'quae te dementia cepit?'

A different form of the legend, Odyss. xi. 321. Catullus (64) agrees with Theocritus. la/qas…lasqh=men. Theocritus is fond of expressing his comparisons thus with the same or analogous words in both clauses, i. 23; ii. 28, 108, 114; vii. 97; x. 2; v. 52, etc.

i(ppomane/s. It is not clear whether Simaetha here makes any use of this philtre or merely refers to its power. It is
rather tempting to transpose the stanza with the next, in order to bring the i(ppomane/s into connexion with the qro/na of l. 59. The change from filtrokatadesmo/s here to fire magic again in 53, and again to philtres in 58, is awkward.
mainome/nw| i)/kelos cf. Ap. Rhod. i. 634 *quia/sin w)mobo/rois i)/kelai.
lipara=s Ovid, Heroid. xvi. 149 'nitida'; ib. xix. 11 'uncta palaestra' (Renies).

Verg. Ecl. viii. 91; Lucian, Dial. Meret. iv. § 5 tau/tas (ta\s krhpi=das au)tou=) krema/sasa e)k patta/lou u(poqumia=| tw=| qei/w|, pa/ttousa kai\ tw=n a(lw=n e)pi\ to\ pu=r. le/gei de\ a)mfoi=n ta\ o)no/mata kai\ to\ e)kei/nou kai\ to\ so/n: ei)=ta e)k tou= ko/lpou prokomi/sasa r(o/mbon e)pistre/fei e)pw|dh/n tina le/gousa e)pitro/xw| th=| glw/ssh|, barbarika\ kai\ frikw/dh o)no/mata, with the result that the possessor of the shoes forthwith appeared.

poto\n kako/n, 'a deadly draught.' Simaetha overcome by her grief and pain gives way to despair. If he will not come, to-morrow I will make an end of him and all. Then she rouses herself to one more attempt by the power of magic herbs smeared on the doorway; see Legrand, Étude, p. 117, note.
de/ in clause after vocative; Iliad i. 282 )*atrei/dh, su\ de\ paue teo\n me/nos; Eurip. Hecuba 372. Not in Comedy or Orators (Jelf. p. 134).

qro/na magic herbs, or a brew prepared therefrom; as a)/nqea for 'honey' in Pseudo-Phocyl. 174:
me/lissa
murio/trhta kat' a)/nqea khrodomou=sa.
Cf. Nicander, Alexiph. 153:
h)= kai\ sirai/oio posin diplh/qea teu/cais
su\n de/ te phgano/entas (of rue) e)niqru/yeias o)ra/mnous
o)rga/zwn (kneading) li/pei+ r(ode/w| qro/na.

kaq' u(pe/rteron, 'on the upper part of the lintel'; cf. Aratus 497 kaq' u(pe/rtera gai/hs a(=s e)/ti kai\ nu/c. MSS. have kai\ nu=n, and then insert (except k) e)k qumw=| de/demai, o( de/ meu lo/gon ou)de/na poiei=. This line is ungrammatical (poiei= should be poiei=tai), and breaks the regularity of the four line verses; it is also nonsense. kai\ nu=n must therefore be altered to make a finite clause. Buecheler's kai\ nu/c, or Ribbeck's a(=s e)/ti nu\c h(=|, or Fritzsche's kairo/s, are all possible, and might all be supported by Schol. k e(/ws e)/ti e)nde/xetai katadeqh=nai au)to/n. a)ll' i)/qi kai\ nu=n, C. Hartung (? ??sse de\ kai\ nu=n, ed.) or a(=s e)/t' e)gw\ nu=n, the sentence breaking off.
a(=s = e(/ws.
e)pifqu/zoisa, 'to avert the evil of the spell from yourself'; cf. vii. 127.

Thestylis goes away on her errand, and Simaetha tells the story of her love to the still night: how at a sacred procession she had seen Delphis, had loved at once, had won him and lost him. Such monologues are common in the Greek drama; cf. Soph. Trach. 1; Eurip. Androm. 91 sqq.:
xw/rei nun: h(mei=s d', oi(=sper e)gkei/mesq' e)/ti
qrh/noisi kai\ go/oisi kai\ dakru/masi,
pro\s ai/qe/r' e)ktenou=men.
Here Simaetha appropriately takes into her confidence the Moon-goddess who had helped her in the working of her spell.
a)/mmin, 'to my woe'; but moi in 65, 'brought on me.'
tw=u)bou/loio = tw= *eu)bou/loio, 'the daughter of Eubulus.'

kanhfo/ros = a)/lsos e)s )*arte/midos. The occasion was a public festival in honour of Artemis. In the procession to the shrine unmarried girls were chosen as bearers of the sacred baskets (kana=). The passage is made clear by Xenophon, Ephes. ii. 2 h)/geto de\ th=s )*arte/midos e)pixw/rios e(orth\ a)po\ th=s po/lews e)pi\ to\ i(ero
…e)/dei de\ pompeu/ein pa/sas ta\s e)pixwri/ous parqe/nous…parh/|esan de\ kata\ sti/xon oi( pompeu/ontes. prw=ta me
 ta\ i(era\ kai\ da=|des kai\ kana= kai\ qumia/mata: e)pi\ tou/tois i(/ppoi kai\ ku/nes kai\ skeu/h kunhgetika\ ta\ me
 polemika\ ta\ de\ plei=sta polemika\…h)=rxe de\ th=s tw=n parqe/nwn ta/cews )/*anqeia: cf. Ovid, Met. ii. 712.
polla\ me\n…e)n de/; a variant on the usual expression a)/lla te…kai/: cf. Cebes Tabula, ad init. polla\ me\n kai\ a)lla a)naqh/mata e)qewrou=men a)ne/keito de\ kai\ pi/nac tis.
ta=| = )*arte/midi 'in whose honour.'
qhri/a see the extract from Xenoph. Ephes., supra. Hartung holds the extraordinary opinion that the beasts were represented in painting.
*qeuxari/da = *qeoxari/dou.
*qra=|ssa probably to be taken as proper name; cf. Herondas, i. 1 qrei/ssa a)ra/ssei th\n qu/rhn tis.
trofo/s not 'my nurse,' but 'Th.'s.'

a( makari=tis, 'now gone to her rest.' Hiller quotes Aristoph. frag. in Stobaeus, Flor. cxxi. 18:
dia\ tau=ta ga/r toi kai\ kalou=ntai maka/rioi
pa=s ga\r le/gei tis, o( makari/ths oi)/xetai.
Cf. Herondas, vi. 55 tou/tw| *pumaiqi\s h( makari=tis e)xrh=to. The expression was therefore one in popular use.
a( mega/loitos. A person commenting on his or her own action uses the adjective with the article; cf. iii. 24; ii. 138; Soph. Antig. 274; Oed. Tyr. 1379.

73, 74 'How we remember such trifles in such awful moments! the scrap of the book that we have read in a great grief, the taste of that last dish that we have eaten before a duel, or some such supreme meeting and parting.'--Thackeray, Esmond.
'And now halfway along the road, at Lycon's gardens, I saw Delphis.'

me/son clearly means 'midway between home and my destination,' and is further defined by ta\ *lu/kwnos: cf. Odyss. vii. 195:
w(s…mh\…ti messhgu/s ge kako\n kai\ ph=ma pa/qh|si
pri/n ge to\n h(=s gai/hs e)pibh/menai.
(= between here and Ithaca). The adverbial use of me/son is rare, but occurs Eurip. Or. 983. The ellipse of one of the two extremes between which a thing is me/sos is common. Arist. Aves 187 e)n me/sw| dh/pouqen a)h/r e)sti gh=s: sc. kai\ tou= ou)ranou=.

'Love at first sight at a religious procession' is part of the stock-in-trade of the New Comedy and the Romancists; cf.
Plautus, Cist. i. 1. 91 (Hiller); Herondas, i. 56 *gru/llos…i)dw/n se kaqo/dw| th=s *mi/shs e)ku/mhne ta\ spla/gxn' e)/rwti kardi/hn a)noistrhqei/s: Musaeus, Hero and Leander, 42 sqq.: Charito, A. 1 (a passage closely modelled on Theocritus) )*afrodi/ths e(orth\ dhmotelh/s: kai\ sxedo\n pa=sai ai( gunai=kes a)ph=lqon ei)s to\n new/n: to/te de\ *xaire/as a)po\ tou= gumnasi/ou e)ba/dizen oi)/kade sti/lbwn w(/sper a)sth/r: e)ph/nqei ga\r tw=| lamprw=| tou= prosw/pou to\ e)ru/qrhma th=s palai/strhs w(/sper a)rgu/rw| xruso/s.
a)po/ belongs to lipo/ntwn (tmesis) not to gumnasi/oio.

w(s i)/don, w(s e)ma/nhn, w(/s meu, 'I saw, was fascinated, my heart was fired'; the three actions followed one on the other immediately. Note that the second w(s is not accented, and we are not to translate, 'as I saw so I was fascinated.' The explanation of the construction is doubtful. Similar passages are found--

(1) With w(s: Theocr. iii. 42; Iliad xix. 16 w(s ei)=d' w(/s min ma=llon e)/du xo/los: Ib. xx. 424 w(s ei)=d' w(\s a)ne/palto (alii w(/s): Ib. xiv. 294: Mosch. i. 74: Coluth. 251 w(s i)/den w(s e)no/hse. Possibly Odyss. xvii. 218; Oppian, Hal. iv. 97.
(2) o(/sson: Theocr. iv. 39 o(/son ai)=ges e)mi\n fi/lai, o(/sson a)pe/sbhs, 'dear are my goats, dear thou in death.'

(3) o(/s: Theocr. xv. 25 w(=n i)/des, w(=n ei)=pes ('si sic legendum'): Theognis 169 o(\n de\ qeoi\ timw=s' o(\n kai\ mwmeu/nenos ai)nei= (? Ib. 800 a)ll' o(\s lw/ios o(\s mh\ pleo/nessi me/loi: Ap. Rhod. iv. 1051 o(/ntina gouna/zoito o(/s min qarsu/neske).
(4) Latin: ut, Verg. Ecl. viii. 41 'ut vidi, ut perii, ut me malus abstulit error!'

(5) dum: Catullus, lxii. 45 'dum ... dum' is usually taken to be 'while,' 'so long,' but wholly unnecessarily. The verb to 'sic virgo' is understood from above, and each 'dum' = while. The reading is conjectural in Anon. ap. Hesych. h)=| me\n kle/os h)=| de\ kai\ h)=sqa. The passages are so curiously alike that a single explanation of them all seeems to be required. M. Haupt (Opusc. ii. 467) took o(/son…o(/sson in Theocr. iv. 39 as both demonstrative, but used by false analogy. This will hardly do for the w(s examples; certainly not for Vergil's 'ut vidi,' and hardly for the o(/s cases, since the demonstrative use of o(/s is limited to its employment in the nominative + me/n or de/, or preceded by kai/ or ou)de/, Monro, Hom. Gram. 265. The Theognis example (169) will not be explained.
(b) To take all as direct exclamations is impossible in view of the fact that o(/s is not so used, and in view of the sense required.

(c) It remains then to recognize all as relatives. Now w(s i)/don = when I saw (or as I saw)-the time of seeing (or the manner of seeing). So w(s e)ma/nhn, 'my fascination.' o(/son ai)=ges e)mi\n fi/lai = how dear my goats are = the dearness of my goats. So o(/sson a)pe/sbhs, 'the dearness of thee.' o(\n qeoi\ timw=s', 'the man loved of heaven.' ut vidi = 'my seeing,' etc. Put these noun equivalents in simple juxtaposition, and we get:
(1) Seeing, madness, fire of love.
(2) The dearness of my goats, the dearness of thee.

(3) The man loved of heaven, the man praised of others. I.e. the things identified are put alongside of one another
abruptly where logically we might have had to\ w(s i)/don i)/son e)du/nato tw=| w(s e)ma/nh.
to\…ka/llos, 'my colour paled from me.' Not as Seyffert would have it, 'the beauty of the scene swam before my eyes.'
w(s, 'how,' for o(/pws, 'as often,' Isocr. 74 e ou)k a)/dhlon w(s a)\n diateqei=en.

o(moi=os…qa/yw| cf. Sappho, ii. 14 xlwrote/ra de\ poi/as e)/mmi, teqna/khn d' o)li/gw| )pideu/hs fai/nomai: Catullus, lxiv. 100 qa/yos: Arist. Wasps 1413 gunai=ki klhteu/ein e)/oikas qayi/nh|, where the Scholiast quoting Theocritus says w)xro\s ga\r o( *xairefw=n kai\ h( qa/yos toiau/th. polla/ki seems here to lose its temporal meaning; cf. vi. 31; xxvii. 41; Meineke, ad loc.
e)/rreun = e)/rreon: cf. Odyss. x. 393 tw=n e)k me\n mele/wn tri/xes e)/rreon: Eurip. Medea 1201.

au)ta/ only bones and skin. For the expression cf. Callim. Ep. 30 o)ste/a soi kai\ mou=non e)/ti tri/xes: Ib. vi. 93:
e)ta/keto me/sf' e)pi\ neura/s:
deilai/w| i)=ne/s te kai\ o)ste/a mw=non e)/leifqen.
e)s ti/nos sc. do/mon, cf. xv. 22.
a(/tis e)pa=|den, 'who knew the use of spells.'

a)ll' h)=s ou)de\n e)lafro/n, 'sensu transitivo: id quod levat.' Wuestemann: compare Bacchyl. fr. 20:
ti/ ga\r e)lafro\n e)/t' e)/st' a)/praxq'
w(=d' o)duro/menon donei=n
kardi/an.
But there the sense must rather be 'what gladness is there' (cf. the use of e)lafro/s = 'gay spirited,' l. 124). So here, 'there was no gladness found'; and the adjective is no more transitive than kou=fon in xi. 3.
pa=san, 'wholly'; cf. ii. 40, iii. 33.
o( *mu/ndios, vid. preface to this idyll.
kei)/f' o(/ti. This use of o(/ti, followed by direct quotation, is an Atticism; cf. Plato, Protag. 356 a ei) ga/r tis le/goi o(/ti )*alla\ po/lu diafe/rei w)= *sw/krates.
u(fage/o = u(fhge/eo: so eu)kle/a, kra/tesks, Pindar; te/leskon, Callim.; h(/geo, A. Pal. ix. 403; site/skonto, Odyss. xxiv. 209, cf. infra, l. 107.
103, 104 The rhythm of the lines is to be noted: the quick dactylic lines here--the sense interrupted by the refrain--then the heavier cadence of the neat stanza.

The lines recall Sappho, fr. 2:
w(s ga\r eu)/idon broxew/s se, fw/nas
ou)de\n e)/t' ei)/kei:
a)lla\ kam me\n glw=ssa e)/age le/pton d'
au)ti/ka xrw=| pu=r u)padedro/maken,
o)ppa/tessi d' ou)de\n o)/rhm', e)pirro/m-
beisi d' a)/kouai:
a) de/ m' i(/drws kakxe/etai tro/mos de\
pa=san a)/grei.
Cf. Theognis, 1017:
au)ti/ka: moi kata\ me\n xroih\n r(e/ei a)/spetos i(drw\s
ptoiw=mai d' e)sorw=n a)/nqos o(mhliki/hs.
Persius, Sat. ii. 53:
'Si dona feram sudes et pectore laevo
Excutiat guttas laetari praetrepidum cor.'
e)pa/ghn, 'torpui'; dagu/s, 'a doll.'
w(/storgos (o( a)/storgos), 'he who loved me not.' Simaetha applies the term to Delphis, not because he has now deserted her, but because he can never have cared for her

e)pi\ xqono\s…ph/cas not coordinate with e)sidw/n. 'Seeing me, he dropped his gaze upon the ground and sate him down.' The words expressed assumed bashfulness on D.'s part, preparatory to his confession. So Musaeus, 160:
parqenikh\ d' a)/fqoggos e)pi\ xqo/na ph=cen o)pwph\n
ai)doi= e)ruqrio/wsan u(pokle/ptousa pareih/n.
But of pondering thought, Iliad iii. 217: of fear, Ap. Rhod. ii. 683 sta\n de\ ka/tw veu/santes e)pi\ xqono/s: of grief, Eurip. Iph. Aul. 1123; h. hymn Demet. 194.

Philinus: see prefatory note. e)/fqassa h)/ me parh=men. For the const. cf. Herod. vi. 108 fqai/hte a)
 e)candrapodisqe/ntes h)/ tina puqe/sqai h(me/wn. The comparative sense of the word is seen also in e)/fqhs pezo\s e)w
 h)\ e)gw\ su
 nhi+\ melai/nh|, Odyss. xi. 58.
h)=nqon…h)=nqon vid. Introd. p. 41.
kh)gw/ (= kai\ e)gw/) MSS., but the a)/n or ken could not be omitted where there is no if-clause expressed; contra, v. 126.
h)\ tri/tos h)e\ te/tartos for the omission of the usual au)to/s Hiller compares Plutarch, Pelop. 13 ei)s oi)ki/an dwde/katos a)pelqw/n.
au)ti/ka nukto/s, 'at the first hour of night.' The genitive depends on au)ti/ka, as xi. 40, and such expressions as pou= gh=s, o)ye\ th=s h(me/ras: cf. xxv. 18.
ma=la. The usual presents of lovers, cf. iii. 10 ff.

*diwnu/soio. Dionysus 'invented' the apple and all fruit, as well as the vine. Athenaeus, iii. 23 (quoting this passage): *neopto/lemos d' o( *pariano\s e)n th=| *dionusia/di kai\ au)to\s i(storei= w(s u(po\ *dionu/sou eu(reqe/ntwn tw=n mh/lwn kaqa/per kai\ tw=n a)/llwn a)krodru/wn. The Scholiast quotes Philetas:
ta/ oi( pote\ *ku/pris e(loi=sa
mh=la *diwnu/sou dw=ken a)po\ krota/fwn.
krati/ locative, 'on my brows.'
'And had ye received me, this had been dear to both--; for gay am I called and fair.

ta/de = 'your receiving me.' The plural is used as in Iliad xiv. 98:
o)/fr' e)/ti ma=llon
*trwsi\ me\n eu)kta\ ge/nhtai, etc.
[ta\ d' h)=s fi/la, Ahrens, which Fritzsche translates sodales mei amicos se praestitissent; even if ta\ d' could refer to the sodales implied in 119 tri/tos, the sense would be absurd.] The syntax is strange but by no means without parallel as Hartung thinks. For ei)/ ke with indic. cf. Ap. Rhod. i. 197 ei)/ k' e)/ti mou=non…metetra/fh *ai)twloi=si: Iliad xxiii. 526: Ap. Rhod. iii. 377 ei) de/ ke mh\ propa/roiqen e)mh=s h(/yasqe trape/zhs.

eu)=do/n t' ei)/ ke. For eu(=don without ke cf. inter alia, Eurip. Hecuba 1111:
ei) de\ mh\ *frugw=n
pu/rgous peso/ntas h)=|smen (*ellh/nwn dori/,
fo/bon pare/sxen ou) me/sws o(/de ktu/pos.
The action is represented for the moment as actually happening: then this impression is corrected by the if-clause; cf. Theocr. xvi. 43.

eu(=don. The sense is simply 'I would have felt assured of your love, and therefore would have slept happily, instead of lying awake for love' (a)grupnh=sai di' e)/rwta, x. 10). It is not 'nihil fecissem,' as Wunder (on Soph. O. T. 65) and others explain, nor is there any need of alteration as eu)/ade, L. Schmidt.

ei)/ ke see last note; for sense cf. A. Pal. v. 296:
h)=n d' a)/ra moi ta\ la/fura kalo\n sto/ma, kai\ to\ fi/lhma
su/mbolon…ei)=xon.
nu=n de/, 'but now, as it is.'

e)/fan (e)/fhn) : cf. v. 120 h)\ ou)xi\ parh/|sqeu. The aorist is used 'referring to the moment just past where English uses the present' (Sonnenschein, Syntax, 485); especially in referring to a judgement of one's own or another's. Iliad xvii. 173 nu=n de/ seu w)nosa/mhn pa/gxu fre/nas oi(=on e)/eipes: Arist. Peace 520 a)pe/ptus' e)xqrou= fwto\s e)/xqiston ple/kos. Elsewhere e)/fhn or e)fa/mhn is used = 'I used to say--contrary to what has turned out'; Iliad xvii. 171; Odyss. xi. 430. The connexion forbids us to take it so here. The form of expression is frequent, cf. Demosth. De Cor. 153, and a passage curiously like this in Julian Apost. kai\ pollh\n o(mologh/sas xa/rin toi=s ou)rani/ois qeoi=s e)n deute/rw| th=| sh=| megaloyuxi/a| xa/rin e)/sxon.
au)/tws, 'just'; cf. v. 40.

se/las flogerw/teron cognate accusative, 'burns with a fiercer flame.' A. Pal. xii. 93:
toi=on se/las o)/mmasin ai)/qei
kou=ros.
Of the rhetorical expression here, M. Legrand says well: 'Ce n'est pas, je pense, fortuitement que ces fleurs de rhétorique
galante sont réservées à l'homme sans amour (a)/storgos): en les lui attribuant, Théocrite entendait démontrer par contraste combien le jargon sentimental diffère du langage de la passion vraie.'
su/n. The madness is regarded not as the means but as the accompaniment; cf. xxv. 251 note.

e)fo/bhse gnomic, 'drives headlong.' This reading is justified against the emendation e)so/bhse by Bacchyl. xi. 43:
ta\s e)c e)ratw=n e)fo/bhse
pagkrath\s (/*hra mela/qrwn
*proi/tou, paraplh=gi fre/nas
kartera=| zeu/cas' a)na/gka|.
oi(. The dative is odd with e)/klina following, and is hardly paralleled by vii. 25 (? e)gw\ de/ toi).

xw(/s ka/…mh\ qrule/oimi, 'and not to tell all at length'; scilicet, 'I say only this.' For w(/s ken + opt. in primary sequence, cf. Odyss. ii. 52; xxiii. 134. makra\ le/gein, usually to speak aloud; here, to speak at length: Callim. Ep. xi. 1 ou) makra\ le/cw (Soph. Antig. 446 su\ d' ei)pe/ moi mh\ mh=kos a)lla\ su/ntoma).

a(/ te *fili/stas ma/thr…a(/ te *melicou=s, 'the mother of Philista and Melixus.' One person is meant not two. The repetition of the article in this way with conjunction is classical but very rare. Xenoph. Anab. iii. 1. 17 tou= o(momhtri/ou kai\ tou= o(mopatri/ou a)delfou=: Plato, Rep. 334 e to
 dokou=nta/ te, h)= d' o(/s, kai\ to
 o)/nta xrhsto
 fi/lon: Antiphon, i. 21 tw=| teqnew=ti kai\ tw=| h)dikhme/nw|: Demosth. De Cor. 205 to
 th=s ei(marme/nhs kai\ to
 au)to/maton qa/naton.

The MSS. have ta=s e)ma=s au)lhtri/dos, k, p; ta=s a)ma=s, s. Ameis keeps the latter = 'quae nobiscum in eodem loco habitat'; but this is hardly possible, and certainly not defended by xi. 4. Lobeck conjectured *sami/as. What I have ventured on (a)laa=s) is nearer to the MSS.
w(s a)/ra, 'that surely'; Plato, Soph. 230 d lekte/on w(s a)/ra me/gisth kai\ kuriwta/th tw=n kaqa/rsew/n e)sti, and constantly in quoting; often with ironical force, 'that as they said ...'
e)ra=tai cf. i. 78.
)/*erwtos a)kra/tw e)pexei\to. a)kra/tw is partitive genitive, 'poured unmixed wine.' oi)/nw is always omitted in this phrase; cf. Arist. Acharn. 1229 a)/kraton e)gxe/as.

)/*erwtos, as oi( (l. 153) shows, must = 'his love' (amores), not 'love' (amor). The genitive is used to express the object of a 'toast,' cf. xiv. 19: A. Pal. v. 109 e)/gxei *lusidi/khs kua/qous de/ka: ib. v. 135 (Meleager) e)/gxei kai\ pa/lin ei)pe\ pa/lin pa/lin (*hliodw/ras: Horace, Odes iii. 19. 9 'da lunae propere novae.' The genitive depends on the noun expressed or suppressed which forms the object of the verb.

puka/sdein. And he (Delphis) declared he would wreath the loved one's (oi() doors with wreaths. puka/sdein (present) instead of pukassei=n (future, which Paley reads) is most unusual after a verb like fhui/. But we find the aorist and present (rarely) after verbs of promising and hoping: e)lpi/zei dunato\s ei)=nai, Plato, Rep. 573 c. As Euripides (Alcest. 372) has
le/gontos mh\ (not ou)) gamei=n a)/llhn, as if le/gw = o)/mnumi, we may be justified in keeping puka/sdein as if fa/to = w)/mose or u(pe/sxeto. For the custom here alluded to, see Lucretius, iv. 1171:
'Lacrimans exclusus amator limina saepe
Floribus et sertis operit.'
A. Pal. v. 280:
filakrh/tous meta\ kw/mous
ste/mmasin au)lei/as a)mfiple/konti qu/ras.

sqq. Cf. line 4. Simaetha comes back wearily to the thoughts wherewith she began. and her last utterances echo the first; cf. 158-71. Her plaint really ends with the sad heavy cadence of a(mw=n de\ le/lastai. Then a long pause; at last she rouses herself fiercely once more to thoughts of magic, and revenge by magic, echoing grimly in the words ta
 )*ai/dao pu/lan a)racei= her former words (l. 6) ou)de\ qu/ras a)/racen a)na/rsios. Yet this is only for a moment. She has lost her faith in all means of help, and stands face to face again with the reality of her loneliness. 'And I must bear my load as I have borne it now'; oi)sw= to
 e)mo
 po/non w(/sper u(pe/stan. She ends not in wild words of revenge nor in rest, but in a calm despair, heightened by the pitiless calm of nature, the 'bright-faced Moon and stars that follow on the silent wheels of Night'; eu)kh/loio kat' a)/ntuga *nukto\s o)padoi/.
kataqu/somai not with reference to the intention expressed in 58. Still less is kate/qusa/ nin (Meineke) to be read. The past spells are not thought of now, only a new effort of revenge.
vai\ *moi/ras a well chosen expression in this passage. Herondas vulgarizes it, iv. 30 pro\s *moire/wn.

kat' a)/ntuga secundum. Following after the chariot as in kat' i)/xnos. The stars are the escort of Night. Wuestemann quotes well Tibullus, ii. 1. 87:
'Iam Nox iungit equos currumque sequuntur
Matris lascivo sidera fulva choro.'
But the lascivo there is in quite a different spirit to the sad calm of these lines.

div1.p: This idyll is again pastoral. A nameless goatherd appeals for favour to his Love, who is hiding herself in a grotto shaded with fern, but in vain; then from direct appeal he turns to the indirect persuasion of a love song, but still without result. The poem falls into three parts:
(a) 1-5 are addressed by the goatherd to his companion Tityros, bidding him tend the herd while he is away.
(b) The scene changes to a spot before the grotto where Amaryllis hides. To her the goatherd appeals.
(c) Encouraged by a favourable sign, he makes a new attempt, and sings of legendary heroes and their success in love. Then, wearying of his appeal, again despairs.

The idyll has been generally brought into connexion with iv, as there (l. 38) the words, w)= xari/ess' )*amarulli/, reoccur in the mouth of Battos. Hence critics, ancient and modern, would make the kwmasth/s of this poem = Battus (ei)ka/seie d' a)/n tis to\n e)pikwma/zonta *ba/tton ei)=nai, Schol.). But Battus is very different from the love-lorn singer of this idyll. The scene of Id. iv is South Italy; of this Sicily or Cos (see Wilamowitz-Moellendorff, Aratos von Kos, p. 183, note).
Theocritus frequently repeats half lines from idyll to idyll without any intention of uniting the one to the other; see i. 38 = vii. 48; xviii. 46 = xxii. 76; ii. 19 = xi. 72; vi. 17 = xiv. 62.

The Scholium on line 8 is interesting: tine\s dia\ to\ simo\s to\n *qeo/kriton kwma/zein fasi/, e)pei\ kai\ e)n toi=s *qalusi/ois (Id. vii) *simixi/das w)no/mastai: plh\n ou)k ai)po/los o( *qeo/kritos ou)de\ *simixi/das a)po\ tou= simo/s, a)ll' a)po\ *simi/xou patrwnumiko/n.

The meaning of the name Simichidas has been discussed in the Introduction, pp. 8, 9; while the idea that Theocritus is the kwmasth/s is absurd, it is not absurd to see in the simo/s of line 8 a hit at himself.
The date of the idyll must be sought in the Coan period, 290-280, vid. Introd. p. 23. In style it approximates to vii, vi and i: all Coan poems.

div2.p:
*kwma/sdw cf. Alcaeus, 56 (Bergk) de/cai me kwma/zonta de/cai li/ssomai/ se li/ssomai: Callim. Ep. 42:
ei) me\n e(kw\n )*arxi=n' e)pekw/masa, muri/a me/mfou
ei) d' a)/kwn h(/kw th\n prope/teian e)/a:
and Bion, xi. 4:
e(/spere…
kai/ moi poti\ poime/na kw=mon a)/gonti
a)nti\ selhnai/as tu\ di/dou fa/os:
in both cases of a serenade. The word is Latinized as 'comissor,' Horace, Odes iv. 1, and has the sense of kw=mon a)/gein, 'to lead a rout of revellers.'
tai\ de/ deictic; vid. i. 31.
1, 2 must be spoken by the kwmasth/s to himself, not to Tityros, as the change from nominative to vocative in line 3 shows.

to\ kalo
 pefilame/ne cf. i. 41; iii. 18. This use of the neut. adj. and article, in place of an adverb of quality, seems hardly to occur before Theocritus. The use is imitated in A. Pal. vii. 219:
h( to\ kalo
 kai\ pa=sin e)ra/smion a)nqh/sasa,
h( mou/nh *xari/twn lei/ria dreyame/nh:
by Herond. i. 54 ploute/wn to\ kalo/n: and by Callim. Ep. 52 to
 to\ kalo
 melaneu=nta *qeo/kriton: but it is grammatically merely an extension of the cognate accusative (cf. Arist. Acharn. 1201:
filh/sato/n me malqakw=s, w)= xrusi/w,
to\ peripetasto
 ka)pimandalwto/n):
and differs from the common kalo/n or kala/ just as th
 kalh
 fili/an pefilhme/nos differs from kalh
 fili/an pefilhme/nos, and indicates therefore a definite standard.

[In i. 15, etc., to\ mesambrino/n as adv. of time is different from Soph. O. C. 1640 tla/sas to\ gennai=on freni/. to\ gennai=on is object to tla/sas.] These lines are reproduced in Verg. Ecl. ix. 23:
'Tityre, dum redeo--brevis est via--pasce capellas,
Et potum pastas age, Tityre, et inter agendum
Occursare capro, cornu ferit ille, caveto.'
But it is noticeable that the untranslatable to\ kalo\n pefilame/ne is omitted, a point which struck Aul. Gellius (N. A. ix. 9) 'caute omissum quod est in graeco versu dulcissimum: quo enim pacto dicebat to\ kalo\n pefilhme/ne verba hercle non translaticia, sed cuiusdam nativae dulcedinis' (quoted by Meineke).
3, 4 On repetition of *ti/turos, *ti/ture, *ti/ture, see Introd. p. 43.
kna/kwna a new formation, from knako/s (Id. vii. 16). Babrias has knhki/as, of a wolf (yellow boy), 122, 12; cf. purri/as (purro/s), *canqi/as (canqo/s), ai)oli/as (ai)o/los, the name of a fish).
kna/kwn seems to be formed on analogy of such names of )*aga/qwn, *ti/mwn, *fi/lwn. Libyan sheep were famous from the time of the Odyssey (Odyss. iv. 85).
6, 7 Verg. Ecl. ii. 6.

tou=to kat' a)/ntron to be joined with parku/ptoisa, 'leaning out through the entrance of your bower.' kat' a)/ntron…kalei=s (= 'call to your bower') is not a use of the preposition which can be supported [xvii. 112 i(erou\s kat' a)gw=nas = 'for'; cf. Thucyd. vi. 31 kata\ qe/an h(/kein, 'to come for the spectacle'] except in very late prose (vid. Jannaris, Hist. Gk. Grammar, § 1586). In the sense given to kata/ here, see Lycurgus, § 86 u(podu/nta kata\ ta\s pu/las: Iliad xii. 469.

e)rwtu/lon. to\n e)rwtiko\n u(pokoristikw=s kai\ ou)x w(/s, MSS. ku/rion: Schol. = 'the love lorn swain.' The word is used by Bion, v. 10 a)lla/ moi au)to\s a)/eiden e)rwtu/la = 'songs of love'; cf. ib. 13:
o(/ssa d' e)/rws m' e)di/dacen e)rwtu/la pa/nt' e)dida/xqhn.
We have a by-form, e)rwti/s (fem.), iv. 59, which shows that it is not formed immediately from e)/rws. For the diminutive termination -u/los, cf. drimu/los, mikku/los, Moschus, )/*erws drape/ths (8, 13).

e)ggu/qen, 'at near view': not e)ggu/s, since Greek marks the point from which we look; cf. xxii. 16: Mosch. Europa, 155 *zeu\s ei)mi\ kai\ e)ggu/qen ei)/domai ei)=nai tau=ros: Plato, Phaedr. 255 b proseme/nou de\ kai\ lo/gon decame/nou, e)ggu/qen h( eu)/noia gignome/nh tou= e)rw=ntos e)kplh/ttei to\n e)rw/menon.

proge/neios 'cui mentum prominet,' Kiessling; but Vergil (Ecl. viii. 35 'Hirsutumque supercilium promissaque barba') certainly took it to denote a scrubby projecting beard; that this was the meaning of Theocritus is rendered certain by Longus, i. 16 ou(=tos de\ purro\s w(s a)lw/phc kai\ proge/neios w(s tra/gos…ka)\n de/h| de filei=n e)mou= me\n filh/seis to\ sto/ma, tou/tou de\ ta\s e)pi\ tou= genei/ou tri/xas. Vergil, Ecl. iii. 7 ('mori me denique coges')
follows both sense and rhythm; cf. supra on 4 and 6. xi. 72 = Ecl. ii. 69; vid. Introd.

thnw=qe = 'thence'; cf. Arist. Acharn. 754; A. Pal. vi. 354; toutw=qen, Id. iv. 48, which establish the form against the variant thnw= de/. For the long vowel, cf. a)mfote/rwqen, etc., but Theocritus has also touto/qe, iv. 10; thno/qi, viii. 44; like au)to/qi, au)to/qen, a)/lloqen.
a)/lla i. e. a)/lla de/ka: Verg. Ecl. iii. 70.

From here to l. 23 the lines drop naturally in groups of three; as above they fell into couplets. This change and the abruptness of some of the transitions from thought to thought have led commentators to rearrange the lines, and by dint of much shuffling and rejecting of lines to get a mathematical symmetry into the poem. On the Theocritean symmetry of verse, see Introd. p. 39. On the second point--the abrupt transitions--the sequence of thought is not logical, but it represents a natural change from sentiment to sentiment as each is suggested by circumstance. At 11 an answer is expected, and not given: so 12 proceeds, 'Yet regard my grief if nothing else,' the thought is changed by the passing bee: in 15 it returns to the complaint of cruelty: 18 is a more piteous appeal, 'I do not ask much, only a little kiss': 21--an expression of peevishness which works itself up to thoughts of self-destruction.
e)mo/n cf. viii. 14; xxv. 203; and Index.

a( bombeu=sa, 'that bee'; cf. A. Pal. v. 83:
ei)/qe r(o/don geno/mhn u(popo/rfuron o)/fra me xersi\n
a)rsame/nh xari/sh| sth/qesi xione/ois.
And a modern Greek song, Legrand, Chansons popul. grecques 41:
xilidona/ki na\ genw= th\n kli/nhn sou na\ e)/lqw
na\ kti/sw th\n fwli/tsan mou e)s ta\ proske/fala/ sou,
na\ khla|dw=, na\ s' e)cupnw=, pa/nta na/ me quma=sai,
na/ me quma=sai, lugerh/, e(/ws te zh=|s kai\ ei)=sai.
Cf. Anacreontea 22, Bergk.
a(=| tu\ puka/sdh|, 'wherewith you shut yourself in,' i.e. the bower is covered with ferns.
Verg. Ecl. viii. 43; Catullus, lxiv. 154 'quaenam te genuit sola sub rupe leaena?'; Iliad xvi. 34. Similar expressions are common enough in Greek and Latin.
e)qh/laze see on xiv. 15.
drumw=| loc. dative; cf. ii. 121; Soph. O. T. 20 a)gorai=si qakei=.

e)s…a)/xris. In the Classical period we find a)/xris or me/xris e)s occasionally (Xen. Anab. v. 5. 4). The order used here seems to be only Alexandrine, but becomes very frequent, e.g. e)s go/nu me/xri, Callim. iii. 12; e)s ai)qe/ra d' a)/xri, Mosch. i. 19; poti\ to\n qeo\n a)xris, Callim. vi. 129; e)s o)sti/on a)/xris, Quint. Smyrn. ix. 376; e)s ai)qe/ra me/xris, Id. ix. 69. The other order appears, Theocr. vii. 67 e(/st' e)pi\ pa=xun, cf. xxv. 31: Aratus 599 me/sfa par': Id. 602 a)/xri par': Theophrast. Char. xi. a)/xris e)pi\ polu\ tw=n pleurw=n: and often.
kua/nofru cf. xx. 24 kai\ leuko\n to\ me/twpon e)p' o)fru/si la/mpe melai/nais: Anacreont. xvi. 11 a(palo\n de\ kai\ drosw=des stefe/tw me/twpon o)fru\s kuanwte/rh drako/ntwn.
to\ kalo\n poqoreu=sa see on xiii. 45.

to\ pa=n li/qos is difficult. The Scholiast gives a variety of explanations: (1) o(/lh leukh\ oi(=on a)galma marma/rinon: (2) h)\ sklhra\ kai\ a)/tegktos: (3) h)\ mo/non ou)xi\ a)podidou=sa tou\s o(rw=ntas tw=| ka/llei. The third is obviously ridiculous. The first would give a good sense, but it is doubtful if li/qos could be so used without further designation; cf. vi. 38 leukote/ran au)ga\n *pari/as u(pe/faine li/qoio: Anacreont. 15:
u(po\ porfurai=si xai/tais
e)lefa/ntinon me/twpon.
Nicet. Eugen. ii. 208 lampro\n to\ ble/mma: xai=re lampro/ths li/qwn, although as description of beauty precedes and follows it would be natural to take li/qos as compliment rather than as upbraiding. This is, however, the sense most easily given to li/qos by itself; cf. A. Pal. v. 228:
au)ta\r e)me\ stena/xonta to/shs kata\ nukto\s o(mi/xlhn
e)/mpnoos *eu)i/pphs ou)k e)le/aire li/qos.
Id. xii. 151:
ei) d' e)sidw\n w)= cei=ne purifle/ktoisi po/qoisin
ou)k e)da/mhs, pa/ntws h)\ qeo\s h)\ li/qos ei)=.
In that case we have a sudden transition from praise of beauty to complaint of coldness; cf. A. Pal. xii. 12 a)/rti geneia/sdwn o( kalo\s kai\ sterro\s e)rastai=s: and verse 39 of this idyll will refer back to the line. Herondas, vi. 4 ma=, li/qos tis ou) dou/lh, of a person standing stock still. Calverley translates rightly, 'O thou whose glance is beauty and whose heart marble.' For the neuter to\ pa=n attached to li/qos, cf. xv. 20 a(/pan r(u/pon: Lucian, Dearum Judic. de Paride to\ pa=n bouko/los. Usually we have attraction, Soph. Philoc. 622 h( pa=sa bla/bh: ib. 927 pa=n dei=ma. li/pos is mentioned as v. l. in Scholiast, but is not justified by the use of liparo/s, Bacchyl. v. 169 lipara\n qei/man a)/koitin. J. A. Hartung reads le/pas. Meg was deaf as Ailsa Craig.
pro/sptucai cf. Odyss. iv. 647 e)pei\ prosptu/cato mu/qw|.
to\n ai)po/lon (see on xiv. 56), me, your own herdsman.

e)/sti kai\ e)n. The line is repeated by the author of xxvii. 4, and quoted by Eustath. Philos. § 105 ti/ soi ke/rdos ei)=pen e)k tou= filh/matos. e)gw\ de\ pro\s th\n ko/rhn meq' h(donh=s e)/sti kai\ e)n keneoi=si filh/masin a(de/a te/ryis.

to\n ste/fanon ti=lai/ me kat' au)ti/ka lepta\ pohsei=s (s. Junt. Call. katauti/ka p, k). There is no word katauti/ka, though we have katauto/qi, Iliad x. 273; Theocr. xxv. 153, kaqa/pac (Attic), etc. parauti/ka (xxv. 222) and new compounds are made by the Alexandrian writers with great freedom: ei)/seti, xxvii. 17; suna/ma, xxv. 126; katenanti/a, Ap. Rhod. ii. 1116; ei)sopi/sw, Quint. Smyrn. i. 243; e)/kpoqen, Ap. Rhod. iii. 262. So divisim: kat' e)/ktoqi, Quint. Smyrn. ii. 413; e)k to/qen, Ap. Rhod. ii. 533; kat' a)nti/on, Quint. Smyrn. ii. 328; ei)s a(/lis, 25; a)p' e)nteu=qen, Polyb. (Jannaris,
§ 1516). Ahrens reads here kai\ au)ti/ka, but we can keep kata/ if we take it as tmesis with ti=lai: cf. Odyss. x. 567 e(zo/menoi de\ kat' au)=qi go/wn: Moschus, Europa 4:
u(/pnos
lusimelh\s peda/a| malakw=| kata\ fa/ea desmw=|.
The construction then is pohsei=s me katati=lai to\n ste/fanon lepta/, 'to pluck the wreath in bits'; h)/toi katati=lai to\n ste/fanon ei)s lepta/, Schol. To a neuter plural thus used as predicate the preposition ei)s may be added, but is usually omitted; but then it is customary to make the adj. immediately dependent on a second verb; cf. Theocr. ix. 27; Odyss. xii. 174:
khroi=o me/gan troxo\n…
tutqa\ diatmh/cas…pi/ezon.
Similar to this passage are Aratos 1054:
…kai\ ga/r t' a)roth/sion w(/rhn
triplo/a mei/rontai.
Quint. Smyrn. xiv. 534:
…a)/far de/ min a)/lludis a)/llh|
e)ske/dasan dia\ tutqa/.
Cf. Demosth. 182 dielei=n e(ka/sthn pe/nte me/rh.
o( du/ssoos vid. on ii. 138.
u(pakou/eis see on xi. 78.
thnw= vid. on iii. 10.

The tunny fishery was practiced throughout Greek waters (Oppian, Hal. iii. 620 sqq.). Oppian, l. c. 637 describes a watcher for the school as here ei)/q' h)/toi prw=ton me\n e)p' o)/rqion u(/yi kolwno\n i)/dris e)pambai/nei qunnosko/pos, o(/ste kiou/sas pantoi/as a)ge/las tekmai/retai, ai(/te kai\ o(/ssai, pifau/skei d' e(ta/roisi.
ta\n bai/tan a)podu/s shows a delightful idea of economy: he may be drowned, but spoil his plaid--no fear!

The MSS. have kai)/ka mh\ )poqa/nw, keeping which Paley translates 'etiam si non moriar at saltem tibi iucundum erit': so the Scholiast. The sense is feeble and the Greek dubious since ge ma/n is not used to introduce an apodosis. Graefe read dh/ for mh/ (a not uncommon confusion): Meineke and Hiller take this and translate 'si obiero tua tibi voluntas effecta est.' But to\ teo
 a(du/ in both these is very doubtful and could only mean 'your sweetness,' not 'what is pleasant to you'; cf. tw=| e)mw=| ai)sxrw=|, Andocid. ii. § 9; to\ semno
 to\ so/n, Eurip. Hippol. 1064; to\ so
 gennai=on, Soph. O. C. 569; to\ sfe/teron a)prepe/s, Thucyd. vi. 11; to\ u(me/teron eu)sebe/s, Antiphon. 141. 2; tw=| sumfe/ronti tw=| u(mete/rw|, Aesch. Ktes. § 8; h(mete/rw| mede/onti, Callim. i. 86; especially to\ au(tou= gluku/, Plato, Phaedrus. I take dh/ and mark an aposiopesis after a)poqa/nw, 'and if I die (well it will all be over), and yet (ge ma/n) thou art sweet to me.'

a(du/ is predicate. to\…teo/n is little more than tu/ (= what thou art); cf. xxii. 61; Arist. Thesm. 1170 ta\ me
 par' h(mw=n i)/sqi
soi pepeisme/na: Plato, Theaet. 161 e to/ g' e)mo
 ou)de
 a)
 proqumi/as a)polei/poi: cf. Soph. Ajax 1313: Arist. Thesm. 105:
eu)pi/stws de\ tou)mo

dai/monas e)/xei sebi/sai.
(Vergil may have taken the lines as Hiller, Ecl. viii. 60; but probably he represented iii. 54 and xxiii. 20, not this line, when he writes 'extremum hoc munus morientis habeto,' vid. Conington, ad loc.).

The object of e)/gnwn is not the following clause, o(/ka (vid. in vi. 21), but the clause supplied from the context, 'that thou care not for me': hence the kai/ in 31. 'I knew it of old, and the old witch too told me sooth.'

memname/nw ei) file/eis me thinking of thee and wondering if thou lovest me (Haupt). There is an exactly similar usage in Ap. Rhod. iii. 535:
th=s me\n a)po\ mega/roio kata\ sti/bon e)nqa/d' i)o/ntes
mnhsa/meq', ei)/ ke du/naito, kasignh/th gegaui=a,
mh/thr h(mete/rh pepiqei=n e)parh=cai a)e/qlw|:
cf. Mosch. )/*erws drap. 2; Xen. Anab. vi. 1. 31 e)quo/mhn ei) be/ltion ei)/h.

ou)de\ to\ thle/filon, k.t.l. According to usual explanation we have here described a popular method of augury. A leaf (? poppy, thle/filon) was held between the fingers and slapped against the arm or hand. If a sharp cracking noise (plata/ghma) was made the sign was favourable; plhtto/menon ei) yo/fon a)pete/lei, e)di/dou au)toi=s shmeiou=sqai o(/ti a)nterw=ntai, Schol.: cf. Pollux, Onom. ix. 127. But potema/cato and e)cemara/nqh are both very obscure with this explanation. Haupt translates 'impingit crepitum': a sense which can hardly be extracted from potema/cato = to press close, xii. 32; to press into, Nicander, Therm. 772, 181 ai(/da prosma/ssesqai: so e)nema/cato ke/ntron, ib. 767; e)mma/ceai o)rgh/n, Callim. Dian. 124; A. Pal. ix. 548; in all the original sense of 'smearing,' 'rubbing in,' is latent. Schol. k gives another rendering: fu/tario/n ti o(\ tine\s tw=n e)rwtikw=n tiqe/ntes e)pi\ tw=n w)/mwn h)\ tw=n karpw=n e)pikrou/ousi, kai\ e)a
 me
 e)ruqro
 ge/nhtai kalou=ntes au)to\ r(o/dion nomi/zousin a)gapa=sqai, tou= xrw=tos (xrw/matos MSS. quidam) d' e)mprhsqe/ntos h)\ e(lkwqe/ntos misei=sqai.…plata/ghma: to\ platagw/nion…mh/kwnos fu/llon. This gives quite a new interpretation, and one which is free from objection. There is no authority for plata/ghma = 'crack.' The word only occurs here and in a mistaken imitation, A. Pal. v. 296. Take to\ thle/filon and to\ plata/ghma in apposition, and translate plata/ghma, 'leaf' or 'cracking leaf,' si lubet.

a(palw=| poti\ pa/xeos MSS. optimi: a(palw=| poti\ pa/xei+ vulgo: pa/xei+ is not a Theocritean form. Read a(palw=| poti\ pa/xeos, 'on the soft part of the arm.' Tr., 'the love-in-absence, the leaf, did not make the (red) smear, but withered dead on the flesh of my arm.' poti/ in Doric does not put back its accent when it follows its case.

There is again considerable doubt as to the right reading (vid. note crit.). We want a proper name with the definite
reference to some particular witch (cf. ii. 145; vi. 40). Meineke's *paraiba/tis is therefore probable: it is a feminine form of the name *paraiba/ths (Herod. v. 46). The lectio vulgata is )*agroiw/. k has a( groiw/, and Schol. k gives *groiw\ o)/noma ku/rion. Hence Ziegler (Hiller) a( *groiw/: but the place of the article is hardly justified for Theocritus by the Homeric to\n *xru/shn a)rhth=ra (which Hiller quotes). Greek says o( r(h/twr *dhmosqe/nhs or o( *dhmosqe/nhs r(h/twr w)/n, not o( *dhmosqe/nhs r(h/twr: see on xiii. 19; xv. 97. a( grai/a is only conjecture and does not explain the MSS. reading. I adopt therefore Warton's conjecture a)groiw=tis a)laqe/a, 'And a country-woman too divining by the sieve told me sooth, Paraebatis who the other day was gathering her herbs, that I dote on thee.'

poiologeu=sa 'haec de spicilega (gleaner) viri docti interpretantur messores subsequente ... at neque poiologei=n idem est quod staxuologei=n neque *paraiba/tis dici potest quae messores sequitur' (Meineke). Paraebatis is therefore an old hag like Cotytaris (cf. vi. 40) who was gathering her herbs to make into charms and simples.

e)riqaki/s misqw/tria u(pokoristikw=s, Schol.: cf. Eustath. ad Iliad 1162. 23 e)/sti de\ kai\ o)/rneon a)f' ou(= to\ o)/noma. Again a double explanation: (1) e)riqaki/s is a diminutive formed from e)/riqos, 'a maidservant' (so Liddell and Scott, s. v.); (2) it is a proper name formed from e)ri/qakos, 'the name of a bird.' But the diminutive of e)/riqos would be e)riqi/s (fem.), vid. on v. 50. The majority of editors therefore take the word as proper name. Tr. 'Erithacis, daughter of Mermnon.' Theocritus often gives the parent's name, ii. 146; x. 15; Herondas, vi. 25 h( *bita=tos eu)bou/lei: v. 3 (*amfutai/h| th=| *me/nwnos: i. 76 th\n *puqe/w de\ *mhti/rxhn.

The twitching of the eyelid was a favourable omen. Plautus, Pseud. i. 1. 105 'ita supercilium salit'; Eustath. Philos. § 322 e)pi\ dh\ tou/tois pa=sin o)fqalmo\s h(/lato me\n o( decio/s. Wuestemann quotes a fragment from a work by one Melampus addressed to Ptolemy Philad. o)fqalmo\s decio\s e)a\n a(/llhtai, e)xqrou\s u(poxeiri/ous e(/cei. The goatherd is encouraged by the sign to believe that he will see Amaryllis, and resolves to try to entice her by a song.
i)dhsw= a new future form; see Synopsis of Dialect, § 3.
a)poklinqei/s, 'leaning back.'
e)pei\ ou)k a)damanti/na refers back to to\ pa=n li/qos, l. 18. Cf. the similar reference from ii. 157 to ii. 4; Stat. Silv. i. 2. 69 'duro nec enim ex adamante creati.'

-51. The song consists of four groups of three verses each, touching briefly on country stories of love. The idea reappears in the Leontion of Hermesianax, and, pretty though this ballad is, it might be regarded as hardly in keeping with the character of a country swain. But Theocritus' shepherds are not all clowns, and, as shown in Introd. p. 37, Theocritus' realism is not particularly attentive to detail of style or expression. The idea is appropriate enough in the country lad, only the form is worked up by the author to give a more artistic setting. What is important is that Theocritus' country folk do not utter moral sentiments or criticisms of current events out of keeping with their station. We have similar appeals to legend in xx. 33; viii. 52.
40, 41 For the story of Hippomenes and Atalanta see Ovid, Met. x. 560.
dro/mon a)/nuen not 'finished the course,' but 'sped on the course'; see i. 93.
See note on ii. 82; for hiatus see Index, s. v.

Neleus, king of Pylus, imposed on him who would wed his daughter Pero the task of bringing to Pylus the oxen of Iphiclus. Melampus undertook the quest for his brother Bias, and having rendered service to Iphiclus received the herd as a present; cf. Odyss. xi. 281; Propert. ii. 3. 51.
)/*oqruos, Mount Othrys in Thessaly.
a( de/, 'and she' (Pero); ma/thr a( xari/essa follows in apposition. Cf. o( d' ei)=p' )*odusseu/s, Soph.; and the frequent deictic use of the article in Theocr. i. 30; vii. 7, 80, etc.
Verg. Ecl. x. 18 'et formosus oves ad flumina pavit Adonis'; cf. Theocr. i. 109 w(rai=os xw(/dwnis, e)pei\ kai\ ma=la nomeu/ei.

e)pi\ ple/on a)/gage lu/ssas. For the genitive see on i. 20; Herond. iii. 8 sumforh=s d' h)/dh o(rma=| e)pi\ me/zon: Aratus 1047:
pri=noi me\n qaminh=s a)ku/lou kata\ me/tron e)/xousai
xeimw=nos ke le/goien e)pi\ ple/on i)sxu/sontos.
Thucyd. ii. 53 e)pi\ ple/on a)nomi/as h)=rcen to\ no/shma. The second limb of the comparison is with e)pi\ ple/on only vaguely understood; and may be '(more) than now is,' or '(more) than usual,' or '(more) than previously.' So here e)pi\ ple/on a)/gage lu/ssas = 'led her on in madness.' Oppian, Hal. iv. 147 sh/piai au)= duse/rwtes e)pi\ ple/on e)/dramon a)/ths.

'That not even in death does she cease to clasp him to her breast.' The Scholiast understood the line to be descriptive of a picture. It rather expresses the legend given by Bion, Epit. Adon.:
pa/xee d' a)mpeta/sasa kinu/reto, mei=non )/*adwni
du/spotme mei=non )/*adwni, panu/staton w(/s se kixei/w,
w(/s se periptu/cw kai\ xei/lea xei/lesi mi/cw.
49, 50 zalwto\s…zalw= Introd. p. 43, § ii.
o( to\n a)/tropon u(/pnon i)au/wn the accus. is cognate. *la/tmion knw/sseis, Herond. viii. 10.

a)/tropon dist. xxiv. 7 eu(/det' e)ma\ bre/fea glukero\n kai\ e)ge/rsimon u(/pnon: Mosch. Epit. Bion. 117 (of sleep of death) eu(/domes eu)= ma/la makro\n a)te/rmona nh/greton u(/pnon. Endymion loved by Selènê was thrown by her into an endless sleep that she might ever look on him and kiss him sleeping; cf. A. Pal. v. 164 (Meleager):
o( d' e)n ko/lpoisin e)kei/nhs
r(iptasqei\s kei/sqw deu/teros )*endumi/wn.

Iasion, loved by Demeter; see Odyss. v. 125: Hesiod, Theog. 970:
*dhmh/thr me\n *plou=ton e)gei/nato, dia\ qea/wn,
)*iasi/w| h(/rwi+ migei=s' e)rath=| filo/thti.
See Paley, ad loc.

tossh=n' e)ku/rhsen. The accusative is used also by Oppian, Hal. i. 34 a)terpe/a d' au)=lin e)ku/rsan; Aesch. Sept. 699 bi/on eu)= ku/rhsas. to/sswn k is therefore probably due to an emending copyist. Iasion is said to have been associated with Demeter in the mysteries of Eleusis (paremfai/nei de\ mustiko\n to\n e)/rwta )*iasi/wnos kai\ *dh/mhtros, Schol.), but only on the authority of this passage.

The words o(/s' ou) peusei=sqe be/baloi (cf. xxvi. 14) can only mean 'which ye shall not learn who are unacquainted with love's mysteries.' To make them refer to any supposed religious rites involves the absurdity of making the singer himself one of the initiated. Catullus imitates the line lxiv. 260 'orgia quae frustra cupiunt audire profani.'
ti/n = soi/, Dialect. § 2.
a)ei/dw for present cf. Aeschines ii. 183 mikra\ ei)pw\n h)/dh katabai/nw: Krüger, liii. 1. 8.
keiseu=mai de\ pesw/n cf. Arist. Clouds 126 a)ll' ou)d' e)gw\ me/ntoi pesw/n ge kei/somai: Ecclesiaz. 963 (to fall and lie where one has fallen).
'Let this be honey for thee in thy throat'; an expression of bitter vexation. The change of style in 52 from smooth running lines to jerky clauses suits the change of temper to cross disappointment.

div1.p: This and the following idyll, together with x, are realistic sketches of the rougher side of Greek country life, while in iii we had the sentimental side. Poetic ornament is less apparent here: in its place we have a genial humour in the presentation of character which makes Battus and Corydon, Milo and his companion, Lacon and Comatas stand out each an individual drawn in a few sharp strokes without elaboration of detail (cf. Introd. p. 32).

Battus is by way of being a wit in this idyll, and finds an easy butt for his jibes in Corydon, his master, and all his belongings; Corydon is quite unconscious that he is being made fun of, and preserves his naive vanity and sententiousness throughout.
The scene of the poem is fixed for South Italy by v. 17, 33. The date is uncertain. but probably before 282 (vid. on line 31).
Recent critics have found in Battus the poet Callimachus, starting from the fact that Callimachus called himself *battia/dhs, but vid. Introd. p. 28.
On the supposed connexion with Idyll iii see preface to that idyll.

lg.l: 'M. Dic mihi, Damoeta, cuium pecus? an Meliboei?
D. Non, verum Aegonis; nuper mihi tradidit Aegon.'

div2.p: *filw/ndas the Boeotian patronymic form like Epaminondas, Herondas.
ye = sfe by metathesis.

ta\ poqe/spera, 'o' evenings'; cf. v. 113 accus. of time. The singular is more usual cf. i. 15; to\ mesa??e/rion, vii. 21; to\ a)rxai=on, Thucyd. ii. 99. 2; to\ pa/lai, Ib. i. 5. 1; to\ au)ti/ka, Ib. vi. 69. 4. But ta\ nu=n, ta\ prw=ta are common in all periods, Krüger, l. 5. 13; and cf. Theocr. v. 13.
o( ge/rwn, 'the boss.'
u(fi/hti, sc. tai=s bousi/: cf. ix. 3 (= u(fi/hsi).
kh)me/. kai/ + e gives in Ionic h, in Attic a: cf. ii. 100; xv. 74, etc. kh)pi\, kh/s are attested by inscriptions (Ahrens, Dial. Dor. p. 221).

a)/fantos rather more than frou=dos: cf. Soph. O. T. 560:
*la/i+os…
……
a)/fantos e)/rrei qanasi/mw| xeirw/mati;
'was swept from men's sight' (Jebb); Aesch. Agam. 624:
a(nh\r a)/fantos e)c )*axaii+kou= stratou=,
au)to/s te kai\ to\ ploi=on.
Hence here we have a colloquial exaggeration of speech.
To Battus the prowess of his master should be famous kaq' (*ella/da kai\ me/son )/*argos.
ou)k a)/kousas; 'you haven't heard the great news?'
)*alfe/on the famous river of Elis.

*mi/lwn the famous athlete, Milo of Croton, thirty-one times victor in the great games, lived in 510 B.C. In l. 31 of this idyll Theocritus mentions song writers of his own day. It is hardly likely then that the scene of the poem is imagined as taking place in Milo's time; Shakespeare may allude to Elizabethan politics in King Lear, but he would not make his fool talk of Essex by name. The exploit of Aegon mentioned in l. 33 sqq. was according to the Scholiast recorded of a certain Astyanax of Miletus, but is transferred by Theocritus to Aegon. But a similar feat on the part of Milo is alluded to by Dorieus (Appendix to Anthologia 20; Brunck, Analecta, ii. p. 63):
toi=os e)/hn *mi/lwn o(/t' a)po\ xqono\s h)/rato bri=qos
tetrae/nh| dama/lhn, e)n *dio\s ei)lapi/nais
w)/mois de\ kth=nos to\ pelw/rion w(s ne/on a)/rna
h)/negken di' o(/lhs kou=fa panhgu/rews:
kai\ qa/mbos me/n: a)ta\r toudi\ ple/on h)/nuse qau=ma
pro/sqen *pisai/ou, cei=ne, quhpoli/ou:
o(\n ga\r e)po/mpeuen bou=n a)/zugon ei)s kre/a to/nde
ko/yas pa/nta kat' ou)=n mou=nos e)dai/sato/ nin.
It would seem then that Aegon was setting himself to break Milo's record for a single meal. As therefore there is in that passage a reference to the famous Milo it is difficult to make the name here merely fictitious. I take this line to mean therefore 'the fame of Milo has sent him to Elis' to become
a second champion of Croton. There is no difficulty in applying the words w)/|xeto a)/gen to an abstraction (the memory of Milo) cf. ii. 7; Theognis 1295:
w)= pai= mh/ me kakoi=sin e)n a)/lgesi qumo\n o)ri/nh|s
mhde/ me sh\ filo/ths dw/mata *persefo/nhs
oi)/xhtai profe/rousa.
The verb oi)/xomai in all these expressions only emphasizes the completion of the action, as in w)/|xeto feu/gwn, oi)/xetai qanw/n.

o)pw/pei may be either pluperfect or a Doric tense from o)pw/pw (cf. i. 63, note), so far as form goes: o)/pwpa = 'I know by having seen,' not 'I see' nor 'I saw' (aorist); cf. Theocr. xxii. 55; Aesch. Eumenid. 57 to\ fu=lon ou)k o)/pwpa th=sd' o(mili/as: Arist. Lysist. 1157 ou)/pa gunai=k' o)/pwpa xai+wte/ran. So the pluperf. 'I knew by experience,' to\ mh\ o)pw/pesan qhri/on, Herod. vii. 125.
e)n o)fqalmoi=si Homeric, Odyss. viii. 459; x. 385; also without e)n, Odyss. iii. 373; x. 197, etc.

e)/laion the oil used by the competitors.
'iuventus
Nudatos umeros oleo perfusa nitescit.' Verg. Aen. v. 134

(*hraklh=i bi/hn kai\ ka/rtos. The Homeric forms are used intentionally (Odyss. iv. 415 ka/rtos te bi/h te: v. 213 a)qana/th|si de/mas kai\ ei)=dos e)ri/zein). Corydon rises to the occasion and eschews the vulgar Doric.
kw)/|xet' e)/xwn, 'he took with him,' the emphasis being on the participle; katagelw=n th=s po/lews a)/peisin, Lysias, xv. 10.

skapa/nan di/kellan…h)\ a)/mhn: oi( ga\r gumnastai\ tou/tois e)xrw=nto u(pe\r gumnasi/as (for exercise) th=| skapa/nh| ska/ptontes kai\ ta\ a)/nw me/rh tou= sw/matos a)narrwnu/ntes, Schol. The athletes trained for thirty days at Elis before going to Olympia (Frazer on Pausanias, vi. 23. 1). The twenty sheep are of course provisions for the month. Briggs quotes well from St. Chrysostom ai)tei=tai th\n pa/lhn kai\ feu/gei to\ ska/mma.
touto/qe see on iii. 10.

pei/sai toi *mi/lwn. The reading is supported by all MSS. except k, which has pei=sai/ ke. This gives a satisfactory sense if we take the optative to express, not a wish, but a 'concession.' The sequence of thought is, Aegon has gone off leaving his flocks and even devastating the fold to provide him food. Milo might as well, says Battus, set the wolves on to the flock at once (au)ti/ka) and make short work of it (k.t.l. the wolves as well as Aegon). For this use of the optative to express indifference cf. Aesch. Prom. V. 1048:
xqo/na d' e)k puqme/nwn
au)tai=s r(i/zais pneu=ma kradai/noi:
……
pa/ntws e)me/ g' ou) qanatw/sei:
'Let the whirlwind shake the earth from her foundations if it will.'

lussh=n we should doubtless expect to have added something like e)pi\ th=| a)ge/lh| to define the verb; but the sense is
given by the w)/xet' e)/xwn ei)/kati ma=la of the preceding line: moreover lussh=n expresses a much more active madness than mai/nesqai: cf. Pseud. Phocyl. 215 polloi\ ga\r lussw=si…pro\s e)/rwta: Eurip. H. F. 846 *lu/tta, personified, says of herself, ou)d' h(/domai foitw=s' e)p' a)nqrw/pwn fo/nous; cf. Plato, Rep. 329 c a)smenai/tata me/ntoi au)to\ (sc. e)/rwta) a)pe/fugon w(/sper luttw=nta/ tina kai\ a)/grion despo/thn a)pofugw/n. Tr., therefore, not 'to be mad,' but 'to go raving.'

h)= ma
…ge Arist. Frogs 104 h)= mh
 ko/bala/ g' e)sti
 w(s kai\ soi\ dokei=. Corydon understands to
 bouko/lon to refer to Aegon who has left his farm. Battus intended a double hit at Aegon and Corydon. The author of the Epit. Bion. imitates the line (v. 23):
kai\ ai( bo/es ai( poti\ tau/rois
plazo/menai goa/onti kai\ ou)k e)qe/lonti ne/mesqai.
lw=nti Doric 3rd pers. plur., from la/w.
Cf. ii. 89; A. Pal. vii. 31 *smerdi/h| w)= e)pi\ *qrh|ki\ takei\s kai\ e)p' e)/sxaton o)steu=n.
au)ta/, 'only.'

The cicada fed according to popular belief on dew; Verg. Ecl. v. 77:
'fluvios dum piscis amabit,
Dumque thymo pascentur apes, dum rore cicadae.'
Anacreont. 42.

ou) *da=n cf. vii. 39. The accusative is used with no particle; cf. v. 17, iv. 29: Soph. O. T. 1087 ou) to\n )/*olumpon: Ant. 758 ou) to/nd' )/*olumpon. *da= is traditionally explained as Doric for ga= (gh=), and *dhmh/thr as *ghmh/thr. There is no evidence for an interchange of g and d in the dialects, and the word is rather to be connected with di=os, *dio/s, *zh=na; see Ahrens, Dial. Dor. pp. 80, 81 (= by Gad).
*ai)/saros a river of Croton (cf. Lycophron, 911; and note on 33). Latymnus, a hill near the same (Schol.).

purri/xos a diminutive from the adj. purro/s (cf. o(ssi/xos, iv. 55), expressing contempt. The termination is otherwise known only in nouns--o)rta/lixos (Theocr. xiii. 12); especially in names--)*amu/ntixos (vii. 132); *si/mixos, )*asw/pixos (Pind. Ol. xiv. 15); *leo/ntixos (A. Pal. vi. 103); cf. Ahrens, Dial. i. 216.
-22. 'I hope Lampriades' folk, the demesmen, may get, when they sacrifice to Hera, one like that. They are dirty blackguards all.'
The point may be (1) if they sacrifice a skinny beast, their offering will be rejected and they will suffer from Hera's wrath.
(2) If they offer this beast, there will not be a good feast afterwards and they will be paid out (cf. Schol. vii. 107 o(/tan lepto\n i(erei=on qu/swsi kai\ mh\ i(kano\n h)=| toi=s e)sqi/ousi).

Beware of translating 'the demesmen of Lampriades.' The repetition of the article shows that the two phrases are in apposition (see note on l. 33). Who Lampriades was is wholly unknown; perhaps an eponymous hero of the deme.

o(/kka^ cf. Nossis, A. Pal. vi. 353 h)= kalo\n o(/kka pe/lh| te/kna
goneu=sin i)/sa: Theocr. i. 87 o(/kk' e)sorh=| (and often so elided): Epicharm. fr. 90 ou)k e)/sti diqu/rambos o(/kx' u(/dwr pi/h|s. o(/kka_ in Theocr. viii. 68; Epicharm. fr. 115 is doubtful.

ka_ (= ken) is always long (Theocr. i. 4, iii. 27, etc.). o(/kka^ should therefore be regarded as = o(/ka with double consonant (cf. o(/tti, o(ppo/ka, etc.; contra, Ahrens, Dial. ii. p. 382) and o(/kka qu/wnti = o(/te qu/wsi: the ka or a)/n being omitted (cf. v. 98).

Hera was the special deity of Croton, and was worshipped with sacrifice of kine; Liv. xxiv. 3 'sex millia aberat a Crotone templum, ipsa urbe nobilius. Laciniae Iunonis: lucus ibi frequenti silva ... laeta in medio pascua habuit ubi ... sacrum Deae pascebatur pecus' (Hartung).
toio/nde --the object of la/xoien is held over to the end--as a para\ prosdoki/an.

kakoxra/smwn. So all MSS. except Q which has kakosxra/mwn. The word cannot be derived from xra/omai which preserves h throughout and would give -xrh/mwn: nor from xrh/|zw which would have -xrh/|smwn. Hiller reads kakoxrh/|smwn (needy), but this does not give a good sense. Ahrens (ed. ii), kakogra/smwn = kako/fagos from √ gra, grastis = gluttonous; formerly he suggested kakosxa/mwn (hyperdorized for kakosxh/mwn) = a)sxh/mwn. This would refer to the penalties imposed on 'unseemly conduct' at festivals (Inscr. Messenia, Collitz and Bechtel, 4689 o)mnu/w tou\s qeou\s e)pime/leian e(/cein o(/pws ge/nhtai ta\ kata\ ta
 teleta
 qeoprepw=s kai\ mh/te au)to\s mhqe
 a)/sxhmon…poih/sein mhde\ a)/llw| e)pitre/yein). kakodra/smwn, Hermann, 'malus sacrorum administrator.' kakoxra/smwn may, however, be right; it must be derived from xrai/nw, 'to defile' (cf. fa/sma from fai/nw), and is a new coinage meaning, as I have translated, 'dirty blackguards ...'
kai\ ma/n takes up and answers 20 lepto\s ma/n.

*stoma/limnon apparently the same marshy lake as is mentioned in v. 146 *subari/tidos e)/ndoqi li/mnas. The word occurs only here, but cf. Oppian, Hal. iv. 506:
*maiw=tis o(/ph| sumba/lletai a(/lmh|
a)gro/menai limnai=on u(po\ sto/ma.
ta\ *fu/skw cf. ii. 76.

*nh/aiqon cf. Lycophron, 919:
*kra=qis (cf. Theocr. v. 16) de\ tu/mbous o)/yetai dedoupo/tos
eu)ra\c )*alai/ou *patare/ws a)nakto/rwn
*nau/aiqos e)/nqa pro\s kli/dwn' e)reu/getai.
Ovid, Met. xv. 51 'Praeterit, et Sybarin, Salentinumque Neaethem' (Briggs).

fu/onti (= fu/ousi), rarely intransitive; cf. vii. 75: (Moschus) Epit. Bion. 108 u(/steron au)= zw/onti kai\ ei)s e)/tos a)/llo fu/onti: and the famous passage, Iliad vi. 149: cf. Mimnernos, fr. 2 h(mei=s d' oi(=a/ te fu/lla fu/ei poluanqe/os w(/rh| e)/aros, o(/t' ai)=y' au)gh=|s au)/cetai h)eli/ou. In all these the sense might indeed be 'puts forth foliage': but the intrans. sense is fixed by Alcaeus, fr. 97 e)la/fw de\ bro/mos e)n sth/qesi fu/ei fobero/s.
Cf. Epigram vi. 3.
o(/ka causal; cf. Arist. Frogs 22; Lysias, xii. § 36; xix. § 5 o(/t' ou)=n toiau=ta polla\ gege/nhtai…ei)ko\s u(ma=s mh/pw tou\s lo/gous h(gei=sqai pistou/s.
h)ra/ssao a Homeric form.
e)pa/ca e)pa/cw, aor. middle.

e)gw\ de/ tis ei)mi\ melikta/s a singer of some note; 'a minstrel in my way' (Calv.): cf. i. 32; Demosth. Ol. iii. § 4 )*olu/nqioi du/nami/n tina kekthme/noi. More commonly with adjectives, cf. vii. 38; Plato, Protag. 334 c e)gw\ tugxa/nw e)pilh/smwn tis w)\n a)/nqrwpos (disparaging) or used alone = 'some one of importance' (Eurip. Electra 939 eu)/xei tis ei)=nai toi=si xrh/masin sqe/nwn: cf. Theocr. xi. 79), in which case instead of tines for the plural ti is generally used, Plato, Gorgias 472 a u(po\ pollw=n kai\ dokou/ntwn ti ei)=nai (so ou)de/n, a 'nobody').

Glaucè of Chios, a contemporary of Theocritus, mentioned by Hedylus in App. Anthol. 34 "Theon the flute player
hu)/lei de\ *glau/khs memequsme/na pai/gnia *mouse/wn,
kai\ to\n e)n a)krh/tois *ba/ttalon h(dupo/thn":
obviously a writer of popular songs.

Of Pyrrhos nothing is known; )*eruqrai=os h)\ *le/sbios melw=n poihth/s, Schol. J. A. Hartung in his note here and Introd. p. xv, strangely makes ta\ *pu/rrw = 'the deeds of King Pyrrhos.' Such a conjunction of ta\ *glau/kas, 'the songs of Glaucè,' with ta\ *pu/rrw, 'the deeds of Pyrrhos,' is wholly impossible. We can, however, get a date for the idyll from the history of the king of Epirus. Pyrrhos entered Italy, 279; Croton was utterly destroyed at the same time. The scene of this poem should therefore be imagined as before 279, and the time of writing probably the same.
ai)ne/w ta/n te *kro/twna the sentence begins as if ta/n te *za/kunqon followed. The interposition of kala\ po/lis changes the latter to the nominative.

kala\ po/lis may possibly be the actual beginning of the song (? anacreontic in rhythm, kalh\ po/lis *za/kunqos), but is more probably to be taken as iii. 15 nu=n e)/gnwn to\n )/*erwta: baru\s qeo/s (Hiller).

*za/kunqos conjectured to be some place near or some part of Croton, the position of the words between *kro/twna and *laki/nion making the commentators adverse to referring the name to the island Zacynthus. But that the island is meant is rendered almost certain by Holm (Hist. of Greece, iii. ch. 3. Appendix). He points out that Croton and Zacynthus (and no other town in Western Greece) in the fourth century adopted a coinage identical with that used by the commercial and political league of Rhodes, Ephesus, Cnidus, and Samos (the type is Heracles strangling the serpents), only omitting the *s*u*n (summaxi/a) which appears on the coins of the league. Some intimate relations must, therefore, have existed between Croton and Zacynthus, and to these Corydon refers, just as every after-dinner speaker now refers to U. S. A., and every Frenchman to his dear ally Russia.

to\ *laki/nion (the temple of Juno Lacinia): vid. supra, v. 22; and cf. Dionys. Perieg. 368:
e)ggu/qi de\ sfw=n
i(merto\n ptoli/eqron e)u+stefa/noio *kro/twnos
kaio/menon xari/entos e)p' *ai)sa/rou proxoh=|si
e)/nqa ken ai)pu\n i)/doio *lakwnia/dos do/mon (/*hrhs.
The double article here is strange, and can only be explained by taking to\ potaw=|on substantivally and in apposition to to\ *laki/nion, the eastward part, the temple of Lacinia (so Hermann), cf. iv. 21; Eurip. I. T. 250 tou= suzu/gou de\ tou= ce/nou ti/ tou)/nom' h)=n; = his comrade, the stranger. For though the order art. adj. art. adj. noun is good Greek (see on xiii. 5), the supposed order art. adj. art noun is not Greek at all. The Scholiast quotes a proverbial saying, ma/taia ta)/lla para\ *kro/twna ta)/stea (lege para\ *kro/twna/ ge or para\ *kro/twn' e)st' a)/stea with Duebner).
-36. Vid. note on iv. 6.
o)gdw/konta mo/nos with the verbal antithesis; cf. ix. 26; xvi. 87, etc.
o(pla=s gen. with pia/cas (pie/sas), catching it by the foot; cf. xxv. 145; v. 133.
xw( bouko/los = Aegon's laughing at the way in which he had frightened the women.
w)= xari/ess' )*amarulli/. Battus is recalled by the mention of Amaryllis to the memory of his dead love, and for the moment drops his banter (se/qen is only used here in the pastorals).

For the construction cf. note on ii. 82, but the sentence is here rendered more difficult by the elliptical form of the comparison, which in full would be o(/son ai)=ges e)mi\n fi/lai, o(/sson fi/la tu\ a)pe/sbhs, 'dear are my goats, so dear art thou in death'; cf. Thucyd. vii. 71 dia\ to\ a)nw/malon kai\ th\n e)/poyin h)nagka/zonto e)/xein: Longus, iii. 21 tosou=to e)pau/eto bra/dion o(/son h)/rcato (Haupt. Opusc. ii. 467).
a)pe/sbhs of death, A. Pal. vii. 20, 422, 295.
tw= sklhrw= genit. with exclamation, Herond. iv. 21 ma\ kalw=n a)galma/twn, and often in Attic mala/ follows the adjective as in Arist. Acharn. 851 o( taxu\s a)/gan.

lelo/gxei probably pluperf. not 'Syracusan' present perfect 'which then possessed me,' Plato, Phaedo 107 d o( e(ka/stou dai/mwn o(/stis zw=nta ei)lh/xei (dist. Soph. O. C. 1337 to\n au)to\n dai/mon' e)ceilhxo/tes). The form lelo/gxa is archaic (Krüger, i. 40, p. 169).
sqq. Consolation by means of proverbs is characteristic of the class to which Theocritus assigns Corydon.

On form of verse cf. Introd. p. 40(b). The proverb is used by Lycurgus, Contra Leocr. § 60 a)nqrw/pw| zw=nti me\n e)lpi\s e)k tou= kakw=s pra=cai metapesei=n teleuth/santi de\ sunairei=tai pa/nta di' w(=n a)/n tis eu)daimonh/seien.

*zeu/s in the original sense 'the sky god,' Theognis 25:
ou)de\ ga\r o( *zeu\s
ou)/q' u(/wn po/ntess' a(nda/nei ou)/t' a)ne/xan.
Arist. Aves 1501:
*p*r. ti/ ga\r o( *zeu\s poiei=;
a)paiqria/zei ta\s nefe/las h)\ sunnefei=;
Verg. Georg. i. 418 'Iuppiter uvidus austris.'
ka/twqe, 'up to the hill.'
ta\ du/ssoa cf. iii. 24.
o( le/pargos not a proper name. Suidas quotes a proverb a)na/ soi ta/de pa/nta le/parge: e)pi\ tw=n ou)de\ meta\ to\n ka/maton a)nieme/nwn, e)k metafora=s tw=n bow=n. See Meineke, p. 455.
See on i. 151. The article with a proper name in the singular is very unusual; cf. however Lucian, Deor. Dial. 20 su\ de\ pro/siqi h( )*aqhna= (k here has si/tt' w)= *kumai/qa).
ei) mh\ a)/pei, 'if you won't go away'; cf. Arist. Aves 759 ai)=re plh=ktron ei) maxei=. ei) with the fut. indic. has always this modal sense; see Sonnenschein, Greek Syntax, § 354 obs.

ei)/q' h)=n moi r(oiko\n to\ lagwbo/lon, ??s tu pa/taca MSS. (p has r(oiko/n tu+). If Theocritus wrote this and meant to\ r(oiko\n lagwbo/lon, as even Hiller thinks, then he learnt but little Greek from Philetas. Hermann reads ti, cutting the knot. It is worth while to examine the passages where the article takes an abnormal position.

(1) Homer has tou= basilh=os a)phne/os, Iliad i. 340; to\n cei=non du/sthnon, Odyss. xvii. 10, etc. The order is always art. noun adj., never adj. art. noun. The article is probably merely a demonst. pron. 'him, the hapless stranger.' This then is no support for the order here; so Bion, Ep. Ad. 34 oi( d' u(po\ mazoi\ xio/neoi.

(2) Soph. Ajax 572 o( lumew
 e)mo/s: Athenaeus, vii. 126 th=| (*eka/th| triglanqi/nh|: Collitz and Bechtel, Inscr. 4427 tw=| *dii\ )*olumpi/w|. In all these the article stands first, and the order may be explained by bracketing the two following words--tw=| [*dii\ )*olumpi/w|]--as a single notion. o( lumea
 e)mo/s means then not 'my destroyer,' opposed to 'some one's else,' but 'this destroyer of me.' Cf. such passages as Aesch. In Ctes. 78 o( miso/teknos kai\ path ponhro/s: Charito, B. iii. 7 qeo
 ei)=nai nomi/zwn th
 ou)de\ a)/nqrwpon eu)tuxh=.
(3) ta\s a)/llas tau/tas pragmatei/as prostetagme/nas kata\ yh/fisma, Aesch. In Ctes. 13. Divided attribute, normal, Krüger, 50. 9. 8.

(4) Wide extensions of the predicative adjective, especially in Lucian, e. g. Quomodo Hist. Conscrib. § 4 ei)/ ge kai\ suggrafe/as tosou/tous a)ne/fuse (o( po/lemos) u(po\ mia=| th=| o(rmh=| (at one go). In the present passage the sense 'would that my staff were crooked that I might have struck thee' is barred by the sense.

It is quite easy to hit a cow with a straight stick. If the text is sound we must translate 'Would that I had a crooked staff' (taking r(oiko/n as a loose predicate as in example (4), and laying the emphasis on h)=n, not on r(oiko/n, as we might say r(oiko\n ei)=xe to\ lagwbo/lon): but I am not sure that we should not read (*roiko\n to\ lagwbo/lon, 'my staff, Crookie.' For the shepherd's staff, used for throwing, cf. vii. 21; A. Pal. vi. 37; Iliad xxiii. 845.

w(/s tu pa/taca must be attached to the preceding, 'that I might have struck thee.' To take it absolutely 'how I would
have struck thee' (Hiller) is impossible Greek. For the construction cf. Soph. O. T. 1392:
ti/ m' ou) labw\n
e)/kteinas eu)qu\s w(s e)/deica mh/pote, k.t.l.
Dinarchus, i. § 10 e)xrh=n zhtei=n i(/na a)phlla/gmeqa (pluperf.) tou/tou tou= dhmagwgou=: Theocr. vii. 86; Ap. Rhod. i. 281.
= tai\ a)traktulli/des.
kakw=s a( po/rtis o)/loito, 'dang the beast'; Lucian, i. 204 Prometheus says tw=| *kaukasw| proshlwme/nos to\n ka/kista o)rne/wn a)polou/menon ai)eto\n tre/fwn tw=| h(/pati.
e)s tau/tan e)tu/phn xasmeu/menos. For the order cf. i. 47; Odyss. xiii. 267 to\n me\n e)gw\ katio/nta ba/lon xalkh/rei+ douri\ a)gro/qen.

te is unusually late in the sentence, but cf. Bacchyl. xviii. 53:
xitw=na porfu/reon
ste/rnois t' a)mfi\ kai\ ou)/lion
*qessala\n xlamu/d(a).
o(ssi/xon, 'a wee bit wound'; cf. purri/xos, iv. 20. Meineke quotes Boissonade's Anecd. ii. 424 dei=con o(ssi/xon to\ tu/mma kai\ le/onta dama/zon h(li/kon fai/h g' a)\n *qeo/kritos.
m' = moi: elided according to Homeric usage, Iliad ix. 673; x. 544; cf. on xv. 112.
e)rwti/da see on iii. 7.
ta=s pok' e)kni/sqh, 'about whom he was excited.' In gen. as in Lucian, Dial. Meret. x. 4 ke/knistai ga\r ka)kei=nos th=s *nebri/dos.
eu)= g' Lucian, i. 228 eu)= ge o( gennai=os.
63. ge/nos with e)ri/sdeis as in the Homeric bi/hn kai\ ka/rtos e)ri/zein: cf. iv. 8. See k. e)ri/sdei MSS. ceteri.

div1.p: This idyll like the fourth presents a living sketch of rough country character, without idealization or mere ornament of language. The characters are Comatas, a goatherd, and Lacon, a shepherd. The idyll opens with badinage between the two, with coarse rustic humour; then proceeds to a singing-match, in which Comatas is adjudged the winner. The scene is South Italian, vid. 16, 73, 124, 146. See further Introd. p. 37.

div2.p: th=non, 'the rascally shepherd.'
to/nde, 'here.'
to/ meu na/kos for to\ na/kos meu (mou), a post-classical order, cf. Herondas, v. 7 to/ meu ai(=ma: vi. 41 th/n meu. glw=ssan: Callim. iii. 139 oi(/ seu pa/ntes a)/eqloi.
ou)k…kra/nas; sc. a)/pite, cf. v. 102, and the Aristophanic ou)k e)s ko/rakas; cf. Frogs 185.

ta\n poi/an cf. Arist. Acharn. 62:
*k. oi( pre/sbeis oi( para\ basile/ws:
*d. poi/ou basile/ws. ('King indeed!')
poi=os is thus used with a word repeated from the previous speaker to express contempt. The article is generally omitted in this idiom; attached when information is really sought.
kala/mas au)lo/n, 'a pipe of straw'; cf. Verg. Ecl. iii. 27 'Stridenti miserum stipula disperdere carmen'; Milton, Lycidas 'Grate on their scrannel pipes of wretched straw.'

e)neu/dein, 'even your master Eumaras had not a rag to sleep in'; cf. Odyss. iii. 349:
w(=| ou)/ti xlai=nai kai\ r(h/gea po/ll' e)ni\ oi)/kw|,
ou)/t' au)tw=| malakw=s ou)/te cei/noisin e)neu/dein.
This use of the infin. of a verb compounded with e)n-, dependent on a substantive, is common even in prose; cf. Herod. vi. 102 xwri/on e)pith/deon e)nippeu=sai. Cf. also Hesiod, Opusc. 781 'the thirteenth day is futa\ e)nqre/yasqai a)ri/sth': Eurip. Bacchae 508 e)ndustuxh=sai tou)/nom' e)pith/deios ei)=.
ta\ loi/sqia, 'now last of all.'

to\n a)/ktion = to\n e)pi\ tai=s a)ktai=s u(po\ tw=n a(lie/wn i(drume/non (Et. Mag.); cf. A. Pal. x. 10:
*pa=na/ me to/nd' i(erh=s e)pi\ lissa/dos, ai)giali/thn
*pa=na, to\n eu)o/rmwn tw=nd' e)/foron lime/nwn.
Aesch. Persae 449:
nh=sos…h(\n o( filo/xoros
*pa\n e)mbateu/ei, ponti/as a)kth=s e)/pi.

h)\…, 'or, if I did, may I go mad'; cf. Arist. Knights 410:
ou)/toi m' u(perbalei=sq' a)naidei/a| ma\ to\n *poseidw=,
h)\ mh/ pot' a)gorai/ou *dio\s spla/gxnoisi paragenoi/mhn.
Isocr. Dem. § 48 toi=s de\ spoudai/ois ou)x oi(=o/n te a)melei=n th=s a)reth=s, h)\ pollou\s e)/xein tou\s e)piplh/ttontas.
*kra=qin a river flowing into the gulf of Tarentum near to Sybaris (Thurii, vid. v. 74).
ai)/…pisteu/saimi, 'if I believe you, may I earn the sufferings of Daphnis.' For construction cf. xiv. 50; vii. 108; v. 150, etc.
'However, if you care (lh=|s) to stake a kid,--it's no great thing, but still I'll sing against you till you cry enough.' The form of the sentence is broken, and altered by the parenthesis.

a)lla/ ge is an unusual combination of particles (cf. Plato, Rep. 331 b a)lla/ ge e(\n a)nq' e(no\s ou)k e)la/xiston e)/gwge qei/hn a)/n: A. Pal. iii. 6 a)lla/ ge to/cw| qh=ra kaqaima/ssei *foi=bos a)po\ skopih=s). A word usually intervenes, as Isocr. 95 d diamartw\n de\ th=s prosdoki/as a)ll' ou)=n| th/n ge eu)/noian kth/sei.
ou)de\n i(ero/n paroimi/a e)pi\ tw=n mhdeno\s a)ci/wn, Schol.
to\n…a)mno/n sc. qe/s, understood from ai)/ka lh=|s qe/men.

e)/risde, 'begin your challenge.' The command is repeated impatiently in l. 30; hence Lacon's answer there, mh\ speu=de. The vulgata lectio a)mno\n e)/risde is not Greek: a)mno\n e)/reide (k corr. Db) is a very doubtful expression ('set your lamb against my kid'). Ahrens conj. o(/risde.
ki/nados tu/, 'you fox.'
e)c i)/sw, 'how shall that be fair?'
dh/leto = e)bou/leto.
The line forms an indirect answer to the question of Lacon: 'Why, such an one as trusts to beat his neighbour as you trust.'
sfa/c ('a hornet') is in apposition to the o(/stis clause.

pepoi/qeis (pepoi/qw) : the verb has to be supplied from subordinate to main clause; cf. Theognis, 541:
deimai/nw mh\ th/nde po/lin *polupai+/dh u(/bris
h(/per *kentau/rous w)mofa/gous o)/lesen (sc. o)le/sh|):
Megara, 45 su\ d' h)u/te lei/betai u(/dwr (sc. lei/beai): Thucyd. i. 82; iii. 68.
a)lla\ ga/r, 'but since the kid is not enough see there's the goat. Begin.' (tui=de = th=|de, Aeolic form.)
stiba/s cf. vii. 67; Longus, ii. 31. 1 e)k fulla/dos stiba/das u(postore/sas.

toi=s o)rqoi=si, 'if you dare look at me with such bold eyes.' The article has deictic force, cf. iii. 13 a( bombeu=sa me/lissa: Soph. O. T. 1371:
o)/mmasin poi/ois ble/pwn
pate/ra pot' a)\n prosei=don:
ib. 1385 o)rqoi=s e)/mellon o)/mmasin tou/tous o(ra=n.
i)/d' a( xa/ris, 'see what becomes of kindness.' Cf. Theognis, 105 deilou\s eu)= e)/rdonti mataiota/th xa/ris e)sti/n.

qre/yai, 'rear wolf cubs, and rear dogs--to be devoured by them.' We might expect either qre/yai kai\ lukidei=s kai\ ku/nas, or qre/yai lukidei=s, qre/yai ku/nas (anaphora); but even when anaphora is used, an anticipatory kai/ (or te) is occasionally found in the first clause: cf. Soph. Antig. 296:
tou=to kai\ po/leis
porqei=, to/d' a)/ndras e)cani/sthsin do/mwn:
cf. ib. 673:
au(/th po/leis t' o)/llusin, h(/d' a)nasta/tous
oi)/kous ti/qhsin.
So in Vergil, 'Iam redit et Virgo, redeunt Saturnia regna.' (See M. W. Humphreys, in Class. Rev. April, 1897.)
ku/nas the dog in Greece was kept in a half wild state; cf. Odyss. xxi. 363; Xenoph. Agesil. i. § 22 w(s mh/te u(po\ kunw=n mh/te u(po\ lu/kwn diafqei/rointo.
a)ndri/on, 'contemptuous.'
au)/tws with an adjective bears the force of 'just' or 'as you are'; cf. ii. 133.
u(/stata, 'and you shall sing for the last time'; Verg. Ecl. iii. 51 'efficiam posthac ne quemquam voce lacessas.'
See note on i. 106. These lines of Comatas answer to Lacon's 31-34.
ou)de\n o(moi/a i. e. 'much better than'; Isocr. 179 e e)ktw=nto ga\r du/namin ou)de\n o(moi/an th=| pro/teron u(parxou/sh|.
kw/nois a great recommendation, because these pine cones were used for food.

u(/pnw malakw/tera cf. xv. 125; Vergil, Ecl. vii. 45 'somno mollior herba'; Herond. vi. 69:
ta\ balli/' ou(/tws a)/ndres ou)xi\ poieu=si;
au)tai\ ga\r e)sme/n, o)rqa/, kou) mo/non tou=to
a)ll' h( malako/ths u(/pnos, oi( d' i(manti/skoi
e)/ri' ou)x i(ma/ntes.

tw=n…a)rnw=n brachylogical comparison; = tw=n para\ soi derma/twn tw=n a)rnw=n, cf. ii. 15. The dialogue here shows strict correspondence between speaker and speaker even though this is before the match begins; cf. Id. viii. ad init.
au)to/qe, 'from where you stand.' Comatas seems at last to have succeeded in making Lacon lose his temper, as a first preliminary to making him lose the match.
ta\n sautw= sc. xw/ran. Soph. Phil. 1060 xai=re th\n *lh=mnon patw=n. Cf. xviii. 20. e)/xe ta\s dru/as, 'and keep your blooming oaks.'
ta\s para\ ti/n, 'over yonder near you.'
kri/nh|s sc. a)rei/w boukoliasta\n ei)=nai.

e)n xa/riti, 'as a favour'; cf. Plato, Phaedo 115 b ti/ de\ e)piste/lleis h)\ peri\ tw=n pai/dwn h)\ peri\ a)/llou tou, o(/ti a)/n soi poiou=ntes h(mei=s e)n xa/riti ma/lista poioi=men; Isocr. xviii. c ta\s kri/seis poi/ou mh\ pro\s xa/rin mhd' e)nanti/as a)llh/lais: Pseudo-Phocyl. ix. pa=si di/kaia ne/mein mhde\ kri/sin e)s xa/rin e(/lke.
to\ ple/on i)qu/nh|s vid. Liddell and Scott under i)qu/nw: but the phrase is an intentional oxymoron, since i)qu/nein can only be used strictly of a right judgement (opp. to skolia\ di/kh).

72, 73 *qouri/w, 'the Thurian.' Thurii was founded in 443 b. c., near the site of the once flourishing town, Sybaris, which had been destroyed in 510 B.C. If reliance is to be placed on this passage we must conclude either that the name Sybaris remained and that a new township had sprung up (so Meineke), or that such families as traced their descent from the ancient Sybarites retained this appellation to distinguish themselves from the newcomers.

be/ntiste (be/ltiste). This seems to be the only place where ou(=tos is attached to a vocative case. The nominative in apposition is usual; Soph. O. C. 1627 w)= ou(=tos ou(=tos *oi)di/pous or ou(=tos alone; Arist. Clouds 723 ou(=tos, ti/ poiei=s;
ei)/ ti le/geis Verg. Ecl. iii. 52 'quin age si quid habes'; Plautus, Stich. v. 4. 35; Herond. vii. 47 fe/r' ei) fe/reis ti.

h)=sqa cf. xxx. 16. The imperfect is used to express what was always true but is only now recognized. Usually with a)/ra. Plato, Gorgias 478 c ou) tou=t' h)=n eu)daimoni/a, kakou= a)pallagh\ a)lla\ th\n a)rxh\n mhde\ kth=sis.

The match begins. Comatas, as challenger, opens with a couplet, to which Lacon has to respond in two lines similar in thought and expression, but better if possible than his rival's. This goes on to l. 137, where Lacon apparently is unable to cap Comatas' couplet and is ruled out.
kai\ ga/r. 'Aye, the Muses may love you, for a greater than the Muses loves me.'
*ka/rnea the great Dorian festival of Apollo.
kai\ dh/ temporal here. 'Here's the Feast just coming on.' For position of the words--not at head of clause--cf. Arist. Wasps 1483; Frogs 604 w(s a)kou/w th=s qu/ras kai\ dh\ yo/fon.
parela=nta accus. masc. particip. parela/w = parelau/nw. -a/onta contracts to -a=nta as in i. 90 gela=nti = gela/onti = gela/ousi.
lei=os Cratidas meeting me in his fair beauty. lei=os belongs of course to the predicate.
