e)kmai/nei A. Pal. vii. 99 e)kmai/nei xei/lh me r(odo/xroa.

lipara\ de/, k.t.l. Eurip. Bacchae 456:
plo/kamo/s te ga/r sou tanao/s, ou) pa/lhs u(/po,
ge/nun par' au)th\n kexume/nos, poqou ple/ws.
92, 93 'Dog-rose and anemone are not to be compared with roses; the rose-bed grows beside the garden wall.'

pefu/kei (pefu/kw) a)/ndhra: cf. Odyss. vii. 127 prasiai\ pefu/asi: ib. v. 72; Achill. Tat. i. 1. 5 ai( de\ prasiai\ tw=n a)nqe/wn u(po\ ta\ pe/tala tw=n futw=n stoixhdo\n e)pefu/kesan na/rkissos kai\ r(o/da kai\ murri/nai.

o(momali/des. Comatas had said 'dog-roses are not to be compared with roses, because dog-roses are inferior.' Lacon alters the order of comparison awkwardly and says, 'medlars are not to be compared with acorns, because medlars are superior.'
ai( me/n sc. a)/kuloi.

Join a)po\ pri/noio lepu/rion, as e)k kriqw=n me/qu. Aesch. Suppl. 931, etc. The comparison in both cases refers of course to Clearista and Cratidas, in the first couplet to appearance (cf. Nonnus, viii. 210 kai\ r(o/da ti/s meta/meiyen e)s w)kumo/rous a)nemw/nas;) in the second to disposition.

e)s xlai=nan, 'for a cloak'; cf. i. 40; Arist. Clouds 612:
w)felou=s' u(ma=s a(/pantas…
prw=ta me\n tou= mhno\s e)s da=|d' ou)k e)/latton h)\ draxmh/n.
si/tt' a)po/ cf. iv. 45.
The verse is repeated from i. 13, but there is absolutely no ground for rejecting it as spurious in either place.
pot' a)ntola/s, 'to the eastward' (a)ntola^s, acc. plural); Thucyd. vi. 2. 5 ta\ pro\s borra=n th=s nh/sou. Tr. w(s, 'where,' as in 101.

*pracite/leus 'Si Praxitelis nomen et fama ad pastores illos pervenerat, poterat ille bonorum suorum iactator craterem quem habebat pro illustrissimi illius sculptoris opere habere. Cf. i. 32. Minime igitur cogitandum de iuniore aliquo Praxitele neque credendum nobilissimi illius artificis cuius statuae maximi aestimabantur opus aliquod penes hos pastores fuisse.'--Wuestemann. (The existence of a 'iunior aliquis Praxiteles' is stated circumstantially by the Scholiast.) Praxiteles' fame was vigorous throughout Greece in Theocritus' day, and his sons also were noted as sculptors; Herond. iv. 23.

mh\ lwbasei=sqe, 'You shall not spoil.' Soph. Antig. 84 a)ll' ou)=n promhnu/sh|s ge tou=to mhdeni/: Eurip. Medea 822 le/ceis
de\ mhde\n tw=n e)moi\ dedogme/nwn: Aesch. S. c. T. 250 ou) si=ga mhde\n tw=nd' e)rei=s kata\ pto/lin. In the last case to print ou) si=ga tw=nde, makes si=ga very awkward and only defers the explanation. In the first two the aorist subj. is often read against the MSS. Others keep the indicative and make the sentences questions, weakening the command unnaturally. In favour of taking all as emphatic negative proclamations (mh/ repudiantis) we have the similar ou) mh/ construction, and most of all an example in Xen. Hell. ii. 1. 22 proei=pen w(s mhdei\s kinh/soito. This can only represent mhdei\s kinh/setai, or mh\ kinh/sesqe, in direct speech: and cannot represent an interrogative clause (mhdei\s kinh/setai;).

a(=bai the abstract noun is used attributively, as dro/soi, Aesch. Agam. 141, for 'lion-cubs'; e(/rsai--'young lambs'--Odyss. ix. 222; cf. Theocr. x. 37. So Odyss. v. 69 h(meri\s h(bw/wsa. The reading of k, au)=ai, makes no sense, and is a mere misreading. b in minuscule is written w.
me/mna| o(/ka, 'remember the time when'; cf. Eurip. Hec. 239 oi)=sq' h(ni/k' h)=lqes )*ili/ou kata/skopos; Iliad xiv. 71, etc.
e)ka/qhre a slang term; 'dusted you down.'
ti/llein infin. for imperative; cf. x. 48.
grai/as gen. sing. 'from an old wife's tomb.'

ski/llas, 'squills'; a remedy for melancholy madness. Herbs plucked from a tomb have double efficacy; especially if the tomb be that of a person who has died unnaturally. Similarly in Brit. Mus. Papyrus (see on Idyll ii) a lead tablet is to be suitably inscribed and buried, ei)s a)w/rou mnh=ma.

tina/ as above, referring to a definite person; cf. Arist. Frogs 606 h(/kei tw| kako/n, 'there's trouble for some one.' Note how the following line corresponds in Chiasmus with 121.
ski/llas…kukla/minon: ti/llein…o)/russe:
i)w
…e)nqw/n: a)po\ sa/matos…e)s to
 )/*alenta.
Join e)nqw
 e)s to
 )/*alenta. The Aleis here is a river of the Sybaris district; contrast vii. 1, note.
(*ime/ra another unknown stream.

ga/la is cognate accusative; cf. v. 126; Lucian, V. Hist. i. 7 potamw=| oi)=non r(e/onti: Theocr. xxv. 15. The dative is less commonly used, Ap. Rhod. iii. 223 h( me\n (krh/nh) a)nablu/zeske ga/lakti: Eurip. Bacchae 142:
r(ei= de\ ga/lakti pe/don, r(ei= d' oi)/nw|, r(ei= de\ melissa=n ne/ktari.
a( *subari=tis sc. phgh/.
to\ po/torqron, 'at dawn.'
ba/yai, 'draw honey in place of water.' On this sense of ba/ptw see Dr. Rutherford on Babrius, lxxi, and cf. Nicand. Alex. 514 th\n a(/la ba/pte.
pollo\s de/, 'and dog-roses flourish here like any rose.' (The Vulg. r(odokisso/s is apparently a vox nihili.)

e)panqei= affords a good example of the fondness of the Alexandrian poets for compound verbs instead of simple; Theocritus has, e. g. ei)sai+/w, katasmu/xw, a)gkle/ptw, e)ndiaqru/ptomai (Legrand). Attic would use a)nqei= or have a dative with e)panqei=.
tw=n w)/twn Tibullus, ii. 5. 92 'oscula comprensis auribus eripiet.'
pau/sasqai. Lacon apparently hesitates over his capping verse; is beginning tardily, but is at once stopped by the umpire and declared beaten.
o(/tti po/k' h)/dh, 'since now at last I have won the lamb' (cf. l. 24).
u)/mmin, 'you shall see me leap sky high.'

kerou/tides a word recovered by Ahrens; it is feminine of kerouth/s, a noun formed from the verb keroutia/w (keroutia=| = gauria=|, Hesych.), 'wanton.' So in 147 korupti/los = koru/pths as nauti/los = nau/ths (Ahrens in Philolog. vii. p. 446).

pri\n h)/ g' e)me/ the emphatic form of the pronoun is required, not me which has been 'restored' by recent editors. The clause belongs as the use of the accus. and infin. shows to ei)/ tin' o)xeusei=s not to flassw= tu.

div1.p: On the Aratus of this poem see Introd. pp. 16, 17 sqq. The date of the piece must be placed in the Coan period of Theocritus' life (Introd. p. 24). The poem is a companion to Idyll xi (see Preface there), but shows the Cyclops in a more delicate and refined character.

In form the poem is a singing-match between Daphnis and Damoetas, though rather irregular in form since the songs do not correspond in length, and there is no adjudication of prize. It is probable that the legendary Daphnis is here intended as he appears in Idyll viii, and not contemporary shepherds of Theocritus' own day; cf. xi (Preface).

div2.p: xw( *da/fnis o( bouko/los. This order of words with article is common in Theocritus; cf. iv. 20 xw( tau=ros o( pu/rrixos: v. 62: vii. 98: ii. 74, etc. (see Ameis' note); and vid. xv. 58.

ta\n a)ge/lan the singular is used distributively, 'each his flock'; cf. xxii. 191; Iliad x. 153:
e)/gxea de/ sfin
o)/rq' e)pi\ saurwth=ros e)lh/lato.
Ap. Rhod. i. 528:
oi( d' a)na\ se/lmata ba/ntes e)pisxerw\ a)llh/loisi,
w(s e)da/santo pa/roiqen e)resse/men ?? e)ni\ xw/rw|
(each in his place); cf. Verg. Ecl. vii. 2.

purro/s cf. Eurip. Phoeniss. 32 h)/dh de\ pursai=s ge/nusin e)candrou/menos: Longus, i. 15 a)rtige/neios meiraki/skos, leuko\s w(s ga/la kai\ purro\s w(s qe/ros me/llon a)ma=sqai. purro/s, 'prima lanugine pubescens,' Paley.
qe/reos, 'in summer'; gen. of time.

pra=tos for pro/teros: cf. a)/llos for e(/teros, vi. 46; vii. 36, etc. Daphnis addresses Polyphemus in his song, calling him to mark how Galatea tempts him, pelting his flock or his dog with apples, mocking him, and coquetting with him. Damoetas answers, in the person of Polyphemus, that he has noted Galatea's wiles, but turns a deaf ear and affects not to care, for he will move her by jealousy.

ma/loisin cf. ii. 120; Verg. Ecl. iii. 64; A. Pal. v. 79
(Plato) mh=lon e)gw/: ba/llei me filw=n se/ tis, and a modern Greek folk-song (Legrand, Chansons popul. 15):
ei)=xa mi/an h(me/ra sko/lh
kai\ e)mph=ka 'sto\ perbo/li (into the garden)
k' hu(=ra mia\ glukou=ssa ko/rh:
k' ei)=pa th=s: na\ zh/sh|s ko/rh:
poi=se me k' e)me/na filon
h)/ me mh=lo h)/ m' a)pi/di
h)/ me ta\ gluka/ sou xei/lh.
(Make me your lover with an apple or a pear, or with your sweet lips.)
duse/rwta vid. i. 85.

to\n ai)po/lon a)/ndra predicative; 'calling him a laggard in love, the goatherd.' For the article cf. xxii. 69, note. ai/po/lon is used contemptuously as in i. 86. The conjecture (Jacobs and Meineke kai\ ai)po/lon) should be rejected. Paley's order kaleu=sa to\n ai)po/lon duse/rwta a)/ndra does not commend itself.
poqo/rhsqa vid. Dial. § 3.

nin sc. ta\n ku/na, not Galatea; 'the fair waves lightly plashing show the dog's reflection as she runs on the sand.' The edge of the sand where the dog runs is just covered with the water. Most editors read kaxla/zontos from the Juntine, but this is only 'emendation' to avoid hiatus, and has no MS. support. For hiatus cf. vii. 8 and Index.
kaxla/zonta ai)gialoi=o is in itself unobjectionable, cf. Pind. Ol. vii. 1 fia/lan a)mpe/lou e)/ndon kaxla/zontos dro/sw|: Propert. iv. 18. 4 'et sonat Herculeo structa labore via.'
fra/zeo mh/ cf. iii. 5.
au)to/qe cf. v. 60; iii. 8, note.
diaqru/ptetai, 'coquets.'

w(s a)p' a)ka/nqas, k.t.l. 'like the dry thistle-down in hot summer's days.' Galatea is as fickle and restless as the thistledown is tossed this way and that never settling; cf. Odyss. v. 328:
w(s d' o(/t' o)pwrino\s *bore/hs fore/h|sin a)ka/nqas
a)\m pedi/on, pukinai\ de\ pro\s a)llh/lh|sin e)/xontai,
w(\s th\n a)\m pe/lagos a)/nemoi fe/ron e)/nqa kai\ e)/nqa.

kai\ feu/gei, k.t.l. : cf. Terence, Eun. iv. 7. 43:
'Novi ingenium mulierum;
nolunt ubi velis,
Ubi nolis cupiunt ultro' (Hiller).
The sentence should probably be taken universally, connecting it with diaqru/ptetai: she plays the coquette; shuns when one loves, and follows when one loves not. For the form of the line cf. xiv. 62; Nonnus, xvi. 297 ktei/neis ga\r poqe/onta kai\ ou) game/onta diw/keis: Nicet. Eugen. iii. 11 misei=s ste/rgonta kai\ ou) poqe/onta poqei=s me.

to\n a)po\ gramma=s li/qon, 'and moves out the piece on the centre line.' The metaphor is taken from the game of pessoi/. This was a kind of draughts played on a board divided into thirty-six squares (6 × 6). The central subdividing line was called i(era\ grammh/, and the piece (basileu/s) placed thereon was
only moved as a last resource. With gramma=s here sc. i(era=s. a)po/, cf. oi( e)k tou= pedi/ou e)/qeon, Xen. Anab. iv. 6. 25, etc.

ka^la\ ka_la/ cf. viii. 19 i^son i)=son: A. Pal. vii. 726 h( kala\ kai\ kalw=s *platqi\s u(fhname/nh: Iliad v. 31 =)*ares )/*ares: Martial, ix. 12:
'Sed Graeci quibus est nihil negatum
Et quos =)*ares )/*ares decet sonare.'

to
 e)mo
 e(/na to
 gluku/n for the use of the article see iv. 33, note. The ellipse of o)fqalmo/n is strange, but is softened by the following words. In Herond. vi. 33 ma\ tou/tous tou\s gluke/as, and Id. v. 59 ma\ tou/tous tou\s du/o, which can now be quoted in support of this line, a gesture would complete the meaning. e)mo/n, cf. viii. 65; i. 115. I have transposed to
 (vid. not. crit.) for two reasons. (1) to
 e)mo/n is not in itself sufficient to balance to
 e(/na gluku/n as co-ordinate attribute. (2) Eustathius refers to the phrase (Opusc. 346. 20) ei)/poi a)
 o( *qeo/kritos to
 e(/na to
 gluku
 tou=ton.
*th/lemos see Odyss. ix. 507 sqq. Telemus had prophesied the coming of Odysseus and the blinding of Cyclops.
fula/ssoi a final clause depending on an optative of wish takes the optative, Aesch. Eumenid. 297 e)/lqoi o(/pws ge/noito tw=nd' e)moi\ luth/rios: Soph. Ajax 1222, etc.

poqo/rhmi. The compound verb is justified by v. 8, 'with which I look at her (if I please).' The present is used with self-assurance for the future, mikra\ ei)pw\n h)/dh katabai/nw, Aesch. ii. 183. The middle of the -mi form is found Odyss. xiv. 343 (2nd person), cf. di/zhmai (see Hiller's note). [Monro, Hom. Gram. § 378 writes: 'The form o(/rhai for o(ra/-eai should possibly be o(ra=ai: if the ending is in its original form it belongs to the non-Thematic conjugation.' If o(/rhai is wrong, o(/rhmai must give place to o(/rhmi here. The same question arises in v. 25].
w)= *paia/n, 'Polyphemus gloats.'
ta/ketai cf. v. 12.

The sense of the line is obviously that Polyphemus set his dog on to bark at Galatea, but there is considerable doubt as to the reading. The imperative u(la/ktei is mentioned as a variant in Schol. k. If this is right we might read si/tta for si=ga (so Britzsche): or keeping si=ga and u(laktei=n explain the infinitive by a gesture or nod (sigh=| neusta/zontes o(/ti xre/os a)llh/loisi, Oppian, Hal. v. 155). Ruhnken's conjecture given in the text seems however the best solution; the aorist as in 21 ei)=don.
h)/rwn keeping up the pretence that he no longer cares for her.

pra=n, 'the other day'; cf. iv. 60; xv. 15; Verg. Ecl. ii. 25; Ovid, Met. xiii. 840:
'Certe ego me novi; liquidaeque in imagine vidi
Nuper aquae placuitque mihi mea forma videnti.'
h)=s de\ gala/na. Parataxis: instead of o(/te h)=n galh/nh.
par' e)mi/n para/ with dative of the person judging; cf. para\ toi=s eu)= fronou=si krei=tto/n e)sti h)\ para\ toi=s a)/llois a(/pasin eu)dokimei=n, Isocr. ix. 74.
u(pe/faine, 'reflected,' sc. po/ntos.

*pari/as li/qoio, 'Parian marble,' Pind. N. iv. 132 sta/lan *pari/ou li/qou leukote/ran. With the whole passage cf. Lucian, i. 290 e)pei\ ta/ ge a)/lla o(po/tan e)qe/lh|s maqei=n oi(/a tugxa/neis ou)=sa th
 o)/yin, a)po\ pe/tras tino/s, ei)/ pote galh/nh ei)/h, e)piku/yasa e)s to\ u(/dwr i)de\ seauth
 ou)de\ a)/llo h)\ xro/an leukh
 a)kribw=s.
e)/ptusa cf. xx. 11; Tibullus, i. 2. 96 'despuit in molles et sibi quisque sinus.'
ni/kh = e)ni/ka, 'neither was victor'; so nikw= is used in perfect sense, 'I am victorious.'

ou)da/llos for ou)de/teros: this use is constant in Alexandrian writers; Ap. Rhod. i. 10 a)/llo…a)/llo, of two; cf. Theocr. xxiv. 61; conversely e(/teros for a)/llos, xxv. 174; so e(/kastos for e(ka/teros, A. Pal. ix. 13. a)nh/ssatoi, 'invincible.'

div1.p: See Introd. p. 12 sqq. for a general discussion of the circumstances and character of this famous poem; ib. 13, 14 for the identification of the persons mentioned. The scene of the poem is definitely fixed as Coan by the researches of Messrs. Hicks and Paton (Inscriptions of Cos). The subjoined map shows the district.

The dotted lines show the divisions of the Demes. A. *kw/|wn: B. *fuciwtw=n, with chief town *fu/ca or *pu/ca (vii. 130): C. *dh=mos (*alenti/nwn, with chief towns Pyli (*pe/lh) and Alike ((/*aleis); so Hicks and Paton, Inscr. 344 toi\ katoikeu=ntes e)n tw=| da/mw| tw=n (*alenti/nwn kai\ toi\ e)nekthme/noi kai\ toi\ gewrgou=ntes e)n (/*alenti kai\ *pe/lh|.

The fountain *bou/rina (viii. 6) still bears the name Vourina, and is shown south-west of the town of Cos. *po/lis of line 2 is the town of Cos. (/*aleis may be either the deme, or the river which runs down to the sea at Alike. Hicks and Paton take it as the former, but the context suits a large district less well than a more definite spot.

div2.p: *eu)/kritos. This name and those of Phrasydamus and Antigenes are doubtless real, and not pseudonyms.
ei(/rpomes, 'walked.'
su)n kai\ tri/tos cf. Ap. Rhod. i. 74 su\n kai\ tri/tos h)=en )*oileu/s.
ta=| *dhoi= in honour of Ceres.

qalu(sia, 'a harvest home.' Iliad ix. 534:
)/*artemis w)=rse
xwsame/nh o(/ oi( ou)/ti qalu/sia gounw=| a)lwh=s
*oi)neu\s r(e/ce.

ei)/ ti/ per cf. ii. 34; Xen. Hellen. v. 3. 6 o(/ti per o)/felos h)=n tou= strateu/matos. *per is usually added in this idiom but can be omitted; cf. Epig. xvii. 4; A. Pal. vii. 472 (Leonidas):
ti/s moi=ra zwh=s u(polei/petai, h)\ o(/son o(/sson
stigmh\ kai\ stigmh=s ei)/ ti xamhlo/teron;
Arist. Frogs 70:
po/teron ei)s *ai(/dou ka/tw;
kai\ nh\ *di/' ei)/ ti/ g' e)/stin e)/ti katwte/rw.
The construction is e)sqloi\ ei)/ ti/ per e)sqlo\n tw=n xa|w=n e)sti/n: cf. Epig. xvii. For the neuter cf. Callim. i. 70 ei(/leo d' ai)zh/wn o(/ti fe/rtaton: Xenoph. Hiero i. 26.
xa|w=n tw=n e)pa/nwqen, 'of the good fellows of old time.' xao\n (leg. xa|o\n) to\ eu)gene\s kai\ a)rxai=on, Schol. k. The word is elsewhere only known in the longer form xai+/os, Ar. Lys. 91.

e)pa/nwqen cp. Epig. xxii. 3 pra=tos tw=n e)pa/nwqe mousopoiw=n. Commoner a)/nwqen, Theocr. xv. 91; xxii. 164; Plato, Timaeus 18 d tou\s e)/mprosqen kai\ a)/nwqen. Chalcon was son of Eurypylus, a legendary king of Cos, and Clytia his wife, daughter of Merops.
o(\s e)k podo\s a)/nuse, 'who made the fount Burina (Vourina) with his foot pressing his knee upon the rock.'

e)k cf. ii. 10; Pind. P. iv. 359 ei)resi/a d' u(pexw/rhsen taxei=an e)k palama=n a)/koros ('by the might of'): i. e. he created the fountain by the pressure of his foot, while he drove his knee against the upright wall of rock. A statue of Chalcon was erected over the fountain; i(/statai e)n *kw=| a)ndria\s kai\ e)k tou= podo\s au)tou= e)kre/ei phgh/, Schol. The fountain is mentioned also by Philetas, e)n proxoh=|si melampe/troio *buri/nhs.
tai\ de/ deictic, 'and there hard by.'

u(/fainon cf. Milton, P. L. iv. 692 of Eve's bower:
'The roof
Of thickest covert was inwoven shade
Laurel and myrtle, and what higher grew
Of firm and fragrant leaf ...'

*brasi/la. This place is not identified, nor is it known who this Brasilas was. 'K. Tümpel (Rhein. Mus. 46) suggests that it is another name for Poseidon; and that the sa=ma--monument--was the same as that described by Pausanias, as standing near the Peiraeus Gate, near a temple of Demeter. This monument represented Poseidon vanquishing the Coan Polybotes, and was assigned not to Poseidon but to another; ? to Brasilas' (Kynaston). Poseidon was certainly connected with Cos in mythology, but the derivation proposed by Tümpel, bra/ssw-la=as = e)nosi/-xqwn, is monstrous. Stone-thrower is not a fair substitute for earth-shaker.
to\n o(di/tan vid. Introd. p. 20.
su)n *moi/saisi construe with eu(/romes cf. ii. 28, note. 'By the grace of the Muses we found our traveller, a noble fellow of Crete.'
*kudwniko/n of Cydonia in Crete (vid. Odyss. xix. 176).
*luki/dan Introd. p. 18.
ai)po/lw|…e)w/|kei Introd. p. 13, where I have explained my view that this means, 'was dressed up as a goatherd.'
15, 16 'For he had on his shoulders a yellow skin from a shaggy thick-haired goat.'
knako/n vid. iii. 5.
e)k is superfluous, as in ix. 10.

lasi/oio dasu/trixos two epithets without conjunction, and practically synonymous; vid. Lobeck on Ajax 708: Odyss. vii. 34 nhusi\ qoh=|si, w)kei/h|si: h. Apoll. 107 podh/nemos w)ke/a: h. Hermes, 171 plou/sion a)fneio\n polulh/ion.
w)/moisi is locative dative, cf. ii. 121.

With the whole cf. the description of Paris in Coluthus, 107:
kai/ tis o)ressau/loio dorh\ meto/pisqe ximai/rhs
e)kkreme\s h)|w/rhto kai\ au)tw=n h(/pteto mhrw=n:
poimeni/h d' u(pe/keito bow=n e)la/teira kalau=roy.
ge/rwn cf. xxi. 12, note.

plakerw=| platei=: plako
 ga to\ plaku/: gra/fetai de\ kai\ plokerw=| para\ th
 plokh
 kai\ th
 u(fh/n, Schol.
18, 19 r(oika\n…koru(nan cf. iv. 49 lagwbo/lon.
m' moi elided, cf. iv. 58.
sesarw/s (sai/rw) : the word loses its classical sense of 'grinning' in later authors, and is used of the lips half opened in a smile. Lucian, Amores, § 13 seshro/ti ge/lwti mikro\n u(pomeidiw=sa.
ei)/xeto, 'a smile played about his lip.'
*simixi/da vid. Introd. pp. 8 and 16.
to\ mesame/rion in the noontide; cf. i. 15.

po/das e(/lkeis either (1) 'toil along,' or (2) simply 'walk.' The latter is supported by Herond. vii. 125:
h)\n e)/xhte xh/terwn xrei/hn
h)\ sambaliskwn h)\ a(\ kat' oi)ki/hn e(/lkein
ei)/qisqe.
The former by Eurip. Medea 1181:
h)/dh d' a)\n e(/lkwn kw=lon e(kple/qrou dro/mou
taxu\s badisth\s termo/nwn a)nqh/pteto.

e)n ai(masiai=si (e)n, k; e)f', vulg.): cf. Herod. ii. 69 oi( kroko/deiloi (lizards) oi( e)n th=|si ai(masih=|si. The ai(masia/ was a rough wall of stones built without mortar and affording plenty of holes for lizards to lie in. For the picture of noonday quiet cf. l. 15 sqq, and Tennyson's Oenone:
'For now the noonday quiet holds the hill:
The grasshopper is silent in the grass:
The lizard, with his shadow on the stone,
Rests like a shadow, and the winds are dead.'
(Callim. vii. 72 mesambrina\ d' ei)=x' e)/ros a(suxi/a.)

meta\ dai=ta. Cobet would alter to kata\ dai=ta, but meta/ in such phrases as this means, 'to go to join.' Cf. Iliad xix. 346 oi( de\ dh\ a)/lloi oi)/xontai meta\ dei=pnon: Theocr. xxv. 87: Ap. Rhod. ii. 460:
sto/lon a)ndrw=n
(*ella/dos e)canio/nta meta\ pto/lin *ai)h/tao.
It is only when used with a noun denoting a moveable thing that it means 'to fetch'; cf. xiii. 16; xxix. 38; Iliad xiii. 248; Arist. Acharn. 728.

toi…nissome/noio. toi = soi, and the construction passes from the dative (of person concerning) to gen. abs.; cf. Iliad xvi. 531 o(/tti oi( w)=k' h)/kouse…eu)came/noio: Ap. Rhod. iii. 371 e)k de/ oi( o)/mmat' e)/lamyen u(p' o)fru/sin i(eme/noio: Theocr. xxv. 67.
a)ei/dei, 'rings.'
a)mei/fqhn first in Pindar, P. iv. 180; see New Phrynichus, p. 187; Babrius, xii. 19 (Rutherford, ad loc.).

qalusia/s, 'this journey leads to a harvest-home.' The adj. is used freely for pro\s ta\ qalu/sia. Cf. *karnei/ades w(=rai, Callim. Apoll. 87; oi)/xet' a)paulo/sunos a)po\ th=s au)lh=s, Leonidas, A. Pal. vi. 221.
eu)/kriqon predicatively. 'Filled up with wealth of grain.'
cuna\ ga/r, 'the way is ours together, ours together the day.'

a)w/s bears this sense frequently in Alex. writers; cf. Bion, iii. (Hermann) 18 xa( nu\c a)nqrw/poisin i)/sa kai\ o(moi/i+os a)w/s. For the style of the line, see Introd. p. 41, and Ap. Rhod. iii. 173 cunh\ ga\r xreiw/, cunoi\ de/ te mu=qoi e)/asi.
a)/llon cf. vi. 47, note.
kapuro/n orig. 'dry'; then of sound, 'clear ringing.' Cf. the Latin 'argutus.' Lucian, i. 271 mousiko/s ei)mi kai\ suri/zw pa/nu kapuro/n: Longus, ii. 5. 1 panu\ kapuro\n gela/sas.
sto/ma cf. Epit. Bion. (/*omhros th=no to\ *kallio/pas glukero\n sto/ma.
ou) taxupeiqh/s cf. ii. 138.

*sikeli/dan vid. Introd. p. 15. There is no indication of the origin of this name for Asclepiades. Hiller's notion that we have to deal with an anagram, 'since the consonants of the name Sicelidas are all found and in the same order in Asclepiades,' is most unlikely. On Philetas, see Introd. pp. 10 and 20.
ba/traxos, 'I am matched like a frog against cicadae.'

e)pi)tades, 'to suit my purpose'; Lucian, i. 255 fhsi\ d' ou)=n o(/ti a)/llws e)pelqo\n ou)k e)cepi/thdes h)/reto ('she asked with no particular object but just at random'): Lysias, i. 11 to\ paidi/on u(po\ th=s qerapai/nhs e)pi/thdes lupou/menon i(/na tau=ta poih=|.
peplasme/non, k.t.l. 'thou art an olive branch moulded in truth by Zeus.'
e)/rnos after the Homeric o( d' a)ne/dramen e)/rnei+ i)=sos (Iliad xviii. 56).
e)k of agent, cf. vii. 112, etc.

e)p' a)laqei/a| not I think 'for truth'--e)pi/ expressing the object aimed at, but keeping the metaphor of peplasme/non, 'made on the mould of truth.' Cf. Pindar, P. i. 167 a)yeudei= de\ pro\s a)/kmoni xa/lkeue glw=ssan.
'Who strives to raise a house as high as the crest of a lordly mountain.'

eu)rume/dontos a fine epithet for a hill whose domain is as wide as the prospect from its summit. So Pindar, N. ii. 29 u(yime/donti *parnasw=|. Empedocles has the same epithet of ai)qh/r. [The v. l. )*wrome/dontos, though better supported by MSS., is certainly inferior in itself.]

e)tw/sia moxqi/zonti cf. i. 38; Pindar, Ol. ii. 156:
la/broi
pagglwssi/a|, ko/rakes w(/s, a)/kranta garue/men
*dio\s pro\s o)/rnixa qei=on:
vid. Introd. p. 20. As this idyll belongs to the first Coan period there can be no reference as so often supposed to Apollonius. The same sentiment is expressed by Callim. ii. 105:
(*o fqo/nos )*apo/llwnos e)s ou)/ata la/qrios ei)=pen
ou)k a)/gamai to\n a)oido\n o(\s ou)d' o(/sa po/ntos a)ei/dei, k.t.l.
kh)gw\ me/n. The sentence is not finished, but passes naturally into a new construction and turn of expression.
e)cepo/nasa the song, therefore, is not an impromptu, but one already elaborated like the Daphnis-elegy of Id. i. See Introd. p. 21.
xw(/tan, 'when the Kids are in the western sky and the south wind chases the waves, and Orion stands upon the seas.'

e)f' e(speri/ois e)ri/fois. e)pi/ is used here of simultaneous time, or circumstances; cf. Ap. Rhod. i. 329:
i)llome/nois e)pi\ lai/fesin, h)de\ kai\ i(stw=|
keklime/nw|, ma/la pa/ntes e)pisxerw\ e(drio/wnto
(while the sails were furling)--an equivalent of gen. absol.; cf. Id. i. 514 o)rqoi=sin e)p' ou)/asin h)reme/ontes khlhqmw=| ('arrectis auribus'): Id. i. 1013 e)pi\ pnoih=|s a)ne/moio. In Attic e)pi/ so used signifies succession, 'after.' e)pi\ xio/ni pesou/sh|, Herodot. ii. 22; e)p' a)sfa/ktois mh/lois, Eur. Ion 228. The Kids--a cluster of stars in Auriga--are low down in the north-west sky (altit. 30°) one hour before sunrise on Nov. 28. Orion is at the same time just touching the horizon, so that he may be said to stand on the
sea. Theocritus here speaks of the 'cosmical' setting. Cf. Aratus, 308 th=mos (at end of November) du/etai h)w=qi pro\ a)qro/os )*wri/wn.
e(speri/ois Aratus, 1065 kai\ e(speri(wn propa/roiqen *plhi+a/dwn i. e. early autumn). Cf. further, Theocr. xxiv. 10; Hesiod, )/*erg. 619.
i)/sxh| (i)/sxh k) is required here as we have two coordinate time clauses, xw(/tan…xw(ri/wn o(/te. Most editors read i)/sxei, vid. xvi. 95, note.

a(lkuo/nes. The belief was current that while the halcyon was sitting calm weather prevailed. Simonides 12:
w(s o(po/tan xeime/rion kata\ mh=na pinu/skh|
*zeu\s a)/mata te/ssara kai\ de/ka
laqa/nemo/n te/ min w(/ran kale/oisin e)pixqo)nioi
i(ra\n paidotro/fon poiki/las a(lkuo/nos.

e)/sxata, 'from the bottom of the sea.' Fritzsche, quoting A. Pal. xiii. 27 bi/h| no/tou prh/santos e)sxa/thn a(/la, which does not prove this meaning for e)/sxatos: cf. xvi. 51, note. Others translate 'from the furthest shore.'

e)fi/lhqen. For aorist cf. xv. 100; Arist. Frogs 229:
e)me\ ga\r e)/stercan eu)/luroi/ te *mou=sai
kai\ keroba/tas *pa/n.
w(/ria, 'seasonable.'
eu)/ploon = ei)s o(\n eu)= pleu/seien a)/n tis: Aesch. Agam. 665 w(s mh/t' e)n o(/rmw| ku/matos za/lhn e)/xein: Quint. Smyrn. xiv. 623 e)lpome/nous eu)/ormon e(/dos lime/nwn a)fike/sqai.
fula/sswn, 'wearing.'

to\n *pteleatiko\n oi)=non, 'our wine of Ptelea.' There were numerous places of this name, one being in Cos according to the Scholiast. Lycidas means doubtless some local vintage. The regular Coan wine was noted for its medicinal properties chiefly. The idea that *pteleatiko/n is to be derived from ptele/a, 'an elm-tree' (wine from vines trained on elms or wine flavoured with elm) is barred by the form of the word. We should have then ptelei+th\s oi)=nos: cf. stafuli/ths, r(odi/ths, kedri/ths, r(oi/ths, etc.; and among the many plants used to flavour wine among the Greeks elm is--happily--not mentioned.
For form of line cf. iv. 25--three nouns joined by te, the last with epithet. So xiii. 45; Odyss. v. 64, 66; iii. 434, 451; ix. 24; xxi. 10, etc.
malakw=s, 'at my ease.'

memnhme/nos I will drink to the memory of Ageanax; cf. A. Pal. vii. 452 (Leonidas):
mnh/mhs *eu)bou/loio sao/fronos w)= pario/ntes
pi/nwmen.

au)tai=sin. This has been variously explained: (1) with e)rei/dwn, 'pressing my lips right into the cups' (Hartung); (2) 'exhauriens calicem ut solus relictus sit calix' (Fritzsche). This is impossible; the first is not good sense. Others emend gluptai=s e)n (Jacobs), au)ai=s e)n Graefe (so Hiller) proleptically,
'draining the cup.' If any alteration is required I should prefer au)/tws e)n kuli/kessi, 'idly,' but au)tai=sin may possibly be kept in the sense of 'merus,' 'unmixed'; cf. au)tokrhh/s and au)toke/rastos, Nicand. Alex. 162 de/pas e)/mpleon oi)/nhs *pramni/ou au)tokrhe/s.
71, 72 See Introd.
ei)=s me/n for o( me/n, o( de/, Callim. Ep. i. 3. h( mi/a me\n dh\ nu/mfh kai\ plou/tw| kai\ geneh=| kat' e)me\ h( d' e(te/rh probe/bhken.
*cene/as see note on i. 65.

o)/ros a)mf' e)ponei=to, 'how the hills round about sorrowed for him, and how the oaks mourned.' Inanimate nature weeps as the beasts do in i. 71 sqq. Cf. Bion, Epit. Adon. 31 ta\n *ku/prin ai)ai= w(/rea pa/nta le/gonti kai\ ai( dru/es ai)ai= )/*adwnin: Epit. Bion. 1:
ai)/lina/ moi stonaxei=te na/pai kai\ *dw/rion u(/dwr
kai\ potamoi\ klai/oite to\n i(mero/enta *bi/wna.
Milton, Lycidas:
'Thee, shepherd, thee the woods, and desert caves,
And all their echoes mourn.'
fu(onti cf. iv. 24, note.
For construction cf. v. 38, note, 'when he faded as fades a streak of snow under the ridge of Haemus.'

tis is unusual with xiw/n. For the simile cf. Odyss. xix. 205:
w(s de\ xiw\n katath/ket' e)n a)kropo/loisin o)/ressin,
h(/nt' *eu)=ros kate/thcen e)ph\n *ze/furos kataxeu/h|:
………
w(\s th=s th/keto kala\ parh/i+a da/kru xeou/shs.
Callim. vi. 91:
w(s de\ *mi/manti xiw\n w(s a)eli/w| e)/ni plaggw\n
kai\ tou/twn e)/ti ma=llon e)ta/keto.

la/rnac. The shepherd Comatas was shut in a chest by his master because he sacrificed cattle to the Muses. After a year the chest was opened and it was found that Comatas had been miraculously fed by bees and his life preserved. The fable was told by Lycus of Rhegium, and elder contemporary of Theocritus, father by adoption of the poet Lycophron.
80, 81 ai( simai\…me/lissai. For order cf. xvi. 34, 35.
a)/nqessi, 'honey'; cf. xv. 116; Verg. Geor. iv. 39, 250 'floribus' = pollen.

ne/ktar Hesiod, Theogn. 83:
tw=| me\n e)pi\ glw/ssh| glukerh\n xei/eusin e)e/rshn
tou= d' e)/pe' e)k sto/matos r(ei= mei/lixa.
pepo/nqeis pluperf. terpna\ pepo/nqeis; cf. Isocr. 199 d sune/bh ga\r au)tw=| dia\ th\n a)/ficin th\n ei)s *ku/pron pai\ poih=sai kai\ paqei=n plei=ot' a)gaqa/.
e)/tos w(/rion apparently = 'the year in all its seasons,' i. e. a whole year.
e)cepo/nasas, 'wert oppressed'; 'Comatas, licet de victu non laboraret, libertate tamen privatus et in cavea quasi inclusus erat' (Wuestemann).

ai)/q' e)p' e)meu=, 'wouldst thou had been numbered among the living in my day, that I might be tending thy goats on the hillside: listening to thy voice whilst thou lay 'neath the oaks or pines sweetly singing, Comatas half-divine.'
e)no/meuon cf. iv. 49, note.
kala/s Dial. § 1.
polla\ me\n a)/lla ii. 67, note.

*zhno/s. Many commentators take this as = *ptolemai/ou. On the view taken of the circumstances of this idyll this is impossible, since Theocritus had not yet sought the patronage of the Alexandrian court. Nor is it necessary to foist on the poet such a subordination of taste to odious flattery, but the words mean what they say, that the poet's song is heard of God himself; cf. Odyss. viii. 74 oi)/mhs th=s to/t' a)/ra kle/os ou)rano\n eu)ru\n i(/kanen: Arist. Birds 215:
kaqara\ xwrei= dia\ fulloko/mou
mi/lakos h)xw\ pro\s *dio\s e(/dras
(of the nightingale's song).

gerai/rein cf. Epit. Bion. 103:
a)/mme gerai/rwn
a)/llois me\n teo\n o)/lbon e)moi\ d' a)pe/leipes a)oida/n.
u(pa/kouson, 'give ear'; vid. Liddell and Scott, s. v. In Attic usage e)pakou/w is generally 'to listen to.' u(pakou/w to 'answer when called'; cf. iii. 24; xi. 78.

e)pe/ptaron. Sneezing has been at all times and in all countries regarded as a lucky omen; cf. xviii. 16; Odyss. xvii. 545; Catullus, xlv. 8:
'Hoc ut dixit Amor sinistra ut ante
Dextram sternuit approbationem.'
ei)/aros Dial. § 1 e)ra=|…e)ra=nti, Introd. p. 43. The point of the comparison lies in the gay carelessness of all nature in spring.

)/*aratos Introd. p. 16. The general idea of the song is 'I am happy and careless in my love: but my friend Aratus loves too, and Aristis knows about it. I know not whom he loves, perhaps Philinus, perhaps another. Whosoever it is may Aratus be lucky, and Pan help him, and be requited for his help.' So far ironically; then the pretended ignorance is laid aside. 'It is Philinus and he shall be made to care. Yet after all Aratus is but an over ripe pear and not worth our toil; we can find better things to do than wearing shoe leather and wearying ourselves; let another torture himself and let us have peace.' A different version is given by Wilamowitz-Moellendorf (Aratos von Kos, p. 187 sqq.). See notes on 118, 123.
a)ne/ri th/nw| = *simixi/da|.

)/*aristis…a)/ristos. The play on words (cf. xxvi. 26)
shows that the name )/*aristis is either genuine or but slightly changed. Among Coan names preserved in inscriptions we have )/*aristos, )*aristeu/s, )*aristi/wn, and a large number with )*aristo- for prefix (Hicks and Paton, Inscriptions of Cos, Appendix, )*aristo/boulos, etc.). No actual identification is possible.

su
 fo/rmiggi join with a)ei/dein. tou=ton de\ to
 )/*aristin ou)de\ o( )*apo/llwn e)n *puqw=ni para\ toi=s i)di/ois tri/posi kiqarw|dou=nta i)dw
 a)postrafh/setai ou)de\ fqonh/sei au)tw=| a)/|dein e)kei=, Schol.
(*omo/las a mountain in Thessaly, not otherwise known as a centre of Pan worship; cf. Eur. H. F. 371.
a)/klhton…e)rei/sais, 'lay him uncalled in my friend's arms.'

a)=ra for a)/ra cf. Plutarch, Lys. 20 ou)k a)=r' )*odusseu/s e)stin ai(mu/los mo/nos, A. Pal. vi. 147. More often with interrogative words, Herond. iv. 21:
ti/s h)=ra th\n li/qon tau/thn
te/ktwn e)poi/ei;
a)/ra added to ei) or e)a/n = possibly. Plato, Rep. 433 a a)/koue ei)/ ti a)/ra le/gw (see Ast, Lex. Plat. s. v.). The Philinus in question may be the same as that of ii. 115 (vid. note there). If so we must lower the date of this idyll as much as possible; but there is no necessity for the identification. If the theory, proposed by Knaack, that *fili=nos is a pet name for *filoklh=s be accepted, then the Philocles might well be the same as one mentioned by Leonidas, A. Pal. vi. 309.

parei/h general time clause; optative by assimilation to masti/sdoien, cf. vi. 24; Mimnernus 1 teqnai/hn o(/te moi mhke/ti tau=ta me/loi. On the custom the Scholiast writes *mou/nato/s fhsin e(orth
 )*arkadikh
 ei)=nai e)n h(=| oi( pai=des to
 *pa=na ski/llais ba/llousi: gi/netai de\ tou=to o(/tan oi( xorhgoi\ lepto
 i(erei=on qu/swsi kai\ mh\ i(kano
 h)=| toi=s e)sqi/ousi.
kna/saio (knh/qw), 'scratch yourself.' Mark the alliteration k, x, x, kn, kn, k, kn, k.

sqq. )*hdwnw=n i. e. in wintry Thrace, Verg. Ecl. x. 65. tetramme/nos, better joined with pa\r potamo/n than with e)ggu/qen a)/rktw, 'turning in the way by the riverside'; cf. Iliad xxi. 603:
o( to\n pedi/oio diw/keto purofo/roio
tre/yas pa\r potamo/n.

a)/rktw the 'Great Bear.' *blemu/es e)/qnos *ai)qiopiko\n melano/xroun Schol. Theocritus places them beyond the sources of the Nile. The town Aenus at the mouth of the river Hebrus has a figure of Pan on its coins. The god of the Nubians (Aethiopians) was identified by the Greeks with Pan. We have therefore two pieces of curious learning in this passage (Wilamowitz). Such recondite allusions are remarkably rare in Theocritus.
Hyetis and Byblis are hills and fountains in the district of Miletus. Oeceus, a spot sacred to Aphrodite in the same neighbourhood; see xxviii. 4.
*diw/nas = )*afrodi/ths, not as in xvii. 36.

ba/llete, k.t.l. : cf. A. Pal. v. 86:
a)lla\ *po/qoi pro\s mhtro\s e)ustefa/nou *kuqerei/hs,
fle/cate th\n a)piqh=, me/xris e)rei=, "*fle/gomai."
See note on 98. Wilamowitz interprets the line, 'make Philinus love another and suffer what Aratus suffers loving him.' The antithesis of l. 120 seems to suit the other version better.
a)/nqos, 'the bloom of thy beauty.'

mhke/ti toi, 'then let us no longer watch at his door, Aratus'; cf. Charito, A. ii. 3 h(mei=s de\ pareta/qhmen au)lei/ais qu/rais prosagrupnou=ntes, k.t.l.: Propert. i. 16. 17:
'Ianua vel domina penitus crudelior ipsa,
Quid mihi tam duris clausa taces foribus?
.........
Me mediae noctes, me sidera plena (v. l. prona) iacentem,
Frigidaque Eoo me dolet aura gelu.'

froure/wmes. Wilamowitz - Moellendorf (Aratos von Kos, p. 186) regards the 1st person as due merely to an identification on Theocritus' part of himself with his friend. 'Theocritus,' he maintains, 'does not paint an actual scene--the two standing together through the night at the door--mhde\ po/das tri/bwmes refers to running after Philinus all day.' With due respect to so high an authority I cannot but think that this is the very reverse of the truth. tri/bwmes is to be taken literally, Aratus is accompanied by his friend for the ignorance of the object of Aratus' care was only assumed (cf. ii. 119), and o)/rqrios a)le/ktwr, k.t.l., loses all its force if we refer it merely to the reminder that morning has come after a sleepless night in one's own bed!
o( d' o)/rqrios, 'and let the morning cockcrow resign another to cruel numb despair.'
na/rkaisin might also be the chill of morning (cf. Propert. loc. cit.), but the word is commonly used of mental rather than physical torpor.
didoi/h cf. Iliad v. 397 eu)=te/ min…balw\n o)du/nh|sin e)/dwken.

ei(=s almost = tis though rather more definite. Plato, Laws iv. 716 c pra=cis mi/a kai\ e(/na lo/gon e)/xousa a)rxai=on. Ast, Lex. Plat. s. v. ei(=s. palai/stras is used metaphorically of the fruitless effort; cf. i. 97.
a)/gxoito also a metaphor from wrestling. 'Let one--Molon--be gripped hard in this toil.'
126, 127 'But let peace of mind be ours,' etc. Ap. Rhod. iii. 640 a)/mmi de\ parqeni/h te me/loi kai\ dw=ma tokh/wn.
e)pifquzoisa cf. ii. 62.

a(/tis…e)ru/koi a relative sentence dependent on an optative of wish, and defining its subject takes the optative without a)/n: cf. xv. 94: Soph. Trach. 954:
*ei)/q' a)nemo/essa/ tis
ge/noit'…au)/ra,
h(/tis m' a)poiki/seien e)k to/pwn.
This dependent clause is not final but consecutive, and the optative is due to assimilation, i.e. such a sentence as ou)/k e)sti qnhtw=n o(/stis e)cepi/statai becomes mh\ ei)/h qnhtw=n o(/stis e)cepi/staito. But such a consecutive relative, dependent on an optative with a)/n, takes normally the optative with a)/n. Plato, Rep. 360 b ou)dei\s a)\n ge/noito ou(/tws a)dama/ntinos o(\s a)\n mei/neien. Examples to the contrary are dubious or capable of another explanation. [Lysias], i. 1 ou)k a)\n ei)/h o(/stis ou)k a)ganaktoi/h: Arist. Frogs 98:
go/nimon de\ poihth\n a)\n ou)x eu(/rois e)/ti
zhtw=n a)\n o(/stis r(h=ma gennai=on la/koi.
la/koi may either be deliberative, dependent on zhtw=n, or conditional (= go/nimos a)\n ei)/h ei)/ tis la/koi): cf. viii. 11, note.

ta
 e)pi\ *pu/cas see sketch-map in Preface. The road taken by Theocritus and his friends must therefore have laid to the north of Pyxa. For e)pi\ *pu/cas cf. Xen. Hellen. v. 1. 26 e)di/wkon au)to
 th
 e)pi\ *prokonnh/sou.
)*amu/ntixos a diminutive of )*amu/ntas (v. 2); cf. iv. 20, note.
oi)nare/oisi adject. used substantivally, 'vine leaves. Vid. Index, Adjectives.

kata\ krato/s, 'and many a branch of poplar and elm swayed and dipped above our heads.' kata/ not u(pe/r (tinassome/nwn ga\r u(/perqen karpo\s u(pe\r kefalh=s au)to\n e)/feuge futw=n, A. Pal. ix. 377) because downward motion is intended.
i(ero/n cf. viii. 33.
kela/ruze cf. Iliad xxi. 261 to\ de/ t' w)=ka kateibo/menon kelaru/zei.

ai)qali/wnes, 'dusky.' A. Pal. vii. 196 (Meleager):
a)/kra d' e)fezo/menos peta/lois prionw/desi kw/lois
ai)qi/opi kla/zeis xrwti\ me/lisma lu/ras.
The word is a diminutive form of ai)/qalos (also ai)qalo/eis, ai)qale/os); cf. *zwpuri/wn, xv. 13 zw/puros: kna/kwn, knako/s.

e)/xon po/non cf. xxi. 187; Hesiod. Scut. 305:
par' d' au)toi=s i(pph=es e)/xon po/non a)mfi\ d' a)e/qlois
dh=rin e)/xon kai\ mo/xqon.

o)lolugw/n, 'the tree-frog.' o( )*aristofa/nhs fhsi
 o(/ti pa/nu o)lolu/zei to\ zw=|on ma/lista e)n toi=s e(lw/desi to/pois kai\ kata\ nu/kta, Schol. A. Pal. v. 291:
kai\ liguro
 bombeu=sin (!) a)kanqi/des: h( d' o)lolugw

tru/zei trhxale/ais e)ndia/ousa ba/tois.
Aratus, 948 (among signs of rain) h)\ tru/zei o)rqrino
 e)rhmai/h o)lolugw/n: where the Scholiast interprets the word to mean o)/rneon kata\ th
 trugo/na.

couqai/ a frequent epithet of bees, of the nightingale (Aesch. Agam. 1142); of wings (h. hymn Diosc. xiii); of wind (Chaeremon in Athen. 608 D). couqo\s i(ppalektruw/n, Arist. Birds 800 (parody of Aeschyl.). In all passages but the last the word is best taken of sound--'shrill'--only so can we give it a consistent meaning. With i(ppalektruw/n it may be used of colour; foinika= ptera\ e)/xwn, Schol. Ar. Pax 1177. Dr. Rutherford
(on Babrius, 118) writes, 'Originally possessing a precise signification it afterwards dropped out of use till it was taken up by the higher poetry to which the indefiniteness of meaning produced by time had a literary value ... and the late literary schools ended by assigning to the word the meaning which they fancied best suited the two or three classical passages, but to which the word may or may not originally have had any claim.' 'When I use a word,' Humpty Dumpty said in rather a scornful tone, 'it means just what I choose it to mean--neither more nor less. ... They've a temper some of them, particularly verbs--they're the proudest--adjectives you can do anything with but not verbs.' With the whole description, cf. Plato, Phaedr. 230 b.
peri\…a)mfi/ cf. Iliad ii. 305 a)mfi\ peri\ krh/nhn: Theocr. xxv. 103, 256: no/sfin a)/ter filo/thtos, Hesiod, Scut. 15.
a)/leifar Horace, Odes iii. 8, 10 'corticem adstrictum pice dimovebit amphorae.'
krato/s, 'neck of the wine jar.'
*nu/mfai *kastali/des. The Nymphs as well as the Muses are patronesses of song; cf. Verg. Ecl. vii. 21 'Nymphae noster amor Libethrides' (Conington, ad loc.): Theocr. vii. 91.
*fo/lw. According to one tradition Pholus, one of the Centaurs, according to the present Chiron entertained Heracles with a famous old wine given by Dionysus.
e)sth/sato cf. v. 58.
)*ana/pw| cf. i. 68.
na=as e)/balle Odyss. ix. 481.
possi/ superfluous as in bai/nei posi/, viii. 43; Odyss. xvii. 27 kraipna\ posi\ probiba/s: A. Pal. vi. 268 kat' ei)nosi/fullon o(/ros posi\ po/tnia bai/neis, etc.

e)/peise…xoreu=sai, 'set a dancing'; cf. iv. 11; Herond. i. 8 ti/s se moi=r' e)/peis' e)lqei=n. So iubeo, Propert. ii. 6. 17:
'Centauros eadem dementia iussit
Frangere in adversum pocula Pirithoum.'
diekrana/sate, 'poured from your spring.'

*nu/mfai in v. 148 the Nymphs are not the Muses, but the Nymphs of the fountain Castalia, queen of all fountains, and therefore the source of all fountains. Hence the Nymphs of Castalia are deities of all springs and may be invoked by the waterside in Cos (Wilamowitz-Moellendorf, loc. cit. p. 193). According to the Greek custom the wine (v. 147) would be mixed with water from the spring; hence the Nymphs are said to be the givers of the draught.

Recently J. Schmidt (Rhein. Mus. 45) has offered a new explanation, taking pw=ma metaphorically = a draught of song. This would be very obscure in this context among krath=ra, ne/ktar, diekrana/sate, with no mention of song, although the metaphorical use of pw=ma can be easily supported. Pind. Is. vi. 1:
qa/llontos a)ndro\s w(s o(/te sumposi/ou
deu/teron krhth=ra *mousa/wn mele/wn ki/rnamen
A. Pal. ix. 364 o(/ssoi ga\r proxe/ousin a)oidoto/kou po/ma phgh=s.
sqq. a)lw|a/dos, 'of the threshing-floor.'
ptu/on, 'winnowing-fan.'

a( de\ gela/ssai (opt.), parataxis for 'while she smiles holding the sheaves and poppies in either hand.' The words seem obviously to refer to a statue--or rough figure of Demeter--decked with corn and poppies.

div1.p: The idyll is a simple singing-match between Daphnis and Menalcas, divided into two portions: (a) 33-60 in alternate quatrains of elegiac verse; (b) 63-80 in hexameter verse. Daphnis and Menalcas are the legendary characters of that name (cf. Id. vi). Both were the subject of a poem by Hermesianax (see Introd. p. 11), and of one by Sositheus in which Menalcas was represented as vanquished in song by Daphnis. It is impossible to hold that Daphnis and Menalcas are merely names applied to contemporary shepherds, in face of i. 91, of the total absence of character drawing, and especially of w(s fanti/ in v. 2. Various critics have regarded as spurious either portions of the idyll, or the whole, but only on internal evidence of very weak character. So far as the idyll contains verbal peculiarities they are confined to the elegiac part, and the change of metre brings with it change of forms (so ai) a)/n, 43, 47, instead of ai)/ ke: w)/n, 52, for e)w/n, on which M. Legrand lays stress, op. cit. pp. 16, 17). The inconsistencies found by Hermann between the first and second songs are utterly trivial, and to an unprejudiced reader unapparent. Wilamowitz argues that 'each idyll is a separate picture (ei)=dos); each therefore had a separate title; recurrence of title is therefore as good as forbidden; therefore viii and ix (bearing same title as vi) are not genuine.' Could dogmatism and pedantry go further? See further Buecheler in N. Jahrbücher f. Cl. Philol. 1860.

div2.p: Compare the setting of Id. vi.
w(s fanti/ this shows that the idyll deals with the legendary Daphnis; see Preface.
purrotri/xw here of the hair of the head, not of the face, as Daphnis and Menalcas are represented as mere lads.
h)/sthn Ahrens, Dial. Dor. p. 326.

lg.l: Et cantare pares et respondere parati.'

div2.p: moi cf. i. 136, note; not an ethic dative.

I have followed Boissonade's punctuation, which connects o(/sson qe/lw with nikasei=n. 'I say I will vanquish you as much as I like in song'; cf. Arist. Equit. 713 e)gw\ d' e)kei/nou katagelw= g' o(/son qe/lw.

ei)/ ti pa/qois, 'not if you hurt yourself in the singing.'
A pretty use of this well known euphemism is given by Isaeus. i. § 4 ei)/ ti pa/qoi *klew/numos a)/pais. The rhythm of the line is not an exception to the rule of the trochaic caesura in fourth foot (see xviii. 15) since ei)/ ti pa/qois almost form a single word.
e)sidei=n vid. Index, Verbs compound; Soph. Elect. 584.
kataqei=nai = depono, 'to stake.'

ti/na. a)=qlos, masc. in the sense of a)=qlon, neut. = prize, is known only from the grammarians, Bekker, Aneed. xxi. 14 a)=qlos a)rsenikw=s to\ e)/rgon kai\ to\ a)gw/nisma kai\ to\ e)/paqlon: diafe/rei te tou=to tou= ou)dete/rou o(/ti to\ me
 ou)de/teron dhloi= kuri/ws to\ e)/paqlon, tou=to de\ to
 a)gw=na. For the optat. ei(/h cf. Theognis 84:
to/ssous d' ou) dh/eis dizh/menos, ou)d' e)pi\ pa/ntas
a)nqrw/pous, ou(\s nau\s mh\ mi/a pa/ntas a)/goi.
Arist. Thesm. 871 (parody) ti/s e)/xei kra/tos o(/stis de/caito: Plato, Euthyd. 292 e ti/s pot' e)sti
 h( e)pisth/mh e)kei/nh h( h(ma=s eu)dai/monas poih/seie (poih/sei Stallbaum). We should expect a)/n in the relative clause in all these, since the sense required is final or consecutive ('of such a kind as to satisfy us'), cf. Demosth. xx. 161 nomoqetei=n oi(=s mhdei\s a)
 nemesh/sai, and there is no preceding optative whereto the following is assimilated (see vii. 125). It is hardly possible to regard the optative as one 'of pure generality,' like Soph. Antig. 666 o(
 po/lis sth/seie tou=de xrh\ klu/ein, since this is only a variant from o(
 a)
 sth/sh|, a form not applicable in the above cases. It is noticeable however that these three optatives occur in a relative sentence dependent on an interrogative or quasi-interrogative. The construction would therefore seem to be parallel to the thorny e)/sq' ou)=n o(/pws )/*alkhstis e)s gh=ras mo/loi (Eur. Alc. 52) etc. See Sonnenschein, Syntax, p. 343 and p. 293, note.
In qhseumesqa the middle has reciprocal force, 'stake for each other.'

qe/s lengthened in arsis in fourth foot, cf. xxv. 203; Iliad vii. 164 qou=rin e)pieime/noi a)lkh/n. The second metrical anomaly--the hiatus before a)mno/n--cannot be justified. a)mno/n has not the v, nor was it supposed to have it by Theocritus; see v. 24, 144, 148. Hiatus in the fifth thesis is not legitimate even in Homer; see Monro, Hom. Gram. § 382. a)mno/n has probably displaced the true word both here and in v. 15. e)/pissan Fritzsche: ? r(h=na, a word used by Ap. Rhod. and later poets, vid. Liddell and Scott. The hiatus r(h=na e)pei/ in 15 would be unobjectionable.
xalepo\s o( path/r cf. xv. 100. mogero\n )*ofiou=xon, Aratus 579 (so p k, xalepo/s q' Vulg.; vid. Ameis).
poqe/spera adverbial; cf. v. 44; ii. 100; tarfe/' a)meibome/nw, Odyss. viii. 379; kala\ me\n h)/ecen, Callim. i. 55. But e)pinu/ktia mh=la nomeu/wn, A. Pal. vi. 262 (Leonidas) is adjective.
o( nikw=n, 'the victor'; cf. i. 109.

to\ ple/on, 'what is the advantage the victor will have?' (not 'the prize'), cf. Thucyd. i. 42. 4 to\ ga\r mh\ a)dikei=n tou\s o(moi/ous e)xurwte/ra du/namis h)\ tw=| au)ti/ka fanerw=| e)parqe/ntas dia\ kindu/nwn to\ ple/on e)/xein: A. Pal. xii. 245 tw=n a)/llwn zw/|wn tou=t' e)/xomen to\ ple/on.

e)nnea/fwnon with nine reeds; seven was the more usual number. Tibullus, ii. 5. 31 describes its shape:
'Fistual cui semper decrescit arundinis ordo
Nam calamus cera iungitur usque minor.'
Reeds of diminishing length were fastened together with wax; cf. i. 129.

kala/n the epithet is used by Theocritus with remarkable frequency. 'Every commendation on every subject is comprised in that one word,' as Henry Filney says of the much abused 'nice'; cf. xv. 62; xviii. 26; vi. 14; ix. 25; ii. 73; i. 52; iv. 18; iv. 32; xv. 99, 73; i. 149; ii. 80, etc. Does Theocritus do this in imitation of popular speech?
katqei/hn, 'I would willingly stake'; see xvi. 67, note.

die/tmace/n me scil. to\n daktulon, the verb taking two accusatives of the person and the part affected; Iliad xxi. 181 to\n de\ sko/tos o(/sse ka/luyen: Aesch. Eumenid. 88 mh\ fo/bos se\ nika/tw fre/nas, etc.

pw=s…h)\n kale/swmes; 'how will it be if we call?' cf. Odyss. xviii. 223:
pw=s nu=n ei)/ ti cei=nos e)n h(mete/roisi do/moisin
h(/menos w(=de pa/qoi;
The usual reading th=no/n pws would be explicable by an ellipse th=nos o( ai)po/los h)\n kale/swmes: but while e)a/n pws is good Greek is pws…e)a/n?
fa/laros, 'with white face'; see Buttmann, Lexil. p. 528.
e)pakou=sai vid. vii. 95; v. l. e)pakou/sas: Cobet u(pakou/sas.
i)ukta/ formed on analogy of eu)ru/opa *zeu/s, i(ppo/ta *ne/stwr, etc.; h)xe/ta te/ttic, Hesiod, Scut. 393; h)xe/ta bo/mbos, A. Pal. v. 295.

w)=n…laxw/n cf. ll. 5, 18, 61; xxv. 1; xxii. 114, 180, 87. etc.; Introd. p. 44. This use of rhyme on second and fourth arsis is fairly common in hexameter verse both in Greek and Latin; Odyss. x. 145; viii. 230; v. 296; vi. 240; Verg. Ecl. viii. 32 'o digno coniuncta viro.' See Fritzsche, Latin edition on viii. 5. For this introductory line cf. vi. 5; ix. 14.
ph/pox' = ph/poka = pw/pote, Dial. § 4.
bo/skoit' = bo/skoite, not -o: cf. l. 39 piai/nete.

e)k yuxa=s sc. u(mete/ras, the dells and rivers being regarded as living persons; cf. xxix. 4; Nicet. Eugen. sou= mh\ filei=n qe/lontos e)k yuxh=s me/shs: Theophrast. Ch. 21 ou)k a)po\ yuxh=s me filei=s.
mhde\n e)/lasson 'no less grace' ('non minus pabuli,' Hiller prosaic); cf. xi. 42.
a)/fqona pa/nta Arist. Eccl. 690 pa=si ga\r a)/fqona pa/nta pare/comen: cf. xv. 111, note.
ne/moi cf. ta\ o)/rh ne/mein, Xen. Cyrop. iii. 2. 20 (= to graze the hills with cattle). Kynaston's translation--'all his sheep ungrudgingly'--is nonsense.

-48. In the MSS. ll. 41-43 and 45-47 are transposed each into the other's place. This is hardly tolerable. e)/nq' o)/is e)/nq' ai)=ges
suits Menalcas the shepherd, not Daphnis the neatherd. In line 51 Milo is the subject of Menalcas' verse; therefore l. 43 also referring to him must be given to Menalcas. [The order in the text was proposed by an anonymous critic in a review of Jacobs' edition, Allgem. Litterat. Zeitung. Oct. 27, 1808, and is now generally adopted.]
o)/is collective singular.
posi/n see vii. 153, note.

*mi/lwn Daphnis and Menalcas are represented in this idyll as mere children (ll. 3, 64). The following verses therefore are not to be understood as expressions of the singer's own feelings and experience; see Hiller's note. This understood, the supposed inconsistencies of the idyll disappear.
For the rhythm cf. xx. 6.
ta\ ne/a its younglings.

plh/qousin can hardly be considered the right reading. k and other good MSS. have phdw=si, 'throb,' which yields no sense. plh/qousin is feeble after plhrou=sin in 42, and the conjunction of singular and plural verb with neuter subject is awkward. plhqu/ei (Meineke) is not much better.
au)o/terai all is parched and drooping in the loved one's absence. au)=os, cf. Arist. Lysist. 385 au)=o/s ei)m' h)/dh tre/mwn: Soph. Elect. 819 a)/filos au)anw= bi/on: cf. Verg. Ecl. vii. 55.

a)/ner, 'lord of the flock'; to
 trieth= krio
 to
 me/gan o(\s h(gei=tai pro\s th
 nomh/n, Lucian, i. 210; Verg. Ecl. vii. 7 'vir gregis ipse caper.'

Strictly w(= = o(/qen, cf. iii. 26 w(=per: iii. 10 w(= (Ahrens, Dial. Dor. p. 374); but no sense can then be made, and we must take it = ou(= (cf. i. 105), allowing a false form for the Doric a(=|. 'Go, lord of the flock, where the wood is deepest--and come ye to the water, kids;--for there is he; go stump-horn and say:--,' i. e. the goat is sent with a message to Milo.

Most editors give this verse to Menalcas, marking a lacuna of four lines in which Daphnis should have replied in lines closely resembling 49-52, just as hitherto the quatrains have answered one another phrase for phrase. But that a verbal correspondence was not always required is shown by Verg. Ecl. vii. 41-44 compared with 37-40. The correspondence of sense is sufficiently obvious, and it is hard to conceive the singer of this perfect verse returned defeated (l. 82).

xru/seia. *kroi/seia is read (by conjecture) by Ahrens and subsequent editors, except Paley. But the mixture of historical names with legendary in a poem of which the scene is legendary is not in place. xru/seia is abundantly supported by Pind. Nem. viii. 37, which Paley quotes, xruso\n eu)/xontai pedi/on d' e(/teroi a)pe/ranton: and Odyss. iv. 129 xrusoi=o ta/lanta. With the whole compare Tyrtaeus, xii. 3-8:
ou)d' ei) *kuklw/pwn me\n e)/xoi me/geqo/s te bi/hn te
nikw/|h de\ qew=n *qrhi/kion *bore/hn,
ou)d' ei) *tiqwnoi=o fuh\n xarie/steros ei)/h
ploutoi/h de\ *mi/dew kai\ *kisu/rew ma/lion,
ou)d' ei) *tantali/dew *pe/lopos basileu/teros ei)/h
glw=ssan d' )*adrh/stou meilixo/ghrun e)/xoi.

*sikela\n e)s a(/la most easily construed with a)/|somai. To join it to e)sorw=n involves an awkward change of construction. Note the exquisite sound of these lines produced by the recurrence of the open a; cf. xi. 43. With the picture cf. Horace, Epist. i. 11. 10:
'illic vivere vellem
Oblitusque meorum obliviscendus et illis
Neptunum procul e terra spectare furentem.'
And Marlowe's:
'We will sit upon the rocks,
And see the shepherds feed their flocks.'

-60. This stanza obviously belongs to Daphnis (cf. 59 parqenika=s and 47), but this gives Daphnis a stanza too much. Either then four lines of Menalcas' are lost after 56, or we must divide the quatrain between the two singers, giving the first couplet to Menalcas, the second to Daphnis, who then finishes his rival's stanza for him. This latter is not very probable, though not impossible; Vergil paraphrases the verse, Ecl. iii. 80.
a)grote/rois substantival, 'to wild things.'

59, 60 Cf. Callim. Epig. 52:
to\n to\ kalo\n melaneu=nta *qeo/kriton, ei) me\n e)/m' e)/xqei,
tetra/ki misoi/hs, ei) de\ filei=, file/ois.
nai/xi pro\s eu)xai/tew *ganumh/deos, ou)ra/nie *zeu=:
kai\ su/ pot' h)ra/sqhs: ou)ke/ti makra\ le/gw.
It is hardly possible in this epigram to refuse to see a reference to Theocritus the poet. Besides the coincidence of phrase in the last line we have the use of to\ kalo/n (see iii. 3, note), and the Doric form melaneu=nta, and the not common name *qeo/kritos. The theory has been advanced, that the epigram is to be interpreted as referring to Callimachus' and Theocritus' friendship and community of view in regard to literary questions (vid. Introd. pp. 26, 27). The plausibility of this is in no way weakened by the fact that the epigram is an expansion of the line h)= kalo\s *qeo/kritos: ou) mo/nos a)nqrw/pwn e)ra=|s, Bacchyl. fr. 25.
di' a)moibai/wn = alternis; cf. dia\ braxe/wn, Isocr. 122 b, etc.
mikko/s = mikro/s.
*la/mpoure h)\ lampra\n ou)ra\n e)/xwn h)\…para\ to\ la/mpouris i)/sws ei)=nai e)peidh\…la/mpouris ga\r h( a)lw/phc, Schol.
ku/on the syllable is lengthened in arsis; cf. i. 115.
tai\ d' o)/ies cf. i. 151, note.
kore/sasqai, 'to sate yourselves.'

ou)/ti kamei=sq', 'ye will not be weary--or famished--when it grows again'; Verg. Georg. ii. 201:
'Et quantum longis carpent armenta diebus
Exigua tantum gelidus ros nocte reponet.'
a)poqw=mai, 'that I may set me some aside in cheese baskets'; cf. Odyss. ix. 246.
ga/r cf. v. 82, 90.

su/nofrus Anacreont. 15:
to\ meso/fruon de\ mh/ moi
dia/kopte mh/te mi/sge,
e)xe/tw d', o(/pws e)kei/nh,
to\ lelhqo/tws su/nofrun,
blefa/rwn i)/tun kelainh/n.
Note that the songs of the two rivals here correspond in nothing, save length. Daphnis' is the more fanciful.
parela=nta cf. v. 89, note.
kalo\n kalo/n cf. vi. 8 ta/lan ta/lan: A. Pal. xii. 130 ei)=pa kai\ au)= pa/lin ei)=pa kalo\s kalo/s.
ou) ma\n ou)de/…, 'and yet I answered her not a word to tease her.' tw)/mpikron (see crit. note) is accusative in apposition to the sentence (to\ e)/mpikron).
e)kri/qhn a)/po a post-classical use for a)pekrina/mhn.
to\ pneu=ma the breeze. [Hiller says 'scilicet ta=s po/rtios.']

79, 80 Cf. xviii. 29; Verg. Ecl. v. 32:
'Vitis ut arboribus decori est, ut vitibus uvae,
Ut gregibus tauri, segetes ut pinguibus arvis.'
The form of couplet is somewhat common; cf. A. Pal. ix. 65:
gh=| me\n e)/ar ko/smos polude/ndreon: ai)qe/ri d' a)/stra
(*ella/di d' h(/de xqw/n: oi(/de de\ th=| po/lei+.
Auctor, Epigramm. Homer. 13:
a)ndro\s me\n ste/fanos pai=des, pu/rgoi de\ polh=os,
i(/ppoi d' e)n pedi/w| ko/smos, nh=es de\ qala/sshs.
a(du/ ti cf. i. 1, note.
ta\s su/riggas each had staked a pipe (ll. 18, 21); the victor therefore takes both.
a(/ma with ai)pole/onta cf. Xen. Anab. iii. 3. 10 oi( ba/rbaroi kai\ feu/gontes a(/ma e)ti/t rwskon.
lh=|s is subjunctive.
'I will give you that stump-horned goat for thy wage.'

ta\n mitu/lan, ta\ di/daktra are in apposition. Both nouns have the article since the sentence represents an 'identical proposition,' ta\ di/daktra e)/stai h( mitu/lh: Plato, Gorg. 489 e tou\s belti/ous po/teron tou\s fronimwte/rous legeis h)\ a)/llous tina/s;
a)molge/a (the milk-pail). For scansion cf. *diokle/a^, xii. 29; fone/a^, Eurip. Hec. 882; u(pe\r kefala=s, 'brim full.'

a(/loito. For the simile cf. Odyss. x. 410:
w(s d' o(/t' a)\n a)/grauloi po/ries peri\ bou=s a)gelai/as,
e)lqou/sas e)s ko/pron, e)ph\n bota/nhs kore/swntai,
pa=sai a(/ma skai/rousin e)nanti/ai…
…w(\s e)me\ kei=noi, e)pei\ i)/don o)fqalmoi=si,
dakruo/entes e)/xunto.
The optative is used without a)/n as in ii. 34; Ap. Rhod. i. 767 o(\ kai\ dhro/n per e)p' e)lpi/di qhh/saio.

gameqei=sa a new form for gamhqei=sa. So eu(/rema for eu(/rhma (Hedylus), su/nqema for su/nqhma (Id.), a)/nqema for a)/nqhma, fqone/sh|s (A. Pal. v. 303). The simile is strange and not fully justified by such expressions of the hardships of married women's lot as Euripides in Stobaeus, lxviii. 19:
w)qou/meq' e)/cw kai\ diempolw/meqa
qew=n patrw/|wn tw=n te fusa/ntwn a)/po
ai( me\n ce/nous pro\s a)/ndras ai( de\ barba/rous
(quoted by Hiller); or Tibullus, iii. 4. 31:
'Ut iuveni primum virgo deducta marito
Inficitur teneras ore rubente genas';
since here we required an expression of disappointment. There is no emendation at all satisfactory. Dahl's nu/mfa gambrw= a)ka/xoito gives a good sense, but has no palaeographical probability. I suggest nu/mfan gameqei/s, so would one grieve relinquishing his bride (tis omitted, cf. xvii. 40, note).
Cf. Verg. Ecl. vii. 70.
*nai+/da ga=men. It is useless to attempt to reconcile this with the Daphnis legend, cf. Id. i and vii. The story appears in many forms; we have here to deal with another version.
a)/krhbos cf. prw/qhbos, Odyss. i. 431.

div1.p: On the interpretation of this poem, see Introd. pp. 22, 23. I have there set forth the view which alone seems to explain the poem, that it is merely a specimen poem written in order to afford an opportunity for the personal references of ll. 22-fin. Hence the slight nature of the two introductory songs. The whole idyll has been rejected as spurious by Weise, and the majority of editors reject all except 7-27. The theory which I have defended accounts for all but the introductory six lines; they are to all appearance spurious and added by an editor who wished to introduce in some fashion the person who speaks in l. 22. The hand of the unskilful interpolator is betrayed by the otiose repetitions: 1. boukolia/zeo - 5. boukolia/sqeu; by the clause tu\ d' w)|da=s a)/rxeo repeated in l. 2 (not a Theocritean touch but found, e.g. Callim. v. 13-15; Epig. 63; Epit. Adon. 51, 54, 58); by the sense of u(fe/ntes in 3; by the extraordinary number of variants in the MSS.; by the rhythm of line 1. boukolia/zeo and the heavy tu\ d' w)|da=s; and by the monotony of rhythm throughout; each of the first five lines has the weak caesura followed by a comma or colon: none has 'bucolic caesura.' The poem began, therefore, without introduction. There is no internal evidence of any weight against the rest of the poem (vid. notes on 21, 28, 29). See further Legrand, Étude sur Théocrite, p. 9 (following Brücker he rejects the whole); Buecheler, Jahrbücher für Class. Philol. 1860.

div2.p: 1, 2 Vergil, Ecl. iii. 58 'Incipe Damoeta: tu deinde sequere Menalca.' The resemblance cannot be accidental, and Ahrens' opinion that the writer of these lines imitated Vergil has nothing to commend it. Therefore these lines, though spurious, were regarded as part of the poem in Vergil's time.
u(fe/ntes tai=s bousi/ cf. iv. 4; Odyss. ix. 245 u(po\ d' e)/mbruon h)=ken e(ka/sth|.

u(po/. Instead of repeating the verb u(fe/ntes only the preposition is repeated, cf. Odyss. viii. 70; but in u(fe/ntes stei/raisi tau/rws the verb has not the same sense as at the beginning of the line, and must = clanculum mittentes (Fritzsche) unless we impute a curious ignorance to the author of the line.

fu/lloisi, 'in the leaves strewn on the ground.' Odyss. vii. 287:
e)/nqa me\n e)n fu/lloisi fi/lon tetihme/nos h)=tor
eu(=don pannu/xios.
Longus, ii. 31. 3 ta\ kre/a e)/qhkan e)n tw=| lei/mwni e)n toi=s fu/llois.

e)k to/qen cf. Ap. Rhod. ii. 533 e)k de\ to/qen. I have taken this in preference to e)/k poqen (Ahrens after Briggs) or e)/kpoqen (Briggs) as giving a better antithesis to a)/llwqen ('from that side').

The names are the same as in viii, Daphnis also in vi, but here are applied to actual shepherds of Theocritus' own day, though not perhaps without an intention of marking the poem as somewhat conventional.
kh)gw/n cf. i. 65 *qu/rsis o(/d' w(c *ai)/tnas, kai\ *qu/rsidos a(de/a fwna/.
Daphnis sketches the comfort of his retreat in summer: Menalcas answers with a picture of winter cosiness.
par' u(/dwr cf. viii. 78.
ne/nastai, 'piled high.' Arist. Eccl. 840 kli=nai/ te sisurw=n kai\ dapi/dwn nenasme/nai.

e)k damala=n de/rmata, 'skins from my goats.' For the adverbial equivalent e)k damala=n added to a noun (here instead of genitive alone), cf. Aesch. Eumenid. 183 me/lan' a)p' a)nqrw/pwn a)fro/n: Batrachom. 37 to/mos e)k pte/rnhs. Cf. note on ix. 34.

'a(pa/sas videtur corruptum. a)p' a)/kras quod in p legitur est sine dubio glossema ad a)po\ skopia=s adscripta et a librario in textum illata.' --Ziegler. a)pw/sas, Meineke (so Buecheler and Hiller), but this is a weak word to attach to li/y and e)ti/nace.
'I care for summer's heat as much as two lovers care to heed their parents' words.'
*ai)/tna ma=ter e)ma/. This fixes the scene of the poem as Sicilian. Pindar, P. viii. 140 *ai)/gina fi/la ma=ter: Isth. i. 1 ma=ter e)ma\ xru/saspi *qh/ba.

puri\ drui/nw|, 'a fire of oak logs.' Cf. Verg. Aen. xi. 786 'pineus ardor': Mosch. Europ. 36 r(ode/h fuh/: Tryphiod. 214 peukh/entos puro/s: Theocr. Ep. v. 4 khrode/tw| pneu/mati: Leonidas, vi. (A. Pal. vii. 273) ai)ph/essa kataigi/s (from off the cliffs). More
strangely, Antipater, Ep. 28 drui/nw| spendo/menos me/liti (from the oak).
zei= better than the 'correction' ze/ei in spite of the neglect of 'bucolic caesura.' The spondee--held on--gives the hissing sound of the boiling pot.

xeimai/nontos impersonal, 'when it is wintry.' Xen. Hellen. i. 1. 16 u(/ontos: Arist. Eccl. 401 kai\ tau=ta peri\ swthri/as prokeime/nou. For the picture of a cosy fireside in winter, cf. Eurip. Cyclops 329:
o(/tan de\ borra=s xio/na *qrh/|kios xe/h|,
dorai=si qhrw=n sw=ma peribalw\n e)mo\n
kai\ pu=r a)nai/qwn,--xio/nos ou)de/n moi me/lei.
Longfellow, Hiawatha:
'Four great logs had he for fire-wood,
One for each moon of the winter,
And for food the fishes served him.
By his blazing fire he sat there,
Warm and merry, eating, laughing,
Singing, O Kabibonokka (the north wind),
You are but my fellow-mortal.'
20, 21 'And I respect not winter more than old Toothless cares for nuts with cream cheese by him'; a quaint simile. For the a)/mulos, see Philoxenus, *dei=pnon (Bergk, Anth. Lyr.), iii. 5.

ou)d' o(/son, 'not a whit.' A common expression in the Alexandrian writers. Ap. Rhod. i. 290 ou)d' o(/son ou)d' e)n o)nei/rw| w)i+sa/mhn, 'I never thought, no not in dreams': id. ii. 190 a)/llote forbh=s ou)d' o(/son a)/llote tutqo/n: Callim. ii. 37 ou)/pote *foi/bou qhlei/h|s' ou)d' o(/sson e)pi\ xno/os h)=lqe pareiai=s, etc. It is probably in origin elliptical; 'Not so much as a snap of the fingers.' Arist. Wasps 213 ti/ ou)k a)pekoimh/qhmen o(/son o(/son sti/lhn;

h)\ nwdo/s. The omission of the comparative (before h)/) is strange here, though an idea of preference is slightly implied in w)/ran e)/xw. But cf. Pseudo-Phocyl. 82 kalo
 ceini/zein taxe/ws litai=si trape/zais h)\ plei/stais qoi/naisi bradunou/sais para\ kairo/n. So ou)de/n is used for ou)de
 a)/llo: Aeschines, i. 51 ou)k a)
 w)/knhsa au)to
 ou)de
 ai)tia=sqai h)\ o(/per: Plutarch, T. Gracch. vi. ou)de
 h)\ to
 libanwto/n.

)*ikari/aisi this--the reading of the best MSS.--may now be kept. We have seen that Theocritus was in Cos for some years, and visited among other places Miletus, where his friend Nicias lived. Why should we not allow him a fishing excursion further afield as far as Icaros, where he found this splendid shell, so large that it provided a bite for each of the party of five? The shell he kept as a curio, and now gave it away on his return to his Sicilian home. Bergk's (*ukkari/aisi ((*ukari/aisi, Meineke, et alii) would place the fishing expedition at Hyccara in Sicily (Thucyd. vi. 62).

'Muses of the country side farewell, and make known to the world the songs which once I sang to those my shepherd friends' (vid. Introd. l. c.). nomeu=si are Theocritus' pseudoshepherd friends in Cos, to whom he sends some of his work.
ma/la xai/rete cf. i. 144; xv. 149.

fai/nete d' w)|da/s Odyss. viii. 499 o( d' o(rmhqei\s qeou= h)/rxeto, fai=ne d' a)oidh/n: Plato, Phaedr. 259 b genome/nwn de\ *mousw=n kai\ fanei/shs w)|dh=s. The Muses must give their sanction, and 'imprimatur' to the poet's work. No exception need be taken to the form w)|dh/ for a)oidh/ here since it appears not in the bucolic song itself but in an envoie of the poet's own.
parw/n when in Cos.

The general connexion as explained, Introd. p. 23, is 'Give to the world my song lest I be accused of dishonesty.' o)lofuggw/n is explained by Hesych. as flukti\s ('a blister') e)pi\ th=s glw/sshs, and Schol. k says o(/tan au(/th ge/nhtai e)pi\ th=| glw/tth| ei)w/qasin ai( guiai/kes le/gein w(s a)poteqei=sa/n soi meri/da ou)k a)pe/dwkas, 'that you have not paid back honestly what was given into your keeping.' Theocritus is the servant of the Muses (u(pakouo\s *pieri/dwn, Ap. Rhod. iv. 1379), and has accepted as a charge upon him the inspiration which they give. Therefore he prays them to be with him and give their authority to the songs he publishes, vouching for the fair payment of the debt. fu/sh|s then cannot be right, and we must take the conj. fu/sw (Briggs and Graefe). mhke/ti, however, is right (mh/pw, Ziegler). The debt has long been unsatisfied, but shall be so no longer.

'Neither sleep, nor the sudden burst of spring sweeter.' e)capi/nas is used in place of adjective, cf. xxiv. 111 )*argo/qen a)/ndres: Aratus 1094 h)peiro/qen a)nhr: Iliad vi. 450 a)/lgos o)pi/ssw: Demosth. 835 a)/rdhn o)/leqros: Arist. Clouds 1120 a)/gan e)pombri/a. When so used the noun cannot have the article, unless the adverb is placed in the attributive position, i. e. h( e)pombri/a a)/gan is not Greek.

It is better to take to/sson as demonstrative, and regard the sentence as irregular in construction, cf. xii. 3-8, than to take it as relative (as), vid. note on xxii. 199. The sentence gains considerably in energy.

div1.p:
There is very little evidence for the date or place of composition of this idyll. The scene is, however, probably Coan. Polybotes (l. 16) is a Coan name; and the use of *su/ran (l. 26), and the mention of Lityerses (l. 41) are more appropriate to
the eastern islands than to Sicily. On the other hand Theophrastus states that the cactus (vid. l. 4) was only found in Sicily. It is one of the more realistic poems, and consists of a dialogue between two reapers, Milo and another (Battus acc. to Scholiast). Battus is in love and cannot work; urged by his companion he relieves himself by singing a sentimental love song to his Bombyca; but meets with small sympathy from Milo, who shows him what a labourer's song should be--a string of rustic maxims in the style of Hesiod, on crops and weather and overseers.

div2.p: boukai=e. Fritzsche makes this a proper name, and bou=kos (l. 38) a shortened form of the same. Nicander, however, certainly uses boukai=os as a common noun. Theriaca, v. 5 polu/ergos a)rotreu\s boukai=o/s te…kai\ o)roitu/pos. Eustathius on Iliad xiii. 824 explains both boukai=os and bou=kos as = a)/groikos. Schol. k on 37 says Nicander used bou=kos = bouko/los, and the false reading bouko/los in that verse is obviously a gloss (Nicander, fr. 35 boukai=oi zeu/gessin a)morbeu/ousin o)rh/wn). It is impossible in face of this evidence to make boukai=os a proper name; and we must regard boukai=os and bou=kos as a doublet like deilo/s dei/laios, e)ruqro/s e)ruqrai=os, and probably as adjectives = a)/groikos.

pepo/nqeis from pepo/nqw. These forms are said to be Sicilian, but are found in Greek of all ages and districts. dedoi/kw, Theocr. xv. 58; pefu/kei, xi. 1; e(sth/kw, Anthol. Append. 65. In participle--a)nw/gousa, Herond. vii. 101; keklh/gontes, Quint. Smyr. xii. 58, etc. (? Iliad xvi. 430); e)rri/gonti e)oikw/s, Hesiod, Scut. 227; tepu/pontes, Callim. iii. 61. Cf. e)me/mhkon, Odyss. ix. 438; e)pe/fukon, Hesiod, Theog. 152; Scut. 76.

e(o/n, 'your.' The possessive pronouns become utterly confounded in late Greek: e(o/s = tuus here and xxiv. 36; xxii. 173; Quint. Smyrn. vii. 294 = suus (plural), Quint. Smyrn. ii. 264 (Theocr. xxvii. 26) = noster, Ap. Rhod. iv. 203. There are possibly traces of this in Homer; Iliad xiv. 221 sh=|si: MS. D has h(=|si. So ei(=o = mei, Ap. Rhod. ii. 635; e(oi= au)th=| = mihi ipsi, Ap. Rhod. iii. 99: sfi/si = nobis, Id. ii. 1278; sfe/teros = tuus, Theocr. xxii. 67 = meus, xxv. 162 = suus (singular), Bacchyl. iii. 36 and often (not in Homer): o(/s = tuus, Callim. iii. 103 = meus (Mosch.) Megara 77 etc. Cf. Monro, Hom. Gram. § 255.
du/na| for du/nasai, cf. Soph. Philoct. 798, etc.; e)pi/sta|, Pind. Cf. Rutherford, N. Phryn. p. 463.

o)/gmon, 'swathe'; cf. Iliad xi. 68:
oi( d' w(s a)mhth=res e)nanti/oi a)llh/loisi
o)/gmon e)lau/nwsin a)ndro\s ma/karos kat' a)/rouran
purw=n h)\ kriqe/wn: ta\ de\ dra/gmata tarfe/a pi/ptei.
Cf. Odyss. xviii. 366 sqq.

a(/ma la|otomei=s Quint. Smyrn. viii. 279:
w(s d' o(po/t' ai)zhoi\ mega/lhs a)na\ gouno\n a)lwh=s
o)/rxaton a)mpelo/enta diatmh/cwsi sidh/rw|
sperxo/menoi, tw=n d' i)=son a)e/cetai ei)s e)/rin e)/rgon

ka/ktos e)/tuye cf. Philetas, fr. (quoted Introd. p. 11); Theophrastus, H. Pl. vi. 4. 10 states that the cactus was peculiar to Sicily, e)n de\ (*ella/di ou)k e)sti/. Does he include the islands in (*ella/s? vid. preface to this idyll.
dei/lan tu kai\ e)k me/sw a)/matos. 'kai/, se corrigentis est; "vesperi et a meridie eris" non significat "atque adeo,"' Hermann, Opusc. v. tu is rather contemptuous, 'what will you be like?'
e)k = 'after.' e)c h)ou=s lei/bein oi)=non, Hesiod, )/*erg. 724.
o)yama/ta, 'who can reap till late.'
poqe/sai tina\ tw=n a)peo/ntwn masc. not neuter. Battus tries to break the subject delicately; 'have you never longed for some absent--friend?'
mhde/ ge sumbai/h, 'no, and may it never'; Arist. Frogs 1045 *e*u. ma\ *di/' ou)de\ ga\r h)=n th=s )*afrodi/ths ou)de/n soi. *a*i. mhde/ g' e)pei/h.

geu=sai, 'to give a taste of.' xalepo/n, 'a bad business.' The phrase is either a recognized proverb or modelled on such. It is noticeable that a large proportion of Greek proverbs form the last half of a hexameter, e.g. kaka\ me\n qri=pes kaka\ d' i)=pes: cu/lon a)gku/lon ou)de/pot' o)rqo/n: su\n )*aqhna=| kai\ xe/ra ki/nei (God helps them that help themselves).
e)/ramai e(ndekatai=os, 'I have been in love for ten days.' The present is used as with pa/lai, Herond. iii. 38 h)\ tritai=os ou)k oi)=den th=s oi)ki/hs to\n ou)do/n.
e)k pi/qw. paroimi/a e)pi\ tw=n a)/fqona e)xo/ntwn, Schol.; Herond. iv. 14 ou) ga/r ti pollh\n ou)d' e(/toimon a)ntleu=men.
dh=lon, 'it is clear'; cf. dh=lon o(/ti in orators.
a(/lis o)/cos. The accus. with a(/lis occurs rarely in Classical period, always in Alexandrian, e. g. a(/lis o)/lbon, Callim. i. 84.

a)/skala pa/nta, 'all is unhoed before my doors.' a)po\ spo/rw, 'from seed-time.' Harvest began in May (see Hesiod, )/*erg. 383), so this must refer to the spring sowing, when the sun enters Taurus (April 20 now); cf. Verg. Georg. i. 215:
'Vere fabis (beans) satio: tum te quoque, Medica (lucerne), putres
Accipiunt sulci, et milio (millet) venit annua cura:
Candidus auratis aperit cum cornibus annum Taurus.'
lumai/netai, 'tortures'; Arist. Frogs 59 toiou=tos i(/mero/s me dialumai/netai.
a( *polubw/ta sc. pai=s. The slave girl of Polybotes, not the daughter.
par' (*ippoki/wni, 'in Hippocion's farm'; cf. xiv. 14.

Solon, xiii. 27:
toiau/th *zhno\s pe/letai ti/sis,……
………
ai)ei\ d' ou)/ e( le/lhqe diampere/s, o(/stis a)litro\n
qumo\n e)/xh|.
Schol. k paroimiw=des e)pi\ tw=n dido/ntwn di/khn th=s a(marti/as, 'your sin has found you out.' pa/lai is to be joined with e)pequ/meis, what
you desired before. pa/lai can refer to comparatively recent events; see Soph. O. T. ei)=pon w(s doi/hn pa/lai. Milo regards Battus' attainment of his desire as a heaven sent punishment for his sins.
ma/ntis kalamai/a a grasshopper (cf. use of seri=fos, Liddell and Scott, s.v.). So Milo calls Bombyca from her bony leanness.
ta\n nu/kta accus. of time.
xroi+cei=tai = sugkoimhqh/setai, vid. Hiller and Paley, ad loc.
au)to/s, 'alone'; cf. ii. 89; Arist. Acharn. 504 au)toi\ ga/r e)smen.

kai/ ti ko/ras, 'and strike up a love song to your girl.' The gen. ko/ras depends on me/los: cf. Pind. Isth. i. 21 )*iola/ou u(/mnw|: Demosth. De Cor. § 100 stratei/as a(\s a(pa/sas th=s tw=n (*ellh/nwn swthri/as pepo/ihtai h( po/lis where th=s swthri/as depends on stratei/as.
a(/dion ou(tw=s e)rgach=| song will relieve your thought and you will work the better; so Propert. i. 9, ad fin. 'dicere quo pereas saepe in amore levat.'
-37. The song falls naturally into couplets, as that in Idyll iii into groups of three lines, Introd. p. 39.
sunaei/sate vid. on ix. 28.
moi is governed by the sun-; cf. Thucyd. viii. 16 cugkaqh/|roun au)toi=s, etc.
poei=te (k): Theocritus has the first syllable short, viii. 18; x. 38; iii. 9, 21: xxix. 24; xiv. 70. The MSS. vary in each case between poiei=n and poei=n.

sqq. Cf. Lucretius, iv. 1151 sqq.; Longus, i. 16 me/las ei)mi/: kai\ ga\r o( u(a/kinqos: a)lla\ krei/ttwn: Nonnus, xxxiv. 118:
*xalkome/dhn me\n a(/pantes: e)gw\ de/ se mou=nos e)ni/yw
*xrusome/dhn o(/ti ka/llos e)/xeis xruse/hs )*afrodi/ths.

a( grapta\ u(a/kinqos. The iris sprang from the blood of the dead Hyacinthus, slain by Apollo, and bore on its edge the letter *u: Verg. Ecl. iii. 106; Milton, Lycidas:
'His bonnet sedge,
Inwrought with figures dim, and on the edge
Like to that sanguine flower inscribed with woe.'
A second legend made the flower spring from the blood of Ajax, and interpreted the writing as ai)\ ai)/. Euphorion, fr. 36:
porfure/h u(a/kinqe, se\ me\n mi/a fh=mis a)oidw=n
(*roitei/h|s a)ma/qoisi dedoupo/tos *ai)aki/dao
ei)/aros a)nte/llein gegramme/na kwku/ousan.

ta\ pra=ta le/gontai, 'they are chosen to be the first in the garlands.' The subject is to\ i)/on kai\ a( u(a/kinqos. For ta\ prw=ta cf. Arist. Frogs 421:
nuni\ de\ dhmagwgei=
e)n toi=s a)/nw nekroi=si,
ka)sti\n ta\ prw=ta th=s e)kei= moxqhri/as.
= the pick of the rascals.
e)pi\ ti/n cf. ii. 40.

32, 33 'Would that I had the fabled wealth of Croesus: our statues would be standing in gold to Aphrodite.' a)nakei=sqai used for passive of a)nati/qemai (middle). For the use with the person whose statue is dedicated as the subject cf. Lycurgus, In Leocr. § 51 e)n tai=s a)gorai=s a)qlhta\s a)nakeime/nous: Plato, Phaedr. 236 b plei/onos a)/cia ei)pw\n tw=n *lusi/ou para\ to\ *kuyelidw=n a)na/qhma sfurh/latos e)n )*olumpi/a| sta/qhti. The protasis of the condition is supplied by a wish; cf. Odyss. i. 265, etc.; Theocr. v. 44. The form of wish must of course be assimilated to the form of if-clause which would have been used. Hence Paley's ei)/h o(/sa is ungrammatical.
'You with your flute and a rose or apple; I with fine dress and new shoes on my feet.'
h)\ ma=lon tu so Ahrens with the best MSS. The Vulgata h)\ tu/ge ma=lon gives a better rhythm, but does not give a sufficiently prominent place to the pronoun.

tw\s au)lw/s cf. l. 16. In the second line kaino/n is usually supplied to sxh=ma from kaina/s, but sxh=ma by itself means a fine dress. Alciphr. i. 34 e)c ou(= filosofei=n e)peno/hsas semno/s tis e)ge/nou…ei)=ta sxh=ma e(lw
 kai\ bibli/dion meta\ xei=ras ei)s th
 )*akadhmi/an sobei=s (Wuestemann). The Scholiast (and some modern editors) take sxh=ma of a dancer's poise; it could not mean this without further definition. It is probably merely confusion on the Scholiast's part that makes him write e)gw\ de\ kalo
 a)/nqos ei)=xon a)/n. If anything were lost it would have to be two lines, and the symmetry of sense and style would not allow of this.

a)mu/klas Amyclean shoes. Things are constantly called from the place of their origin, e.g. )*axai+ka/s (fetters), Herond. v. 61, in English, 'Hollands,' 'Newfoundlands,' 'Skyes,' 'St. Bernards,' 'Havannas.'
a)stra/galoi 'instar talorum eburneorum,' Fritzsche; cf. xxviii. 13.

tru/xnos. Photius, Lex. tru/xnon: kai\ para\ th\n paroimi/an a(palw/teros tru/xnou: parw|dw=n o( *kwmiko/s fhsi ei)mi\ mousikw/teros tru/xnou: Theophrastus, H. Pl. ix. 11 calls it tru/xnos u(pnw/dhs, and says that mixed with wine it formed a narcotic (Hiller). The point of the comparison lies in the soft soothing tone of the voice: 'Her voice was ever soft, Gentle and low' (King Lear).

e)lelh/qei. This pluperfect form becomes common in place of the aorist, Lucian, *nekuom. 486 e)lelh/qei *me/nippos h(ma=s a)poqanw/n. So with other verbs: e)pei\ parelhlu/qeimen, Lucian, V. H. ii. 29; w(/ste au)ti/ka e)peptw/kei, Id. Tox. 16; e)/nqa katadedeme/non kateleloipei to\n i(/ppon, ib. 49; e)pei\ e)dedei/pnhto, ib. 25.
bou=kos see note on line 1. Hiller objects to the absence of the article if the word is taken as a common noun, but unnecessarily. Milo means 'a labourer,' not 'the labourer.'

ta\n i)de/an…e)me/trhsen, 'he measured off the tune'; Lucian, Imagg. 14 to\ ga\r th=s te a(rmoni/as a)kribe/staton diafula/ttein, w(s mh\ parabai/nein ti tou= r(uqmou= a)ll' eu)kai/rw| th=| a)/rsei kai\ qe(sei diamemetrh=sqai to\ a)=|sma (Fr. Jacobs); cf. Plato, Theaet. 175 ad fin.
tw= pw/gwnos gen. after exclamation; cf. iv. 40.

a)ne/fusa. Greek of the Classical period would have said e)/fusa. a)nafu/w is common from 300 b. c., Ap. Rhod. ii. 1212 o)/fis…o(\n au)th\ gai=' a)ne/fuse *kauka/sou e)n knhmoi=si. The sense of the line is 'Alas that I am a bearded man, and so inferior to him!' in mockery, as his whole behaviour shows.

*litue/rsa. Lityerses was son of Midas, king of Celaenae in Phrygia. After hospitably entertaining strangers he made them reap with him, and such as could not equal him in work he slew. Hercules finally ended him.
