Athenaeus 619 a says merely that the harvesters' song was called the Lityerses; and Photius, i. 54 speaks of *litue/rshn w)|dh/n tina h(\n a)/|dousin oi( qeri/zontes w(s e)pi/shmo/n tina gegono/ta tw=n palaiw=n to\n *litu/ersan. It seems then that according to the popular version Lityerses was merely a hero of agriculture, and barbarity was not ascribed to him (see Wuestemann's note). Milo's song is intended as a representation of the traditional popular songs of Theocritus' day; it is not to be regarded as Milo's own invention.
-55. The lines form seven couplets of maxims strung together without any close connexion as in Hesiod, )/*erg. 706-764.

a)mallode/tai, 'binders,' here and A. Pal. x. 16 for a)mallodeth=res. The form in -hs is usual in nom. sing.; that in -hr in other cases, in hexameter and lyric verse (K. Lehrs, praef. Oppian, ed. Didot, p. vi).
su(kinoi a)/ndres, 'useless fellows.' The fig-tree was useless for timber, Hor. Sat. i. 8. 1 'inutile lignum.'

a)pw/leto xo??tos o( mi/sqos, 'that hire is a dead loss'; Theophrast. Char. ix. kai\ fi/lw| de\ e)/ranon keleu/santi ei)senegkei=n ei)pei=n o(/ti ou)k a)\n doi/h, u(/steron h(/kein fe/rwn, kai\ le/gein o(/ti a)po/llusi kai\ tou=to to\ a)rgu/rion.

ei)/poi. The optative in final sentence in primary sequence becomes very common in Alexandrian and later writers, especially Lucian (Madvig, Adv. i. 682); Ap. Rhod. i. 660, 1005, 490 ei) d' a)/ge dh\…dw=ra po/rwmen i(/n'…e)/ktoqi pu/rgwn mi/mnoien: cf. Theocr. xxiv. 100.

46, 47 a( toma/. The sheaf is to be turned with the cut end of the stalk to the west wind, in order that the grain may be dried and fattened. Cf. A. Pal.:
*eu)/dhmos to\n nho\n e)p' a)grou= to/nd' a)ne/qhka
tw=n pa/ntwn a)ne/mwn piota/tw| *zefu/rw|.
eu)came/nw| ga\r o(/ g' h)=lqe boaqo/os o)/fra ta/xista
likmh/sh| pepo/nwn karpo\n a)p' a)stuxu/wn.
'When winnowing avoid sleep in the noontide.'

to\ mesambrino/n cf. i. 15. The precept is given generally, not addressed to the winnowers; hence absence of article, and the use of the accusative, Hesiod, )/*erg. 753 mhde\ gunaikei/w| loutrw=| xro/a faidru/nesqai a)ne/ra: then 755 mhd' i(eroi=sin e)p' ai)qome/noisi kurh/sas mwmeu/ein a)i+/dhla (addressed to Perses, hence nominative). Hermann alters the text to feu/goi…u(/pnos (so Hiller. Ziegler) without any need.
tele/qei. pe/tetai (C. Hartung) possibly right.

a)/rxesqai d' a)mw=ntas. The de/ is justified here since this
precept attaches closely to the preceding couplet, and is in contrast to it. Hermann (Ziegler, Meineke, Hiller, Fritzsche) reject it and read a)/rxesq' a)mw/ontas.

ou) meledai/nei, 'he does not trouble about the filler of the glass, for he has to spare.' meledai/nw with accus. here, as Archiloch. 8 e)pi/rrhsin meledai/nwn, with gen. in ix. 12; vid. Index, Accusative.

to
 propiei=n e)gxeu=nta Herond. vi. 77 gluku
 piei=n e)gxeu=nta: Herod. iv. 172 e)k th=s xeiro\s didoi= piei=n. The MSS. have to
 to\ piei=n e)gxeu=nta. Fritzsche supports this by A. Pal. xii. 34 ei(=s e)/feren to\ piei=n (his drink), but both are to be emended. The infinitive with the article cannot stand for a concrete noun; here = to\ poto/n. In Plato, Rep. 439 b a)/gein w(/sper qhri/on e)pi\ to\ piei=n it = a verbal noun 'drinking'; Soph. Ajax 555 e(/ws to\ xai/rein kai\ to\ lupei=sqai ma/qh|s = rejoicing and sorrowing; cf. Aesch. Agam. 498 to\ xai/rein ma=llon e)kba/cei le/gwn: Isocr. 85 e e)cesthkw\s tou= fronei=n. It can be used freely in consecutive sense when negatived, Aesch. Agam. 15 to\ mh\ bebai/ws ble/fara sumbalei=n u(/pnw|, so that though we could say kwlu/ei to\ mh\ piei=n e)me/ we could not say e)gxei= to\ piei=n e)me/, 'so that I drink.' Lastly it can be used dependent on nouns, as Lucian, i. 457 ou)demi/a mhxanh\ to\ diafugei=n au)tou/s. None of these uses in the least justifies to\ piei=n e)gxeu=nta. propiei=n is nearer MSS. than pie/ein Herm. or ti piei=n: vid. also Jannaris, Hist. Greek Gram. p. 580.

limhro/n, 'starveling,' A. Pal. vi. 287:
kakw=n limhra\ gunaikw=n
e)/rga, ne/on th/kein a)/nqos e)pista/mena.

div1.p: We have seen in Idylls vi and viii that Theocritus imagined to himself a legendary past of the country side and country character. The heroes Daphnis, Menalcas, and Damoetas sang in rivalry, as did the shepherds of Cos and Sicily in the year 280, and their times were not far different from the modern in tone. Here the heroic mask is stripped away completely. The giant Polyphemus is no more the cannibal brute of the Odyssey, but an uncouth boor; huge and ugly still, above the mortals in loving a nymph, but at the last only a Brockenshadow of Comatas.

The theme of the 'Cyclops and Galatea' was a favourite, and was treated in verse by Philoxenus (Bergk, fr. 8), Hermesianax, Theocritus, Callimachus, and Bion, besides whom the author of the Epit. Bionis alludes to the story (see Rohde, Der Griech. Roman, p. 74). We do not know how Philoxenus and Hermesianax dealt with the story. In Theocritus it forms, like Idyll xiii, the illustration of a text, 'There is no remedy in science against the plague of love'; even heroes like Heracles were subject to it; nay, even that old
hero of Sicily, the Cyclops Polyphemus, was as love-sick as any one of us, and found solace in song alone. The object of the poem is therefore not to present to us a burlesque pastoral, but to combine with certain grotesque features a pathos and feeling of pity.

Like Id. xiii the poem is addressed to Nicias, whose profession is gently satirized. The doctor answered the poem with one of which the opening lines are preserved:
h)=n a)/r' a)lhqe\s tou=to *qeo/krite: oi( ga\r e)/rwtes
pollou\s poihta\s e)di/dacan tou\s pri\n a)mou/sous.

Bion would seem to have softened down the rougher features of the sketch and to have made his Cyclops sing more daintily, if we may judge from the four lines left of his poem:
au)ta\r e)gw\ baseu=mai e)ma\n o(do\n e)s to\ ka/tantes
th=no poti\ ya/maqo/n te kai\ a)i+o/na yiquri/sdwn,
lisso/menos *gala/teian a)phne/a: ta\s de\ glukei/as
e)lpi/das u(stati/w me/xri gh/raos ou)k a)polei/yw.

Callimachus' work is an epigram less on Polyphemus' than on Theocritus' poem (Epig. xlvi):
w(s a)gaqa\n *polu/famos a)neu/reto ta\n e)paoida\n
tw)rame/nw|: kai\ *ga=n ou)k a)maqh\s o( *ku/klwy:
ai( *mou=sai to\n e)/rwta katisxnai/nonti, *fi/lippe.
h)= panake\s pa/ntwn fa/rmakon a( sofi/a.
tou=to doke/w, xa( limo\s e)/xei mo/non e)s ta\ ponhra\
tw)gaqo\n e)kko/ptei ta\n filo/paida no/son, etc.
Besides these poets Ovid (Metam. xiii. 789) has imitated the poem (vid. notes on this idyll); but according to his wont has expanded all the phraseology to very weariness.
On date, etc., see Introd. p. 23.

div2.p: 1, 2 pefu/kei see on x. 1.
The words fa/rmakon…e)/gxriston…e)pi/paston are chosen in view of Nicias' profession (cf. 5 and 80).
e)pi/paston is explained by Iliad xi. 515 e)pi/ t' h)/pia fa/rmaka pa/ssein.

For e)/gxriston cf. Aesch. P. V. 480; Eurip. Hippol. 516. The metaphor of fa/rmakon is common; Bion, xiv:
molpa
 tai\ *moi=sai/ moi a)ei\ poqe/onti didoi=en
ta
 glukera
 molpa
 ta=s fa/rmakon a(/dion ou)de/n.
Isocr. 167 c tai=s yuxai=s tai=s a)gnoou/sais kai\ gemou/sais ponhrw=n e)piqumiw=n ou)de
 e)sti
 a)/llo fa/rmakon plh
 lo/gos.

kou=fon…, 'but light it is and sweet among men.' kou=fon is not = koufi/zon: but = gentle and painless. Cf. Pind. P. iii. 6 te/ktwn nwduni/an a(/meros (cf. Aesculapius); Horace, Odes i. 32. 15 'dulce lenimen'; Pind. P. iii. 91:
tou\s me\n malakai=s e)paoidai=s
a)mfe/pwn, tou\s de\ prosane/a pi/nontas, etc.

e)pi/ here = among, not 'in power of.' Cf. Odyss. xiii. 59:
gh=ras
e)/lqh| kai\ qa/natos, ta/ t' e)p' a)nqrw/poisi pe/lontai:
Bacchyl. vii. 8:
w(=| de\ su\ presbu/taton nei/mh|s ge/ras
ni/kas, e)p' a)nqrw/poisin e)/ndocos ke/klhtai.
tai=s e)nne/a dh/ cf. Epig. x; on Nicias as a poet, vid. Introd. p. 13.
ou(/tw gou=n, ''Twas thus at least that Polyphemus eased his pain.'
r(a/ista cf. v. 81; Timo, fr. 41 (Brunck) pw=s pot' a)nh\r e)/t' a)/geis r(h=|sta meq' h(suxi/hs.

o( par' a(mi=n. These words cannot be taken as evidence that the poem was written in Sicily. In Xenoph. Hellen. iii. 4. 5 Agesilaus when in Asia says, e)n th=| par' h(mi=n (*ella/di, i. e. in the Greece from which we come. But the words obviously do imply that Theocritus was a native of Sicily.
w(rxai=os cf. Callim. Ep. 59 w(rxai=os )*ore/stas.
h)/rato de/, etc. He loved not with apples nor roses, nor locks of hair, but with real fits of madness, i. e. not with what men call a wild passion, but with a fiercer madness.
ma/lois cf. vi. 7.
r(o/dw| collective singular; vid. note on xiv. 17.

o)rqai=s mani/ais cf. Aelian, H. An. xi. 32 e)/kfrwn geno/menos ei)/s te o)rqh
 mani/an kai\ w(s ta\ ma/lista i)sxura
 e)kfoita=| (Fritzsche); cf. Lucian, Tox. xv. katabalw
 e(auto
 ei)s tou)/dafos e)kuli/ndeto kai\ lu/tta h)=n a)kribh\s to\ pra=gma.

The lines are imitated in a pretty epigram; A. Pal. vii. 173 (? Leonidas):
au)to/matai dei/la| poti\ twu)li/on ai( bo/es h)=lqon
e)c o)/reos pollh=| neifo/menai xio/ni:
ai)ai=, *qhri/maxos de\ para\ drui+\ to\n makro\n eu(/dei
u(/pnon: e)koimh/qh d' e)k puro\s ou)rani/ou.
Cf. Verg. Ecl. iv. 21. au)tai/ alone.

a)ei/dwn au)toq' e)p' a)io/nos, 'singing his Galatea there on the weed-strewn shore.' Cf. the picture of Odysseus on the desolate coast of Calypso's island:
h)/mata d' a)\m pe/trh|si kai\ h)i+o/nessi kaqi/zwn
po/nton e)p' a)pru/geton derke/sketo.--Odyss. v. 156.
au)to/q' is for au)to/qi elided as in Odyss. x. 132, etc. The MSS. have au)tou=, au)tw=, or au)to/s, but au)tw= in Doric = au)to/qen, thence not there. Hence Ahrens, au)tw= a)po/ (Dial. Dor. 375), but this gives an awkward order, or au)tei= e)pi/, introducing a new dialect form. au)toq' explains the variant. au)tou= was written as gloss and altered to au)to/s or au)tw=.

to/ oi( h(/pati. The antecedent to to/ is e(/lkos. Cf. Syrinx, o(\s *moi/sa| ligu\ pa=cen i)ostefa/nw| e(/lkos: Iliad xvi. 5DI e(/lkos, o(\ dh/ min *teu=kros e)pessu/menon ba/len i)w=|: Pind. Pyth. ii. 167 e(/lkos e(a=| kardi/a| e)ne/pacan. The phrase is partly Homeric; Odyss. xxii. 83 e)n de/ oi( h(/pati ph=ce qoo\n be/los.

sqq. The opening of this song has found many imitators. Verg. Ecl. vii. 37:
'Nerine Galatea, thymo mihi dulcior Hyblae,
Candidior cycnis, hedera formosior alba'
(following as usual even the rhythm of Theocritus' lines). Ovid, Met. loc. cit. 'Candidior folio nivei, Galatea, ligustri, etc., the comparison running through nineteen lines. Gay, in Acis and Galatea:
'O ruddier than the cherry,
O sweeter than the berry,
O nymph more bright than moonshine night
Than kidlings blithe and merry.'
On the balance and symmetry of the lines, vid. Introd. p. 39.

pakta=s 'Mollior lacte coacto' (Ovid, loc. cit.); Lucian. )*ena/l. *dia/l. Doris to Galatea, kai/toi ti/ a)/llo e)n soi\ e)paine/sai ei)=xen (the Cyclops) h)\ to\ leuko
 mo/non; kai\ tou=to oi)=mai o(/ti cunh/qhs e)sti turw=| kai\ ga/lakti. Diodorus says that Tyro was so called dia\ th
 leuko/thta kai\ th
 tou= sw/matos malako/thta (Renier).
sfriganwte/ra, 'more plump than ripening grape'; vid. note on xxvii. 9, and J. A. Hartung on this line.

au)=q' = au)=qi. au)=qi in Homer = e)nqa/de (Odyss. v. 208), but in Alexandrine poets is used for au)=qis or au)=, with the meaning 'again,' 'in turn' (not 'a second time'); Callim. iii. 241:
w)rxh/santo
prw=ta me\n e)n sake/essin e)no/plion, au)=qi de\ ku/klw|
sthsa/menai xoro\n eu)ru/n.
(Homer uses au)=te in this sense, Odyss. xxii. 5; Iliad i. 237); cf. i. 112. The -i- is elided as in Iliad xii. 85, etc. The couplet then connects with 19, 'Why dost thou reject thy lover ... but come in turn when sleep possesses me, but straight art gone when sleep doth disenchain me.'
u(/pnos a)nh=| me Odyss. vii. 289 kai/ me gluku\s u(/pnos a)nh=ken. Cf. Odyss. ix. 333.
teou=s = teu = sou. Dialect, § 2. It is a Boeotian form, Ahrens, Dial. i. p. 223.
u(aki/nqina fu/lla cf. xviii. 39.
e)gw\ d' o(do/n Odyss. vii. 30 e)gw\ d' o(do\n h(gemoneu/sw.

e)c o)/reos, 'on the hills.' Vergil adapts and makes a pretty picture, Ecl. viii. 38:
'Saepibus in nostris parvam te roscida mala--
Dux ego vester eram--vidi cum matre legentem.
Alter ab undecimo tum me iam acceperat annus;
Iam fragilis poteram a terra contingere ramos.'

pau/sasqai sc. e)rw=n. Beware of joining pau/sasqai e)sidw/n. Verbs of ceasing and beginning take the present participle, never the aorist. Tr. 'Having seen thee, from that time onward I cannot even yet cease to love.'
pa| = pw. For the conjunction of ou)de/ pw nu=n, cf. Isocr. 94 b w(/ste mhde/ pw nu=n e)cith/lous ei)=nai ta\s sumfora/s.
ti\n d' ou) me/lei cf. iii. 52.

ei(=s d' o)fqalmo\s e)/pesti cf. Hesiod, Theog. 142 mou=nos d' o)fqalmo\s me/ssw| e)ne/keito metw/pw|: Lucian, )*ena/l. *dia/l. 1 (i. 288) o( o)fqalmo\s e)pipre/pei tw=| metw/pw| ou)de\n e)ndee/steron o(rw=n h)\ ei) du/' h)=san. These passages show that e)pi\ tw=| metw/pw| is to be supplied with e)/pesti, and support that word against u(/pesti (Warton's conject. adopted by Ziegler). Callim. iii. 52 pa=si d' u(p' o)fru\n fa/ea mouno/glhna sa/kei i)/sa tetraboei/w|.
ou)=tos toiou=tos e)w/n, 'but this Cyclops, though he be such, keeps a thousand cattle.'
ou)=tos (MSS. alii, wu(to/s) is contemptuous. 'This fellow whom you despise.'
toiou=tos e)w/n, 'such as I have described.' Demosth. xxv. 64 a)ll' o(/mws toiau=ta pra/ttwn kai\ toiou=tos w)\n e)n a(pa/sais a)ei\ boa=| tai=s e)kklhsi/ais.

ou)/t' e)n qe/rei, k.t.l. Another Homeric ending, of which Theocritus has several in this idyll. Odyss. xii. 75:
ou)de/ pot' ai)/qrh
kei/nou e)/xei korufh\n ou)/t' e)n qe/rei ou)/t' e)n o)pw/rh|.

xeimw=nos a)/krw in the depth of winter. Cf. Soph. Ajax 285:
a)/kras nukto/s, h(ni/x' e(/speroi
lampth=res ou)ke/t' h)=|qon.
Jebb's note ad loc., a)/kra nu/c, a)/kra e(spe/ra, etc., usually mean 'at the fringe of night, evening.' Cf. the adjectives a)kro/nuxos, a)kre/speros (Theocr. xxiv. 77); cf. Aratus 775:
a)/lla d' a)nerxo/menos, tote/ d' a)/krh| nukti\ keleu/wn
h)e/lios (e)re/ei).

tarsoi/ Odyss. ix. 219:
tarsoi\ me\n turw=n bri=qon stei/nonto de\ shkoi\
a)rnw=n h)d' e)ri/fwn.
Verg. Ecl. ii. 21.

w(s ou)/tis, 'as none else.' Ar. Plutus 901:
*x. su\ filo/polis kai\ xrhsto/s; *s. w(s ou)dei/s g' a)nh/r.
ti\n…a)ei/dwn, 'singing thee, my dear sweet-apple, and myself together.'
ti/n, cf. 69, is accusative; vid. Dial. § 2.
a(ma=| (cf. ix. 4): a Doric form for a(/ma. Ahrens, Dial. Dor. pp. 372 and 34.

gluku/malon Sappho, fr. 93:
oi)=on to\ gluku/malon e)reu/qetai a)/krw| e)p' u)/sdw|
a)/kron e)p' a)krota/tw|: lela/qonto de\ malodro/phes
ou) ma\n e)klela/qont' a)ll' ou)k e)du/nant' e)pike/sqai.
nukto\s a)wri/ cf. xxiv. 38. For the genit. cf. ii. 119; Xen. Hellen. ii. 1. 23 h(me/ras o)ye\ h)=n.

lg.l: Inter se similes, vix ut dignoscere possis,
Villosae catulos in summis montibus ursae:

div2.p:
mhnofo/rws, 'crescent-marked,' i. e. with a white crescent mark on the forehead, as Horace describes a calf (Odes iv. 2. 57):
'Fronte curvatos imitatus ignes
Tertium Lunae referentis ortum,
Qua notam duxit, niveus videri,
Cetera fulvus.'
Iliad xxiii. 455; Moschus, Europa 86:
tou= d' h)/toi to\ me\n a)/llo de/mas canqo/trixon e)/sken
ku/klos d' a)rgu/reos me/ssw| ma/rmaire metw/pw|.
The MSS. mannofo/rws would mean 'wearing collars,' but a rare natural beauty is obviously required.

a)fi/keuso = afi/keu. The form is stated by the Scholiast to be Syracusan, but is not known beyond this passage, and cannot be considered certain. This idyll contains a rougher form of dialect than the others: teou=s, l. 25; ti/n, l. 39.

ta\n glauka\n de\ qa/lassan e)/a note the expressive vowel alliteration on the broad open -a-, giving the dull roar of the sea. ('The league long roller thundering on the reef.') Vergil translates the line, but less well than usual: 'Huc ades; insani feriant sine litora fluctus,' Ecl. ix. 43.

o)rexqei=n probably of sound = r(oxqei=n (Odyss. v. 402 r(o/xqei ga me/ga ku=ma poti\ cero
 h)pei/roio), but if so Theocritus has given the word a new sense. In Iliad xxiii. 30 it = to gasp, bo/es o)re/xqeon a)mfi\ sidh/rw|: Eustath. ad loc. mi/mhma/ e)sti traxe/os h)/xou e)n tw=| sfa/zesqai bou=n: *qeo/kritos de\ e)pi\ th=s qa/lasshs ti/qhsi th
 le/cin kaq' o(moio/thta tou= r(o/xqei ga me/ga ku=ma: Arist. Clouds 1368 pw=s oi)/esqe/ mou th
 kardi/an o)rexqei=n; and Oppian, Hal. ii. 583 e)/ndon o)rexqei= kradi/h use it in sense of 'gasping'; vid. Liddell and Scott, s. v.
polude/ndreos *ai)/tna Pind. P. i. 53 *ai)/tnas e)n melamfu/llois korufai=s: ib. 38 nifo/ess' *ai)/tna panetes xio/nos o)cei/as tiqh/na.
ti/s ka tw=nde…e(/loito; 'who would prefer the sea and waves to this for his possession?' Verg. Ecl. ix. 39 'Huc ades, o Galatea; quis est nam ludus in undis?'

e(/loito takes the gen. tw=nde from the idea of preference contained in the verb, Soph. Philoct. 1100:
eu)=te/ ge paro\n fronh=sai
tou= lw/|onos (vel tou= ple/onos) dai/monos ei(/lou to\ ka/kion ai)nei=n.
Cf. bou/lomai h)/.
a)ka/maton pu=r cf. Odyss. xx. 123 e)p' e)sxa/rh| a)ka/maton pu=r.

u(po\ spodw=| cf. Callim. Ep. 44 pu=r u(po\ th=| spodih=|: Odyss. v. 488:
w(s d' o(/te tis dalo\n spodih=| e)ne/kruye melai/nh|
a)grou= e)p' e)sxatih=s, w(=| mh\ pa/ra gei/tones a)/lloi
spe/rma puro\s sw/zwn, i(/na mh/ poqen a)/lloqen au)/h|.

52, 53 kaio/menos de\…a)nexoi/man, 'and fain would I endure that thou shouldst burn my very soul and that one eye.' There is a quaint confusion of the ideas of literal burning and of the fire of love.
teu=s = sou=, Dialect, § 2.
a)nexoi/man vid. on xvi. 67.

w)/moi, o(/ t' ou)k e)/teken, 'alas that I was not born with fins that I might have dived down to thee.' o(/ t' is for o(/ te not o(/ ti: cf. xvi. 9; xviii. 11; xi. 79. This is shown by the fact that whereas there is no certain example of o(/ti elided, we have o(/, o)/te, o(/ti used indifferently in Epic, Iliad xvi. 433:
w)/moi e)gw/n, o(/ te moi *sarphdo/na,…
moi=ra……damh=nai.
Odyss. xix. 543 o)lofurome/nhn o(/ moi ai)eto\s e)/ktane xh=nas. With elision Odyss. viii. 299 gi/gnwskon, o(/ t' ou)ke/ti fukta\ pe/lonto: cf. ib. 78. Similarly Iliad xvi. 35:
glaukh\ de/ se ti/kte qa/lassa
……o(/ti toi no/os e)sti\n a)phnh/s.
Odyss. xxi. 254:
tosso/nde bi/hs e)pideue/es ei)me\n
a)ntiqe/ou )*odush=os, o(/ t' ou) duna/mesqa tanu/ssai
to/con.
Cf. Theocr. xviii. 11: Odyss. xviii. 332:
h)= r(a/ se oi)=nos e)/xei fre/nas,……
……o(\ kai\ metamw/nia ba/zeis.
In Arist. Frogs 22 o(/te is used as often causally:
ou)x u(/bris tau=t' e)sti\…
o(/t' e)gw\ me\n w)\n *dio/nusos…
au)to\s badi/zw.

w(s kate/dun, 'that I might have dived,' Soph. O. T. 1392:
ti/ m' ou) labw\n
e)/kteinas eu)qu/s, w(s e)/deica mh/pote;
Goodwin, M. and T.
kri/na not the lily but the snowdrop, as the naive admission of 58 shows.

60, 61 nu=n ma/n, 'but now,' i. e. as things now are, since I cannot live in the water like a fish I will do the best I can and learn to swim, if I can get any one to teach me. Line 61 seems to be a reminiscence of Odyss. ix. 125:
ou) ga\r *kuklw/pessi ne/es pa/ra miltopa/rh|oi,
ou)d' a)/ndres nhw=n e)/ni te/ktones, oi(/ ke ka/moien
nh=as e)usse/lmous.
The Cyclops had no knowledge of life in or on the sea. A touch of humour is added when we remember that the stranger who
came sailing with his ship to the Cyclops' island after this was Odysseus who found other work than to teach Polyphemus swimming. The reading of 60 is hopelessly uncertain; vid. note crit. memaqeu=mai for memaqh/somai is defended by Meineke who quotes A. Pal. xii. 120 m\axh/somai ou)d' a)perou=mai (= a)perh/somai). But a)perou=mai seems only to be a barbarous middle for a)perw=, and in any case would not be a parallel for this 'second future'; maqeu=mai might be taken for maqh/somai through a hypothetical form maqe/somai (vid. on viii. 91) but then ge is intolerable. None of the proposed conjectures are convincing (masem=mai Ahrens; me maqei=n xrh/ Hartung; mema/qoimi Kreussler). I have written ke ma/qoimi in order to have some translatable word; but did the line end me/ga sou=mai? This is palaeographically nearer to MSS. Then au)= to/ ga must be altered; au)ti/ka Paley; au)to/qi ed. Ant.

e)ce/nqois…kai\ e)cenqoi=sa cf. ii. 113; xxi. 50. The repetition of the verb in the participle expresses a close conjunction of the true action, 'come, and coming straightway forget,' Soph. Elect. 1487 w(s ta/xista ktei=ne kai\ ktanw\n pro/qes tafeu=si: Eurip. Supp. 743 u(/briz', u(bri/zwn t' au)=qis a)ntapw/leto.
a( ma/thr, k.t.l. 'it is my mother only does me wrong, who never said a kind word to you on my behalf.' The words are rather an aside than addressed to Galatea in spite of poti\ ti/n.
ma/thr vid. Odyss. i. 71.
ph/pox' = pw/pote.

poti\ ti/n le/gein pro/s tina differs from le/gein tini/ as 'to address oneself to some one' differs from to 'say to some one'; cf. Odyss. xvi. 151; Theocr. ii. 109; xxx. 25; Isocr. 27 d dhlou=n pro\s u(ma=s.

a)=mar e)p' a)=mar, 'day after day,' A. Pal. ix. 499:
w)= zwh=s a)o/ristos e)n a)nqrw/poisi teleuth\
h)=mar e)p' h)=mar a)ei\ pro\s zo/fon e)rxome/nois.
Cf. xvii. 96; Oppian, Hal. v. 472:
pollai\ d' h)io/nwn
a)gorai\ pe/las h)=mar e)p' h)=mar i(eme/nwn.
Soph. Antig. 340 e)/tos ei)s e)/tos.

fasw=…, 'I will say that my head and feet are throbbing, that she may be sorry.' Fritzsche evolves a wonderful reading out of the variant flasw=: flassw=…nin sfu/sdein, 'I will break her head and feet, and make them throb.' The Greek and the conduct would be equally barbarous, flassw= sfu/sdein being impossible for flassw= sfu/sdonta or w(/ste sfu/sdein.

w)= *ku/klwy *ku/klwy Introd. p. 45; Verg. Ecl. ii. 69 'Ah Corydon! Corydon! quae te dementia cepit!' Like the surge in Idyll iii Polyphemus wearies of singing and receiving no answer; but does not as there cease in mere mortification but turns to practical politics, adding at the same time a hint of successful rivals--as he fancies them in his conceit--to Galatea, hoping thereby to find some weak spot of jealousy; cf. vi. 26.

ai)/k'…ple/kois ai)/ke with optative, Iliad v. 273; vi. 50,
etc. This is not to be confused with the rare Attic use of ei) with opt. + a)/n where the verb and a)/n = the apodosis of a suppressed condition, and the whole of this condition is in turn made subject to the ei), Demosth. De Cor. 190; Isocr. 220 e; Aesch. Agam. 930 ei) pa/nta d' w(\s pra/ssoim' a)\n eu)qarsh\s e)gw/.

ta
 pareoi=san, k.t.l. : cf. vi. 17; xi. 19 ti/ to
 feu/gonta diw/keis; There is no reference to any particular object of pursuit, but the words are proverbial and a current form of expression; cf. Aesch. Agam. 394 e)pei\ diw/kei pai=s potano
 o)/rnin: Hesiod. fr. 209 nh/pios o(\s ta\ e(toi=ma lipw
 a)ne/toima diw/kei: Callim. Epig. 31:
ou(mo\s e)/rws toio/sde: ta\ ga feu/gonta diw/kein
oi)=de ta\ d' e)n me/ssw| kei/mena parpe/tetai.

cit.quote: 'invenies alium, si te hic fastidit, Alexin.'

div2.p:
u(pakou/sw, 'when I answer them'; cf. iii. 24 (vii. 95, note); Odyss. x. 83:
o(/qi poime/na poimh\n
h)pu/ei ei)sela/wn, o( de/ t' e)cela/wn u(pakou/ei.
Arist. Acharn. 405.
dh=lon o(/ te see note on 54.
tis somebody of importance; cf. xxxiv. 30, note.
80, 81 'Thus then it was that Polyphemus tended his love, and got him ease better than by giving gold--to doctors.' The hit at Nicias is obvious, and is clearly enough expressed.
e)poi/mainen cf. Pind. Ol. xi. 9 ta\ me\n a(mete/ra glw=ssa poimai/nein e)qe/lei. Cf. the use of boukolei=n.

r(a=|on de\ dia=g' cf. l. 7. The end of the idyll returns to the expressions of the beginning; cf. notes on ii. 157. r(a=|on dia/gein is the regular expression for 'feeling better,' Xen. Sympos. vii. 5 polu\ a)\n oi)=mai r(a=|on au)tou\s dia/gein; Aeschin. Epist. i. 5 polu\ r(a/|wn e)geno/mhn.

ou(/tw toi. A demonstrative pronoun with toi is used retrospectively at the end of a narrative, with the force of 'such then is the tale you asked for'; cf. Aesch. Agam. 312 toioi/de toi/ moi lampadhfo/rwn no/moi at the end of Clytaemnestra's account of the beacon-signals from Troy.

div1.p: This poem is more akin to xxix, xxx than the others in the collection, though it is written in hexameter measure and a soft Doric, not in lyric metre and Aeolic dialect. Like those it is purely personal, addressed to some nameless boy friend; and while it does not attain to their grace of form and expression exhibits still a delicate fancy and restraint of feeling, a revelation of personal sentiment not unworthy of the poet whose image we saw disguised in Idyll vii and whose songs have an enduring charm. On date, etc. vid. Introd. p. 35.

The dialect is partly Doric, partly Ionic. The superscription in certain MSS. states that it is written in koinh=| )*ia/di, whence most of the editors have substituted Ionic forms for Doric throughout. This is not warranted by the MSS. I have therefore followed Ziegler, Paley, and Ameis in retaining the Dorisms, as they appear in k and in Db (a MS. not used by Ziegler), on the value of which see Introd. p. 48.

div2.p:
h)/luqes, 'hast thou come dear lad with the third night and morn? thou hast come.' Catullus, ix. 3:
'Venistine domum ad tuos Penates
Fratresque unanimos, anumque matrem?
Venisti. o mihi nuntii beati.'
Hiller prints the sentence with a colon, instead of as a question, and writes that 'it is out of place here to take the line as a question, both on account of the de/ following and because the surprised delight of first meeting is now over.' This is just what I imagine is not the case. I picture Theocritus holding the lad before him, hand on either shoulder, looking him in the eyes, and take the whole poem as a first utterance of a delighted friend.
su\n nukti\ kai\ a)oi= = tritai=os in sober parlance. nu\c kai\ a)w/s being simply = 'a full day'; cf. Hesiod, )/*erg. 612 dei=cai d' h)eli/w| de/ka t' h)/mata kui\ de/ka nu/ktas. Cf. Theocr. ii. 86.

e)n h)/mati, 'in a day'; Hesiod, )/*erg. 43:
r(hidi/ws ga/r ken kai\ e)p' h)/mati e)rga/ssaio
w(/ste se/ k' ei)s e)niauto\n e)/xein kai\ a)ergo\n e)o/nta.
Odyss. ii. 284 e)p' h)/mati pa/ntas o)le/sqai.

to/sson e)/m' eu)/franas. The comparison is not logically carried out, but loses thereby nothing in clearness or naturalness. Such difference hast thou made to me by coming as the difference between spring and winter, between the song of nightingale and other birds.

skiera\n d' u(po\ fago/n, 'I have run under thy shadow like some traveller in summer's heat'; cf. Anacreont. xvii. 10:
para\ th\n skih\n *baqu/llou
kaqi/sw: kalo\n to\ de/ndron:
a(pala\s d' e)/seise xai/tas
malakwta/twn kladi/skwn:
para\ d' au)to\ yiquri/zei
phgh\ r(e/ousa peiqou=s:
ti/s a)\n ou)=n o(rw=n pare/lqoi
katagw/gion toiou=to;

o(maloi\ pneu/seian, 'may the loves breathe on us with even breath.' Tibullus, ii. 1. 80 'felix cui placidus leniter adflat Amor'; Ap. Rhod. iii. 936:
ou)de/ se *ku/pris
ou)/t' a)ganoi\ file/ontes e)pipnei/ousin )/*erwtes.

a)oida/ a theme of song. Theognis, 251:
pa=si ga\r oi(=si me/mhle kai\ e)ssome/noisin a)oidh\
e)/ssh| o(mw=s o)/fr' a)\n h)=| gh= te kai\ h)e/lios.
Juvenal, x. 167 'ut declamatio fias'; Propert. i. 15. 24 'Tu quoque uti fieres nobilis historia.' Cf. Theocr. xxiv. 78; Iliad vi. 358:
w(s kai\ o)pi/ssw
a)nqrw/poisi pelw/meq' a)oi/dimoi e)ssome/noisi.

qei/w…gene/sqhn, 'more than men were these twain in days gone by, the one a knight as the Amyclean tongue would say, the other the squire in the speech of Thessaly.' I have taken Meineke's qei/w in preference to Ahrens di/w, since the latter is a merely complimentary term; qei=os is used for one dead who has passed in the ranks of exalted heroes. Cf. vii. 89; x. 41; Arist. Eth. vii. 1. 3 e)pei\ de\ spa/nion kai\ to\ qei=on a)/ndra ei)=nai kaqa/per oi( *la/kwnes ei)w/qasi prosagoreu/ein, oi(\ o(/tan a)gasqw=si sfo/dra tou, sei=os a)nh/r fasi: Epictet. xv. ou(/tw poiw=n *dioge/nhs kai\ (*hrakle/htos a)ci/ws qei=oi/ te h)=san kai\ e)le/gonto.
w(muklai+a/sdwn. Speaking the dialect of Amyclae (o( d' ei)=pe dwria/zwn, Anacreont. x. 6).

ei)/spnhlos…a)i/tas Schol. k e(/teros me\n u(po\ tw=n *lakw/nwn lego/menos ei)/spnhlos, toute/stin e)rasth/s, e(/teros de\ u(po\ tw=n *qessalw=n a)i+/tas, toute/stin e)rw/menos. ei)/spnhlos would seem to be therefore a local word, brought into use by the Alexandrian poets. (Callimachus in Et. M. s. v. me/mbleto d' ei)spnh/lais o(ppo/te kou=ros e)/hn.) Amyclae is a city of Laconia some six miles south of Sparta in the Eurotas valley. Its dialect was Doric (Collitz and Bechtel, Griech. Dial. Inschriften, 4508 sqq.).

to\n d' e(/teron…a)i/tan. The word a)i/tas (deriv. a)i/w, 'to hear,' Vanietcbreve;ek, Etym. Wörterb. i. p. 66) must be taken as a local Thessalian use, though it was brought into literary use by Alcman. A branch of Aeolic was spoken in Thessaly, see Ahrens, Dial. i. § 50. The construction of the line presents a curious example of attraction; we should expect o( d' e(/teros…a)i/tas or o( d' e(/teros…a)i/tan. The nominative is changed to the accusative under the influence both of ei)/poi and the preceding fai/h. There is no instance exactly like this, but we have frequent instances of a parenthetical clause drawing what follows out of its own construction into dependence on the parenthetical words. Aesch. Persae 187:
tou/tw sta/sin tin' w(s e)gw\ 'dokou=n o(ra=n
teu/xein e)n a)llh/laisi
(for e)/teuxon, or for tou/tw| e)do/koun teu/xein); Soph. Trach. 1238 a)nh\r o(/d' w(s e)/oiken ou) ne/mei=n e)moi\ moi=ran: Herodotus, i. 65 (Stein, ad loc.). Here not only what follows but what precedes is drawn into the construction of the parenthesis.
i)/sw| zugw=| cf. xiii. 15, note; Suidas, s. v. filhqei\s to\ lego/menon i)/sw| zugw=|.
*xru/seioi pa/lin, 'then was an age of gold again, for love was returned.'

o(/, 'in that,' see on xi. 54. This seems to have been the reading known to Nicetas, Eugen. vi. 451:
xrusou=n ge/nos pro\s fi/ltron h)=n to\ profqa/san:
o( ga\r filhqei\s a)ntefi/lei meizo/nws.
ou)x oi(=o/n e)sti tou=to xa/lkeion ge/nos:
filou/menon ga\r a)ntifilei=n ou) qe/lei.
Whether so or not, a causal rather than a temporal sentence is required. o(/te could only be temporal after to/te, and o(/ka (MSS.) could hardly be used immediately after to/te (not to/ka). Cf. Bion, xi. 1 o)/lbioi oi( file/ontes e)ph\n i)/son a)ntera/wntai.
geneai=s de\…e)/peita, 'two hundred generations hence.'

a)ne/codon ei)s )*axe/ronta cf. xvii. 120; Vergil, Aen. vi. 425 'irremeabilis unda'; Philetas:
a)trapo\n a(|de/w
h)/nusa th\n ou)/pw tis e)nanti/on h)=lqen o(di/ths,
'the dead know the fame of the living.' Pind. Ol. xiv. 28:
melanoteixe/a nu=n do/mon
*fersefo/nas i)/qi, )*axoi= patri\ kluta\n fe/rois' a)ggeli/an.
Cf. Theognis, 243 sqq.
dia\ sto/matos, 'per ora virom.' Cf. xiv. 27.

u(pe/rteroi, 'but the Heavenly Ones shall order this as they will'; as Sophocles, fr. 515:
ou)k e)/stin
plh\n *di/os ou)dei\s tw=n mello/ntwn tami/as o(/ ti
xrh\ tetele/sqai.
The usual sense of u(pe/rteros ('victorious over') is slightly changed here, and becomes = ku/rios, 'controlling.' There is an approximation to this in Pindar, Pyth. viii. 4 (*asuxi/a boula=n te kai\ pole/mwn e)/xoisa klai=das u(perta/tas, where the genit. is partly dependent on the adjective; cf. the use of u(/perqen: Solon, iv. 4 *palla\s )*aqhnai/h xei=ras u(/perqen e)/xei (sc. th=s po/lews).

yeu/dea cf. ix. 30. 'Pimples on the forehead were a sign of mendacity.' The sense is therefore, 'Praise thee as I will I shall never go beyond the truth.' The word yeu/dea is almost certainly corrupt; one Scholium would seem to indicate yeu/smata--an equally uncertain word--as the original. Another runs yeu/dea: tou\s e)pi\ th=s r(ino\s fuome/nous i)o/nqous *sikeliw=tai yeu/stas e)/legon tou\s yeu/stas diele/gxontes: whence Buecheler, yeusta\s (yeusth\) a)raia/s. But we might keep yeu/stas. They called the pimples 'liars.'

e)/qhkas, 'thou makest all well.' By a general condition the aorist appears not uncommonly for the present to express that the action is done at once; Goodwin. M. and T.; Thucyd. i. 70 h)\n a)/ra sfalw=sin a)ntelpi/santes a)/lla e)plh/rwsan th\n xrei/an.
sqq. The Dioclea was a feast celebrated in Megara to the honour of one Diocles (Arist. Ach. 774), who saved the life of a youth in battle, but fell in saving him.
ei)/ari cf. vii. 97.
e)ridmai/nonti = e)ridmai/nousi. The verb is only here construed with infinitive.

filh/matos a)/kra fe/resqai. To win the prize for a kiss; A. Pal. vi. 118:
a( de\ fe/roito
a)/kra lu/ras, o( d' e)/xoi prw=ta kunagesi/as.
prosma/ch|, 'who presses close lip to lip.' Cf. Mattius, Mimiamb. fr. 4 'labra conserens labris.'

a)ph=nqen for aorist, cf. l. 25 e)/qhkas. Alexis:
o(\s d' a)\n plei=sta gela/sh| kai\ pi/h|
panhguri/sas h(/dist' a)ph=lqen oi)/kade.

e)s mhte/ra Pind. Pyth. viii. 120:
toi=s ou)/te no/stos o(mw=s
e)/palpnos e)n *puqia/di kri/qh
ou)de\ molo/ntwn pa\r mate/r' a)mfi\ ge/lws gluku\s
w)=rsen xa/rin.

o)/lbios. An exclamatory nominative, used without verb; cf. Bion, xiii. 1 (quoted on line 16); Hesiod, Theog. 954:
o)/lbios o(\s me/ga e)/rgon e)n a)qana/toisin a)nu/ssas
nai/ei a)ph/mantos.
Cf. Monro, H. G. § 164.

e)pibwta=|, 'calls aloud to Ganymede, that he may have lips as fine as the Lydian stone.' e)pibwta=| = e)pibohta=|, a form attested by Eustathius (a)po\ tou= bow= gi/netai bohtw= kai\ kata\ kra=sin bwtw=). Ahrens writes e)pibw=tai = e)piboa=tai: but the contraction in the present is not supported by the future and aorist forms in -w (bw/somai, bw=son, Herond. iv. 41).

36, 37 xruso\n o(poi/h| the Lydian stone wherewith moneychangers investigate the gold whether it be true or false. The *ludi/a li/qos is the ba/sanos, 'the touchstone.' Cf. Bacchyl. fr. 22 *ludi/a me\n ga\r li/qos manu/ei xruso/n.
mh\ fau=los e)th/tumw. The word a)rguramoiboi/ gives an idea of exchange, which accounts for the genitive in e)th/tumw (cf. xru/sea xalkei/wn e(kato/mboi' e)nneaboi/wn a)/meibe).

peu/qontai mh/ sc. a)mei/bousi. Cf. Eurip. Heracl. 483:
qe/lw puqe/sqai mh\ 'pi\ toi=s pa/lai kakoi=s
proskei/meno/n ti ph=ma sh\n da/knei fre/na.
Id. Phoeniss. 93:
w(s a)\n prou)ceurenh/sw sti/bon
mh/ tis politw=n e)n tri/bw| fanta/zetai.
Plato, Theaet. 145 b o(/ra mh\ pai/zwn e)/lege. The construction is simply the same as a direct question with mh/: hence the use of mh/ + indic. after verbs of fearing (see Krüger, i. 54. 8. 12).

div1.p: On Theocritus' narrative poems, see Introd. p. 30 sqq. On the date of this (before 280) ib. p. 14; on Nicias, to whom it is dedicated, ib. p. 13.

This idyll differs from the other narratives in being written (like xi, vid. Preface to that idyll) as illustration of a text. 'Not for us alone, poor creatures of a day, was Love born; the heroes knew his power, and even the staunch Heracles loved a lad.' So Propertius, who follows the design of this poem closely (i. 20), addresses it as a warning to his friend Gallus:
'Hoc pro continuo te, Galle, monemus amore,
Id tibi ne vacuo defluat ex animo.
Saepe imprudenti fortuna occurrit amanti:
Crudelis Minuis dixerit Ascanius.'

The story of Hylas was a favourite among poets of the Alexandrian time (vid. Hiller's note here), so much that Vergil exclaims, 'Cui non dictus Hylas' (Georg. iii. 6), and can recall the story by brief allusion, Ecl. vi. 43:
'His adiungit, Hylan nautae quo fonte relictum
Clamassent ut litus Hyla! Hyla! omne sonaret.'

The fable forms an episode in Apollonius Rhodius (i. 1207 sqq.), but is there treated somewhat differently in detail. Yet the resemblances in phrase are such that we cannot deny imitation in one poet of the other. That Theocritus was the earlier will be clear from what has been said in the Introduction.

In style the poem has much of the symmetry which marks the pastorals (vid. Introd. p. 39 sqq.). Thus lines 1-4 fall naturally into two antithetical couplets, and l. 4 falls into two balanced divisions; ll. 10-12 are made parallel in form by the anophora of ou)/t' ei), ou)/t' a)/r', etc.; ll. 43, 44 are made dainty by the analepsis of *no/mfai: 58 and 59 form another antithetical couplet. Catullus has caught the melody in his Marriage of Peleus (64), though with a certain monotony:
'Saxea ut effigies bacchantis, prospicit, eheu,
Prospicit et magnis curarum fluctuat undis,
Non flavo retinens subtilem vertice mitram,
Non contecta levi velatum pectus amictu,
Non tereti strophio lactentis vincta papillas.'

The reminiscences or suggestions of Homer become as is natural more pronounced in this poem; cf. l. 32--Iliad xviii. 558 dai=ta pe/nonto: l. 47--Odyss. xxiv. 410 e)n xeiressi\ fu/onto: ll. 20, 44 a Homeric ending: l. 58--Iliad ii. 462. Homeric epithets are used, l. 36 canqo/s: 49 me/lan u(/dwr: 56 eu)kampe/a to/ca: 13 ai)qalo/en. Yet here as always Theocritus assimilates the old with the new. There is never any mere slavish following,
or mere patchwork (cf. G. Frith, De Theocriti Studiis Homericis, Halle, Saxony, 1876).

div2.p: 'Not for us only, Nicias, was Love born, as we once thought, whose son soever of the gods he was.'
w(s e)dokeu=mes we used to tell one another that only we knew what love really was.
e)/gento cf. i. 88.

w(=| tini Plato, Sympos. 178 b gonei=s ga\r )/*erwtos ou)/t' ei)si\n ou)/te le/gontai u(p' ou)deno\s ou)/te i)diw/tou ou)/te poihtou=, a)ll' (*hsi/odos prw=ton me\n xa/os fhsi\ gene/sqai,
au)ta\r e)/peita
gai=' eu)ru/sternos, pa/ntwn e(/dos a)sfale\s ai)ei/,
h)d' )/*eros.
*parmeni/dhs de\ th\n ge/nesin le/gei o(/ti
prw/tiston me\n )/*erwta qew=n mhti/sato pa/ntwn.

e)sorw=mes = 'do not see the morrow,' not 'do not foresee' as Pind. Nem. vi. 10:
kai/per e)fameri/an ou)k ei)do/tes ou)-
de\ meta\ nu/ktas a)/mme po/tmos
oi(/an tin' e)/graye dramei=n poti\ sta/qman.

w(mfitru/wnos, o( xalkeoka/rdios ui(o/s (o( )*amfitru/wnos). For the repetition of the article when two attributes stand together before the noun cf. tw=n e)k *skapth=s u(/lhs tw=n xruse/wn meta/llwn, Herod. vi. 46; e)n th=| tou= *dio\s th=| megi/sth| e(orth=|, Thucyd. i. 126; e)n th=| a)rxai/a| th=| h(mete/ra| fwnh=|, Plato, Crat. 398 b. Each attribute is hereby brought more into prominence. After the noun the repetition is normal and emphatic, Lysias, x. 15 tou\s no/mous tou\s *so/lwnos tou\s palaiou/s. With a)/llos the repetition is usual, Plato, Rep. i. 328 d ai( a)/llai ai( kata\ to\ sw=ma h(donai/: Lysias, xxiv. 5 to
 a)/llon to
 e)mo
 bi/on, etc.

plokami=da the singular is used collectively; cf. Pseudo-Phocyl. 210 tre/fein plokamhi/da xai/tan: cf. Theocr. vii. 66; xi. 10; viii. 45; xiv. 17; x. 54. The Scholium is delightful, i)/sws ga\r a)\n falakro\s h)=n periebe/blhto de\ a)llotri/as tri/xas th=| kefalh=|.

'And never was parted from him; neither when Day leapt to the zenith, nor when the white team of Dawn rushed upward to the Heaven, nor when the shrill 'brood of chicken looked to their roost.' The homely picture is characteristic of Theocritus, cf. xvi. 93.

ou)de/poka. The negative with -de is very frequent in
Theocritus (cf. ii. 4, 82 kou)de/ ti: xxv. 215; ii. 157). Callimachus seems to have the lines in mind when he writes v. 59:
ou)/poka xwri\s e)/gento
a)lla\ kai\ a)rxai/wn eu)=t' e)pi\ *qespie/wn
h)\ pi\ *korwnei/as h)\ ei)s (*aliarto\n e)lau/nou
……
polla/kis a( dai/mwn nin e(w=| e)pebh/sato di/frw|.

o)/roito me/son, 'rose to its midmost course.' The verb here keeps its true sense (Odyss. iii. 1 h)e/lios d' a)no/rouse: Ap. Rhod. ii. 475 e)p' h)/mati d' h)=mar o)rw/rei ku/nteron): but we find it from this period weakened in meaning so as to be almost = te/tuktai or e)ge/neto, Ap. Rhod. iii. 203; ii. 312 o(/ssa d' o)/rwre qeoi=s fi/lon ou)k e)pikeu/sw: Quint. Smyrn. xiv. 518 po/nos d' a)/prhktos o)rw/rei.
o(rw=|en optative; see Sonnenschein, Syntax, 347. 2.

peponame/nos Dial. § 4; Eurip. Iph. Aul. 208:
to\n a( *qe/tis te/ke kai\
*xei/rwn e)cepo/nasen.
kata\ qumo/n, 'after his own heart,' not 'in heart.'
au)tw=| d' eu)= e(/lkwn. The au)tw=| corresponds in position to au)tw=| in 14--an argument for the soundness of the reading.

eu)= e(/lkwn, 'well yoked in fellowship.' The metaphor is of frequent occurrence, cf. xii. 15; Herond. vi. 12 tau)to/ moi zugo\n tri/beis: Propert. i. 5. 2 'sine nos cursu quo sumus ire pares'; cf. Iliad xiii. 703; Eurip. Medea 242.

au)tw=| is 'dativus commodi'; not 'with him.' Kayser su\n de/ oi( eu)= e(/lkwn from a misunderstanding of this. The line has been much 'emended,' but never without deterioration of the sense, and never with good reason. Dr. Kynaston's interpretation 'drawing well the scale' is not possible. Greek says i)/son e(/lkein or the like in this sense, not eu)= e(/lkein.
e)s a)laqino\n a)/ndr' a)pobai/h cf. xiv. 28; Mosch. Europa 27 a)lla/ moi ei)s a)gaqo\n ma/kares krh/neian o)/neiron: Isocr. 147 a e)peidh\ d' ei)s a)/ndras dokimasqei=en.

meta\ kw=as, 'to fetch the fleece'; cf. xxix. 42; xxiv. 42; Iliad xiii. 247:
meta\ ga\r do/ru xa/lkeon h)/|ei
oi)so/menos.
Ap. Rhod. i. ad init.:
*po/ntoio kata\ sto/ma kai\ dia\ pe/tras
*kuane/as basilh=os e)fhmosu/nh| *peli/ao
xru/seion meta\ kw=as e)u/zugon h)/lasan )*argw/.

Catullus, lxiv. 4:
'Cum lecti iuvenes, Argivae robora pubis,
Auratam optantes Colchis avertere pellem
Ausi sunt vada salsa cita decurrere puppi.'

w(=n o)/felo/s ti cf. Arist. Eccl. 52:
o(rw= prosiou/sas xa(te/ras polla\s pa/nu
gunai=kas o(/ ti pe/r e)st' o)/felos e)n th=| po/lei.
Xen. Hell. v. 3. 6 o(/ ti per o)/felos h)=n tou= strateu/matos.
*midea/tidos from the town Midea; cf. Pind. Ol. vii. 29; Theocr. xxiv. 1; Eurip. Alc. 838 h( *tirunqi/a )*alkmh/nh.
Cf. Pind. Pyth. iv. 335 e)s d' )*iawlko\n e)pei\ kate/ba nauta=n a)/wtos (cf. v. 27) le/cato pa/ntas e)painh/sais )*ia/swn.
kate/baine = 'came down to the coast,' not 'embarked.'

eu)/edron. Most of MSS. (= eu)/zugon according to Eustathius, but e(/dra is not so used). The original seems to have been eu)…on with lacuna; hence eu)/ergon m, eu)/andron b, eu)/edron Vulg., eu)/endron k, Ahrens eu)/andron.

a(/tis simply for a(/ as in Hellenistic Greek; cf. xv. 98; Herond. ii. 26:
ka)f' o(/tw| semnu/nesqe
th\n au)tonomi/an u(me/wn *qalh=s lu/sei.
Callim. ii. 23 pe/tros o(/stis e)ni\ *frugi/h| diero\s li/qos e)sth/riktai.
23, 24 The hiatus in 24 is free from objection; cf. vii. 8. etc. and Index. Hence Jacobs' transposition of the latter half of each line (with dieca/icen) is unnecessary.

baqu\n d' ei)se/drame *fa=sin is parenthetical; cf. xxv. 97; Hesiod, Theog. 157:
pa/ntas a)pokru/ptaske (kai\ e)s fa/os ou)k a)ni/eske),
*gai/hs e)n keuqmw=ni.
Ap. Rhod. iii. 130:
h)e/ min au)/tws
h)/pafes (ou)de\ di/kh| perie/pleo), nh=i+n e)o/nta.
Eurip. Ion 700:
nu=n d' h( me\n e)/rrei sumforai=s (o( d' eu)tuxei=)
polio\n ei)spesou=sa gh=ras.
The MSS. text presents two difficulties:

(1) ai)eto\s w(\s me/ga lai=tma dieca/ice must refer to the passage of the Symplegades, but me/ga lai=tma cannot denote this narrow strait, being a regular phrase for the open expanse of sea (Odyss. iv. 504 fuge/ein me/ga lai=tma qala/sshs), and is therefore not the immediate object of dieca/ice. We are forced therefore to take it with ai)eto\s w(/s, and to translate 'which touched not the Dark Rocks but sped through--and won to Phasis--as the eagle speeds o'er the deep' (Rannow). This is not satisfactory. I believe that w(/s is a mere intruder and has displaced e)s (cf. xiv. 51). Tr. 'but sped through--and won to Phasis--like an eagle into the wide sea: from which time then they stood a hog's back in the strait.' w(s is frequently omitted in brief comparisons, Theognis 1361 nau=s pe/trh| prose/kursas e)mh=s filo/thtos a(martw/n: Herond. i. 8 ti/ su\ qeo\s pro\s a)nqrw/pous (see Holden on Plutarch, Pericles 4). The alteration finds support in the parallel in Ap. Rhod. ii. 330:
h)\n de\ di' au)tw=n
petra/wn po/ntonde so/h pteru/gessi di/htai.

(2) a)f' w(= to/te is an awkward combination of words ('ex quo tempore iam tum'), and without any exact parallel (a)f' w(= t' e)/ti,
Kiessling; kai\ e)/ktote, Hermann; a)/fnw de/ te, Meineke). It was fated that the rocks should be fixed immovably if any ship should pass unscathed.
pe/trai d' ei)s e(/na xw=ron e)pisxedo\n a)llh/lh|sin
nwleme\s e)rri/zwqen,
Ap. Rhod. ii. 606. The rocks were at the entrance of the Euxine; the scene of the adventure was on the coasts of the Kiani (l. 30) in Bithynia. The description of Argo in these lands is therefore only ornamental.

25, 26 'The rising of the Pleiads' when spoken of without further designation means always their heliacal rising, i. e. the season when they first begin to be visible before sunrise after their total disappearance for forty days in early spring. This takes place at the beginning of May, and was reckoned as the commencement of summer (and therefore of the shipping season); cf. Jebb, Oed. Tyr. Appendix, note xv; Hesiod, Works and Days, 383.
'Came to Hellespont with a three days' wind' (a wind blowing for three days).

no/tw| for dative cf. Soph. Antig. 335:
poliou= pe/ran
po/ntou xeimeri/w| no/tw|
xwrei=.
Aesch. Agam. 691 e)/pleuse zefu/rou gi/gantos au)/ra|. The dative is merely instrumental not temporal as Hiller makes it, but the addition of tri/ton a)=mar a)e/nti makes the phrase express succinctly the means by which they came and how long the means was employed. A participle is similarly added to a dative of instrument in Xen. Hell. v. 2. 4 ta/fron w)/rutte…toi=s me\n h(mise/si tw=n stratiwtw=n prokaqhme/nois su\n toi=s o(/plois tw=n tafreuo/ntwn: cf. Thucyd. ii. 90 deciw=| ke/ra| h(goume/nw|. Cf. note on xvii. 127.
*kianw=n cf. Ap. Rhod. i. 1321.
au)/lakas eu)ru/nonti, 'drive a wide furrow.'

kata\ zuga/ 'imago non a iugo cui bina armenta iungebantur, sed a transtris navis in quibus bini sedebant, petita est' (Wuestemann); cf. Ap. Rhod. i. 391:
klhi=das me)\n prw=ta pa/lw| diemoirh/santo,
a)/ndr' e)ntuname/nw doiw\ mi/an.
Tr. 'bench by bench' (thwart by thwart), not 'in pairs.'
deielinoi/ for the adjective of time used personally cf. xxv. 223, note.

polloi\ de\ mi/an, 'many made one common bivouac,' not 'many made each a single'; Ap. Rhod. iii. 1193:
toi\ de\ xameu/nas
e)/ntuon h(/rwes para\ pei/smasin.

sqq. Cf. Ap. Rhod. i. 1207:
to/fra d' (/*ulas xalke/h| su\n ka/lpidi no/sfin o(mi/lou
di/zhto krh/nhs i(ero\n r(o/on, w(/s ke/ oi( u(/dwr
fqai/h a)fussa/menos potido/rpion.
a)stemfei= in Homer an epithet of things only. It is used of e)/rws, A. Pal. v. 267 a)stemfh\s a)do/nhtos e)ne/zetai, ou)de\ mete/sth.

Ap. Rhod. i. 1221:
ai)=ya d' o(/ ge krh/nhn meteki/aqen h(\n kale/ousin
*phga\s a)gxi/guoi perinaie/tai.
Propert. i. 20. 23:
'At comes invicti iuvenis processerat ultra
Raram sepositi quaerere fontis aquam.'

h(me/nw| e)n xw/rw|, 'in a low-lying spot'; 'depressa loca kaqh/mena vel kaqeime/na dicuntur: fluctuat enim scriptura; h(/menos vereor ut recte dicatur xw=ros,' Hermann apud Meineke, p. 289; Achill. Tat. i. 15 ei)/sw tou= tw=n o)ro/fwn stefanw/matos o( leimw\n e)ka/qhto. Briggs compares in Latin 'et sedet ingentem pascens Mevania taurum,' Silius Ital. vi. 647.

43, 44 *nu/mfai…*nu/mfai cf. i. 31; Introd. p. 43: Ap. Rhod. i. 1223:
oi( de/ pou a)/rti
*numfa/wn i(/stanto xoroi/: me/le ga\r sfi/si pa/sais,
o(/ssai kei=s' e)rato\n *nu/mfai r(i/on a)mfene/monto
)/*artemin e)nnuxi/h|sin a)ei\ me/lpesqai a)oidai=s.
And with the whole passage compare the charming description in Propertius, loc. cit.:
'Hic erat Arganthi Pege sub vertice montis
Grata domus Nymphis umida Thyniasin.
Quam supra nullae pendebant debita curae
Roscida desertis poma sub arboribus,
Et circum irriguo surgebant lilia prato
Candida purpureis mixta papaveribus.'
deinai\ qeai\ a)groiw/tais. The line suggests by its rhythm and expression, Odyss. x. 136, of Circe, deinh\ qeo\s au)dh/essa.

e)/ar q' o(ro/wsa cf. iii. 18; xviii. 27 (note). 'Spring's sunshine in her eyes.' Tennyson, In Mem. 39, has:
'And hopes and light regrets that come
Make April of her tender eyes.'
But the English poet takes his image from an English April, the Greek from the Mediterranean skies of spring; for the other image, cf. A. Pal. xii. 156.

Propert. i. 20. 43; Ap. Rhod. i. 1234:
au)ta\r o(/g' w(s ta\ prw=ta r(o/w| e)/ni ka/lpin e)/reisen
le/xris e)pixrimfqei\s
…au)ti/ka d' h(/ge
laio\n me\n kaqu/perqen e)p' au)xe/nos a)/nqeto ph=xun
ku/ssai e)piqu/ousa tere\n sto/ma. deciterh=| de\
a)gkw=n' e)/spase xeiri/, me/sh| d' e)nika/bbale di/nh|.
e)pei=xe potw=| reached 'down to the stream.'
e)n xeri/ a Homeric expression; Odyss. xxiv. 410 e)n xeiressi\ fu/onto. Cf. Soph. O. C. 1113. Then in common use, Plutarch, T. Gracch. vi. 2 e)nefu/onto tai=s xersi/.

h)/ripen, 'as when falls a star.' The aorist is used in similes, as in gnomic phrases, expressing that which has habitually happened. Odyss. xi. 411:
e)/kta su\n ou)lome/nh| a)lo/xw|, oi)=ko/nde kale/ssas,
deipni/ssas, w(/s ti/s te kate/ktane bou=n e)pi\ fa/tnh|.

Shooting stars are regarded as a sign of coming wind. Verg. Georg. i. 365:
'Saepe etiam stellas vento inpendente videbis
Praecipites caelo labi.'
Aratus, 926:
kai\ dia\ nu/kta me/lainan o(/t' a)ste/res a)i+/sswsin
tarfe/a, toi\ d' o)/piqen r(umoi\ u(poleukai/nwntai
deide/xqai kei/nois au)th\n o(do\n e)rxome/noio
pneu/matos: h)\n de\ kai\ a)/lloi e)nanti/oi a)i+/sswsin
a)/lloi d' e)c a)/llwn mere/wn, to/te dh\ pefu/laco
pantoi/wn a)ne/mwn, oi(/ t' a)/kritoi ei)si\ ma/lista
a)/krita de\ pnei/ousin e)p' a)ndra/si tekmai/resqai.
And, as appears from the last passage, of stormy wind. What then is the meaning of koufo/tera poiei=sqe? The editors mostly take it = metewri/zete (koufi/zein) ta\ i(sti/a, a sense which would seem to be supported by Odyss. ii. 420:
*thle/maxos d' e(ta/roisin e)potru/nas e)ke/leusen
o(/plwn a(/ptesqai, k.t.l.
'of spreading sail.' But the comparative is against this: and Schol. k interprets eu)/luta, eu)treph= poiei=te ta\ o(/pla. So Aratus, 418:
oi( d' ei) me/n te pi/qwntai e)nai/sima shmainou/sh| (nukti\)
ai)=ya/ te kou=fa/ te pa/nta kai\ a)/rtia poih/swntai
au)ti/k' e)lafro/teros pe/letai po/nos: ei) de/ ke nhi+\
u(yo/qen e)mplh/ch| deinh\ a)ne/moio qu/ella
au)/tws a)pro/fatos ta\ de\ lai/fea pa/nta tara/ch|
a)/llote me\n kai\ pa/mpan u(po/bruxa nauti/llontai.
i. e. 'If they lighten sail and make all snug aloft.' Cf. Germ. Caesar's trans.:
'Tum mihi spissentur substricto cornua velo
et rigidi emittant flatus per inane rudentes.'
Cicero more loosely, 'omnia caute armamenta locans.' On the evidence of these passages and Schol. k koufo/tera poiei=sqe must mean 'ease' or 'lighten sail,' i. e. prepare not for a good sailing wind but for rough weather. Hence I have rejected pleustiko/s for pneustiko/s (k and Callierges) in the sense of 'gusty.'

ou)=ros is indeed usually a fair wind; but is used of a squall. Pind. Isth. ii. 59:
ou)de/ pote ceni/an ou)=ros e)mpneu/sais
u(pe/steil' i(sti/on a)mfi\ tra/pezan.
pareyu/xonto, 'calmed.' The middle does not occur elsewhere.
peri/ Iliad x. 240 e)/deisen de\ peri\ canqw=| *menela/w|: and in Attic, peri\ tw=| xwri/w| dedio/tes, Thucyd. i. 67. 1; though the genitive is usually used (Krüger, i. 68. 32).
maiwtisti/ to be joined with eu)kampe/a. Cf. ii. 137; xvi. 22 (Hiller).

Iliad xi. 462:
tri\s me\n e)/peit' h)/u+sen o(/son kefalh\ xa/de fwto/s,
tri\s d' a)/i+en i)a/xontos a)rhi+/filos *mene/laos.
Ap. Rhod. i. 1248:
mega/l' e)/stenen: a)mfi\ de\ xw=ron
foi/ta keklhgw/s. mele/h de/ oi( e)/pleto fwnh/.
Propert. i. 20. 48:
'Tum sonitum rapto corpore fecit Hylas.
Cui procul Alcides iterat responsa, sed illi
Nomen ab extremis fontibus aura refert.'
baru/s Odyss. ix. 257 fqo/ggon baru/n, 'loud-voiced.' Cf. Soph. Philoct. 208 (so Ameis from k, Db against baqu/s, MSS. 'ceteri').

-63. I have left the MSS. reading undisturbed, but it is hardly what Theocritus wrote, and certainly not what Schol. k commented on, writing nebrou= fqegcame/nas ou)k h)/rthtai kaq' e(auto\ (i. e. is not genit. absol.) …nebrou= fqegcame/nhs le/wn tis kat' o)/ros h)|sqhme/nos katalipw
 th
 eu)nh
 o)ce/ws a)
 e)pidra/moi. Only the most recent Scholiasts have any note on h)uge/neios. Hence Ziegler ejects 61 and reads nebrou= fqegcame/nas tis e)n ou)/resi, li=s e)sakou/sas…speu/sai ken. (e)/speusen is right, the aorist being used in gnomic sense: the Scholiasts are not particular to maintain a construction in their paraphrases.) 61 is altogether omitted by k. This is the best of many attempts at alteration; cf. Ap. Rhod. i. 1246:
bh= de\ metai+/cas *phge/wn sxedo
 h)u/te tis qh
a)/grios, o(/n r(a/ te gh=rus a)po/proqen i(/keto mh/lwn
limw=| d' ai)qo/menos metani/ssetai.

(*hrakle/hs toiou=tos. After a simile the direct narrative is resumed by a demonstrative w(s, toi=os, etc., standing at the head of the clause. Fritzsche compares Aen. xii. 689:
'Disiecta per agmina Turnus
Sic urbis ruit ad muros.'
In both passages the proper name is placed in a prominent position, as indicating that the characteristics noted are summed
up in the person. Callimachus departs from the rule without due reason, iv. 141:
w(s o(po/t' *ai)tnai/ou o)/reos puri\ tufome/noio
sei/ontai muxa\ pa/nta katoudai/oio gi/gantos
ei)s e(te/rhn *briarh=os e)pwmi/da kinume/noio,…
th=mos e)/gent' a)/rabos sa/keos to/sos eu)ku/kloio.
For the normal order, see Iliad xvii. 679; xvi. 635, 644, etc.
sxe/tlioi see on xii. 34.

a)lw/menos…ou)/rea, 'wandering over hills.' Cf. Soph. Ajax 30 phdw=nta pedi/a: Callim. iii. 193:
o( d' e)nne/a mh=nas e)foi/ta
pai/pala/ te krhmnou/s te kai\ ou)k a)ne/pause diwktu/n.

lg.l: oi)/kou diai/ths ei) path\r trofh\n e)/xoi.

div2.p: nau=s ge/men, k.t.l. So Hermann for the meaningless nau=s me/n of the MSS. Fritzsche with this reading interprets 'navis armamenta habens sublata plena erat sociis navalibus excepto Hercule praesentibus.' But ge/mw and gemi/zw are apparently only used of filling with stores and cargo. I take tw=n pareo/ntwn therefore as neuter = her stores (cf. Homeric xarizome/nh pareo/ntwn), and translate 'The ship was waiting with tackle ready raised (a)/rmena = sails, mast, and running-gear) and was filled with her stores': cf. Odyss. xv. 446 a)ll' o(/te ken dh\ nhu=s plei/h bio/toio ge/nhtai. So Schol. k h( me\n nau=s ta\ siti/a kai\ ta\ prosh/konta fe/rousa, mete/wra tw=n e)no/ntwn. [The last three words should be separated from the rest of the Scholium: mete/wra is a gloss on meta/rsia: tw=n e)no/ntwn a gloss on tw=n pareo/ntwn.]

'But the heroes at midnight cleared away the sails waiting for Heracles.' The sense of the two lines is--the ship was ready for departure with mast and yard-arm raised, and sails clewed up to the yard, all stores on board. But at midnight the crew unbent the sails and postponed their sailing. Cf. Odyss. iii. 10:
oi( d' i)qu\s kata/gonto, i)d' i(sti/a nho\s e)i+/shs
stei=lan a)ei/rantes, th\n d' w(/rmisan e)k d' e)/ban au)toi/.
Putting into shore for a short time they left the ship anchored in the surf, and furled the sails to the yard (cf. Odyss. iv. 785). Disembarking for a long time they would take down sail and mast altogether.

e)ceka/qairon does not occur in this sense elsewhere, but there is no objection to so taking it. (Lucian, Tox. xix, has a)po\ yilh=s th=s kerai/as ple/ontes.) No emendation explains the origin of the corruption if such there be (au)=te kaqh/|roun, Cobet; e)cexa/lainon, Ziegler, = 'unbolted).'

mesonu/ktion (mesonu/ktioi, Cobet, Ziegler, Meineke). The use of the neut. adj. without article in a temporal sense, though rare enough, is proved by Arist. Eccles. 377:
*b. a)ta\r po/qen h(/keis e)teo/n; *x. e)c e)kklhsi/as.
*b. h)/dh le/lutai ga/r; *x. nh\ *di/', o)/rqrion me\n ou)=n.
Cf. Aratus, 1111 dei/elon ei)sela/ontes.

'Went whither his steps led him,' i. e. went at random. Ap. Rhod. i. 1263:
e)s de\ ke/leuqon
th\n qe/en h(=| po/des au)to\n u(pe/kferon a)i+/ssonta.
But Odyss. xv. 555 to\n d' w)=ka probiba/nta po/des fe/ron, it is used simply of walking.

Theocritus' account differs here and onwards from that of Ap. Rhod. The latter makes Heracles' companions leave him unwittingly, and not discover their loss till out at sea. Was it merely from desire to give a different version that Apollonius conceived this fatuous idea? (Ap. Rhod. i. 1273 sqq.) The journey of Heracles on foot to Colchis is not mentioned elsewhere than in Theocritus.

'Thus Hylus was numbered among the gods.' For the partitive genit. used predicatively, cf. Soph. O. C. 38 ti/s d' e)/sq' o( xw=ros; tou= qew=n nomi/zetai; Demosth. xl. 34 tou= au)tou= dh/mou e)moi\ prosagoreu/etai. a)miqrei=tai=a)riqmei=tai.

h(/rwes…h)rw/hse. The jingle seems intentional; and is little better than a pun, and that on the wrong word. It cannot be compared with the superstitious connexion of names with significant words, vid. on xxvi. 26.
(*hrakle/hn. The same form is used by Ap. Rhod. ii. 769 and elsewhere for (*hrakle/a.

div1.p: For circumstances of this poem, see Introd. pp. 30, 31 where the date is placed after 269. The scene is undoubtedly Cos--not Alexandria, since Aeschines is setting out for Egypt (l. 68), nor Sicily, since Hiero would then be the captain under whom he would take service; only in Cos can we find a reasonable meeting-place for a philosopher from Athens (l. 6), an Argive, and a Thessalian horse-dealer. Aeschines is waiting impatiently: to him enters Thyonichus.

div2.p:
xairei=n to
 a)/ndra *quw/nixon. The use of the infinitive and the phrase to
 a)/ndra *quw/nixon makes the sentence somewhat formal and stiff. For the construction cf. Plato, Ion 530 a *to
 )/*iwna xai/rein: po/qen ta\ nu=n h(mi=n e)pidedh/mhkas; the accus. and infin. forms a wish. So in official announcements, Arist. Acharn. 172 tou\s *qra=|kas a)pie/nai pare??nai d' ei)s e)/nhn. [Distinguish this from the use of the infinitive for imperative, to which the nominative is attached when the command is addressed to a person present; Thucyd. v. 9. 5 ta\s pu/las a)noi/cas e)pekqei=n: Aesch. P. V. 712.]

to\n a)/ndra *quw/nixon: simply a formal address. For use of article, i. 105 ta\n *ku/prin, and note, ad loc.; not as Hermann says, 'eccum quem expectabam.' For a)/ndra attached to proper name (in apposition), Soph. O. C. 109 oi)ktei/rat' a)ndro\s *oi)di/pou to/d' a)/qlion ei)/dwlon: Lucret. v. 621 'Democriti quod sancta viri sententia poscit.' Cf. Lobeck on Ajax, 817.

a)lla\ toiau=ta i. e. polla\ xai/rein, Reiske, and *ai)sxi/na|, modern editors. e(/tera toiau=ta and a)/lla toiau=ta = 'the same thing over again.' Plato, Gorgias 481 e pro\s to\n neani/an toiau=ta e(/tera pe/ponqas: ib. 501 b toiau=tai a)/llai pragmatei=ai: but it is doubtful if we could say, (1) kai\ xai=re polla/: (2) su\ de\ kai\ e(/tera toiau=ta pa/sxois. Further the dative *ai)sxi/na| is only conjectural. a)lla/ not a)/lla is given by all MSS., and though after a)lla/ there is great divergence, tu/ is well established, and au)ta/ is given by almost all MSS.

w(s xro/nios cf. xv. 2. For the use of the adjective of time, cf. Eurip. Ion 403 mw=n xro/nios e)lqw/n s' e)ce/plhc' o)rrwdi/a|; Alexis in Lucian, 732 w)= de/spoq' u(gi/ain': w(s xro/nios e)lh/luqas: and note on xxv. 223.

tau=t' a)/ra lepto/s, 'that's why you're so thin.' Cf. Aesch. Pers. 165 tau=ta/ moi diplh= me/rimn' a)/frasto/s e)stin e)n fresi/. But this accusative is commonest with verbs of motion; Plato, Prot. 310 e a)ll' au)ta\ tau=ta kai\ nu=n h(/kw: Soph. O. T. 1005 tou=t' a)fiko/mhn: ib. O. C. 1291 a(\ d' h)=lqon: Babrius, xcv. 28 tau=t' h)=lqon: examples which show the construction to be originally a cognate accusative; cf. Theocr. xv. 8.
Aeschines has ceased to take any care of his appearance; his hair and moustache are long and unkempt; cf. v. 46.
Cf. the description in Arist. Clouds 103 tou\s w)xriw=ntas tou\s a)nupodh/tous le/geis.

'He too I think was in love--with a mess of pottage.' Thyonichus knows that Aeschines' trouble is that he is in love, but does not know what the latest developments have been (cf. l. 11), nor why Aeschines has now summoned him. There is a similar turn of expression in Herond. ii. 80:
e)ra=|s su\ me\n i)/sws *murta/lhs: ou)de\n deino/n.
e)gw\ de\ purw=n.
pai/sdeis…e)/xwn, 'you keep on jesting.' Arist. Frogs 202 ou) mh\ fluarh/seis e)/xwn.
lasw=…manei/s, 'I shall slip into madness.' Aesch. Ctes. § 5 prole/gw u(mi=n o(/ti lh/sete kata\ mikro\n th=s politei/as tisi\ paraxwrhsantes: Herond. ii. 80 kat' ou)=n lh/seis takei=sa.

qri\c a)na\ me/sson, 'a hair divides me from it now.' For qri/c, as smallest measure of division, cf. Xen. Symp. vi. 2 metacu\ tou= u(ma=s le/gein ou)d' a)\n tri/xa mh\ o(/ti le/gein a)/n tis parei/reie.
a)na\ me/sson cf. xxii. 21.

a(suxa=| o)cu/s, 'a little hasty'; cf. h(suxh=| grupo/s, Aelian, N. A. iii. 38; h)=ka me/lan, 'slightly black,' Oppian, C. iii. 39. So Ahrens. The old reading a(/suxos o)cu/s (kept by Fritzsche) = indolent or hasty (by turns), but this suits toiou=tos badly.

'Desiring that things turn out well.' kata\ kairo/n = favourably as pra/ssontas e)n kairw=|, Bacchyl. fr. 3; but there is no parallel to the omission of the infinitive (gene/sqai) here, even though e)qe/lw in late Greek can take a direct accus. after it (cf. xxiii. 22), and the text is almost certainly corrupt (para\ kairo/n, Meineke; kat' a)/kairon, Grever). ? pa/nt' e)qe/lein kata\ kairo/n, as command, 'consent to everything in due season.'

ti/ to\ kaino/n, 'what is the new development?' Lucian,
*nekuom. 457 kaino
 ou)de
 a)lla\ oi(=a kai\ pro\ tou=: Soph. O. C. 722 ti/ d' e)sti
 w)= pai= kaino/n;
qhla/zonta cf. iii. 16. This reversal of the usual meaning occurs first in Aristotle, H. A. vi. 23. 7; cf. superscrip. of A. Pal. vii. 623 ei)=s pai=da…masto\n qhla/zonta.
teto/rwn e)te/wn, 'four years old.' For the genitive cf. Plato, Laws 721 a gamei=n dei= e)peida\n e)tw=n h)=| tis tria/konta mexri\ e)tw=n le': Krüger, i. 47. 8.

sxedo\n w(s a)po\ lanw=, 'fresh as from the press' (Paley): Nonnus, xix. 131 lhnou= oi)=non e)/ti pnei/onta: 'ferme tam copiose praebens quam si vindemiae tempus esset' (Briggs); but the other is the better sense.

bolbo\s ktei\s koxli/as. The singular is used collectively when speaking of natural products; cf. vii. 66; x. 54; Odyss. xiii. 409 ai( de\ ne/montai e)/sqousai ba/lanon menoeike/a: Ib. x. 241 toi=si de\ *ki/rkh pa/r' r(' a)/kulon ba/lano/n t' e)/balen. So Callim. vi. 27 e)n pi/tus, e)n mega/lai ptele/ai e)/san. bolbo/s tis koxli/as, best MSS., which Hermann once defended--'tis dicit ut aliquam multos significet.' Six (inferior) MSS. omit the tis altogether: whence we might regard the word as a mere attempt to fill up the metre, and by simple dittography write *b*o*l*b*i*c*k*o*c (bolbi/skos, dimin. of bolbo/s). The text is Wordsworth's correction now generally adopted; cf. Alexis in Athenaeus, 63 f pi/nnas ka/rabon bolbou\s koxli/as: id. Athenaeus, 356 f:
fe/rwn pa/reimi kh/rukas kte/nas
bolbou\s me/gan te poulu/poun, i)xqu=s q' a(drou/s.
[A menu in A. Pal. xi. 35 includes kra/mbh, ta/rixos, bolbi/skoi, h(pa/tion, xoirei=on, w)|o/n.]
e)ch|re/qh, 'were served,' 'prompta sunt.' Cf. Arist. Pax 1145 tw=n te su/kwn e)/cele (Fritzsche).
proi+o/ntos sc. tou= po/tou.
e)pixei=sqai cf. ii. 152.
w(=tinos cf. ii. 151 e)/rwtos, 'to drink to each one's fancy.'

e)/dei mo/non w(=tinos ei)pei=n sc. e)qe/loi. For ellipse of verb in dependent question cf. xii. 37; xxv. 64; A. Pal. v. 130:
w)= yuxh\ fle/cei se: to\ d' e)k ti/nos h)\ po/te kai\ pw=s
ou)k oi)=da: gnw/sh|, du/smore, tufome/nh.
a( d' ou)de/n sc. e)fqe/gcato. a( d' is Cynisca.

'Can't you speak; you saw the wolf,' cried one in jest, 'how clever,' she said, and blushed red. According to a well known superstition if a wolf saw a man before the man saw the wolf, the man became dumb. It is not related what happened to the wolf in the opposite case. Verg. Ecl. ix. 53:
'vox quoque Moerim
Iam fugit ipsa: lupi Moerim videre priores.'
Hence lu/kon ei)=des cannot be taken as a question; 'Have you seen a wolf?' since to be seen, not to see, caused dumbness, but--you saw the wolf you know, so you can still speak. (Cf. Plato, Rep. 336 d kai/ moi dokw= ei) mh\ pro/teros e(wra/kh au)to\n [sc. Thrasymachus] h)\ e)kei=nos e)me/, a)/fwnos a)\n gene/sqai.)
e)/sti *lu/kos. The words are to be assigned to Aeschines speaking to Thyonichus: not to the companion who made the unlucky jest at the drinking-bout (Hermann, Opusc. v. 96).
*lu/kos, *lu/kos the repetition gives bitterness to the utterance; cf. 47. It is Wolf, Wolf if you please.
to\n klu/menon 'ironice dicit: nobilem illum et praeclarum amorem' (Meineke).
kateta/keto cf. xi. 14. e)/rwta is cognate accus.
tou/tw depends on e)/rwta.
'And this came once whispered (a(suxa=| ) in my ears, but I sought not out the truth.'

di' w)to/s cf. xii. 20 dia\ sto/matos: Eurip. Androm. 95 dia\ glw/sshs e)/xein: Soph. O. T. 1386:
ei) th=s a)kouou/shs e)/t' h)=n
phgh=s di' w)/twn fragmo/s.

ou(tw=s not 'to this effect'; but with a(suxa=|, 'just softly whispered.' ou(/tw(s) with an adjective or adverb gives a sense of indifference and carelessness, 'just.' Vid. Rehdantz, Neun Philipp. Reden, Index, s. v.; and cf. e)n diatribh=| ou(/tws i)di/a|, Demos. xxi. 71; Plato, Symp. 176 e a)ll' ou)/tw pi/nontas pro\s h(donh/n: Gorgias 503 d i)/dwmen dh\ ou(twsi\n a)tre/ma skopou/menoi.
ma/tan ei)s a)/ndra geneiw=n cf. x. 40 w)/moi tw= pw/gwnos o(\n a)liqi/ws a)ne/fusa. For ei)s a)/ndra see note on xiii. 15.

'Then he of Larisa began to sing "My Wolf," from the beginning, some Thessalian song, the clumsy fool.' to\n e)mo\n *l??kon is to be taken as the beginning of the song, whether the actual words of a popular ditty, or parodied and suited to an old tune (me/lisma). (So Ziegler, after Gräfe.)

*qessaliko/n…me/lisma is then accus. in apposition to a)=|den to
 e)mo
 *lu/kon. Others make me/lisma direct accus. after a)=|den and *lu/kon as accus. governed by the verbal equivalent a)=|de me/lisma: as Soph. Elect. 122 ti/n' a)ei\ ta/keis oi)mwga
 )*agame/mnona; etc.; but to
 e)mo/n has then to be awkwardly interpreted 'meum Lycum' = 'infestissimum mihi.'
kakai\ fre/nes in apposition to o( *larisai=os. Cf. Aeschrio (Bergk) lo/gwn ti paipa/lhma kai\ kakh\ glw=ssa.

e)piqumh/sasa…e)/klaie. Although the action of the two verbs is really contemporaneous, the aorist participle is used as expressing the reason and motive felt before the 'weeping' began. Similarly to/de moi xa/risai a)pokrina/menos, Plato, Gorg. 516 b. The answer must be given before it can be said that the speaker has done the favour, although the granting of the favour and giving of the answer are one and the same action.

i)/sais. The Attic 3rd plural of oi)=da--i)/sasi--(Doric i)/santi, Theocr. xv. 64) is from a 1st person singular, i)/sami. i)/sais--2nd person sing.--shows the Aeolic -ais for -a|s (mai=s or lai=s = lh=|s, Sappho, i. 19); vid. Ahrens, Dial. i. p. 138; ii. p. 312.
34, 35 For the sake of Aeschines' gallantry it would be pleasant to take Paley's view that Thyonichus struck the Thessalian, not Cynisca: but this leads to a hopeless change of persons.

a)/llan sc. plhgh/n. A common ellipse; Aesch. Agam. 1384:
pai/w de/ nin di/s:…
…kai\ peptwko/ti
tri/thn e)pendi/dwmi.
Herond. iii. 77:
ko/sas, ko/sas (= po/sas)
*la/mpriske, li/ssomai me/lleis e)/s meu forh=sai.
Cf. xv. 95; xviii. 11. We may distinguish three classes of this ellipse of noun.

(a) The adjective has completely passed into substantival use, so that it can be used in any context, e. g. a)/kratos (sc. oi)=nos), e)p' a)mfote/rois (sc. posi/), traferh=| (gh=|), u(grh/ (qa/lassa), th\n au)lei/an (qu/ran), xv. 43.

(b) The noun is suggested by the verb and would usually be cognate accus.: kairi/an, a)/llhn plh/ssw (plhgh/n), polu\n e)/pinon (oi)=non), w(s baqu\n e)koimh/qhs (u(/pnon) Lucian, i. 293; Arist. Frogs 191.

(c) No definite noun could be supplied; the adjective (usually feminine) has become a fixed adverbial expression, a)/llhn kai\ a)/llhn a)poble/pontos ei)s h(ma=s, Plato, Euthyd. 273 b kata\ prw/tas, e)k prw/ths, e)k kainh=s (anew): Iliad ii. 379 e)/s ge mi/an bouleu/somen.
qa=sson cf. xv. 29. e)mo\n kako/n. So in xv. 10 Praxinoe dubs her husband fqonero\n kako/n.

A. Pal. v. 274 oi)xo/menos d' a)/llhn u(poko/lpios eu)qu\s e(li/ceis. For u(poko/lpios (an Alexandrian word) = u(po\ ko/lpw|, cf. diapo/ntios (xiv. 55), u(perou/rion (xxiv. 95), prodei/elos (xxv. 223), u(podei/elos (Aratus, 118), u(poka/rdion (xi. 15), u(pwrofi/oisi (xiv. 39), a)paulo/sunos, A. Pal. vi. 221 (Leonidas) = a)po\ th=s au)lh=s: paristi/dios = para\ to\n i(sto/n, A. Pal. vii. 726.
i)oi=sa qa/lpe, 'go and cherish'; cf. i. 113.
'For him thy tears fall large as apples.'

r(e/onti = r(e/ousi: for plural cf. ii. 109; iv. 23, etc. Schol. k tw=| *lu/kw| ta\ r(e/onta/ sou da/krua mh=la pi/ptei, toute/sti e)/rws kai\ e)piqumi/a, apparently taking mh=la as = tokens of love. This is in the highest degree artificial, and we can only understand it to mean large round drops of tears; cf. Megara, 56:
ta\ de/ oi( qalerw/tera da/krua mh/lwn
ko/lpon e)s i(mero/enta kata\ blefa/rwn e)xe/onto.
The clause th/nw|…r(e/onti, put without conjunction paratactically with preceding, is really causal; 'go and cherish another; since it is for him that thy tears flow.' Hence we can dispense with the conjectures tw=| nu=n…r(e/onti, Hiller, and th/nw|…r(eo/ntwn, C. Hartung.
bi/on = bi/oton, Aratus 111 kai\ bi/on ou)/pw nh=es a)po/proqen h)gi/neskon.
w)kute/ra. The sentence follows irregularly on the simile, but with greater liveliness and vividness than would be given by w(s th/na: cf. the structure of x. 31; xii. 8; ix. 35.

'A fable runs: the bull dashed through the forest'; vid. loc. cit. The Scholiast tries to explain *ke/ntauros, saying paroimi/a e)sti\ dia\ to\ tou\s *kentau/rous u(/lhs e)pilambanome/nous a)lh/ptous ei)=nai,
but ai)=nos is particularly used of animal fables, Hesiod, Works and Days, 200; Archiloch. 89. The image of a bull breaking away through the forest is graphic; cf. Soph. O. T. 476:
foita=| ga\r u(p' a)gri/an
u(/lan a)na/ t' a)/ntra kai\
pe/tras i)so/tauros,
me/leos mele/w| podi\ xhreu/wn.
cf. A. Pal. vi. 255 tau/rou…a)timage/lou: ib. vi. 217 a)n' u(lh=en d' w)ku\s e)/qunen o)/ros: Babrius 95:
th\n de\ fu/za deilai/hn
qu/rhs katiqu\s h)=gen ei)s me/sas u(/las.
[e)/ba ta/xa is palaeographically more probable than Meineke's e)/ba poka/. Some copyist took ta/xa in its late sense = a)/n, and wrote e)/ba ta/xa (ken)].
ei)/kati sc. h(me/rai as is shown by sa/meron in 45. Aeschines counts the days by groups marked by subsequent events: 'twenty days up to then--then eight till I--,' and so on.
poti/qei du/o = pro/sqes du/o h(me/ras: so xxiv. 36 a)/nsta for a)na/sthqi, but vid. Ahrens, Dial. ii. p. 314.

'And she knows not even if I be shorn like any Thracian'; cf. l. 4. The Thracians as a barbarian tribe wore their hair long and ragged, Lucian, Tox. 51 a)lla\ kai\ tou=to ei)/kasto au)toi=s kai\ a)pekeka/rkei th=s ko/mhs o(po/son ei)ko\s h)=n e)la/ttw koma=n to\n )*alano\n tou= *skuqou=. (This with Ziegler's text keeping ou)d' ei) and oi)=de of the MSS. and deleting stop at ke/karmai.) Ahrens takes ou)d' ei) = ou)de/, but it is only so used after a preceding negative, vid. Arist. Vesp. 352 kou)k e)/stin o)ph=s ou)d' ei) se/rfw| diadu=nai.
a)p' a)lla/lwn (e)sme/n), 'since we are parted.'
*lu/kos nu=n pa/nta, 'Lycus is everything to her'; Demosth. De Cor. § 43 fi/lon eu)erge/thn swth=ra to\n *fi/lippon h(gou=nto: pa/nt' e)kei=nos h)=n au)toi=s.
a)nw=|ktai, sc. to\ dw=ma.

The Megarians, sending to Delphi to inquire which was the most noble city in Greece, received the answer, Argos was the best soil, Thrace was supreme for its horses, Sparta for her women, Syracuse for men; but
u(mei=s w)= *megarei=s ou)/te tri/toi ou)/te te/tartoi,
ou)/te duwde/katoi, ou)/t' e)n lo/gw| ou)/t' e)n a)riqmw=|.
Hence the expression became a proverb, Callim. Ep. xxv:
th=s de\ talai/nhs
nu/mfhs w(s *megare/wn ou) lo/gos ou)d' a)riqmo/s.
nu=n de\ po/qen; sc. a)poste/rcw: 'but now how I am to,' Demosth. De Cor. 47 a)ll' ou)k e)/sti tau=ta: po/qen; pollou= ge kai\ dei=: Id. De Fals. Leg. 34.

mu=s, fanti\ *quw/nixe, geu/meqa pi/ssas, 'we have tasted pitch like the mouse in the adage'; cf. Herond. pe/ponqa pro\s *qalh=tos o(/ssa kh)m pi/soh| mu=s: Nicet. Eugen. iv. 409:
a(li/sketai ga\r toi=s e)/rwtos di/ktuois
w(s mu=s pro\s u(gra=s e)mpesw\n pi/sshs xu/tron.
For omission of w(s cf. note on xiii. 24. For the parenthetic use of fanti/ (fasi/), Lucian, *nekuom. § 4 e)lelh/qein d' e)mauto\n ei)s au)to/, fasi/, to\ pu=r e)k tou= kapnou= biazo/menos and often.

geu/meqa. Meineke makes this a perfect without reduplication, but none of his examples are above suspicion. On such perfects as they are without reduplication vid. Monro, Hom. Gram. § 23. 4. Still less probable is the view that it is present contracted for geuo/meqa: vid. on xxx. 32. Paley regards it as an Epic aorist from e)geu/mhn, the only objection to which is that the syncopated aorist seems to be used only in 3rd person or participle (lu^to or lu=to, plh=to, xu/to, xu/nto, Iliad iv. 526: a)/mpnuto, e)/mpnuto, e)/leipto, Ap. Rhod. i. 45: a)pamei/pto, Nonnus: le/kto, blh/menos, klu/menos). If this cannot be admitted read mu=s fanti\ *quw/nixe geu=ma/ ti pi/sshs (Briggs geu=m' e)/ti pi/sshs), omitting the verb, as not uncommonly in proverbs, e.g. glau=k' ei)s )*aqh/nas.
diapo/ntios see on 37. For the adject. instead of an adverbial expression of space cf. v. 115; xxiv. 93; e)/ptaq' u(pourani/h, Aratus, 134.
o(malo\s de/ tis 'unus e grege.'

o( stratiw/tas, 'I, the trooper.' 'Aliquotiens Theocr. cum quis de se ipso atque officio suo praedicat ita ponit articulum ut aut cum conscientia quadam dignitatis suae ea persona quae verba facit loqui videatur, aut id quod redit eodem officium ipsius notum significetur' (Fritzsche); cf. iii. 19. So xv. 129.
kata\ nou=n teo/n 'e sententia tua'; cf. kata\ qumo/n, xiii. 14.
dokei= w(/ste. The w(/ste is redundant; cf. Isocr. 36 b labw\n e)cousi/an w(/ste poiei=n.

oi(=os a)/ristos, 'the best that could be'; Plato, Apol. 23 a pollai\…a)pe/xqeiai/ moi gego/nasi kai\ oi(=ai xalepw/tatai. So with attraction Plato, Symp. 220 b o)/ntos pa/gou oi(/ou deinota/tou, e. g. toiou/tou oi(=os deino/tato/s e)sti.

The division of the line is very uncertain. I assign it all to Aeschines and translate 'and what must a man be like in other ways to be the best master to a free man?' It would be more usual to have the article in this construction, but cf. Plato, Theaet. 149 d poi/an xrh\ poi/w| a)ndri\ sunou=san w(s a)ri/stous pai=das ti/ktein. With article Plato, Rep. 332 d h( ti/si ti/ a)podidou=sa te/xnh dikaiosu/nh a)\n kaloi=to; (Ast, Lex. Plat. ii. p. 394).
to\n ou) file/onta not mh/, although the participle is generic, since ou) file/onta = to\n misou=nta, and the ou) connects closely with the verb, but vid. Introd. p. 35.
basilh='. For the elision cf. basile/(a), Pind. P. iv. 110; )*odush=(a), Odyss. v. 336.
ai)tei=n de\ dei= ou)k e)pi\ panti/, 'but you must not ask on every occasion'; Theognis, 325 ei) tis…e)pi\ panti\ xolw=|to. Another reservation of praise as in l. 62.
lw=pos, 'a military cloak.'

e)p' a)mfote/rois sc. posi/, vid. l. 35. Tyrtaeus, x. 31:
a)lla/ tis eu) diaba\s mene/tw posi\n a)mfote/roisi
sthrixqei\s e)pi\ ga=s, xeilos o)dou=si dakw/n.
a(= ta/xos, 'with all speed'; cf. ii. 36; Pind. Ol. vi. 23. For ellipse of verb cf. xv. 147.

a)po\ krota/fwn cf. xvi. 49. a)po/ expresses properly 'looked at from,' 'judging from.' Theophrastus, Char. xxxi. (xxviii.) kai\
ga\r ei)dexqh/s tis a)po\ tou= prosw/pou e)sti/: Lucian, Dial. Mort. x. 8 semno\s a)po\ tou= sxh/matos. Not 'from the brows down,' since pelo/mesqa = e)sme/n not gigno/meqa.
e(/rpei cf. Arist. Equit. 520 a(/ma tai=s poliai=s katiou/sais. Probably a personal reference on Theocritus' part, vid. Introd. p. 34.
a(=s = e(/ws.
xlwro/n Statius, Silvae i. 2. 276 'Longe viridis sic flore iuventae perdurent vultus'; Horace, Ep. xiii. 4 'genua virent.'

div1.p: See Introduction, pp. 30, 31. Two Syracusan ladies--Gorgo and Praxinoa--resident in Alexandria go out to see the Adonis festival, and hear the dirge over Adonis sung. The greater part of the idyll is a racy sketch of their conversation, and their adventures by the way: the Adonis song affords the occasion of the piece, but is not to be regarded as its essential part.
Matthew Arnold's essay on the poem and excellent translation should be read (Essays on Criticism, 1st series).

According to the Scholiasts, Theocritus founded the sketch on a mime of Sophron--ta\ )/*isqmia qa/menai (qew/menai) or )*isqmia/zousai (Ahrens, Dial. Dor. p. 469). Among the fragments preserved are a few which show resemblance to Theocritus--fe/r' w)= to\n dri/fon (cf. v. 2); fe/re to\ qau/maktron ka)p' i)qu\s i)/wmes (cf. v. 39, etc.); e)/ti me/qen a( kardi/a pa/qh| (v. 4); cf. Preface to xviii. 2. There are sundry parallels between the idyll and the first and fourth mimes of Herondas. In style and prosody the poem approaches more nearly than the other idylls to common speech. Note especially the large number of cases in which, as in Attic comedy, a vowel is left short before a mute and liquid; ll. 2, 3, 14, 16, 19, 40, 43, 53, 78, etc.

div2.p: e)/ndoi *pracino/a, 'Is Praxinoa at home?' Arist. Acharn. 395 pai= pai=: ti/s ou)=tos; e)/ndon e)/st' *eu)ripi/dhs; The words may be taken as addressed to the servant; then Praxinoa, overhearing, answers herself; or Gorgo, not standing on ceremony, opens the door and looks in without knocking.
w(s xro/nw|, 'what an age since you have been here'; Eurip. Phoeniss. 305 xro/nw| so\n o)/mma muri/ais e)n a(me/rais prosei=don.
o(/rh di/fron, 'see to a chair for her.' Cf. Soph. Ajax 1165.
poti/kranon a cushion = proskefa/laion.

w)\ ta=s a)lema/tw, 'this gadabout spirit' (Mat. Arnold); cf. iv. 40. h)le/matos = 'vain,' 'trifling'; almost = h)li/qios: cf. Timo, xv (Brunck):
oi( de/ min h)u+/te glau=ka pe/ri spi/zai teratou=nto
h)le/maton deiknu/ntes o(qou/neken o)xloare/skhs.
ou) me/ga prh=gma ta/las: ti/ platu/neai h)li/qios w(/s;
'ad me certe quod attinet non video quid aptius reponi possit et minori cum mutatione quam a)lema/tw ut illa quae haec dicit
stultitiae seipsam accuset quod, dum pompae nihil ad se pertinentis spectatrix esse vult, stulta curiositate inducta in discrimen vitae venerit' (Stephanus); the emendation was made before this by Scaliger.
'I've scarcely got here alive from all the crowd and all the carriages.' The genitives depend on e)sw/qhn, cf. Eurip. Alc. 770 kakw=n ga\r muri/wn e)rru/eto.
krhpi=des…xlamu/des, 'riding boots and uniforms' (? 'gentlemen in khaki').

e(kasta/tw o(/sson, 'and you live such a dreadful way off.' The construction is explained by such phrases as qaumasto\n o(/son, etc.; the superlative being found also in Lucian, Tox. xii. fili/as plei=ston o(/son a)pode/ontas: cf. i. 45. ss and w can be easily confused both in uncial and minuscule, as can em and on. e(kastate/rw is read by Hermann, but is equally a vox nihili. Greek forms double superlative as kudi/statos: more commonly double comparatives, a)ssote/rw, xeiro/teros, a)meino/teros: but a comparative termination added to a superlative, as e(kastate/rw would be, is unparalleled. Meineke read e(kaste/rw w)= me/l(e). The first mime of Herondas opens in much the same way; see especially v. 10 sqq.:
h)/dh ga/r ei)si pe/nte kou doke/w mh=nes
e)c ou(= se\ *gulli\s ou)d' o)/nar ma\ ta\s *moi/ras
pro\s th\n qu/rhn e)lqou=san ei)=de/ tis tau/thn.
*makrh\n a)poike/w te/knon e)n de\ tai=s lau/rais
o( phlo\s a)/xris i)gnu/wn prose/sthken:
e)gw\ de\ drai/nw mui=' o(/son.

tau=ta vid. xiv. 3, note; where the quoted examples show that Meineke is incorrect in stating that tau=ta, used to mean 'propterea,' is always accompanied by a particle a)/ra, dh/, toi, etc. Tr. 'That is why that intractable creature came to the ends of the earth and took this rat-hole--house indeed!--to prevent us being neighbours.'
See Liddell and Scott on parh/oros.

o(/pws, k.t.l. explains the tau=ta. Meineke puts a colon at th=nos and explains, 'that's the fault of that fellow--'; a construction by no means justified by Eurip. And. 168 ou)/k e)sq' (/*ektwr ta/de: Menand. 354 tou=q' e(tai=ro/s e)stin ou(/tws. (In Soph. O. T. 1329 a comma not a full stop stands at h)=n: see Jebb.)
pot' e)/rin, 'out of spite.'
fqonero\n kako/n, 'the jealous brute.'
ai)e\n o(moi=os, 'always the same.'
