ta\n po/tnian Persephone. ma\ th\n (/*aidew kou/rhn, Herond. i. 32.
a)pfu=s ma\n th=nos, 'well that daddy the other day--we call everything "the other day"--was a-buying soap and rouge in the bazaar, and came back with salt, the overgrown blunderer.'

le/gomes de\ pro/an qhn, k.t.l. is to be taken as a comment of the constant use of the word pro/an (pra=n) in common speech. Theocritus himself uses it thirteen times (cf. use of kalo/s, note on viii. 187). pa/nta is awkward; but it should probably be
taken as direct object with pro/an as 'tertiary predicate,' not as an ellipse of ei)=nai (le/gomes de\ proaqrei=n pa/nta, Seidler, is ingenious but not necessary; 'we told him to be very careful').
a)po\ skana=s cf. Theophr. Char. 18 e)c a)gora=s o)ywnh/sas ta\ kre/a.
a)gora/sdwn probably represents h)go/raze = 'tried to buy.' Herod. i. 69 pe/myantes e)s *sa/rdis xruso\n w)ne/onto, k.t.l.
kuna/das (kuna/s) : dog's hair, substantival; vid. Index, Adjectives.
a(/pan r(u/pon, 'mere filth.' a(/pan, adverbial; cf. iii. 18. note.
e)/rgon e)p' e)/rgw| in apposition to sentence; 'trouble on trouble.' Cf. xxv. 94; Quint. Smyr. v. 602 e)pi\ pe/nqei+ pe/nqos.
ba=mes = bw=men, through the form ba/omen.
e)s…*ptolemai/w sc. au)la/n: cf. xiii. 11.

to\n )/*adwnin. The festival commemorated the untimely death of Adonis and the grief of Aphrodite. Figures of the two were exhibited in costly work, and a dirge sung by the popular singer of the day. How far any religious significance which the festival may once have had gave way to mere holiday making, and courtly flattery can best be judged by this idyll. Nor is there more depth in Bion's Epit. Adon., written to suit a similar occasion. The admission of Musaeus is frank, that the festival of Adonis and Cypris was an opportunity eagerly seized not for worship but for flirting. Hero and Leander, 52:
o(/ph| fa/tis e)sti\n e(orth=s
ou) to/son a)qana/toisin a)/gein speu/dousi quhla\s
o(/sson a)geirome/nwn dia\ ka/llea parqenika/wn.
w(=n i)/des, k.t.l. : see note on ii. 82. The aorists are to be taken as gnomic. The expression is obviously proverbially from the use of the masculine and the generic mh/ in tw=| mh\ i)do/nti.
w(=n. The first w(=n is genit. by attraction; the second depends on ei(=pes ('tell of'), cf. Odyss. xi. 174 ei)pe\ de/ moi patro/s te kai\ ui(e/os. Tr. 'The sights you see are tales to tell another.'
w(/ra cf. Arist. Eccl. 30 w(/ra badi/zein.
(The distribution of the verses between the two speakers is here very uncertain. I have followed Hiller, Ziegler, and Paley.)

a)ergoi=s, 'idle folks have always holiday.' Praxinoa does not fall in at once with Gorgo's invitation, and puts her off with excuses embodied in proverbial wisdom; in l. 27 she suddenly changes her mind and agrees to go.

'Eunoa, take up the spinning and put it down again out there if you dare--a nice soft bed for the cats--you lazy good-for-nothing.' So Hermann (Opusc. v), giving a capital sense. It is, however, also possible to make gale/ai a term of reproach addressed to Eunoa: 'these lazy cats are always asleep.' Cf. Herond. vii. 4:
tai=s gunaici\n ou) qh/seis th\n me/zon' e)/cw sani/da
*drimu/l'; au)= fwne/w pa/lin kaqeu/deis;
The former explanation is preferable. na=ma (MSS.) is merely a false Doric form of nh=ma: it could not be taken as = water for washing.
sma=ma, 'soap' (not in a cake but in some kind of paste).

mh\ dh\ polu\ a)/plhste I have left this--the reading of k (mh\ de/, p)--believing that the exceedingly harsh scansion is intended to bring the verse near to the level of common speech. Herondas affords parallels, e. g. v. 7 to\ me\nai(=ma: ib. 9 moi au)to/n (?): vi. 29 pro/sqen h)\ au)th/: ii. 53 h)\ o(/rous (spondee). Cf. next note.

pau=e. o(koi=a. The hiatus is justified by the pause; and is perhaps in imitation of colloquial speech; but cf. Odyss. xxiv. 351 *zeu= pa/ter h)= r(a e)/t' e)ste/: ib. x. 536 mhde\ e)a=n: A. Pal. ix. 70 pau=e: e)pei/ se me/nei kai\ kato/pin da/krua.
'That's as good a wash as the gods allow.'
toiau=ta is cognate accusative.

kla/|c (= klei/s), 'where's the key of the big chest?' For the ellipse cf. Herond. iii. 60 kou= *ko/kkalos kou= *fi/llos; Throughout this idyll the conversation is seldom uninterrupted for more than a few lines: there are frequent intervals to be filled up by action, as here where Praxinoa dresses herself; l. 43 change of scene; 51-77, a long struggle through the crowd; and so on.
e)mpero/nama the same as pero/natris of l. 21; see Liddell and Scott under latter word.

po/ssw…, 'how much did it cost you off the loom?' po/ssw is genit. of price. 'Ad usum verbi kate/ba perspiciendum opus est teneamus telam apud veteres in altum erectam stetisse, ita ut opus perfectum de tela deorsum depromeretur' (Wuestemann).
mh\ mna/sh|s, 'don't make me think of it,' i. e. I don't like to think of it. Beware of the active and do no not translate 'don't mention it.'

ple/on, k.t.l. : construe kate/ba mna=n ple/on h)\ du/o kaqarw= a)rguri/w, so that mna=n and du/o are genit. of price. du/o as genit. is correctly used with the genit. plural (mna=n); with genit. dual du/oin is always found; Krüger, i. 24; ii. 3; Thucyd. i. 74 du/o moirw=n.

a)rguri/w kaqarw=, 'hard cash'; 'aridum argentum' (Plautus, Rudens, 726). Cf. the Irish expression 'dry money' ('£700 of dry money'--Spectator, Nov. 8, 1890); and the similar expressions, "a)rguri/w kaqarw=," 'Blankes Geld.' aridus, 'without moisture,' easily suggests the meaning 'nothing but.' Sonnenschein on Plautus, loc. cit.
pote/qhka (prose/qhka, f), 'I gave my soul to the work on it.' Bion, vii. 8 yuxa\n poti\ ke/rdea kai\ poti\ te/xnas ba/llomes.
kata\ gnw/man, 'it has turned out all you could wish'; cf. xiv. 57 kata\ nou=n teo/n: xiii. 14 kata\ qumo/n.

mormw/, 'Bogey!' Cf. Callim. iii. 66:
a)ll' o(/te koura/wn tis a)peiqe/a mhte/ri teu/xoi
mh/thr me\n *ku/klwpas e(h=| e)pi\ paidi\ kalistrei=
…o( de\ dw/matos e)k muxa/toio
e)/rxetai…au)ti/ka th\n kou/rhn mormu/ssetai.
to\ kako/n, 'this nuisance,' i.e. 'the crowd'; not 'this difficulty,' as Lang seems to take it. Cf. Arist. Birds 294 o(/son sunei/lektai kako\n o)rne/wn, 'what a plaguey lot of birds.'
mu/rmakes, 'they are thick as ants'; cf. Aeschrio (Bergk, A. Lyr.) steno\n kaq' (*ellh/sponton e)mpo/rwn xw/rhn nau=tai qala/sshs e)stre/fonto mu/rmhkes.
*ptolemai=e, i. e. Ptolemy II, the reigning king, son of Ptolemy Soter; see Introduction.

e)c w(= e)n a)qana/tois, 'since your father was deified.' Herondas (i. 26) speaks similarly of the prosperity of Egypt under the Ptolemies:
ta\ ga\r pa/nta
o(/s' e)sti/ kou kai\ gi/net' e)/st' e)n *ai)gu/ptw|,
plou=tos palai/strh du/namis eu)di/h do/ca
qeai\ filo/sofoi xrusi/on vehni/skoi.
qew=n a)delfw=n te/menos o( basileu\s xrhsto/s:
*moush=|on oi)=nos a)gaqa\ pa/nq' o(/s' a)\n xrh/|zh|s.
(This was written later than Theocr. xv; see Introd. p. 31.) Professor Mahaffy writes (Emp. of Ptol. p. 148), 'It is remarkable that among the many complaints of injustice found in the Petrie and Serapeum papyri made by poor people who seek redress from the law, there is not a single tale of horror. ... The effect which these papers produce upon a careful student is that they belong to an orderly and well-managed society where there is but little actual want and but little lawlessness.'
*ai)guptisti/, 'in old Egyptian fashion.' a)pathloi\ ga\r oi( *ai)gu/ptioi w(s kai\ *ai)sxu/los fhsi/: deinoi\ ple/kein toi mhxana\s *ai)gu/ptioi.
e)c a)pa/tas kekrothme/noi, 'a mass of deceit' ('welded together of deceit'). e)c, cf. xvii. 21.

kaka\ pai/gnia it is easier to make this cognate accusative to e)/paisdon and in apposition to oi(=a, than to take it in apposition to the subject as a term of reproach. The latter way is however favoured by the parallel lines, Hesiod, Theog. 26 poime/nes a)/grauloi, ka/k' e)le/gxea, gaste/res oi)=on, and Epimenides' *krh=tes a)ei\ yeu=stai, kaka\ qhri/a, gaste/res a)rgai/.

e)rioi/ (k) or e)reioi/ (other MSS.) is an unknown word; it may be right, but though Theocritus has many a(/pac lego/mena they are all simple new formations: he does not go out of his way to find strange words. Convincing emendation is impossible. Meineke's e)rinoi/ is perhaps the best (e conj. Spohn). To add one more to the existing many, I suggest e(ortai/: cf. Herond. vi. 17:
e)kpodw\n h(mi=n fqei/resqe nw/bustr'
w)=ta mou=non kai\ gla=ssai (= glw=ssai)
ta\ d' a)/ll' e(ortai/:
'idle good-for-naughts.'

ti/ genoi/meqa; 'what is to become of me?' Aesch. S. c. T. 297 ti/ ge/nwmai; For the optative cf. Soph. Philoct. 895 ti/ dh=ta drw=|m' e)gw/; and Mr. Sidgwick's Appendix to his edition of the Agamemnon. In Alexandrian writers the use of the bare optative in questions becomes frequent; Herond. v. 76 ti/s ou)k e)mptu/oi; A. Pal. v. 245 kai\ ti/s u(potlai/h;

polemistai/. polemisth\s i(/ppos ou)x o( ei)s tou\s pole/mous e)pith/deios a)ll' o( e)n toi=s a)gw=si sxh=ma fe/rwn w(s ei)s po/lemon eu)trepisme/nos: h)=n ga\r toiou=ton a)gw/nisma (Photius). These gaily caparisoned horses were led, not ridden, as appears from l. 53.
o)rqo\s a)ne/sta, 'has reared.'
kai\ dh/…, 'there we've got past, and they've gone to their position.'

sunagei/romai, 'I am beginning to collect my nerves.' Cf. Ap. Rhod. i. 1233:
th=s de\ fre/nas e)ptoi/hsen
*ku/pris, a)mhxani/h| de\ mo/gis sunagei/rato qumo/n.
Plato, Protag. 328 d mo/gis pws e)mauto\n w(sperei\ sunagei/ras ei)=pon.

i(/ppon kai\ to
 yuxro
 o)/fin. For the article with second only of two nouns cf. vi. 1; xxii. 140; vii. 132; xxii. 34; Epig. iii. 3. The second has always an attribute. Without attribute, Pind. P. iv. 118 )*apo/llwn a(/ te *puqw/: Moschus, v. 5:
a)ll' o(/tan a)xh/sh| polio\s buqo\s a( de\ qa/lassa
kurto
 e)pafri/zh|.
dedoi/kw see i. 63.

cit.quote: 'sciunt quod Iuno fabulata est cum Iove.'

div2.p: ta\s qu/ras sc. th=s au)lh=s, at which they have now arrived.
*eu)tuxi/dos sc. xe/ra, not 'take hold of Eutychis,' as this would require labou=. Eutychis is presumably Gorgo's maid as Eunoa is Praxinoa's.
po/tex' (pro/sexe), attend to her lest you lose yourself.

e)/xeu a(mw=n, 'hold on to us with your teeth'; see a)pri/c in Liddell and Scott; Theognis 31:
kakoi=si de\ mh\ prosomi/lei
a)ndra/sin a)ll' ai)ei\ tw=n a)gaqw=n e)/xeo.

ei)/ti ge/noio, 'as you wish to be saved' (M. Arnold); a neat representation of the sense. For the construction cf. Herond. iii. 56:
a)ll' ei)/ ti soi *la/mpriske kai\ bi/ou prh=cin
e)sqlh\n teloi=en ai)/de (sc. *moi=sai) ka)gaqw=n ku/rsais.
(sc. 'Thrash this boy.') Ib. 79 ei)/ ti/ soi zw/|hn pau=sai. But in all three examples we have merely an extension of the use of an 'if clause' to express an object aimed at, 'if haply.' The optative is used in primary sequence as in Eurip. Rhesus 3 ba=qi ei) de/caito: Lucian, i. 224 badiou=mai ei)/ pou eu(reqei/h.
fula/sseo, 'mind my shawl,' i.e. not 'take charge of' but 'mind not to tear.'

a)/qrws Doric for a)/qrous, the contracted form of a)qro/os. The corrupted forms a)qre/ws k, a)qro/ws p seem simply to arise from a misreading, final s being taken for S (= ws). See Sir E. M. Thompson's Palaeography, p. 95.

e)n kalw=|, 'in a good place,' 'all right'; Eur. H. F. 201:
to\ sw=ma d' ou) di/dwsi toi=s e)nanti/ois
e)n eu)fula/ktw| d' e)sti/.

'And may you be "all right" year in, year out, and afterwards'; cf. Odyss. ix. 134 ma/la ken baqu\ lh/ion ai)ei\ ei)s w(/ras a)mw=|en. The noun is used always in the plural in the idiom. Contr. ei)s e)niauto/n, ei)s e)/tos. fi/l' a)ndrw=n: cf. xxiv. 40.
xrhstw= genit. of exclamation; 'a good kind man.'
bia/zeu, 'shove your way in.' [Ziegler here reads a)/g' w)/qei kai/ because the Scholiast has a)/ge bia/zou kai\ w)/qei, but the Scholiast constantly paraphrases one verb by two.]

ka/llista, 'that's all right'--they get through the crush into the court--'all inside' as the man said when he shut the door on his bride. The point of the joke in the last phrase is lost; and its recovery is rendered doubly difficult by the uncertainty whether a)pokla/|cas means 'shut out' or 'shut up.'

(1) The former is the better attested, Lucian, 473 ad fin. of clients at the door, w)qou/menoi kai\ a)pokleio/menoi pro\s tw=n oi)ketw=n; cf. Epictet. xxxiii. 14 o(/tan foith=|s pro/s tina tw=n me/ga duname/nwn pro/bale o(/ti…a)pokleisqh/sei, o(/ti e)ntinaxqh/sontai/ soi ai( qu/rai. Haupt takes this meaning and adds the phrase to the number of those in which a ridiculous action is described introduced by 'as the man said who' (e.g. 'not such a bad shot after all, as the man said, who missed the dog and killed his mother-in-law').

(2) 'Shut up,' i.e. 'shut up alone'; not as Lang translates 'when he had shut himself in with his bride,' Charito, A. x. 2 th\n e)/ndon a)pokekleime/nhn. In this case understand a man shutting up his wife alone for 'safety,' cp. Ap. Rhod. i. 775 nhgate/h|sin e)ergo/menai kalu/bh|si nu/mfai: 'all safe at home, as the man said, when he locked his bride in.' The 'paraprosdokian' would then lie in nuo/n: it was unmarried girls who were generally so securely watched, Callim. frag. 118 h( pai=s h( kata/kleistos th\n oi)/ fasi teko/ntes eu)nai/ous o)arismou\s e)/xqein i)=son o)le/qrw|.

(3) We could take e)/ndoi = ei)/sw, and make the sentence a command: 'Come in all of you, as the man said, when he had shut his wife out of the way.' This gives far the best sense if this meaning of e)/ndoi can be allowed in Theocritus; vid. Liddell and Scott (e)/ndon).

lepta\ kai\ w(s xari/enta after Odyss. x. 222:
oi(=a qea/wn
lepta/ te kai\ xari/enta kai\ a)glaa\ e)/rga pe/lontai.
Cf. Odyss. v. 231.

perona/mata, 'embroidered robes.' See Iliad xiv. 178:
a)mfi\ d' a)/r' a)mbro/sion e(ano\n e(/saq', o(/n oi( )*aqh/nh
e)/cus' a)skh/sasa, ti/qei d' e)ni\ dai/dala polla/:
xrusei/h|s d' e)neth=|si kata\ sth=qos perona=to.
Cf. Et. Magn. 260. 43 dei/kana: ta\ polla\ u(fa/smata kai\ morfa\s e)/xonta: Hesych. dei/kana: poiki/la i(ma/tia.
zw|ogra/foi. The tapestries represented scenes in the story of Adonis and Venus. So Achill. Tat. liii. 4 describes a pe/plos wrought by zw|ogra/foi representing the story of Tereus and Philomela.
'How true to life they stand, how true they move.'

e)ndineu=nti is here intransitive; cf. 'animosa signa,' Propert. iv. 9. The whole passage resembles Herondas iv--a visit to the temple of Asclepius in Cos. See v. 33: ma=, xro/nw| kot' a)/nqrwpoi | kh)s tou\s li/qous e(/cousi th
 zo/hn qei=nai. v. 56: ou)x o(rh=|s fi/lh *kunnoi= | oi(=' e)/rga; kainh
 tau=t' e)rei=s )*aqhnai/hn | glu/yai ta\ kala\…to
 pai=da dh\ to
 gumno
 h)
 kni/sw tou=ton | ou)x e(/lkos e(/cei. This mime of Herondas is probably earlier than Theocritus.
a)rgure/as. There is no other example of klismo/s in feminine, but all the good MSS. give a)rgure/as here, and it is hard to explain the introduction of the form if it is erroneous.
kataba/llwn for the use of the active cf. ii. 26; x. 40; Xen. Symp. iv. 23 para\ ta\ w)=ta a)/rti i)/oulos kaqe/rpei.

The ceaseless chatter and broad provincial accent of the women raises the wrath of a testy bystander. It is curious that the offended person should speak equally broad Doric, but so does even the singer of the dirge.

trugo/nes cf. Alexis in Athenaeus iv. 133 b:
sou= d' e)gw\ laliste/ran
ou) pw/pot' ei)=don ou)/te kerkw/phn gu/nai
ou) ki/ttan ou) xelido/n' ou)/te trugo/na.
But not only the ceaselessness but the monotony of the ringdove's note is meant.
e)kknaiseu=nti of the bore, cf. Theophr. Char. 7 o(/tan ge tou\s kaq' e(/na a)poknai/sh|.
plateia/sdoisai, 'with their ā, ā, ā.'
ma= simply an exclamation, common in Herondas, 'my word!'
pasa/menos, 'buy your slaves before you order them about'; cf. Soph. O. C. 839 mh\ )pi/tass' a(\ mh\ kratei=s.
*kori/nqiai…a)/nwqen, 'an old Corinthian family.' Syracuse was founded from Corinth.
dwri/sden, 'I suppose Dorian folk may speak in Dorian.'
94, 95 On construction see vii. 126.
*melitw=des = Persephone.
a(mw=n kartero/s, 'master over us.'
pla\n e(no/s, 'save only one': sc. 'the king.'

kenea/n sc. xoi/nika (Herond. iii. 33 e)k tetrhme/nhs h)qei=), 'I am not afraid of you cutting down my rations.' Wuestemann's explanation is the only one available; 'that the daily rations of a slave--a modius or xoi=nic--was measured out and levelled down with a scraper.' (a)po/yhstron, Herond. vi. 30: a)poma/ktras ta\s skuta/las ai(=s a)poyw=si ta\ me/tra, Hesych.) A stingy bailiff would level it down till the measure was almost empty, and so could be said kenea\n a)poma/ttein: cf. Theophr. Char. 17 (30) feidwni/w| me/trw| to\n pu/ndaka e)gkekrousme/nw| metrei=n au)to\s toi=s e)/ndon ta\ e)pith/deia sfo/dra a)poyw=n.

a( ta=s )*argei/as. For order of words cf. vii. 11; xiii. 19; Plato, Epig. 5 to
 *numfa=n qera/ponta filo/mbrion u(gro
 a)oido/n: Herond. iii. 38 th
 ma/mmhn grhu
 gunai=ka.
Catullus, lxiv. 96 'quaeque regis Golgos quaeque Idalium frondosum.'
e)fi/lasas cf. vii. 95.
)*eru/kan the same as Eryx (in Sicily).

xrusw=| pai/zois', 'toying with gold'; a curious expression and hardly what Theocritus wrote (we should expect pai/sdois'), but not improved by such conjectures as xrusw=pis di=' (Bergk), )/*eruk' a)\n *xrusw\ pai/zois' (or pai/zeis) )*afrodi/th (Ahrens), xrusw=| sti/lbois' (Stadtmüller), or what is open to any one to suggest, xrusw= pai=s di='.
106, 107 a)qana/tan…*bereni/kan cf. xvii. 34 sqq. and Introduction.
a)po\ qnata=s Isocr. 119 b e)peidh\ (*hraklh=s meth/llace to\n bi/on qeo\s e)k qnhtou= geno/menos.
*berenikei/a cf. Iliad xiii. 67 *telamw/nion ui(o/n: Odyss. xviii. 353, etc.
pa/ntessi kaloi=s. A neuter adjective used substantivally without article can have pa/nta attached as attribute; cf. viii. 40; Demosth. viii. 9 e)pi\ pa=si dikai/ois sumbouleu/ein.
'Beside him lie all the fruits of the season, all the fruits of the trees.'
druo\s a)/kra division for a)kro/drua: see Xen. Oecon. xix. 19. dru/es here 'trees' in general not 'oaks'; cf. Hesiod, )/*erg. 233.

pa\r me/n oi(. We may either scan as a dactyl adding this to the passages when the v of oi( is neglected, (cf. Iliad vi. 101 ou)de^ ti^s oi(: Ib. 90 pe/plo^n o(/ oi( doke/ei. Add Iliad ii. 665; xi. 339; xxiii. 865; xxiv. 72, in all of which ga/r precedes); or (2) we may scan as spondee pa_r me_n v' and elide the oi. See Monro, Hom. Gram. 376; Odyss. ix. 360 w(\s e)/fat': au)ta\r v' au)=tis.

bri/qonti see crit. note. bri/qontes is impossible after xlwrai\ skia/des, even if dro/soi…tiqe/ntes is allowed in Aesch. Agam. 545, where the words are far separated. Nicander (Ther. 329) has katayhxqe/ntos a)ka/nqhs, but on false analogy to adjectives in -eis (Odyss. xvi. 123 u(lh/enti *zaku/nqw|: Nicand. Alex. 48 poih/entos xamelai/hs). Nor can the occasional use of dual masculine forms be quoted in support of this: see Soph. O. C. 1678. Given bri/qonti as the original the corruption is easily explained through the confusion of the sign for es with i+. For hiatus cf. v. 10. Tr., 'and green bowers are built with weight of dill.' For construction cf. xiii. 29; Xen. Cyrop. i. 4. 28 h(/kein i(drou=nti tw=| i(/ppw|. Fritzsche and Hartung mark a lacuna at skia/des, so that bri/qontes a)nh/qw| is end of the following line.
o)/zon a)p' o)/zw, 'flying from branch to branch'; cf. Arist. Acharn. 235 diw/kein gh=n pro\ gh=s.
e)k made of; cf. xxi. 11; A. Pal. v. 157 zw/nion e)c a)nqe/wn.

125, 126 a( *mi/latos e)rei=. This seems by the rhythm and absence of conjunction to go with the preceding not the following line. What Miletus--the great wool-growing district--says is therefore 'malakw/teroi u(/pnw' (cf. v. 51), a commendation of the quality.

a)/lla, 'another' for this year's festival. Theocritus looks back at the previous year as Bion (Epit. Adon. ad fin.) looks forward to the next, lh=ge go/wn *kuqe/reia, to\ sa/meron i)/sxeo kommw=n. dei= se pa/lin klau=sai, pa/lin ei)s e)/tos a)/llo dakru=sai.

ta
 me
…ta
 de/. The passage suffers clearly by being
over condensed; this line proceeds as if we had had already mention of a second kli/nh for Cypris.
e)nneakai/deka for e)nneakaideketh/s, e)tw=n or the termination -eths being easily understood from the preceding, cf. xxvi. 29; Iliad xxii. 349 deka/kis te kai\ ei)kosinh/rit' a)/poina.

purra/ fem. sing.; sc. qri/c. Cf. Epit. Adon. 12:
kai\ to\ r(o/don feu/gei tw= xei/leos a)mfi\ de\ th/nw|
qna/skei kai\ to\ fi/lama to\ mh/pote *ku/pris a)fh/sei.
*ku/pridi me\n to\ fi/lama kai\ ou) zw/ontos a)re/skei
a)ll' ou)k oi)=den )/*adwnis o(/ nin qna/skont' e)fi/lasen.
a(/ma dro/sw|, 'when the dew is fresh on the ground.'

e)pi\ sfura/, 'ut defluat vestis superior pars ad talos zona, sc. retenta. Parant se mulieres ad kommo\n qualis deinceps canitur,' Paley; cf. Iliad xxii. 80. But ko/lpon does not necessarily mean the folds about the breast; cf. Ap. Rhod. iv. 947:
parqenikai\ di/xa ko/lpon e)p' i)cu/as ei(li/casai
sfai/rh| a)qu/rousin perihge/i+.
'Gathering the folds about the waist'; cf. Theocr. xxvi. 17.

gerai/teros cf. xxv. 48; Odyss. vii. 156 o(\s dh\ *faih/kwn a)ndrw=n progene/steros h)=en: Iliad v. 898 kai/ ken dh\ pa/lai h)=sqa e)ne/rteros *ou)raniw/nwn, where the comparative seems equally to be used for the superlative.
*deukali/wnes, 'Deucalion and his sons' (Hiller), or 'such men as were Deucalion' as Greek says, (*hrakle/es te kai\ *qhse/es (Plato, Theaet. 169 b).
*pelophia/dai cf. Pind. N. viii. 21.
a)/kra neut. for masc. 'the pride of Argos'; cf. xx. 31; x. 29, note; Aesch. Eumenid. 489 kri/nasa d' a)stw=n tw=n e)mw=n ta\ be/ltata: Id. Persae 1 ta/de me\n *persw=n…pista\ kalei=tai.
i(/laqi an Alexandrian form, Ap. Rhod. iv. 1600; Homer has i(/lhqi.
e)s ne/wta, 'next year.'
h)=nqes sc. fi/los.
to\ xrh=ma: in apposition to a( qh/leia. to\ xrh=ma is something colloquial; 'ain't she wonderful? the woman's happy for her learning, most happy for her voice.'

kei)s oi)=kon sc. a)pie/nai, Arist. Frogs 1279 e)gw\ me\n ou)=n e)s to\ balanei=on bou/lomai. So in Shakespearian English 'he shall with speed to England' (Hamlet). Note how here as in Idyll i and elsewhere Theocritus brings us back at the close to the commonplace of daily life. 'So with the song still in her ears ends the incorrigible Gorgo' (M. Arnold).
xai=re )/*adwn the hiatus is allowed on the analogy (though false) of xai=re a)/nac. xvii. 135.
)/*adwn a colloquial form of the name; cf. )*artemi=s = )*artemisi/a (Herond.); *au)tokli=s = *au)toklh=s (Inscr.).

div1.p: The circumstances of the poem have been dealt with fully. Introd. p. 5 sqq. It is an ungenerous money-making age, in which the arts are scorned, the claims of friendship and hospitality neglected, all the true uses of wealth forgotten; men care no longer for the great deeds nor the song in which alone great deeds shall live, remembering not that but for the singers of old the heroes had been lost to memory, and from the Muses glory comes to men. Yet is it labour spent in vain to address oneself to the covetous; gold they have and ever shall desire, but I will choose men's honour and men's love, and with the help of the Muse will yet find a friend. Some one will arise who yet in this age will do a deed of fame; for now war is upon the land; Carthage and Syracuse are putting on their armour, and Hiero stands in our midst like one of the old heroes. Gods of the land cast our enemies out over the sea, all that is left of them, and let our towns and countrysides have peace from the long agony of battle; and let Hiero's fame be carried wide to the uttermost east by song. For many there are whom the Muses love; and may all tell of Sicily her folk, and Hiero. Daughter of Eteocles, ye Graces, let one call me and I will come with my muse, and will not leave you, for all that is fairest among men ye give.

Such is the argument of this fine poem, which starting with a tirade against a selfish time ever exalts the power of song, and turns at the last gracefully to praise of Hiero and outburst of prayer for Sicily's deliverance. The theme is complex, but the leading motif of the whole is the honour of poetry and vindication of the poet's place, as is shown by the key-words: u(mnei=n (2), *xa/ritas (6), eu)= ei)po/nta (13), a)oidw=n (24), *mousa/wn u(pofh/tas (29), a)oido\s o( *kh/ios (44), a)oidoi/ (50), a)oidai/ (57), thmh\n kai\ a)nqrw/pwn filo/thta (66), a)oidou= (73), u(mnei=n (103), *xari/twn (108). Indirectly the poem is an appeal on the poet's own behalf, but the claim is pressed rather by suggestion than immediate request. As the first Hiero had honoured the poets of his age--Pindar, Simonides, Bacchylides--as the heroes of Thessaly, and Troy had found their singer, so the latter Hiero is addressed in a poem which by direct mention or constant reminiscence of phrase calls to mind the lyrics of the fifth century. The title *xa/rites, the use of the word *xa/rites in l. 6, the last announcement of attachment to the *xa/rites in l. 104 are full of memories of Pindar and Bacchylides, Pind. Pyth. ix. ad init.:
e)qe/lw xalka/spida *puqioni/kan
su\n baquzw/noisin a)gge/llwn
*telesikra/th *xari/tessi gegwnei=n.
Bacchylides, v. 9:
su\n *xari/tessi baquzw/nois u(fa/nas
u(/mnon a)po\ zaqe/as
na/sou ce/nos u(mete/rwn pe/mpei
kleenna\n e)s po/lin
xrusa/mpukos *ou)rani/as kleino\s qera/pwn.
Bacchyl. xix. (vid. on l. 69). The outburst against the wrong use of wealth (Theocr. v. 22-28) echoes Pindar and Bacchylides alike (vid. ad loc.), as does the passage 40-58, of which the motif is 'carent quia vate sacro.'

div2.p:
H. hymn Apoll. 189:
*mou=sai me/n q' a(/ma pa=sai a)meibo/menai o)pi\ kalh=|
u(mneu=si/n r(a qew=n dw=r' a)/mbrota h)d' a)nqrw/pwn
tlhmosu/nas.
Hesiod, Theog. 43:
ai( d' a)/mbroton o)/ssan i(ei=sai
qew=n ge/nos ai)doi/wn prw=ton klei/ousin a)oidh=|.
Matthew Arnold, Empedocles:
'First hymn they the Father
Of all things; and then
The rest of immortals
The action of men.'
u(mnei=n…u(mnei=n vid. Introd. p. 41.
kle/a a)ndrw=n Iliad ix. 524 tw=n pro/sqen e)peuqo/meqa kle/a a)ndrw=n.

'We are mortals here on earth; let man sing fellow-man.' The careful antithesis of these things is noticeable. Each line falls into two balanced halves: 1-2 = 3-4; 1 and 2 correspond in alternating order, *dio\s kou/rais…u(mnei=n a)qana/tous :: a)oidoi=s…kle/a a)ndrw=n.

*xa/ritas Pind. Isth. v. 26:
su\n *xa/risin d' e)/molon *la/mpwnos ui(oi=s
ta/nd' e)s eu)/nomon po/lin.

peta/sas sc. oi)=kon. The accus. and dative both being required in the construction, only the latter is actually introduced, Isocr. 31 a sumbou/lois xrw=ntai, oi( me\n tw=n a)stw=n toi=s tolmhrota/tois oi( de\ e)c a(pa/ntwn e)kleca/menoi toi=s fronimwta/tois: cf. Odyss. iv. 597.

o(/ t(e) see on xi. 79; Odyss. v. 356:
w)/moi e)gw/, mh/ ti/s moi u(fai/nh|sin do/lon au)=te
a)qana/twn, o(/te me sxedi/hs a)pobh=nai a)nw/gei.
Homer uses o(/, o(/te, o(/ti indifferently = 'in that' or 'because,' Odyss. viii. 78; xx. 269; v. 340.

'And hide on their chill knees once more their patient head' (Calv.). The poems are personified and represented as begging from house to house, returning empty-handed and blaming their master for their fruitless journey, and sitting dejected, head on hand, till they are sent forth again.

gona/tessi is an unexampled form. Homer uses gou/nessi or gou/nasi: so dou/ressi (Hartung yuxrai=s e)n koni/h|si). For the imagery cf. Cebes, Tabula 9 *lu/ph…th\n kefalh\n e)n toi=s go/nasin e)/xousa (Renier).
'Men care not as of old to be praised for noble deeds.' The statement is compressed, but means obviously 'care not for noble deeds nor yet for noble fame.'
e)pi/, 'on the ground of,' Isocr. 44 d e)f' e(ka/stw| tima=sqai tw=n e)/rgwn.

u(po\ kerde/wn not quite equivalent to ke/rdei, but 'under the influence of gain,' Demosth. p. 107. 71 ou)de\ proh/xqhn ou)/q' u(po\ ke/rdous ou)/q' u(po\ filotimi/as. The use is commoner with adjectives (cf. xxiv. 60, note) and verbs that are only virtually passive, Plato, Laws 695 b u(po\ me/qhs mai/nesqai: Thucyd. ii. 85 ad fin u(p' a)ploi/as e)ndie/triyen ou)k o)li/gon xro/non.
Join a)/rguron with po/qen oi)/setai, 'whence he shall win money,' Arist. Equites 800 e)ceuri/skwn o(po/qen to\ triw/bolon e(/cei: Theocr. xvii. 10.

a)pwte/rw h)\ go/nu kna/ma, 'the knee is nearer than the shin,' Plaut. Trinum. v. 2. 30 'tunica pallio propior'; Arist. Eth. ix. 8. 2 kai\ ai( paroimi/ai de\ pa=sai o(mognwmonou=si, oi(=on to\ "mi/a yuxh/" kai\ "koina\ ta\ fi/lwn," kai\ "i)so/ths filo/ths" kai\ "go/nu knh/mhs e)/ggion." The equivalent of 'charity begins at home.'

o(\s e)c e)meu= oi)/setai ou)de/n. The future must bear a modal sense, 'who will have nought from me,' 'who intends to get nothing,' Eurip. frag. 33:
gunai=ka d' o(/stis pau/setai le/gwn kakw=s
du/sthnos a)=ra kou) sofo\s keklh/setai.
'He who gets' (or 'shall get') would of course be o(\s a)\n fe/rhtai: cf. ei) maxei= with e)a\n ma/xh|.

sqq. The true use of wealth. The retort to churlish greed is given courteously in "daimo/nioi": 'Blanda est appellatio qua utitur etiam is qui alterum leniter increpat vel amice admonet' (Ast, Lex. Plat.); Plato, Rep. 344 d w)= daimo/nie *qrasu/maxe, oi(=on e)mbalw\n lo/gon e)n nw=| e)/xeis a)pie/nai; With the whole passage following cf. Theocr. xvii. 106 sqq.; Bacchylides, iii. 13 (addressed to Hiero):
oi)=de purgwqe/nta plou=ton mh\ melamfare/i+
kru/ptein sko/tw|.
bru/ei me\n i(era\ bouqu/tois e(ortai=s,
bru/ousi filoceni/as a)guiai\
la/mpei d' u(po\ marmarugai=s o( xruso\s
u(yidaida/ltwn tripo/dwn staqe/ntwn
pa/roiqe naou=.
Pind. Nem. i. 44:
ou)k e)/ramai polu\n e)n mega/rw| plou=ton katakru/yais e)/xein,
a)ll' e)o/ntwn eu)= te paqei=n kai\ a)kou=sai, fi/lois e)carke/wn.

yuxa=| dou=nai Horace, Ode iv. 7. 19; Simonides 85:
a)lla\ su\ tau=ta maqw\n bio/tou poti\ te/rma
yuxh=| tw=n a)gaqw=n tlh=qi xarizo/menos.

a)oidw=n repeated again in 29 *mousa/wn ti/ein u(pofh/tas, but this is no tautology, since it is for new emphasis and with a new turn of phrase that the duty of granting somewhat to the arts is insisted on.

trape/zh, 'hospitality.' The passage seems suggested by Odyss. xv. 69:
nemessw=mai de\ kai\ a)/llw|
a)ndri\ ceinodo/kw|, o(/s k' e)/coxa me\n file/h|sin,
e)/coxa d' e)xqai/rh|sin: a)mei/nw d' ai)/sima pa/nta.
i)=so/n toi kako/n e)sq', o(/s t' ou)k e)qe/lonta ne/esqai
cei=non e)potru/nei kai\ o(\s e)ssu/menon kateru/kei.
Cf. Theognis, 467 sqq.

u(pofh/tas, 'the interpreters'; cf. xxii. 116. The poet is the servant by whose mouth the Muses speak. So Vergil 'Musae quarum sacra fero': Ap. Rhod. iv. 1379 *mousa/wn o(/de mu=qos: e)gw\ d' u(pakouo\s a)ei/dw *pieri/dwn: Horace 'Musarum sacerdos.'
e)sqlo\s a)kou/sh|s, 'may win a noble name'; cf. xxix. 21. a)kou/w being used as for the passive of kale/w.

Pind. Isth. i. ad fin.:
ei) de/ tis e)/ndon ne/mei plou=ton krufai=on,
a)/lloisi d' e)mpi/ptwn gela=|, yuxa\n
)*ai+/da| tele/wn ou)
fra/zetai do/cas a)/neuqen.

w(sei/ tis make/la|, 'as one whose hands are hardened with the mattock's toil, poor of poor line bewailing hapless poverty'; Shirley (though in very different context):
'Sceptre and crown
Must tumble down,
And in the dust be equal made
With the poor crooked scythe and spade.'
a)xh/n Hesych. h)xh=nes, pe/nhtes.
e)k pate/rwn cf. xvii. 13; xxv. 117; xxiv. 108 e)k pate/rwn a)fneio/s: the preposition expressing inherited characteristics, 'poor by descent.'

sqq. Theocritus illustrates his text by the example of the old heroes who but for song would have been lost to memory, but now, doing great deeds and finding a bard, live in the songs of men. Antiochus and Aleuas were kings of Thessaly, contemporaries and patrons of Simonides. The Scopadae were feudal lords of the territory of Crannon in Thessaly; the head of the house, Scopas, son of Creon, was addressed by Simonides in a song of which Plato (Protag. 339 b) preserves the famous fragment: a)/ndra a)gaqo
 me
 a)laqe/ws gene/sqai xalepo
 xersi/ te kai\ posi\ kai\ no/w| tetra/gwnon a)/neu yo/gou tetugme/non.
pene/stai, 'serfs.'

a(rmalih/, 'the portions of food assigned month by month to each dependent'; cf. on xv. 95. The word is used by Hesiod; then revived, as were many obsolete words, by the Alexandrians. Ap. Rhod. i. 393; Leonidas, 95 (Geffck.).
e)metrh/santo, 'had measured to them'; cf. Hesiod, W. and D. 349 eu)= me\n metrei=sqai para\ gei/tonos eu)= d' a)podou=nai.
-39. Note the careful antithetical arrangement of these lines: 34, 35 = 36, 37 = 38, 39; polloi/ = polloi/ = muri/a.

e)ndia/askon, 'drove afield'; but the word is not elsewhere used transitively; vid. Liddell and Scott. [Hence e)/ndi' a)/geskon, Graefe; e)/ndi' e)/laskon, Meineke; most unlikely after e)launo/menoi in 36. Or if change is necessary we might read e)/ndioi e)/sxon, cf. l. 95. e)/ndi^os and e)/ndi_os are both used. poi/mnais for poi/menes, Voss.]
poime/nes e)/kkrita for rhythm cf. xxii. 49.
a)ll' ou)/ sfin tw=n h)=dos. There is a Homeric ring in the line; Odyss. xxiv. 95 au)ta\r e)moi\ ti/ to/d' h)=dos e)pei\ po/lemon tolu/peusa; cf. Iliad xviii. 80; A. Pal. v. 291.

eu)rei=an sxedi/an Leonidas, 94 (A. Pal. vii. 67):
ei) kai/ soi me/ga bri/qetai o)kruo/essa
ba=ris a)pofqime/nwn.
Both expressions are chosen in order to call to the mind a picture of a vast throng of spirits embarking (see Geffcken on Leonidas, loc. cit.).

ta\ polla\ kai\ o)/lbia, 'the wealth they had on earth.' A. Pal. vii. 326:
to/ss' e)/xw o(/ss' e)/maqon kai\ e)fro/ntisa kai\ meta\ *mousw=n
se/mn' e)da/hn: ta\ de\ polla\ kai\ o)/lbia tu=fos e)/maryen.

e)/keinto see on ii. 124. The sentiment is repeated by Horace, Od. iv. 9. 25:
'Vixere fortes ante Agamemnona
Multi, sed omnes illacrimabiles
Urgentur ignotique longa
Nocte carent quia vate sacro.'
Pind. Nem. vii. 17; Ol. x. 109:
kai\ o(/tan kala\ e)/rcais, a)oida=s a)/ter,
)*aghsi/dam', ei)s )*ai+/da staqmo\n
a)nh\r i(/khtai, kenea\ pneu/sais
e)/pore mo/xqw| braxu/ ti terpno/n:
ti\n d' a(dueph/s te lu/ra
gluku/s t' au)lo\s a)napa/ssei xa/rin.
o( *kh/ios Simonides, 556-468 b. c., the first of the great writers of 'epinikia'; author also of Paeans, Dithyrambs, Hymns, and other forms of Lyric poetry of which fragments remain.

ai)o/la not 'in varied style,' i. e. different forms of lyrics, but a song of varied mood and rhythm, as Pind. N. iv. 24 poiki/lon kiqari/zwn: A. Pal. ix. 584 ai)o/lon e)n kiqa/ra| no/mon e)/krekon. Dryden's 'Alexander's Feast' is an ai)o/lon me/los.
o(plote/rois, 'posteris.' In Homer = younger; as here, A. Pal. iv. 2. 6, where palaiote/rwn and o(plote/rwn are opposed. In A. Pal. ii. 362 o(plo/teros kw=mos = New Comedy.

i(/ppoi cf. Pind. Ol. i. 18; Bacchyl. v. 37:
canqo/trixa me\n
*fere/nikon )*alfeo\n par' eu)rudi/nan pw=lon a)ellodro/man
ei)=de nikasa/nta xruso/paxus )*aw/s.
*luki/wn. Sarpedon and Glaucus; Iliad xv.
*ku/knon. The story of Cycnus was related in the 'Cypria.' See Herod. ii. 116; Proclus, Chrestom. 1 e)/peita )*axilleu\s au)tou\s tre/petai a)nelw\n *ku/knon to\n *poseidw=nos: Quint. Smyrn. iv. 153.
a)po\ xroia=s see on xiv. 68.

e)/sxaton not 'lowest' (as Fritzsche), but furthest; 'at the limit of the world.' Odysseus, in Odyss. xi, sails beyond the sunset to the world of the dead. Cf. Soph. O. T. 177; Hesiod, Theog. 621:
e)/nq' oi(/g' a)/lge' e)/xontes u(po\ xqoni\ naieta/ontes
ei(/at' e)p' e)sxati/h| mega/lhs e)n pei/rasi gai/hs.
bousi\…a)mf' a)gelai/ais cf. Bacchyl. x. 43 oi( d' e)p' e)/rgoisi/n te kai\ a)mfi\ bow=n a)ge/lais qumo\n au)/cousin.
w)/nasan cf. vii. 36.

sfeas as monosyll. sfeas. For the sense cf. Spenser, Ruines of Time:
'For not to have been dipt in Lethe lake
Could save the son of Thetis from to die;
But that blind bard did him immortal make
With verses dipt in dew of Castalie.'

ku/mata metrei=n, 'to count the waves.' Expressions of size and number are constantly confused in Greek; Soph. Ajax 130 makro\s plou=tos: Herod. i. 203 o)/ros plh/qei+ me/giston: vid. Lobeck, Ajax, loc. cit.

o(/ss' a)/nemos, 'which the wind drives shoreward with the grey sea.' It seems better to take meta/ as coupling glauka=s a(lo/s to o(/ssa, than to join a)/nemos meta\ glauka=s a(lo/s. The whole surface of the sea seems to be driving coastwards; cf. Catullus' 'Sea-picture' (lxiv. 274):
'Post, vento crescente, magis magis increbrescunt,
Purpureaque, procul nantes, a luce refulgent.'
For meta/ cf. Plato, Rep. 591 b dikaiosu/nhn meta\ fronh/sews ktwme/nh. (Paley translates 'vis venti cum vi maris'; so Hiller.) For the expression cf. Verg. Georg. ii. 108.
u(/dati_ ni/zein. The i is lengthened before a liquid; cf. xxii. 121; xi. 45; Iliad xii. 459; see Monro, H. G. § 371.
pli/nqon 'laterem lavare.' Terence, Phorm. i. 4. 9.

parelqei=n, 'to win to better things'; see Iliad vi. 337. I have taken this--the reading of three MSS.--as yielding the best sense. The vulgata lectio is parelqei=n = 'to get the better of,' but usually 'to get the better of by craft,' not suitable here.
pare/lkein (Hemsterh.) paraspa=n (Briggs) means 'to draw away from the right path.' parainei=n, Warton (Bergk, Hiller), does not take an accusative. C. Hartung's pare/rpein ('subdole accedere') is bad. Cf. generally Theognis, 105:
deilo??s eu)= e)/rdonti mataiota/th xa/ris e)sti/n,
i)=son kai\ spei/rein po/nton a(lo\s polih=s.
xaire/tw, 'farewell to him'; cf. xxvii. 15; Herond. vi. 31 xaire/tw fi/lh polla\ e)ou=sa toi/h. Often in Attic, Eurip. Medea 1044 xaire/tw bouleu/mata ta\ pro/sqen.

e)/xoi i(/meros cf. on ii. 45; Callim. vi. 68 sxe/tlios: o(/ssa pa/saito to/swn e)/xen i(/meros au)=tis: cf. Pind. Nem. viii. 64:
xruso\n eu)/xontai, pedi/on d' e(/teroi
a)pe/ranton: e)gw\ d' a)stoi=s a(dw\n
kai\ xqoni\ gui=a kalu/yaim'
ai)ne/wn ai)nhta/.

e(loi/man. The opt. without a)/n in 1st person expresses not unfrequently willingness; Odyss. vii. 314 oi)=kon de/ t' e)gw\ kai\ kth/mata doi/hn = dare velim not dederim: Iliad xv. 45; Theocr. xxix. 38 kh)pi\ ta\ xru/sea ma=la…bai/hn, 'I should like to go': Pind. Pyth. iv. 118 (210) ou)x i(koi/man, 'I would not go'--'nolim venire' (Opinio cum voluntatis quadam significatione, Hermann).

o(doi/ here, literally, 'journeyings.' Others read a)oida=n with majority of MSS.; o(do/s is then metaphorical. Cf. Bacchyl. 19 ad init. pa/resti muri/a ke/leudos a)mbrosi/wn mele/wn: and after o(do\s ke/leuqos, oi)=mos, in Pindar.

Here Theocritus passes to the address to Hiero. Yet even in this age there is hope for heroic song. The world has not yet run its course; and great deeds will once more be done: there is the stir of war throughout the land, and a new champion of Hellenic freedom has arisen--Hiero: and my song will find a worthy subject of praise.

mh=nas a)/gwn cf. Aratus, 551:
e)n toi=s h)e/lios fe/retai duokai/deka pa=sin
pa/nt' e)niauto\n a)/gwn.
Verg. Georg. i. 5:
'Vos, o clarissima mundi
Lumina! labentem caelo quae ducitis annum.'

i(/ppoi the horses of the Sun (not a reference to Olympia as Vahlen would have it). Mimnermus, frag. 12:
h)e/lios me\n ga\r po/non e)/llaxen h)/mata pa/nta,
ou)de/ pot' a)/mpausis gi/gnetai ou)demi/a
i(/ppoisi/n te kai\ au)tw=|.
)/*ilou cf. Iliad x. 415 qei/ou para\ sh/mati )/*ilou.
*foi/nikes the carthaginians; see Introd. loc. cit.

a)/kron sfuro/n the extreme spur; Musaeus, 45 o(/ssoi naieta/eskon a(listefe/wn sfura\ nh/swn. The phrase is merely a geographical description of the Carthaginian city, and does not
imply that Sicily was not occupied by the invader. Kniper's *lilu/bhs is not needed.
e)rri/gasin, 'shudder'; excitement of preparation, rather than fear, seems to be meant. The word can hardly without further designation mean 'horrent armis' (as Rumpel, Lex. Theocr.).

basta/zousi…me/sa dou=ra, 'grip by the middle.' Cf. Aesch. Eumenid. 158 e)/tuyen di/kan difrhla/tou mesolabei= ke/ntrw|, 'gripped by the middle to give the blow force.'--Sidgwick. For me/sos cf. e)/xei me/sos, Arist. The threatening war is graphically described in the image of troops preparing for instant battle.

ai) ga\r… Another Homeric echo; Iliad ii. 371 ai)\ ga\r *zeu= te pa/ter kai\ )*aqhnai/h kai\ )*apo/llwn. With this fine prayer for blessing on the arms of Syracuse, and expulsion of her enemies from the island, cf. Pind. Pyth. i. (to Hiero I) 134:
*zeu= te/leie:…su/n toi ti/n ken a(ghth\r a)nh/r,
ui(w=| t' e)pitello/menos da=mon gerai/-
rwn tra/poi su/mfwnon e)f' a(suxi/an.
li/ssomai, neu=son, *kroni/wn, a(/meron
o)/fra kat' oi)=kon o( *foi=nic, o( *tursanw=n t' a)lalato\s e)/xh| nau-
si/stonon u(/brin i)dw\n ta\n pro\ *ku/mas:
oi(=a *surakosi/wn a)r-
xw=| damasqe/ntes pa/qon,
w)kupo/rwn a)po\ naw=n,
o(/s sfin e)n po/ntw| ba/leq' a(liki/an,
(*ella/d' e)ce/lkwn barei/as
douli/as.
)*efurai/wn. Ephyra is the old name of Corinth; of which city Syracuse was a colony: cf. xv. 91.

kou/rh Persephone. matri/ Demeter; the special divinities of Sicily. Bacchyl. iii. 1:
a)ristoka/rpou *sikeli/as kre/ousan
*da/matra i)oste/fano/n te kou/ran u(/mnei.
Cf. Pind. Ol. vi. 160 where *zeu\s *ai)tnai=os is added as a third to the gods of Syracuse.
*lusimelei/as Thucyd. vii. 53.

a)gge/llontas, 'with news of disaster.' For the present cf. Demosth. Crown, § 169 e(spe/ra me\n ga\r h)=n h(=ke d' a)gge/llwn tis w(s…h( (*ela/teia katei/lhptai. The sense differs from that of the future ('that they may tell'), and conveys an idea of hurried flight and confused telling of the news, without discrimination of tune.
Cf. Herod. vi. 27 a)po\ e(kato\n kai\ ei)/kosi ei)=s mo/nos a)pe/fuge.

Vid. Introd. p. 6. Theocritus refers not only to the impending war with Syracuse but to the years of struggle under Pyrrhus, when the land was laid waste, and the subsequent return of the Carthaginians.
A charming picture of peaceful country sides, the more effective by contrast with the heroic tone of the preceding lines.
blhxoi=nto. From a Doric form blhxe/omai; vid. Dialect, § 3 (a).
sknifai=on a(/p. leg. from ski/fos, 'twilight.' The adjective is used as in 95, etc.
e)pispeu/doien tersely put for 'warn him to hasten.'

'What time the cicada in the thickets, watching the shepherds at their noontide toil, makes its loud music in the boughs.' The summer ploughing is obviously meant; see Hesiod, )*erg. 460, where Paley points out that there were three seasons for ploughing: (1) late autumn; (2) in spring, after the land had been benefited by the frost (polei=n); (3) in summer, for a second crop (new=sai). neio/s is land thus ploughed three times (dist. novalia). Cf. generally Alcaeus, 39:
to\ ga\r a)/stron (dog-star) perite/lletai
a) d' w)/ra xale/pa, pa/nta de\ di/yais' u(po\ kau/matos
a)/xei d' e)k peta/lwn a)de/a te/ttic, pteru/gwn a)/po,
kakxe/ei ligu/ran pu/knon a)oi/dan.

96, 97 'And the spiders spin out their webs on the armour.' Bacchyl. frag. 13 (Bergk = 46 Kenyon):
e)n de\ sidarode/tois po/rpacin ai)qa=n
a)raxna=n i(stoi\ pe/lontai.
a)xei= indicative, because a(ni/ka is here a relative time-adverb (not a conjunction)--see Sonnenschein, Syntax--defining further the implied thought 'in the summer time.'

diasth/sainto, 'weave loosely.' Plato (Phaedrus 268 a) calls a loosely woven work h)/trion diesthko/s. [W. Schulze, Hermes xxviii. p. 30, assumes a word dia-ste/omai = to weave, from which this aorist is to be derived, not from dii/sthmi: diastikh/ is given = a spider's web, and Hesych. has e)ndi/astra = klw=sma. J. A. Hartung as usual emends dii+stourgoi=nto: but the usual derivation is not impossible.]
e)/ti mhd' for mhke/ti, 'no longer.' Cf. Soph. O. T. 24 po/lis ga\r…e)/t' ou)x oi(/a te.
Hiero's fame is to be carried far east to the Euphrates, and northward into Thrace--far away from his own land. Cf. Propert. ii. 7. 18 'gloria ad hibernos lata Borysthenidas.'

See Introd. The mention of Orchomenus is led up to by the reminiscences of Pindar, and is introduced to represent the *xa/rites as a)rxai=ai qeai/ (Holzinger, Philolog. li. p. 193). Eteocles, son of Cephisus, king of Orchomenus, was (according to the Scholiast) the first to sacrifice to the *xa/rites as divine.
)*orxomeno\n *minu/eion cf. Odyss. xi. 284. The feud between Thebes and Orchomenus dated from prehistoric times. In 364 Orchomenus was destroyed by her rival.
'If none call me I will abide here: but if any call, boldly will I go forth with my song'; i.e. if anywhere I can gain recognition I will go there and try my fortune boldly.

u)/mme = *xa/rites. For the conception of *xa/rites here, cf. Theognis, 1138:
w)/|xeto me\n *pi/stis mega/lh qeo/s, w)/|xeto d' a)ndrw=n
*swfrosu/nh: *xa/rite/s t', w)= fi/le, gh=n e)/lipon.
'The Graces are the representatives of a civilizing moral law. Where they are, there are rules, manners, harmony, and that ineffable magic power from which spring the charm and grace of spiritual life.' Buchholz on Theog. loc. cit. Pind. Ol. xiv. 3:
w)= lipara=s a)oi/dimoi basi/leiai
*xa/rites )*orxomenou=, palaigo/nwn *minua=n e)pi/skopoi,
klu=t' e)pei\ eu)/xomai: su\n u)/mmin ga\r ta/ te terpna\ kai\
ta\ gluke/a gi/gnetai pa/nta brotoi=s:
ei) sofo\s ei) kalo\s ei)/ tis a)glao\s a)nh/r.

div1.p: Vid. Introd. p. 2 sqq. and Ib. 27 sqq.; date 273-271; place of composition Alexandria.

div2.p:
e)k *dio\s a)rxw/mesqa. The same words form the opening line of the Phaenomena of Aratus. That poem is probably to be dated 275 b. c., and as it at once became famous the phrase is frequently set down as Aratus' (A. Pal. xii. 1 e)k *dio\s a)rxw/mesqa kaqa\s ei)/rhken )/*aratos); we can hardly refuse to believe that Theocritus intentionally used the other poet's words, although the phrase is little more than a formula; cf. Hesiod, Theog. 48 (*zh=na) a)rxo/menai/ q' u(mneu=si qeai\ lh/gousi/ t' a)oidh=s: Theognis 1:
w)= a)/na *lhtou=s ui(e/, *dio\s te/kos, ou)/pote sei=o
lh/somai a)rxo/menos ou)d' a)popauo/menos.
a)ll' ai)ei\ prw=ton se\ kai\ u(/staton e)/n te me/soisin a)ei/sw.
e)s *di/a lh/gete, 'cease with Zeus'; cf. xiii. 15; xiv. 28; but Iliad ix. 97 e)n soi\ me\n lh/cw se/o d' a)/rcomai.
au)dw=men, 'sing of' (Pind. Ol. i. 12).

3, 4 e)ni\ prw/toioi, k.t.l. : cf. Theognis (quoted above). Aratus, 14 tw= min a)ei\ prw=to/n te kai\ u(/staton i(la/skontai: Demosth. xxv. 8 ta\ toiau=ta qhri/a w(=n me/sos kai\ teleutai=os kai\ prw=to/s e)stin ou(=tos: Milton, Paradise Lost, v. 165 'Him first, Him last, Him midst and without end.'
profere/statos a)/llwn cf. Ap. Rhod. i. 180 podwkhe/staton a)/llwn: cf. l. 121 mou=nos prote/rwn: Thucyd. i. 1 po/lemos a)ciologw/tatos tw=n progegenhme/nwn.
u(mnh/saim', 'I am fain to sing'; cf. xvi. 67, note.

u(mnh/saim': u(/mnoi cf. Introd. p. 112 sqq. The whole of this introductory paragraph 1-12 affords a good example of Theocritean symmetry, the whole dividing into six couplets, each complete in itself, and forming an antithesis with the following.

sqq. The encomium deals first with Ptolemy Lageides, the father of Ptolemy II, and with the divine rights paid to the house (13-26); then with Berenice, the mother of the king (27-52). On these persons and on their deification see Introd. p. 3 sqq.
e)k pate/rwn oi)=os me\n e)/hn, 'how great was Ptolemy in virtue of his race in doing mighty deeds.'
e)k pate/rwn see note on xvi. 33 (not 'ut a parentibus ordiar' as Wuestemann).

oi(=os e)/hn is exclamatory ('qualis erat ad opus perficiendum,' Ameis), and the infinitive is epexegetic as in xxii. 2 fobero
 pu\c e)reqi/zein: cf. Odyss. ii. 272 oi(=os kei=nos e)/hn tele/sai e)/rgon te e)/pos te. Beware of confounding this construction with the wholly different consecutive use of oi(=os with infinitive, Xen. Anab. ii. 3. 13 ou) ga h)=n w(/ra oi(/a to\ pedi/on a)/rdein (w(/ra toiau/th w(/ste e)n au)th=| a)/rdein), cf. note on xxx. 6. In this use the oi(=os must be joined immediately with the infinitive, and the copula, if expressed, must stand before the oi(=os. The usages are quite wrongly given in Liddell and Scott, who apparently treat oi(=os as a demonstrative, but Arist. Vespae 970 o( d' e(/teros oi(=o/s e)stin oi)kouro\s mo/non = the other is more as a watch-dog is, i.e. e)sti
 oi(=os oi)kouro/s e)stin. In Plato, Phaedr. 256 a oi(=o/s e)stin mh\ a)
 a)parnhqh=nai read e)sti
 oi(=os mh\ a)
 a)parnhqh=nai. Harpocration's note (oi(=os ei)= kai\ oi(=o/s te ei)=: to\ me
 xwri\s tou= te shmai/nei to\ bou/lei to\ de\ su
 tw=| te to\ du/natai) has no support in fact.

14, 15 *lagei/das = Ptolemy I (Soter), who was either the son of Lagos and Arsinoe, or son of Philip and Arsinoe, and stepson to Lagos, who afterwards had Arsinoe to wife. We should expect *lagi^das, but this form is attested by inscriptions, C. I. G. 2613.
fresi\n e)gkata/qoito Simon. lxxxv. 5 ste/rnois e)gkate/qento. For the whole passage cf. Callim. i. 87 e(spe/rios kei=no/s ge telei= ta/ ken h)=ri noh/sh|.
path/r, sc. qew=n: 'pater superum iam signat honore,' Verg. Aen. vi. 780

do/mos…oi)/kw| 'hoc nomine totum significat illo partem,' Lobeck (Ajax 65); Pind. N. i. 112. Teiresias prophesies of Heracles that deca/menon qalera\n (/*hban (l. 32) a)/koitin kai\ ga/mon dai/santa pa\r *dii\ *kroni/da| semno\n ai)nh/sein do/mon.
ai)olomi/tras vid. Callim. iv. 168 (quoted below, l. 58).
(*hraklh=os vid. note on 14. Whichever genealogy is adopted the Ptolemies were connected with the house of Macedon, and therefore claimed descent from Heracles.
tetugme/na e)c a)da/mantos cf. xv. 123; xxviii. 8.

qali/as e)/xei sc. Heracles, who
met' a)qana/toisi qeoi=si
te/rpetai e)n qali/h|s kai\ e)/xei kalli/sfuron (/*hbhn,
Odyss. xi. 603.

ui(wnw=n…ui(wnoi=sin cf. Tyrtaeus, xii. 30 kai\ pai/dwn pai=des kai\ ge/nos e)copi/sw: Eurip. H. F. 7 oi(\ *ka/dmou po/lin teknou=si pai/dwn paisi/, by which 'significatur ex una eademque generis propagatione paullatim prolem prognatam esse' (Klotz). Here the phrase expresses all the line of the house of Heracles, not only Ptolemy and Alexander (the a)mfw/ of l. 26); Scholiast xai/rwn e)pi\ toi=s tw=n e)kgo/nwn ui(oi=s kai\ a)pogo/nois a)paqanatisqei=sin.

e)cei/leto gh=ras Soph. O. C. 607:
mo/nois ou) gi/gnetai
qeoi=si gh=ras ou)de\ katqanei=n pote.
mele/wn cf. Odyss. vi. 140 e)k de/os ei(/leto gui/wn: Quint. Smyrn. viii. 494 ou(/neka/ oi( stono/enta *qe/tis meledh/mata gui/wn e)ce/leto.

ne/podes see Liddell and Scott, s. v.; Eustath. at Odyss. iv. 404 ne/pous kata\ glw=ssa/n tina o( a)po/gonos. This is doubtless the meaning in Homer and the Alexandrian writers, the word being connected with a)neyio/s, 'nepos,' Sansk. 'nápāt' (Vanietcbreve;ek, p. 428). In late writers it is used as = i)xqu/s (Oppian, passim), whether from a false derivation or by specialization of the Homeric use.
a)/mfw = Ptolemy and Alexander (note the form a)/mfw for a)mfoi=n). Cf. du/o for duoi=n.

pro/gonos could hardly be applied to Philip, so we must understand the founder of the Macedonian dynasty, either Ceranos, brother of Pheidon of Argos, or Perdiccas an exile from Argos (Herod. viii. 137. The native Macedonian legend accepted the latter. Through this Perdiccas the Macedonian kings traced their line through the Temenidae of Argos up to Heracles (see Grote, Hist. of Greece, vol. iii. p. 432).

e)s e)/sxaton (*hraklh=a, 'count back their time to Heracles at last.' This descent was claimed officially by the Ptolemies, C. I. G. 5127 (a document of Ptolemy III Euergetes) basileu\s me/gas *ptolemai=os ui(o\s basile/ws *ptolemai/ou kai\ basili/sshs )*arsino/hs, qew=n a)delfw=n, tw=n basile/wn *ptolemai/ou kai\ basili/sshs *bereni/khs qew=n *swth/rwn a)po/gonos ta\ me\n a)po\ patro\s (*hrakle/ous tou= *dio\s ta\ de\ a)po\ mhtro\s *dionu/sou tou= *dio/s.
oi(/a de\…*bereni/ka = the wife of Ptolemy Soter, mother of the ruling Ptolemy, who now like Soter was deified (Introd. p. 4).
oi(/a de/ takes up the oi(=os me\n e)/hn of 13.
qhlute/rais substantive here and often in Alexandrian poets. In Homer only adjective, qhlute/rh|si gunaici/n: vid. Index, subject Adjective.
r(adina/s, 'delicately slender'; Hom. hymn Demet. 183 r(adinoi=si qea=s possi/.

38, 39 tw=|, 'therefore.' With the whole passage cf. Hesiod, Scutum 7 sqq.:
th=s kai\ a)po\ krh=qen blefa/rwn t' a)po\ kuanea/wn
toi=on a)/hq' oi(=o/n te poluxru/sou )*afrodi/ths:
h( de\ kai\ w(\s kata\ qumo\n e(o\n ti/esken a)koi/thn
w(s ou)/pw tis e)/tise gunaikw=n qhlutera/wn.

w(=de/ ke paisi/, 'thus might one entrust, secure in mind, all his house to his children when love is truly given and returned' ('hoc poeta dicit qui ex tali coniugio castae et amantis uxoris liberos suscipiat tuto iis domum totam committere posse utpote veris et genuinis,' Madvig). The words are to be taken as a general reflection, though hinting at Ptolemy Soter. tis is omitted as often; vid. Liddell and Scott, tis sub finem. e)pitre/pein oi)=kon paisi/ may be taken in two senses:

(1) 'Leave during absence'; cf. Odyss. ii. 226:
kai/ oi( i)w\n e)n nhusi\n e)pe/trepen oi)=kon a(/panta,
pei/qesqai/ te ge/ronti kai\ e)/mpeda pa/nta fula/ssein.
Xen. Hiero, i. 12 ou) ta\ oi)/koi ke/kthntai e)xura\ w(/ste a)/llois parakataqeme/nous a)podhmei=n.

(2) 'Leave at death'; Odyss. vii. 150:
toi=sin qeoi\ o)/lbia doi=en
zwe/menai, kai\ paisi\n e)pitre/yeien e(/kastos
kth/mat' e)ni\ mega/roisi ge/ras q' o(/ ti dh=mos e)/dwken.
The Scholiast and many of the editors see a reference to Soter's abdication in favour of his son (285 B.C.). paisi/n is then awkward. It seems better to take e)pitre/pein in the second sense (leave at death), and regard the plural paisi/n as referring to the two children of Soter, Ptolemy II and his queen, Arsinoe Philadelphus, son and daughter of Soter and Berenice. It is no objection to this that this marriage did not take place till after Soter's death.

a)sto/rgou de\ gunaiko/s again a general sentiment, though some covert reference may be intended. If so it must remain covert. The words have been referred to almost every unfaithful woman known in the years 320-270 (and they were many). No one critic has convinced another as to who is meant. All that is certain is that Arsinoe I cannot be intended. On other claimants see Hiller.
poteoiko/ta Hesiod, )/*erg. 235 ti/ktousin de\ gunai=kes e)oiko/ta te/kna goneu=si: Catullus, lxi. 226.
meme/lhto a late Epic form used instead of me/mblhto; cf. xxvi. 36 and note on i. 50. For deification of Berenike see Introd. p. 4.

pa/roiq' e)pi\ nh=a katelqei=n. This use of pa/roiqe = pri/n does not occur elsewhere (? pa/ros as in xxii. 189; Iliad xi. 573); Quint. Smyrn. has even mexri\s i(ke/sqai, i. 830. Neither of these are given in Liddell and Scott.
kuane/an Leonidas 94 (A. Pal. vii. 67) tou=t' )*axe/rontos u(/dwr o(\s plw/eis porqmi/di kuane/h|: Verg. Aen. vi. 303 'ferruginea ... cumba.' So Theognis, 709 kuane/as te pu/las paramei/yetai.
stugno\n porqmh=a Propert. iii. 18. 24 'Scandenda est torvi publica cumba senis.'
e(a=s = sh=s. For genit. cf. Callim. iv. 9 *dh/lw| nu=n oi)/mhs a)poda/ssomai.
h(/de = Berenike, who receiving her divinity from Aphrodite receives the special cares and powers of that goddess.
didoi= cf. Odyss. iv. 237; Monro, Hom. Gram. § 18.
sqq. The panegyric turns now to the reigning Ptolemy; his birth in Cos (53-70), the power and extent of his kingdom (76-105), his bounty (106-120), his institution of divine honours to his parents.

)*argei/a = Deipyle, daughter of Adrastus, king of Argos, wife of Tydeus. The cruel Diomede is contrasted with the perfect knight Achilles; Achilles in turn is contrasted with Ptolemy, warrior son of warrior father, who is greater and better than either. Such is the simplest explanation of the three adversative clauses, su/, a)lla/, se\ de/. Others interpret 'as Achilles is above Diomede, so is Ptolemy above X; and X = Antigonos, son of Demetrius (so Droysen); cf. Legrand, Étude, p. 60.

a)ri/zhlos Callim. Ep. 51:
eu)ai/wn e)n pa=sin a)ri/zalos *bereni/ka
a(=s a)/ter ou)d' au)tai\ tai\ *xa/rites *xa/rites.

*ko/ws Ptolemy was born in Cos in 308 (Mahaffy, Empire of the Ptolemies, p. 54). This is made occasion for a piece of laboured flattery by Callimachus, iv. 160 (Leto in her wandering):
)*wgugi/hn dh/peita *ko/wn *merophi/da nh=son
i(/keto, *xalkio/phs i(ero\n muxo\n h(rwi/nhs:
a)lla/ e( paido\s (the unborn Apollo) e)/ruken e)/pos to/de mh\ su/
ge, mh=ter,
th=| me te/kois: ou) th\n e)pime/mfomai ou)de\ megai/rw
nh=son e)pei\ liparh/ te kai\ eu)/botos, ei)/ nu/ tis a)/llh:
a)lla/ oi( e)k moire/wn tis o)feilo/menos qeo\s a)/llos
e)sti/, *sawth/rwn u(/paton ge/nos: w(=| u(po\ mi/trhn (Theocr.
xvii. 19)
i(/cetai, ou)k a)e/kousa *makhdo/ni koirane/esqai,
a)mfote/rh meso/gaia kai\ ai(\ pela/gessi ka/qhntai,
me/xris o(/pou pera/th te kai\ o(ppo/qen w)ke/es i(/ppoi
)*he/lion fore/ousin: o( d' ei)/setai h)/qea patro/s.
It is instructive to compare the methods of Callimachus and Theocritus in dealing with the event.
)*antigo/nas Schol. k h( ga\r *bereni/kh e)sti\n h( quga/thr )*antigo/nhs th=s *kasandrou tou= )*antipa/trou.
bebarhme/na a form substituted by the later Epic for the old bebarhw/s.

sqq. *ko/ws d' o)lo/lucen cf. Callimachus' description of Delos at the birth of Apollo (h. Delos 264):
au)th\ de\ (Delos) xruse/oio a)p' ou)/deos ei(/leo pai=da,
e)n d' e)ba/leu ko/lpoisin, e)/pos d' e)fqe/gcao toi=on:
w)= mh=ter polu/bwme, polu/ptoli, polla\ fe/rousa,
au)th\ e)gw\ toih/de: dush/ratos a)ll' a)p' e)mei=o
*dh/lios )*apo/llwn keklh/setai: ou)de/ tis a)/llh
gaia/wn tosso/nde qew=| pefilh/setai a)/llw|
…w(s e)gw\ )*apo/llwni.
Both the Alexandrian poets extend the metaphorical expression of the island's joy as it appears in (e. g.) Theognis 8:
pa=sa me\n e)plh/sqh *dh=los a)peiresi/h
o)dmh=s a)mbrosi/hs, e)ge/lasse de\ gai=a pelw/rh
gh/qhsen de\ baqu\s po/ntos a(lo\s polih=s.

o)/lbie kou=re. The vocative stands by attraction as in xviii. 10; Eurip. Troad. 1221:
su/ t' w)= pot' ou)=sa kalli/nike muri/wn
mh=ter tropai/wn.
Livy, xxii. 50 'Tu quidem Cn. Corneli macte virtute esto,' etc.

e)n de\ mia=| tima=| *tri/opon kataqei=o, 'and set apart the hill of Triopon in one and the same united honour, giving equal right
to the Dorian states hard by.' The promontory Triopon or Triopion in Caria was the centre of cults of Demeter, Poseidon, the Nymphs, and especially Apollo, celebrated by the Dorian pentapolis of Lindus, Ialysus, Camirus, Cnidus, and Cos to the exclusion of other Dorian cities (Herod. i. 44; Stein, ad loc.). Great respect was paid to this religious union by Ptolemy II.
mia=| = a single united honour; not 'in one cult' with Cos, since Triopon was not a sovereign city participating in the league, but only a central point of meeting for the league.
*dwrie/essi…e)ggu\s e)ou=sin = the five Dorian cities above mentioned, united in one festival.

i)=son kai\ (*rh/naian. Rhenea is a small rocky island close to Delos, enumerated among the places which acknowledged the divine rule of Apollo (h. hymn Apoll. 44). The point of this line is not very clear; but by the position of i)=son at the head of ll. 69 and 70, the two lines are made parallel in expression and thought, as if it were written i)=son ne/mwn ge/ras *dwrie/essi w(s kai\ (*rh/naian e)fi/lasen )*apo/llwn (Valck. conjectures o(/sson unnecessarily for the second i)=son, cf. viii. 19). The sense seems therefore to be, 'Exalt Triopon to honour and include the neighbouring Dorians in one celebration, as Apollo exalted Delos and included even Rhenea in equal honour.' [Buecheler, followed by Ziegler, ejects the line; Reitzenstein reads *da=lon for i)=son: but the explanation above given seems sufficient justification, though the thought is not very happily expressed.
e)s tri/s cf. ii. 45. The cry of the eagle is the sign of the approval of Zeus thy well beloved king.

o( d' e)/coxos cf. h. hymn 30 (e)s *gh=n):
o( d' o)/lbios, o(/n ke su\ qumw=|
pro/frwn timh/sh|s: tw=| d' a)/fqona pa/nta pa/resti.
bri/qei me/n sfiu a)/roura fere/sbios……
…o)/lbos de\ polu\s kai\ plou=tos o)phdei=.

muri/ai a)/peiroi/ te kai\ e)/qnea. As the conjunctions te kai/ show, this phrase is to be taken as expressing a single notion, 'a thousand lands with their thousand tribes of men.' As a)/peiroi is the leading idea the feminine o)fello/menai stands rightly in l. 78, uninfluenced by e)/qnea muri/a. Meineke's remark (Praef. vii) 'Continentibus non gentes opponendae erant sed insulae,' and his conjecture, ei)n a(li\ na=soi, are therefore pointless. Cf. h. hymn. Apoll. 142 a)/llote d' a)\n nh/sous te kai\ a)ne/ras h)la/skazes.

*dio\s o)/mbrw| cf. Aesch. Agam. 1391. This is opposed to *nei=los a)nablu/zwn of l. 80; 'illae terrae laudantur propter fertilitatem pluvia auctam, Aegyptus magis fecundata esse dicitur Nilo exundante' (Ameis).

e)/rga dae/ntwn a civilized community acquainted with the arts; h. hymn. xx (ei)s (/*hfaiston) 3:
pa/ros per
a)/ntrois naieta/askon e)n ou)/resin h)u+/te qh=res.
nu=n de\ di' (/*hfaiston klutote/xnhn e)/rga dae/ntes, k.t.l.
sqq. The total number is 33333. A number which can be expressed in multiples of 3 or 9 has something sacred about it to a Greek. Cf. xxx. 27; Plato, Rep. 587 d.
meta\ de/ sfisin cf. i. 39.

e)mbasileu/ei should be kept against the proposed alterations a)ghnori/h| basileu/ei, etc., as we want a contrast between Ptolemy's home dominion in which he rules, and his foreign acquisitions. e)mbasileu/ei here takes the genit. like the simple verb.

a)pote/mnetai does not necessarily imply that the process of absorption is going on in active military operations at the time, though with *suri/as it could have this sense as referring to the Syrian war (Introd.). Tr. 'holds a slice of Phoenicia ...' Koepp holds that Palestine and Coele-Syria had been Egyptian provinces since the battle of Ipsos, and that Ptolemy II held these lands as inheritance from his father: Libya, Syria, Phoenicia, Cyprus, Lycia, Caria and the Cyclades passed by inheritance to Ptolemy III (Euergetes), who says also of himself that he made expeditions into Asia and e)kuri/euse th=s te e)nto\s *eu)fra/tou xw/ras pa/shs kai\ *kiliki/as kai\ *pamfuli/as kai\ )*iwni/as kai\ tou= (*ellhspo/ntou kai\ *qra/|khs. This does not however imply a first conquest but only a consolidation of dominion (vid. C. I. G. 5127).

*ai)qioph/wn. Ptolemy's control of Aethiopia was rather in the nature of a 'sphere of influence' than that of actual possession. There is no monumental record of Ptolemy higher than Philae, above the first cataract, but this temple was nominally on Nubian territory (Mahaffy). Much objection has been made to the omission of Cyprus in this list, and it has therefore been held that the poem must have been written at the time when the island was in revolt (? date). This would be as bad a blunder on Theocritus' part, as for an Egyptian court poet in 1888 to speak of the Soudan as loot to the Khedive. Cyprus is doubtless included loosely in na/sois *kukla/dessi.
na=es a)/ristai. On Ptolemy's fleet see Mahaffy, Empire of the Ptolemies, p. 126

qa/lassa…ai)=a…potamoi/. For this division of the globe into land, sea, and rivers, cf. Hesiod, Theog. 108 qeoi\ kai\ gai=a ge/nonto kai\ potamoi\ kai\ po/ntos a)pei/ritos: Eurip. H. F. 1295:
fwnh\n ga\r h(/sei xqw\n a)penne/pousa/ me
mh\ qigga/nein gh=s kai\ qa/lassa mh\ pera=n
phgai/ te potamw=n.
Wilam.-Moellend. ad loc.

a)na/ssontai *ptolemai/w| not simply 'by Ptolemy,' as if it were u(po\ *ptolemai/ou. The dative is the 'dativus commodi'; 'Are Ptolemy's dominion.' Cf. Odyss. iv. 177 (po/leis) ai(\ perinaieta/ousin a)na/ssontai d' e)moi\ au)tw=|.
a)fneo\n…oi)=kon see Mahaffy, p. 130. S. Jerome puts the income of Ptolemy at 14,800 silver talents.

to/sson cf. ii. 161; xxiv. 77, 118; where an explanatory clause is similarly introduced. Callim. Delos, 216:
su\ d' ou)k a)/r' e)/melles a)/pustos
dh\n e)/menai: toi/h se pare/dramen a)ggeliw=tis.
Early writers usually add ga/r: Iliad xxi. 288; Solon, iv. 3. This is dropped when ga/r becomes distinctly = 'for.' So even Odyss. xiv. 326.

-101. boa\n…e)pi\ bousi/n. There is neither formal invasion, nor raid of freebooters. Cf. Bacchyl. xviii. 5:
h)= tis a(mete/ras xqono\s
dusmenh\s o(/ri' a)mfiba/llei
stratage/tas a)nh/r;
h)= lh|stai\ kakuma/xanoi
poime/nwn a)e/kati mh/lwn
seu/ont' a)ge/las bi/a|;
e)pi/ of the object aimed at; cf. i. 49; xxii. 145.
e)pi\ pa/gxu. Another instance of the fondness of later Greek for joining a preposition with an adverb. Cf. Ap. Rhod. iii. 511 e(h=| e)pi\ pa/gxu pe/poiqen h)nore/h| (e)pi\ ma=llon, Herod. i. 94).
ou) ma\n a)xrei=o/s ge, 'Yet his wealth is not piled idle in his rich treasure house like the wealth of toiling ants.' Cf. xvi. 22.
a)ei/ belongs to ke/xutai as well as to mogeo/ntwn.

murma/kwn cf. Crates (Bergk, xlviii):
xrh/mata d' ou)k e)qe/lw suna/gein kluta/, kanqa/rou o)/lbon
mu/rmhko/s t' a)/fenos xrh/mata maio/menos.

qew=n…oi)=koi, k.t.l. : with the whole passage compare the parallel lines 16, 22 sqq., and the references there given. Ptolemy's munificence towards the state religion is attested by the monuments. Professor Mahaffy (loc. cit. p. 184 sqq.) mentions as founded or restored by Ptolemy the temple of Philae (Upper Egypt), a common temple of the Greek gods near Naukratis (West Delta), a temple of Isis near Sebennytos (Central Delta), a temple at Pithom (East Delta).
a)parxome/noio gen. abs. with subject unexpressed. Cf. Xen. Anab. v. 4. 16 oi( de\ pole/mioi, prosio/ntwn, te/ws h(su/xazon.

kat' a)gw=nas either 'through the contests,' or better, 'for the contests,' as kata\ qe/an h(/kein, Thucyd. vi. 31; cf. iii. 6, note. There was a guild of Dionysiac artists settled at Ptolemais (Mahaffy, p. 79). In 275 B.C. was celebrated a great pomph/ in which Dionysus and Semele were the recipients of especial honour. Athenaeus, pp. 198 sqq., 118 sqq.; cf. xvi., 40 sqq.

a)e/ri pa| ke/kruptai. 'But that uncounted wealth which they won by capture of the halls of Priam is buried somewhere in the gloom from whence there is no returning.' a)e/ri pa| = 'the gloom of the dead world.' The phrase is freed from ambiguity by the clause o(/qen pa/lin ou)ke/ti no/stos (cf. xii. 19, note). a)h/r passes from the meaning of air to that of mist (which is only thickened air, for in nubem cogitur aer, Verg. Aen. v. 20; cf. Odyss. xi. 15 h)e/ri kai\ nefe/lh| kekalumme/noi), thence to that of darkness; Ap. Rhod. i. 777 a)sth\r kuane/oio di' h)e/ros…kalo\n e)reuqo/menos: iv. 1285:
o(/tan h)e/lios me/sw| h)/mati nu/kt' e)pa/gh|sin
ou)rano/qen ta\ de\ lampra\ di' h)e/ros a)/stra faei/nh|.
So h)e/rios = dark; Aratus, 349 h)eri/h kai\ a)na/steros, and h)erofoi=tis )*erinu/s is the vengeance that walketh in darkness (vid. Buttmann, Lexilogus, pp. 37 sqq.). Add a quaint derivation in Et. Mag. 437 h)ri/a tou\s ta/fous…para\ to\n a)e/ra h)/goun to\n e)pikei/menon sko/ton toi=s teqnew=si.

a)e/ri here is therefore = zo/fon h)ero/enta (Iliad xv. 191) or h)ero/enti bere/qrw| (Quint. Smyrn. vi. 264). Cf. A. Pal. vii 283 (Leonidas) )*ai/dao kako\n e)pieime/nos a)xlu/n: Ap. Rhod. ii. 923 kai/ r(' o( me\n au)=tis e)/dune me/gan zo/fon.

mou=nos de/. 'But alone, of all who went before or whose warm steps are yet printed in the trodden dust, has he established temples sweet with incense to his mother and his sire.' This refers of course to the newly established cult of Ptolemy I (Soter) and Berenice, as qeoi\ swth=res (Introd. p. 10).

w(=n e)/ti qerma/, k.t.l. is simply a periphrasis for the living; qerma/ = warm with life, Herond. sa/rkes oi(=a qerma\ phdw=sai: A. Pal. vii. 371 which Hiller quotes is hardly parallel, but cf. the 'Carol of King Wenceslaus':
'In his master's steps he trod,
Where the snow lay dinted.
Heat was in the very sod
Which the saint had printed.'
Plutarch, Moral 517 F ou)x e(/wla kaka\ a)/lla qerma\ kai\ pro/sfata.
a)rwgou/s with reference to their title; qeoi\ swth=res.

mhsi\ periplome/noisi lit. 'in the months as they return.' Arist. Clouds 311 h)=ri/ t' e)perxome/nw|: Soph. O. T. 156 peritellome/nais w(/rais. The dative is temporal, and the notion of time given in the subst. is further defined by the participle (nukti\ d' i)ou/sh|, 'at the coming of night'; Ap. Rhod. iv. 977).
e)reuqome/nwn e)pi\ bwmw=n cf. Shirley's 'upon Death's purple altar.'
kasi/gnhto/n te Iliad xvi. 432 (/*hrhn de\ prose/eipe kasignh/thn t' a)/loxo/n te.

w(=de kai/… The comparison--inevitable though blasphemous--with the marriage of Zeus to Hera is suggested by the relationship of Ptolemy and Arsinoe given in l. 130: this cannot be taken as a proof that this poem was written for the marriage, an idea which is precluded by l. 127.

e(\n de/ cf. xviii. 19 e)/ti parqe/nos in reference to a little known myth of the marriage of Iris and Zephyr; Nonnus, xxxi. 110:
=)*iris a)ecifu/tou *zefu/rou xruso/ptere nu/mfh
eu)/loxe mh=ter )/*erwtos.
(See Legrand, p. 96.)

xai=re a)/nac… The encomium ends in the manner of the Homeric hymns:
kai\ su\ me\n ou(/tw xai=re, *dio\s kai\ *lhtou=s ui(e\
au)ta\r e)gw\ kai\ sei=o kai\ a)/llhs mnh/som' a)oidh=s--(h. Apoll.).
e)k *dio/s. The promise of the opening line is redeemed, and the poem which began with Zeus ends with Zeus.

a)reth/n…ai)teu=, 'wealth thou hast and the praise of men, but goodness comes by prayer to God alone.' The poem touches for the moment a higher strain as do Horace's greater odes ('Dis te minorem quod geris imperas'). That wealth must be accompanied by a)reth/ is a frequent theme in Pindar (Pyth. v. 1):
o( plou=tos eu)rusqenh/s,
o(/tan tis a)reta=| kekrame/non kaqara=|
broth/sios a)nh\r po/tmou parado/ntos ai'to\n a)na/gh|
polu/filon e(pe/tan.
Cf. the close of Callimachus' Hymn to Zeus:
xai=re, pa/ter, xai=r' au)=qi: di/dou d' a)reth/n t' a)/feno/s te.
ou)/t' a)reth=s a)/ter o)/lbos e)pi/statai a)/ndras a)e/cein,
ou)/t' a)reth\ a)fe/noio: di/dou d' a)reth/n te kai\ o)/lbon.

div1.p: This poem is an epithalamium for the marriage of Menelaus and Helen, sung before the bride-chamber by twelve Spartan maidens. Theocritus is said by the Scholiast to have imitated Stesichorus' epithalamium in this idyll. This cannot be proved or disproved, but it is certain that the poem shows marked traces of Sappho's influence (vid. notes on ll. 16, 49, 29). From l. 43 sqq. G. Kaibel (Hermes, xxvii. 249) argues that the object of the poem is aetiological--to explain the origin of a Spartan cult; cf. Helen of the Plane Tree. If there was such a cult it is only known from the poem, but there was a worship of Helen *dendri=tis in Rhodes (Pausan. iii. 19. 10). In the same way Kaibel would explain the a)/ra of line 1; 'I have taken on me to explain this cult; know then that it was in Sparta that ...' But the manner in which the reference to this cult is introduced makes it impossible to recognize aetiology as the motif of the poem; 'the lines 43 sqq. appear as a simple episode, not as the kernel of the piece' (Legrand, p. 83 sqq.).

The a)/ra must be differently explained. If there is no context unknown to us of the poem it must be taken as marking a very sudden break, 'in medias res' (cf. xxii. 27). This is not probable, and the beginning would not be justified by such a sudden opening as that of xxv or Bret Harte's 'Which I wish to remark ...' It is more likely that the poem was written under some special conditions which we do not know, to which this a)/ra refers--either as an answer to some friend's work (cf. Nicias' answer to xi), or in answer to some request for a poem on the subject of Helen--or, it might be, merely after reading some Helen legend or poem which impressed Theocritus by its beauty or its strangeness. There is a striking resemblance
between the opening lines and the fragment that is left of Bacchylides' Ode xx
*spa/rta| pot' e)n [
canqa=| *lakeda[i/mon
toio/nde me/los k [
o(/t' a)/geto kallipa/rh|on
ko/ran qrasuka/r[dios )/*idas
*marph/ssan i)o[ste/fanon,
and it is not unlikely that had we all the poem we should have the key to this idyll. Date and place of composition are wholly unknown.

div2.p: a)/ra, 'so it was in Sparta in golden-haired Menelaus' halls.'
canqo/trixi Odyss. i. 285 para\ canqo\n *mene/laon.

e)n…*spa/rta|. For separation of prep. from case cf. Pind. Ol. i. 17 a)mfi\ qama\ tra/pezan: Plato, Laws 797 d e)n w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n ou) toi=s me\n toi=s d' ou): Callim. i. 10 e)n de/ de *parrasi/h| (*rei/h te/ke.
parqenikai/ substantival, cf. xii. 5: often in Alexandrine poetry.

neogra/ptw qala/mw. A new qa/lamos was built for each marriage; see Xen. Ephes. A. viii. 2 h)=n d' au)toi=s o( qa/lamos ou(/tws pepoihme/nos: kli/nh xrush= strw/masin e)/strwto porfuroi=s kai\ e)pi\ th=s kli/nhs babulwni/a e)pepoi/kilko skhnh/: pai/zontes e)/rwtes oi( me\n )*afrodi/thn qerapeu/ontes (h)=n de\ kai\ )*afrodi/ths ei)kw\n) oi( de\ i(ppeu/ontes a)naba/tai strouqoi=s, k.t.l. Buecheler quotes from the Rhetor. Graec. ix. 271 qa/lamos de\ pepoi/kiltai a)/nqesi kai\ grafai=s pantoi/ais.

me/ga xrh=ma *lakaina=n, 'all the flower of Lacedaemon's beauty'; Xen. Ephes. A. i. 1 pai=s )*abroko/mas me/ga ti xrh=ma ka/llous: Plut. Anton. 31 th
 a)delfh
 xrh=ma qaumasto
 w(s le/getai gunaiko/s.
*tundarida=n katede/cato, 'when he woo'd and received to his home (kata-) from the Tyndaridae that lovely bride, Helen.'

*tundarida=n = the Dioscuri, brothers of Helen. I have ventured to adopt a new reading for this line--vid. Note Crit. Assuming katede/cato as the original the variants can be satisfactorily explained: katele/cato (D) by *l for *d: katekli/neto (s) as an attempt to explain katele/cato (the writer understood it as = kata/lekto): kategle/geto (h 11) show g and l confused (easy in uncial or minuscule), etc. Juntine has katekla/cato, whence Meineke and recent editors katekla/|cato: cf. xv. 77, not a very happy expression here. This makes it necessary to take *tundarida=n ta
 a)gaphta/n as 'caram Tyndaridarum,' i.e. 'eam quae erat de Tyndarei liberis carissima' (Hiller). But *tundarida=n always = the Dioscuri without Helen (vid. xxii. 216; Pind. Ol. iii. 1); and ta
 a)gaphta
 *tundarida=n is doubtful Greek. We can say daimo/nie a)ndrw=n, but not o( daimo/nios a)ndrw=n: and a)gaphta/n is not a superlative in sense.
d' a)/ra resuming after the digression.

ei)s e(\n me/los; cf. Catull. lxi. 38:
'Agite in modum
Dicite, O Hymenaee Hymen,
Hymen O Hymenaee.'
e)gkrote/oisai of the beat of the foot in the dance.

possi\ periple/ktois the 'woven paces' of the dancers; cf. Odyss. viii. 264:
pe/plhgon de\ xoro\n qei=on posi/n: au)ta\r )*odusseu\s
marmaruga\s qhei=to podw=n, qau/maze de\ qumw=|.

u(po\…u(menai/w| (not u(pi/axe); cf. Callim. ii. 49 u(p' e)/rwti kekaume/nos: Bacchyl. iii. 17 la/mpei d' u(po\ marmarugai=s o( xruso\s u(yidaida/ltwn tripo/dwn. The use of u(po/ with dative differs little from the simple dative of cause; cf. Soph. Trach. 205.
sqq. From here follows the song of the maidens sung in unison by the whole band. It is useless to attempt to cut the song into equal strophes.
prwize/ vocative by attraction; cf xvii. 16. The adjective is used for the adverb as in xiv. 2; xvi. 95, etc.
h)= r(a polu/n tin' e)/pines, k.t.l. 'hast thou drunk somewhat heavily that thou hast thrown thyself a-bed?'

polu/n tina, sc. oi)=non: Herond. vi. 77 gluku\n piei=n e)gxeu=sa. The addition of tis to this elliptical use of polu/s gives great offence to Cobet, but cf. Lucian, i. 474 tw=| *mi/nwi mi/a tis (sc. di/kh) kai\ pro\s xa/rin e)dika/sqh.
o(/t' cf. xii. 16; xvi. 11; xi. 54, notes.
eu(/dein ma\n speu/donta, 'if thou didst wish to sleep betimes thou shouldst have slept alone.'
For au)to/n cf. x. 19; v. 85. kaq' w(/ran cf. xxi. 40.

e)/nas kai\ e)s a)w=, 'since to-morrow and to-morrow, and from year to year'; cf. Hesiod, )/*erg. 408 ei)/s t' au)/rion ei)s t' e)/nnhfin: Lucian, i. 229 w)= (/*hlie mh\ e)la/sh|s th/meron mhd' au)/rion mhd' e)s tri/thn h(me/ran. Observe that e)s is to be used thus only when the date is still prospective; ei)s th\n e)piou=san i(ke/tai h(/kontes, Lucian, Tox. 55, is incorrect for th=| e)piou/sh|.

*mene/lae tea\ nuo\s a(/de for nuo/s see xv. 77. The trochaic caesura in the fourth foot of a hexameter is exceedingly rare in Greek, and may generally be excused by the close conjunction of the words forming it or by elision, Monro, Hom. Gram. § 367, but cf. Odyss. xvii. 399 mh\ tou=to qeo\s tele/seien. There is however no true example in the Alexandrian poets. Hence Meineke here *mene/la tea\ a( nuo\s a(/de.

o)/lbie ga/mbre cf. Sappho, 99:
o)/lbie ga/mbre soi\ me\n dh\ ga/mos, w)s a)/rao,
e)ktete/lest', e)/xh|s de\ pa/rqenon, a(\n a)/rao.
a)gaqo/s tis e)pe/ptaren, k.t.l. (sc. a)/nqrwpos). Some man of good omen sneezed upon thee as thou didst go, as went the other heroes unto Sparta, that thou might'st win thy quest.

w(s a)nu/saio depends on e)pe/ptaren not on e)rxome/nw|. For the good omen cf. vii. 96; Xen. Anab. iii. 2. 9, where a sneeze is called oi)wno\s tou= *dio\s tou= *swth=ros: Arist. Aves 720 ptarmo/n t' o)/rniqa kalei=te.

a)gaqo/s, 'lucky'; cf. Callim. v. 124:
gnwsei=tai d' o)/rnixas o(\s ai)/sios oi(/ te pe/tontai
h)/liqa kai\ poi/wn ou)k a)gaqai\ pte/ruges.
Cf. Schol. vii. 96 tw=n ptarmw=n oi( me\n w)felou=si oi( de\ ei)si\ blaberoi/. (Fritzsche-Hiller explain a)gaqo/s = a good man, and assume that the sneeze of a saint was more effective than a rogue's.)
a(/per sc. poiou=si.

e)s *spa/rtan. In the usual form of the story Helen was woo'd at Amyclae, not Sparta; but Theocritus here follows another legend, which appears also in Isocr. 215 e meta\ ga th
 *qhse/ws ei)s (/*aidou kata/basin e)panelqou/shs (th=s (*ele/nhs) au)=qis ei)s *lakedai/mona kai\ pro\s to\ mnhsteu/esqai labou/shs h(liki/an a(/pantes oi( to/te basileu/ontes kai\ dunasteu/ontes (these are Theocritus' a)/lloi a)riste/es) th
 au)th
 gnw/mhn e)/sxon peri\ au)th=s…u(perido/ntes ga tou\s oi)/koi ga/mous h)=lqon e)kei/nhn mnhsteu/sontes.
*kroni/dan penqero/n cf. Odyss. iv. 569 ou(/nek' e)/xeis (*ele/nhn kai/ sfin gambro\s *dio/s e)ssi.
h(miqe/ois cf. Isocr. x. 43. Not to be altered to h)iqe/ois.

penqero/n both Greek and Latin affect this roundabout way of stating connexion by marriage, cf. Pind. Isth. vi. 37 *phleu\s…gambro\s qew=n: Verg. Georg. i. 31 'teque sibi generum Tethys emat omnibus undis.'
ta\n mi/an, 'the same'; Callim. iv. 75 feu=ge kai\ )*anni/h to\n e(/na dro/mon.

oi(/a )*axaiia/dwn gai=an patei=, 'whose peer treads not the earth among the maids of Greece'; cf. Odyss. xxi. 107 oi(/h nu=n ou)k e)/sti gunh\ kat' )*axaii/da gai=an: Sappho, 106 ou) ga\r h)=n e)te/ra pa/i+s w)= ga/mbre toiau/ta.

patei= cf. Soph. Philoc. 1060 xai=re ga\r *lh=mnon patw=n: Lycoph. 200 xw( me\n path/sei xw=ron ai)a/zwn *sku/qhn. ai)=an here is 'the earth' not 'a land' as usually; cf. Quint Smyrn. ix. 416 w(=n e(ka\s ou)/tis a)nh\r e)pini/ssetai ai)=an.

ai)=s dro/mos wu(to/s, k.t.l. : see Eurip. Androm. 597 sqq.; Propert. iii. 14:
'Multa tuae Sparte miramur iura palaestrae,
Sed mage virginei tot bona gymnasii.
Quod non infames exercet corpore ludos
Inter luctantes nuda puella viros.'
qh=lus fem. as in Homeric qh=lus e)e/rsh.
ta=n ou)d' e(/n tis a)/mwmos, 'of whom no one is faultless when compared with Helen.' The MSS. reading ou)d' a)/n presents an impossible ellipse.

26, 27 )*aw\s a)nte/lloisa, k.t.l. In this couplet and in 29, 30 we have similes expressive of Helen's beauty. The restoration of the text in the latter place may be considered certain. As there the comparison is threefold and gives an image of Helen's gracefulness, so here we have an expression of her bright beauty, and for the sake of uniformity of style expect three similes and an absence of any introductory particle. I have therefore ejected a(/te in 28, and introduced what is suggested by the ductus litterarum and the form of the verse to/ te. Tr. 'lovely shines forth the face of rising dawn, lovely the face of holy night, and lovely the clear spring when winter ceases from the land. So shines forth golden Helen among us; a glory to the rich field springs up the great harvest, a glory to
the garden is the cypress, a glory to the chariot the horse of Thessaly. So is blushing Helen a glory to Lacedaemon.'

po/tnia nu/c has been strangely objected to and more strangely altered. It is not the moon but the clear night of stars, for Helen 'walks in beauty like the night.' po/tnia personifies nu/c into a living goddess; cf. ii. 69 and 167; cf. Grenfell's 'Erotic fragment,' col. ii. a)/stra fi/la kai\ sunerw=sa po/tnia nu/c moi. to/ te also Kaibel, but with po/tn' a)w/s for po/tnia nu/c: h)/ for a(/te, Steig.
