Other 'emendations' proceed chiefly on the assumption that a contrast between the dark night and bright day is intended; po/tnia disproves this, and the threefold comparison must be kept.
leuko/n cf. Callim. vi. 122 leuko\n e)/ar leuko\n de\ qe/ros, kai\ xei=ma fe/roisa.
die/fane gnomic aorist. For sense of shines out cf. Pind. Pyth. iii. 79 kaiome/na d' au)tw=| die/fane pura/.
a)/trion (h)/trion), 'warp.'

eu)ru/sternon denotes Athene as the goddess of battle, not here the goddess of cunning work. Helen is not imagined as singing at her loom as Ahrens supposes, when he conjectures kro/kan and eu(resi/ergon for lu/ran and eu)ru/sternon.

e)p o)/mmasin i(/meroi cf. Eurip. Bacch. 456 po/qou ple/ws: Pind. N. viii. 1 w(/ra po/tnia,…parqenhi/ois pai/dwn e)fi/zoisa glefa/rois: hom. h. Demet. 214 e)pi/ toi pre/pei o)/mmasin ai)dw\|s kai\ xa/ris.
oi)ke/tis, 'housewife.'

a)/mmes d' e)s dro/mon, 'we will hie us in the morning to our course, and to the flowers of the field.' fu/lla, as in xi 26, of flowers. The passage seems to be imitated by Coluthus, who says of Helen (340) oi)=de keleu/qous e)s r(o/don e)s leimw=na.
sqq. Vid. Introductory note, pra=tai, referring to the establishment of this cult of Helen--if such existed. The plane tree was a marked feature of Sparta (Pausan. iii. 14. 8).
staceu=mes = sta/comen (sta/zw).
gra/mmata d' e)n floiw=|, 'and letters shall be written on the bark, for the passer-by to read, in Dorian wise: honour me: I am Helen's tree.'
a)nnei/mh| (a)nane/mw) in rarer sense of 'reading' = a)nagignw/skw.

*dwristi/ cf. xiii. 56; xiv. 46. The argument for regarding ll. 44 sqq. as referring to the establishment of a cult is considerably strengthened by this line. *dwristi/ cannot be taken here as = in Doric. It was by no means a peculiar Dorian custom to cut a name on a tree trunk; but these tree worships seem to have been especially Dorian. gra/mmata then = not only the name 'Helen,' but the dedication of the tree, and injunction to worship. Hiller takes *dwristi/ = in Doric brevity! This is surely absurd, and should at least be *spartiati/. Ameis 'Doriensium more,' i. q. pie, sancte. Why?
xai/rois cf. Sappho, 103 xai/roisa nu/mfa, xai/retw d' o( ga/mbros: ib. 105 xai=re nu/mfa xai=re ti/mie ga/mbre po/lla.

-52. *latw\…*latw\ kourotro/fos. The repetition of the name in each case in these three lines, adds a solemnity and dignity to the prayer. In l. 51, qea/, 'that great goddess'; cf. Aesch. Eumenid. 224 dika\s de\ *palla\s tw=nd' e)popteu/sei qea/. The repetition can easily be paralleled, e. g. Verg. Aen. viii. 71: Macaulay's 'O Tiber, Father Tiber.'

w(s…e)/nqh| the subject is o)/lbon.
'From princely sire to princely son
For ever to descend.'--Calverley.
e)s o)/rqron see on l. 14.
pra=tos a\oido/s, 'the first cockcrow.'

eu)/trixa of a bird; is now paralleled by Bacchyl. v. 28:
lepto/trixa su\n *zefu/rou pnoai=sin
e)/qeiran a)ri/gnwtos met' a)nqrw/pois i)dei=n:
of an eagle.
Catull. lxii. 5 'Hymen O Hymenaee, Hymen ades O Hymenaee.'

div1.p: See Introd. § 3, esp. p. 54. The piece is not by Theocritus; probably by Bion (Bion, xix, Hermann: Incert. iv, Ahrens). The idea is reproduced in Anacreont. 33 (Bergk); Nicet. Eugen. iv. 313.

div2.p: suleu/menon. From an -e/w form, collateral with sula/w. The middle only here.
da/ktula vid. Liddell and Scott.
5, 6 tutqo/n…a(li/ka trau/mata cf. iv. 55.
ma/thr sc. Aphrodite.

e)/fus, 'wert born,' so 'art'; cf. e)/gento, l. 88. The hiatus kai\ a(li/ka is excused by the slight pause before the exclamatory a(li/ka, and by its position at the bucolic caesura. Cf. ii. 154, etc. For the sense cf. Anacreont. xxxiii. 13:
a( d' ei)=pen ei) to\ ke/ntron
ponei= to\ ta=s meli/ttas
po/son dokei=s ponou=sin
)/*erws o(/sous su\ ba/lleis;
Moschus, ii. ()/*erws drape/ths) 18:
to/con e)/xei ma/la baio\n u(pe\r to/cw de\ be)lemnon.
tu/tqon me\n to\ be/lemnon, e)s ai)qe/ra d' a)xri\ forei=tai.

div1.p: On the authorship of this poem see Introduction, § 3: Hiller, Beiträge, pp. 70-73.

div2.p: It is not clear to whom the speaker addresses himself. If it is to the poime/nes of l. 19 the long delay in showing the situation is most inartistic. If it is gh=| te kou)ranw=|, the apostrophe of the poime/nes is ridiculous. Contrast this awkwardness with any of the genuine Theocritean pieces.
qli/bein, 'to press'; qli/bein da/ktula, Musaeus, 114.

oi(=a ble/peis. Theocritus has a^ before bl only elsewhere in xvii. 136. In later Greek more often; Anacreont. xv. 18 to\ de^ ble/mma: A. Pal. xii. 199 (Strato) a)lla\ pa/rwra ble/pw (Plato, Ep. 14 w(s polloi=s o)/mmasin ei)/s se ble/pw). The form of verse in three detached divisions occurs in Theocritus only in viii. 41; often in late writers, vid. Meineke.
o(ppoi=a wrongly used for oi(=a (exclamation).
ai)ka/lleis, 'wheedle.'

a(de/a h(du/s is here treated as of two terminations, as in Odyss. xii. 369 h(du\s a)u+tmh/: and makes accus. in -ea instead of -un, as eu)re/a po/nton, Iliad vi. 291. So Epit. Bion. 83 a(de/a po/rtin. (Theocritus has nom. a(de/a, accus. a(dei=an.)
tri\s ei)s e(o/n imitated from Theocr. vi. 39. The spitting averted evil.
muxqi/zoisa cf. A. Pal. v. 178 (Meleager) ti/ ma/taia gela=|s kai\ sima\ seshrw\s muxqi/zeis;

sesaro\s…e)ge/lacen (e)ge/lasse would be the correct form; and so Ahrens restores), 'laughed in derision and disdain.' seshro/s is here used in its usual sense--smiling scornfully; see note on vii. 19. It is cognate accus., cf. Babrius, l. 14 seshro\s ai)ka/llousa sobaro/n: A. Pal. vi. 1 h( sobaro\n gela/sasa kaq' (*ella/dos…*lai+/s.

w(s r(o/don e(/rsa| cf. Callim. v. 27:
to\ d' e)/reuqos a)ne/dramen, prw/ion oi(/an
h)\ r(o/don h)\ si/bdas ko/kkos e)/xei xroi+/an.
u(poka/rdion o)rga/n from Theocr. xi. 15.

to\ krh/guon, 'the truth.' The word is used in this sense by Archias, A. Pal. 57 *nh/pi' e)/rws porqei=s me to\ krh/guon: and by Leonidas, A. Pal. vii. 648 h)/|dei )*aristokra/ths to\ krh/guon. It is usually used of persons 'true,' 'honest'; Theocr. Ep. xix; Herond. vi. 39 gunaiko/s e)sti krhgu/hs fe/rein pa/nta.
a)/llon, 'different'; Lucian, i. 208 (Ganymede to Zeus) pw=s ou)=n ta\ ptera/ soi e)kei=na e)cerru/hke su\ de\ a)/llos h)/dh a)nape/fhnas;
-31. The whole passage is imitated from Theocritean lines; vi. 34; xi. 19, 31, 38, 76.

21, 22 u(ph/nh must here = 'lip' or 'chin,' not the moustache; cf. A. Pal. ii. 136 i)/oulon ku/klon u(ph/nhs. Nor do the difficulties of the lines stop with this. As ka/llos is subject to e)pu/kazen, e)pa/nqeen a(du/ ti ka/llos must be taken of a growth of hair; not of complexion, as would naturally be the case (to\ e)ru/qhma e)panqei=, Lucian, Imag. 7); and though a)nqe/w and a)/nqos are used of hair it involves a violation of language to use e)panqei=n so without further definition. The expression is therefore only partly justified by such phrases as tou\s i)/oulon a)nqeu=ntas (Herond. i. 52):
pw/gwn eu)ru\s e)pe/ptato ka/llos u(fai/nwn
sth/qei+ gumnwqe/nti kai\ i(mero/enti prosw/pw| (A. Pal. ii. 328);
pri\n…u(po\ krota/foisin i)ou/lous
a)nqh=sai puka/sai te ge/nus eu)anqe/i+ la/xnh| (Odyss. xi. 319).
Graefe conjectured a(du\s i)/oulos, but this is palaeographically most improbable. Nor is the transposition of 22 and 23 (Graefe and Meineke) of service since xai=tai oi(=a se/lina can only be used of thick clustering curls on the brow.

26, 27 glukerw/teron should be kept in both places. The writer tries to imitate the Theocritean repetition of leading words (Introd. § 2). Valckenaer's a(palw/teron is hardly justified by Longus' xei/lh me\n r(o/dwn a(palwte/ra kai\ sto/ma khri/wn gluku/teron (whence Nicet. Eugen. vi. 356 xei=los me\n au)xei=s a(palw/teron r(o/dou, k.t.l.). Nonnus seems to imitate the present passage; Dionys. xlvii. 105:
e)k stoma/twn de\
h(dumanh\s a)la/laze xe/wn a)/graulon a)oidh/n.
dw/naki = do/naki, formed on analogy of ou)/noma, dou/rata, *douli/xion. First in Leonidas, 81 (see Geffcken, ad loc.).
ta\ d' a)stika/. The neuter plural is used contemptuously; 'those town girls.'

I have left the text as printed by Ziegler. Tr. 'And does not know that the fair Dionysus tended cattle in the glades.' But there is no legend of Dionysus as a herdsman; the only fable which could be used to justify this line is one preserved by Plutarch (Sympos. iv. 5. 3), that Adonis was none other than Dionysus; to\n de\ )/*adwnin ou)x e(/teron a)lla\ *dio/nuson ei)=nai nomi/zousi kai\ polla\ tw=n teloume/nwn e(kate/rw| peri\ ta\s e(orta\s bebaiou=si to\n lo/gon. Another account, says Plutarch, made Adonis loved by Dionysus: w(s qei=on )/*adwnin o)reifoi/ths *dio/nusos h(/rpasen (Phanocles). It it just possible, therefore, that the writer of this poem identified the two persons, or expanded the latter legend. But the text is very uncertain, and the head of the line was apparently lost. Possibly we should read a)kou/ei. ou)k a)/llos *dio/nusos…e)lau/nw; 'do I not ... a second Dionysus (in beauty)?'

From Bion, Epit. Adon. 68 mhke/t' e)ni\ drumoi/si to
 a)ne/ra mu/reo *ku/pri. With the whole passage cf. Longus, iv. 17. 6 ei) de\ nemo/ntos h)ra/sqhn qeou\s e)mimhsa/mhn: bouko/los h)=n )*agxi/shs kai\ e)/sxen au)to
 )*afrodi/th: ai)=gas e)/neme *bra/gxos kai\ )*apo/llwn au)to
 e)fi/lhse: poimh
 h)=n *ganumh/dhs kai\ au)to
 *zeu\s h(/rpase. Cf. Theocr. iii. 40 sqq.

la/qrion…h)=lqe, 'stole secretly through the grove.' The reading *la/tmion (Juntine) should be unhesitatingly rejected. The reading in the text, ei)s e(/na, is only conjectural. To explain it understand not to/pon but u(/pnon, easily supplied from kaqeude (cf. Lucian, i. 293 w(s baqu\n e)koimh/qhs). ei)s with numerals as l. 25, etc. paidi/ is dative of association, or of advantage. Tr. 'Slept one sleep with the lad.' (Paley conjectures ei)n e(ni/: cf. A. Pal. v. 293 ei)n e(ni\ qhteu/sei *palla/di kai\ *pafi/h|: near to MSS. would be a(de/a often written a)de/a in MSS.)

o)/rnis e)pla/gxqhs according to one form of the legend, Zeus himself in the form of an eagle snatched away Ganymede. Lucian, i, 208; Nonnus, xv. 280:
kai\ *dio\s oi)noxo/os pe/le bouko/los, o(\n dia\ ka/llos
feidome/nois o)nu/xessin e)kou/fisen u(yipeth\s *zeu/s.
The sense is, 'Have no more amours in country or in town, Cypris; Eunica has laid down a new law for gods and men' (Zettel).

div1.head: (Incert. III, Ahrens).
div1.p: On the authorship of this idyll see Introd. § 3, pp. 54, 55. The scheme of the poem is as follows:--After the prefatory lines to Diophantus the writer passes to narrative. Two fishermen lie asleep in their cabin by the sea, with the poor implements of their craft about them. Waking before the night is half done one tells his fellow how he had dreamed that he had caught a wondrous golden fish, and sworn that he would desert his calling and live on land on the gold he had won. The oath he swore in his sleep troubles him. Is it binding? His companion bids him pay no thought to his dream, or likely enough he will starve while he neglects more solid fish.

div2.p:
au)ta/, 'alone.' For sentiment cf. Arist. Plutus 533:
*peni/a.
e)gw\ ga\r
to\n xeirote/xnhn w(/sper de/spoin' e)panagka/zousa ka/qhmai
dia\ th\n xrei/an kai\ th\n peni/an zhtei=n o(po/qen bi/on e(/cei.
e)pimu/sshsi. The i_ is lengthened as in Epic; cf. xxii. 19; die_moira=to, Odyss. xiv. 434; mono_/lukos, Aratus, 1124, etc.

e)fista/menai, 'haunting,' properly 'standing over the bed';
so Aesch. Agam. 14 fo/bos ga\r a)nq' u(/pnou parastatei=. Cf. Odyss. xix. 515:
au)ta\r e)ph\n nu\c e)/lqh|, e(/lh|si/ te koi=tos a(/pantas,
kei=mai e)ni\ le/ktrw|, pukinai\ de/ moi a)mf' a(dino\n kh=r
o)cei=ai meledw=nes o)durome/nhn e)re/qousin.
o(/mws, 'although poverty and care snatch away sleep.' o(mw=s Steph. and most editors unnecessarily.
i)xqu/os the singular is to be taken collectively; cf. xiv. 17, note, and Introd. p. 55.
bru/on, 'seaweed.'
plektai=s, 'woven of reeds and wattles'; cf. kalu/bh| sxoini/tidi, A. Pal. vii. 295 (Leonidas).
strwsa/menoi, 'making them a bed' (middle).

keklime/noi toi/xw|, 'leaning against the wall of grass.' For the dative cf. Odyss. xvii. 339:
i(=ze d' e)pi\ meli/nou ou)dou= e)/ntosqe qura/wn,
klina/menos staqmw=| kuparissi/nw|.
Hermann's pro/s for tw=| is not wanted.
a)qlh/mata, 'implements'; a new meaning for the word.

fukio/enta de/lhta, 'baits of seaweeds.' On fukio/enta see Introd. p. 55. de/lhta: a contracted plural from de/lear. Seaweed is mentioned as a bait by Oppian, Pisc. iii. 414:
sa/lpai d' i)kmale/ois me\n a)ei\ fu/kessi ma/lista
te/rpontai, kei/nh| de\ kai\ a)grw/ssontai e)dwdh=|…
Ib. 421:
th=mos e)pentu/ei ku/rtou do/lon: e)n de/ oi( ei)/sw
fu/kesin ei)lome/nous la=as ba/len, a)mfi\ de\ poi/as
ei)nali/as stomi/oisin e)dh/sato th=|si ga/nuntai
sa/lpai t' h)d' o(/ssoi botanhfa/goi i)xqu/es a)/lloi.

o(rmiai/, 'lines of horsehair,' Oppian, Hal. iii. 75:
dona/kessin a)naya/menoi dolixoi=sin
o(rmih\n i(/ppeion e)u+/plokon.

ku/rtoi, 'lobster pots,' Oppian, iii. 341:
ku/rton de\ ple/caio peri/dromon o(/tti ma/lista
teu/xwn h)\: spa/rtoisin )*ibhri/sin h)e\ lu/goisi
r(a/bdous a)mfibalw/n: leurh\ de/ oi( ei)/sodos e)/stw
gasth/r t' eu)ruxanh/s.
With the whole list cf. the Epigram of Leonidas, A. Pal. vi. 4.
e)k sxoi/nwn, 'made of cord'; cf. xv. 123.
ge/rwn…le/mbos, 'an old boat.' For ge/rwn cf. Soph. O. C. 1259 ge/rwn ge/ronti sugkatw/|khken pi/nos: Eurip. H. F. 26 ge/rwn lo/gos.
o( pa=s po/ros, 'all their revenue'; cf. Ovid, Met. iii. 588 'Ars illi sua census erat'; Plaut. Rudens 294 'Hisce hami atque haec harundines sunt nobis quaestu et cultu.'

15, 16 The MSS. reading of these two lines is:
ou)dei\s d' ou) ku/qran (xu/qran 11) ei)=x', ou) li/na: (ki/na 11 M sec. man.)
pa/nta perissa/. (f must have had lkina)
pa/nt' e)do/kei th/nois a)/gra peni/a h( sfa=s e(te/rh.
In 15 the Juntine has ou) xu/tran ou) ku/na ('none had dish or dog,' nonsense); in 16 it has sfin e(tai/rh (conj.). The confusion of e(te/rh and e(tai/rh occurs elsewhere (e.g. Theocr. xxii. 120; Xen. Anab. iv. 3. 30). Briggs emended 15 to ou)do\s d' ou)xi\ qu/ran ei)=x' ou) ku/na: Buecheler to ou) klei=d' ou)xi\ qu/ran ei)=x' ou) ku/na, and connected it with the preceding so that plou=tos should be subject; but line 14 is obviously complete in itself and ku/na is doubtful; ou) klei=d' is too far from MSS. In 16 a( ga\r peni/a sfas e)th/rei is an emendation of Ameis and Ahrens. Better e)/teire (Wordsworth), a( ga/r (Reiske); cf. A. Pal. ix. 654. The reading which I have adopted in 15 seems palaeographically more probable than the above mentioned, and comes easily from the uncial *o*u*i*c*u*q*r*a*n transpose the *q. *o*u*q*i*c*u*r*a*n this from *o*u*c*i*c*u*r*a*n. Tr. 'Neither had blanket nor linen; all, all seemed extravagance to them; for poverty pressed hard upon them.' For sisu/ra cf. Arist. Clouds 10: for li/na, Odyss. xiii. 73 )*odussh=i+ sto/resan r(h=go/s te li/non te. ou)dei/s should of course be ou)de/teros, but the Alexandrian writers are notoriously careless in their use of pronouns; vid. Theocr. vi. 46, note.

ou)dei\s d' e)n me/ssw|, 'there was no neighbour at hand.' An unusual sense of e)n me/ssw|, but cf. Theocr. xv. 27; Callim. Epig. 31:
ta\ ga\r feu/gonta diw/kein
oi)=de: ta\ d' e)n me/ssw| kei/mena parpe/tatai.
Herond. vi. 81 h)=lqen ga\r h( *bita=tos e)n me/sw| dou/lh.
qlibome/nan peni/a|, 'oppressed by poverty.'
trufero/n lit. 'delicately'; here of the sea lapping lazily on the beach.
kou)/pw to\n me/saton cf. vii. 10.
tou\s d' a(liei=s parataxis instead of a time clause. The conjunction is generally kai/ not de/.
fi/los po/nos Homeric; an utterly un-Theocritean use.

u(/pnon a)pwsa/menoi cf. A. Pal. vii. 726 (quoted Introd. p. 55). So with other abstract nouns gh=ras a)pwsame/nh, hom. h. Demet. 276; de/os, Quint. Smyrn. ix. 96; fqo/non a)mfote/raisin xersi\n a)pwsa/menoi, Bacchyl. v. 189.

fresi
 h)/reqon au)da/n a curiously far-fetched phrase; 'provoked speech by their thought.' For fresi/ Meineke compares Iliad xvii. 260 ti/s ken h(=|si fresi
 ou)/nomat' ei)/poi; cf. also Odyss. xv. 445 e)/xet' e)n fresi\ mu=qon: Pseudo-Phocyl. 20 lo/gon e)n fresi
 i)/sxein.
mh\ laqo/mhn; k.t.l. 'have I forgotten what was the thing?' He refers to his dream, which for the moment is blurred in his memory.

xro/non d' ai( nu/ktes impatiently; 'the watches of the night are slow.' nu/ktes in plural as Arist. Clouds 1 w)= *zeu= basileu= to\ xrh=ma tw=n nuktw=n o(/son. (ti/ to\ xrh=ma xro/nou tai\ nu/ktes here Martini and Wilamowitz-Moellendorf, but we require an exclamation not a question.)
)*asfali/wn the name occurs Odyss. iv. 216.

pare/ba to
 e(o
 dro/mon. The season has not wilfully gone out of its course, Lucian, i. 229 (Deor. Dial. 10), Helios loq. a)lla\ mh\ parabai/nein ti e)/doca e)n tw=| dro/mw| kai\ e)/cw e)la/sai tw=n o(/rwn,
ka)=|ta/ moi a)/xqetai *zeu\s kai\ th
 nu/kta triplasi/an th=s h(me/ras poih=sai die/gnwken;

o(\s ga\r a)\n ei)ka/ch|, 'for whosoever guesses in his mind, he is the best interpreter of dreams who has his mind for teacher'; 'qui ingenio non arte divinat, is optimus est coniector' (Paley); Eurip. fr. 63 ma/ntis d' a)/ristos o(/stis ei)ka/zei kalw=s.
a)/llws kai\ sxola/, 'besides we have time to spare.' Bion, iii. (Hermann) 8 imitates the line lale/ein ga\r e)pe/trapen a( sxola\ a)/mmin.
mhde\ kaqeu/dwn mhde/ because the clause is conditional; 'if he lies by the sea and does not sleep.'

a)ll' o)/nos, k.t.l. 'but like an ass in a thorn bush, or the lamp in the town-hall: for they say that these are ever sleepless.' We have here two proverbial expressions, whether current or invented. Ahrens' conjecture is also possibly a)dw\n (? a)do/nes) e)n drumw= (a)dw\n = a)hdw/n), referring to the proverb ou)d' o(/sson a)hdo/nes u(pnw/ssousi: cf. Longus, iv. 40 a)grupnou=ntes o(/son ou)de\ glau=kes, and Chaucer's 'smale foules ... that slepen alle night with open eye.' w(s is omitted as in Theocr. xiii. 24; xiv. 51, etc.

37, 38 The restoration of the lines is almost hopeless, but le/gei manu/en seems certain and should not be altered. All proposed emendations are violent and unconvincing, e. g. Haupt. o)/yin ta
 i)/des ei)/ge qe/leis manu/en: Ahrens qe/le dh/ pote…pa| toi e)/oike le/gein, manu/en: Kaibel ta
 i)/des: e)sqla\ d' e)gw\ manu/sw. Best perhaps Ahlwardt ta
 tu/ sew| g' e)/leges manu/en. The MSS. e)/sseo de/ is obviously a corruption by dittography. I trust in my conjecture to have got somewhat nearer to the letters of the MSS. than has been done in previous attempts. Tr. 'Tell me some day (pote/) your vision of the night, since what one knows he promises to reveal to his companion.'
tis is used to refer to the speaker; cf. Soph. Antig. 745.
le/gei, 'promises'; vid. note on ii. 154.
manu/en Doric infin. for manu/ein.
deilino/n, 'in the evening'; cf. xiii. 69, note.
e)n w(/ra|, 'early,' Arist. Eccl. 395 tosou=ton xrh=m' o)/xlou ou(/tws e)n w(/ra| cunele/gh.

pla/non, 'deceptive'; cf. Ovid, Met. iii. 586:
'Pauper et ipse fuit; linoque solebat et hamis
Decipere et calamo salientes ducere pisces.'

tw=n traferw=n w)re/cato, 'reached after the food.' trafero/s is used in Homer always of dry land (traferh/) as opposed to sea (u(grh/), and this use is retained by the Alexandrian writers. The word is however used by Aratus as meaning 'fattening' (tre/fw), e)k nomou= e)rxo/mena traferou= e)pi\ o)/yion au)=lin. Here then as substantive 'the fattening thing,' i. e. 'food.' Others interpret 'one of the fat ones,' as if it were used in the place of eu)trefh/s, but this leaves w)re/cato awkwardly without an object.
a)/rkton manteu/etai, 'scents his bear and I my fish.' manteu/etai is of course used in a greatly strained sense.
i)xqu/a for i)xqu/n, a novel form. So o)i+zu/a, Quint. Smyrn. ii. 88; i)cu/a, Id. xi. 201; o)fru/a, Oppian, Cyn. iv. 405. None of these accusatives occur in the Classical period.

to\n ka/lamon de/, k.t.l. I have kept the MSS. reading, only deleting comma at ei)=xon, so that tw\ xe/re is subject; 'my hands held the rod which bent with the strain, pulled (teino/menon) and was like to break (periklw/menon), a wide reaching struggle.'
a)gw=na is accus. in apposition to sentence.
eu)ru/n because the fish had to be played for a long time; vid. following lines (eu(=ron, Junt.: so Hermann with colon at periklw/menon).
sida/rois, 'a solitary use of the plural'; cf. our use of 'irons.'
i)xqu/n with u^ is abnormal, but recurs in Oppian, Hal. iv. 44; klitu^n, Nicander Alex. 34, and a few others.

'Asphalion first hooked his fish which ran gamely and nearly doubled up the rod; then the fish sulked and the angler half despaired of landing him. To stir the sullen fish he "reminded him of his wound," probably as we do now by keeping a tight line and tapping the butt of the rod. Then he slackened, giving the fish the line in case of a sudden rush; but as there was no such rush he took in line ... and so landed him' (A. Lang).

A hopeless line. Musurus conjectured kai\ to
 me
 pisth=rsi kata=gon e)p' h)pei/roio. Worthless. Most modern critics proceed on the assumption that h)ph/raton conceals h)peirw/tan, and evolve such readings as speu/sas a)ka/l' a)/gagon h)pei/rwtan (Graefe); to/te pisteu/sas a)ka/l' a)/gagon a)phrw/tan (Renier); pi/steusa kalw=s e)/xen h)peirw/tan (Ziegler); but h)peirw/tas i)xqu/s is an impossible expression. Others are pi/steusa kala/greton eu)pe/rnaton (Ribbeck, Rhein. Mus. 45 'feliciter captum bene vendibilem'). Most ingenious is the suggestion of the Rev. B. H. Streeter, to
 e)/xwn pi/steusa kalw=s a)/gen h)peirw/tas, 'having him I trusted to live happily on land.' (I am indebted to A. C. Clark, Esq., of Queen's College, Oxford, for this.) I believe however that to
 h)ph/raton hides to
 e)ph/raton and have emended accordingly. Tr. 'Him I made bold to call the fish I had prayed for.' [I find that Brunck suggested this end to the line, reading however tw=| me
 pi/sunos xala/sas to
 e)ph/raton i)xqu
 w)/mosa mhke/ti.]
w)/mosa d' ou)ke/ti, 'I swore I would never again set foot on the sea, but stay on land, and be an emperor with my gold.'
ou)ke/ti for mhke/ti is irregular; cf. Herond. vi. 93 o( d' w)/mos' ou)k a)\n ei)pei=n moi: Babrius, l. 6 o( d' ou) prodw/sein w)/mnue.

po/da qei=nai cf. A. Pal. v. 39:
h)\n ga\r a)pe/lqw
kai\ qw= a(/pac e)/cw to\n po/da th=s po/lews.
For the aorist qei=nai see Goodwin, M. and T.; Eurip. H. F. 746 ou)/pot' h)/lpisen paqei=n.

tw=| xrusw=| basileu/sein cf. Plaut. Rudens 931, Gripus after his big find exclaims:
'Navibus magnis mercaturam faciam: apud reges rex perhibebor.
... sed hic rex cum aceto pransurust et sale sine bono pulmento.'
e)/reide ta\n gnw/man probably 'bring your judgement to bear on it,' or more simply = prose/xe (to\n nou=n) as no/on prose/reisa *lea/ndrw|, A. Pal. v. 231; o)/yin a)perei/dein, Lucian, i. 259.
i)/sa d' h)=n. The vision was like to the 'thing that is not.'
65, 66 e)lpi\s tw=n u(/pnwn in apposition to o)/yis, 'a mere hope of sleep.'
ei) ga/r pa|…, 'For if perchance you will hunt thus in vain in sleep again, ... you might die of hunger and of your golden dreams.'

mh/ qa/nh|s the construction is the independent use of mh/, with subjunctive to express a polite affirmation. The stock example is Plato, Gorgias 462 c mh\ a)groiko/teron h)=| to\ a)lhqe\s ei)pei=n: cf. Meno 94 e. It is common in Homer, Odyss. v. 356; Iliad xviii. 8; ib. viii. 95 mh/ tis toi feu/gonti metafre/nw| e)n do/ru ph/ch|. The difficulty with the usual order of the lines is that however we emend ei) ga/r me, k.t.l., e)lpi\s tw=n u(/pnwn remains unsatisfactory as an apodosis. (J. A. Hartung's emendation is ingenious but too violent, ei) ga\r u(/par knw/sswn e)/ti mwrei=s tau=ta ma/taios e)lpi\s tw=n u(/pnwn, but u(/par is not likely and mwrei=s is a vox nihili.) With the order adopted in the text e)lpi/s, in apposition to o)/yis, may be paralleled by Oppian, Pisc. i. 36 e)lpi\s d' ou) staqerh\ sai/nei fre/nas h)u/t' o)/neiros: and keneai=s e)lpi/sin o)/neiropolei=n in Adamantius, Dial. Cont. Marcionitas, 842 B.
e)tw/sia…mateu/seis cf. Pind. P. iii. 40 metamw/nia qhreu/wn a)kra/ntois e)lpi/si.

div1.head: (XX Ahrens).
div1.p: The poem is a hymn to the Dioscuri, Castor and Polydeuces. Lines 1-26 form a prelude addressed to the two brothers. From that point the poem passes to narrative, relating first the encounter between Polydeuces and Amycus, king of the Bebryces, and secondly the fight between Castor and Lynceus for the possession of the daughters of Leucippus. The first episode is narrated also by Ap. Rhod. Argon. ii. ad init., but in a tame manner altogether inferior to Theocritus. The second story was narrated in the old Epic, the Cypria, and in Pindar, Nem. x. Theocritus has in both stories differences of detail, which will be noted in their place.

The dialect is Epic, with a few Doric or new Greek forms intermixed. The MS. tradition is twofold for the latter part of the poem; and goes back to the two archetypes *fm and *p (Introd. § 3). Up to l. 68 the poem is lacking in the MS. D, and hence we have only the *fm tradition for this part. The two sources differ greatly; the *p tradition gives almost entirely Epic forms, *fm a large admixture of Doric. The former is claimed as the better by Hiller (Beiträge, p. 77 sqq.) and the Epic forms were generally restored by Ahrens in his edition. Ziegler keeps the dorisms in ll. 1-26 only. See further Introd. § 1, pp. 29, 30. The Vocabulary contains many words new to Epic verse; e.g. ei)kh=|, patage/w, buqo/s, e)rhma/zw, kolosso/s, podew/n, pu/kths, probolh/, pi/tulos, a)kribh/s, e)mfu/lios, o(/maimos (vid. Legrand,
Étude, pp. 263, 264). On metrical points see Introd. p. 57. The symmetry which marks the pastoral poems is only occasionally apparent (e.g. ll. 156, 138, 23, 213, and in the dialogue 54 sqq.; vid. Introd.), and the periods are longer and more flowing.

div2.p: fobero\n e)reqi/zein are to be taken together; the infinitive depending on the adjective.

boe/oisin i(ma=sin the leathern cestus (Verg. Aen. v) which was wound round the hand and forearm more as a protection to the wearer in the delivery of swinging blows than to increase the weight of the blow.
*qestia/dos cf. Eurip. Iph. Aul. 49. The father of Leda was Thestius the Aetolian. The adjective *qestia/s is used like *bereneikei/a in xv. 110; )*ihsoni/hs, xxii. 31.

sqq. swth=ras. The 'Great Twin Brethren' lent their aid to those in distress on land and water. Cf. the well-known legend of the battle of Lake Regillus, and Horace, Odes iv. 8. 31:
'Clarum Tyndaridae sidus ab infimis
Quassas eripiunt aequoribus rates.'
The whole passage is parallel to h. hymn 33 (e)s *dioskou/rous):
swth=ras te/ke pai=das e)pixqoni/wn a)nqrw/pwn
w)kupo/rwn te new=n, o(/te te spe/rxwsin a)/ellai
xeime/riai kata\ po/nton a)mei/lixon: oi( d' a)po\ nhw=n
eu)xo/menoi kale/ousi *dio\s kou/rous mega/loio
a)/rnessin leukoi=sin, e)p' a)krwth/ria ba/ntes
pru/mnhs: th\n d' a)/nemo/s te me/gas kai\ ku=ma qala/sshs
qh=kan u(pobruxi/hn, oi( d' e)capi/nhs e)fa/nhsan
couqh=|si pteru/gessi di' ai)qe/ros a)i+/cantes
au)ti/ka d' a)rgale/wn a)ne/mwn kate/pausan a)e/llas,
ku/mata d' e)sto/resan leukh=s a(lo\s e)n pela/gessi,
nau/tais sh/mata kala/, po/nou sbe/sin.

e)pi\ curou=. A very old expression for a perilous position. The metaphor is apparently from a balance trembling how it will turn. Cf. Theognis, 557:
ki/nduno/s toi e)pi\ curou= i(/statai a)kmh=s:
a)/llote po/ll' e(/ceis, a)/llote pauro/tera.
Simonides, 97 a)kma=s e(stakui=an e)pi\ curou= (*ella/da: Iliad x. 173:
pa/ntessin e)pi\ curou= i(/statai a)kmh=s
h)\ ma/la lugro\s o)/leqros )*axaioi=s h)e\ biw=nai.

ou)rano\n e)canu/onta, 'stars setting and coming into the heavens.' e)canu/w takes accus. of object reached; cf. Eurip. Orest. 1685 a)strw=n po/lon e)canu/sas. The Vulgate could only be defended if we took ou)ranou= as genit. of space in which--rising up (out of the sea) in the heaven. This would be exceedingly obscure. The rising or setting of constellations mark the seasons of the year (cf. Quint. Smyrn. vii. 310:
a)/stra ta/ pou mogeroi=si pe/lei de/os a)nqrw/poisi
duo/men' h)\ a)nio/nta kata\ platu\ ku=ma qala/sshs).
Ships which sail despite the warning of the stars are said a)/stra bia/zontai, 'to set aside with violence the stars.' Cf. Herod. ix. 41 ta\ sfa/gia bia/zesqai.
e)k prw/|rhqen cf. Iliad viii. 19 e)c ou)rano/qen: Theocr. xxv. 180 ou(c (*eli/khqen. Without e)k, i. 24; xvii. 28; vii. 80, etc.
a)/rmena pa/nta, 'all the tackle.' Cf. generally Alcaeus, fr. 18.

au)toi=sin nau/th|sin. This use of the comitative dative with au)to/s, applied to animate beings, is Attic. Homer only has it of inanimate objects (Iliad xi. 699, etc.). The Alexandrian poets used it both with and without su/n: Ap. Rhod. i. 503:
potamoi\ kela/dontes
au)th=|sin nu/mfh|si kai\ e(rpeta\ pa/nt' e)ge/nonto.
(Cf. Fritzsche, lat. ed.)
a)polh/gont' (a)polh/gousi): for elision cf. Pind. N. iii. 7; Scolion of Hybrias toi\ de\ mh\ tolmw=nt' e)/xein do/ru kai\ ci/fos. o is counted long before the liquid l: cf. xxi. 4, note.

o)/nwn t' a)na\ me/sson, 'and faintly shows the crib between the Asses showing that it is fair sailing.' The constellation, which is only visible in very clear weather, is thus described by Aratus (892):
*ske/pteo kai\ fa/tnhn: h( me/n t' o)li/gh| ei)kui=a
a)xlu/i+ borrai/h u(po\ *karki/nw| h(ghla/zei
a)mfi\ de/ min du/o lepta\ faeino/menoi fore/ontai
a)ste/res……
ei(=s me\n pa\r *bore/ao: no/tw| d' e)pike/klitai a)/llos:
kai\ toi\ me\n kale/ontai )/*onoi me/ssh de/ te *fa/tnh.
a)na\ me/sson cf. xiv. 9; with genit. Hesiod, Scut. 209 a)\m me/son au)tou=.

ta\ pro\s plo/on. The use of article with adverb equivalent = a noun is not Homeric. First in Hesiod, )/*erg. 364, 365 to\ qu/rhfin: Monro, H. G. § 264. For pro/s cf. Isocr. 45 e tw=n pro\s to\n po/lemon.
prw/tou belongs to both substantives; cf. x. 35, note; A. Pal. vii. 31 kw/mou kai\ pa/shs koi/rane pannuxi/dos.
a)/ra marks the transition to the main narrative; cf. xviii. 7. In xxiv. 50 it is resumptive; xxiv. 46 it marks a further detail in the narrative (cf. xxii. 12). Cf. xviii. 1, note.
*be/brukas a tribe on the coastland of Bithynia. In Ap. Rhod. loc. cit. the Bebrycians are placed on the Propontis, and the adventure takes place before the passing of the Symplegades.
purei=a, 'firesticks'; Lucian, V. H. i. 32 au)toi\ de\ ta\ purei=a suntri/yantes kai\ a)nakau/santes dei=pnon e)poiou/meqa.
o(/ t' oi)nwpo/s cf. vi. 1; xv. 58, note; xxii. 140.
e)rhma/zeskon, 'were left alone.'

lissa/s a feminine form of lisso/s, 'smooth.' These feminines are formed in great numbers by Alexandrian and later writers: r(wga/s (Theocr. xxiv. 95); e)rhma/s (Nonnus); lussa/s, a)gria/s (Aratus); lepra/s (Theocr. i. 40); penqa/s (Epit.
Bion.); qalusia/s (vii. 31); e)rhma/s (Manetho); fwla/s (i. 115); limna/s (v. 17), etc. See Rutherford (Babrius), p. 82.
la/llai, 'pebbles.'
i)nda/llonto, 'were like.'

e)k buqou= not e)n buqw=| because the pebbles gleam from the bottom of the pool; cf. the description of Arethusa in Lucian. Dial. Marin. 3 diaugh/s te/ e)sti kai\ dia\ kaqarou= a)nablu/zei kai\ to\ u(/dwr e)pipre/pei tai=s yh/fisin o(/lon u(pe\r au)tw=n faino/menon a)rguroeide/s.

e)ndia/aske, 'dwelt beneath the open sky.' The description of the place and of Amycus is modelled on Odyss. ix. 184 sqq.:
peri\ d' au)lh\
u(yhlh\ de/dmhto katwruxe/essi li/qoisi
makrh=|si/n te pi/tussin i)de\ drusi\n u(yiko/moisin.
e)/nqa d' a)nh\r e)ni/aue pelw/rios, o(/s r(a/ te mh=la
oi)=os poimai/nesken a)po/proqen……
kai\ ga\r qau=m' e)te/tukto pelw/rion, ou)de\ e)w/|kei
a)ndri/ ge sitofa/gw|, a)lla\ r(i/w| u(lh/enti.

pe/troi o(loi/troxoi, 'rounded stones.' Theocritus uses the Attic form for the Homeric o)looi/troxoi (deriv. from root volu. 'to roll'; see Vanietcbreve;ek, vol. ii. p. 916); cf. the description of a statue of an athlete, A. Pal. ii. 235:
a)mfi\ de\ puknoi=s
muiw=nes mele/essin a)noidai/nonto taqe/ntes
trhxale/oi doioi\ de\ sunistame/nwn palama/wn
eu)re/es e)sfh/kwnto braxi/ones h)u/te pe/trai:
kai\ paxu\s a)lkh/enti te/nwn e)pani/stato nw/tw|,
au)xe/nos eu)gna/mptoio peri\ platu\n au)lo\n a)ne/rpwn.
And for general sense cf. Tennyson's description of the sleeping Geraint.

a)/krwn…podew/nw|n, 'a lion skin suspended by the claws.' For e)k cf. Bion, v. 2 e)k xeiro\s a)/gousa: more usually of the object on which a thing is hung, e)k tw=n de/ndrwn tine\s a)ph/gxonto, Thucyd. iii. 81. 2.

xai/rw pw=s cf. Aesch. Agam. 538:
*x. kh=ruc )*axaiw=n xai=re tw=n a)po\ stratou=.
*k. xai/rw.
Soph. O. T. 596 nu=n pa=si xai/rw = 'now I bid hail by all.'
mh/ generic; any men whom I have not seen before.
mh/t' a)di/kous mh/t' e)c a)di/kwn cf. Lysias, x. 23 belti/wn kai\ e)c beltio/nwn: Arist. Frogs 731 ponhroi=s ka)k ponhrw=n.
fa/qi leu/ssein, 'deem not that you see'; much more emphatic than the simple negation ou) leu/sseis. So Soph. Elect. 9 fa/skein *mukh/nas ta\s poluxru/sous o(ra=n.
th=s sh=s…e)pibai/nw sc. xw/rhs: cf. v. 61; 'I do not trespass on your land,' i.e. the interference is not of my seeking, and if you choose to obtrude you must take me as you find me.
e)/lqois in answer to ou)k e)pibai/nw. The optative expresses a wish: 'Come; and tasting my hospitality return.'

ta/ t' e)c e)meu= properly 'what should proceed from me.' But little more than e)gw/; cf. iii. 27; Isocr. 39 e a)\n ta\ par' u(mw=n u(phre/thtai: Soph. O. C. 1628 pa/lai dh\ ta)po\ sou= bradu/netai: Arist. Thesm. 1170 ta\ me\n par' h(mw=n i)/sqi soi pepeisme/na.

e)n e(toi/mw| = e(toi=ma: cf. xxii. 212; Antiphon, cxxx. 4 ta\ e)n a)dh/lw| u)/nta: Thucyd. ii. 53 e)n o(moi/w|: Eurip. Hec. 806 tou=t' ou)=n e)n ai)sxrw=| qe/menos. So in Latin, Livy, iii. 65 'in difficili' = 'difficile'; cf. xxii. 148, note.

te/rsei. The sense requires a present, so we should recognize here an active form of the Homeric te/rsetai: Hesych. has te/rsei chrai/nei: Liddell and Scott treat te/rsei as a future, but without just ground. The sense is 'you shall know of that if you are parched with thirst' (Hartung).
-67. Reiske's assignment of these lines to Amycus and Polydeuces in turn leaves o)/mmata d' o)rqo/s inexplicable and without grammatical connexion.

pugma/xos refers to the stand up boxing; possi\ qenw/n to the scrimmage of the Pancratium of which Philostratus writes--Imag. ii. 6--dei= de\ au)toi=s kai\ te/xnhs ei)s to\ a)/llous a)/gxein: oi( de\ au)toi\ kai\ sfurw=| prospalai/ousi kai\ th\n xei=ra streblou=si proso/ntos tou= pai/ein kai\ e)na/llesqai: touti\ ga\r tou= pagkratia/zein e)/rga plh\n tou= da/knein kai\ o)ru/ttein, and ibidem dei= ga\r u(ptias mw=n…kai\ sumplokw=n. Now o)/mmata d' o)rqo/s cannot refer to this, but obviously suits boxing (pugma/xos). o)/mmasin o)rqoi=s (Paley) is useless; a(/mmata d' o)rqa/ (Juntine) requires h)/ and not de/, and has no construction; Hartung's a(/mmasi d' a)/rqra makes an exceedingly harsh 'zeugma'; qenw/n is not applicable to the second clause, and a(/mmasi and possi/ can hardly be made coordinate. I do not understand Kynaston's note; there is possibly some reference to 'gouging.' Philostratus--as quoted above--says expressly that this was barred. I therefore give o)/mmata d' o)rqo/s and the following line to Amycus and read g' for d'. The dialogue then runs:
Amyc. Put up your hands, man against man.
Polyd. Boxing or tripping?
Amyc. Nay, eye to eye. Lay yourself out, and do not spare your tricks.
mh\ fei/deo cf. Pind. Isth. vi. 50 sfete/ras d' ou) fei/sato xersi\n barufqo/ggoio neura=s.
xei=ras a)/eiron cf. Odyss. xviii. 89; Ap. Rhod. ii. 14 pri\n xei/ressin e)mh=|si e(a\s a)na\ xei=ras a)ei=rai.
sfete/rhs cf. x. 2, note.
ou) gu/nnis e)w/n, k.t.l., 'no weakling is he, and shall be called "The Boxer."' On the reading see Hiller, Beiträge, p. 54.
o( pu/kths. For the article with the predicate cf. Aeschin. i. 131 o( *ba/talos prosagoreu/etai: Id. ii. 167 to\n kalo\n stratiw/thn e)me\ w)no/masan.
so\s me\n e)gw/ sc. keklh/somai ai)/ke krath/sh|s. For ellipse cf. xv. 144.

kudoimoi/, 'fights' (Liddell and Scott). If this is right we have here an example of that exaggeration in the use of words which becomes frequent in a declining state of language, e. g. in Oppian, me/lh h)li/bata for mega/la, v. 66; xa/os for sko/tos,
v. 52. eu)/ripos = 'cistern,' Babrius, 120 (cf. Rutherford, ad loc. and p. lx of his introduction). But we ought probably to keep to the old meaning = 'battle-cry' here (? 'cock-a-whoop'). For the sense cf. Ar. Birds 70 *qe. o)/rnis e)/gwge dou=los. *eu. h(tth/qhs tino\s a)lektruo/nos; The beaten bird was called dou=los.
maxessai/mesqa cf. xvi. 67, note.
a)ei/ apparently with komo/wntes cf. ii. 137; vii. 33; xiii. 56; xvii. 107, where words are similarly displaced.

e)kartu/nanto, 'bound themselves about' or 'had got themselves bound,' since this was the office of the squires; cf. Odyss. xviii. 76 drhsth=res a)/gon zw/santes a)na/gkh|: Ap. Rhod. ii. 62; Iliad xxiii. 681.

su/nagon must be taken intransitively (vid. Liddell and Scott); contrast Odyss. xviii. 89 e)s me/sson d' a)/nagon: tw\ d' a)/mfw xei=ras a)ne/sxon. Wakefield reads pne/ontas, but this makes sfi/si in l. 83 very obscure.
fo/non…pne/ontes cf. xxv. 137; Quint. Smyrn. xi. 10 o)loo\n pnei/ousai o)/leqron.

la/boi, 'which should get'; delib. optative, Ap. Rhod. i. 1154:
e)/nq' e)/ris a)/ndra e(/kaston a)risth/wn o)ro/qunen,
o(/stis a)polh/ceie panu/statos.
polu\s d' e)pe/keito, 'lunged heavily, head down.'
polu/s Aesch. Choeph. 36 fo/bos baru\s pi/tnwn, etc.

qarsu/neskon Quint. Smyrn. imitates the passage (iv. 339):
me/ga d' i)/axon e)/nqa kai\ e)/nqa
laoi\ e)potru/nontes e)risqene/wn me/nos a)ndrw=n
mi=cai e)n ai(/mati xei=ras.
*tituw=| see Odyss. xi. 577.
a)mfote/rh|sin cf. vii. 157. Note the quick dactylic character of these lines, and contrast the slow movement of l. 98.
e)/sth sc. Amycus.

plhgai=s mequ/wn cf. Odyss. xviii. 240:
=)*iros……
h(=stai neusta/zwn kefalh=|, mequ/onti e)oikw/s,
ou)d' o)rqo\s sth=nai du/natai posi/n.
kela/dhsan, 'shouted in applause,' Iliad xxiii. 869.
e(/lkea lugra/ Homeric; Iliad xix. 49.
e)tw/sia…prodeiknu/s, 'with feint blows'; cf. Verg. Aen. v. 376.

h)/lase intrans. 'drave with his fist'; cf. Ap. Rhod. ii. 108:
tou= d' a)=sson i)o/ntos
deciterh=| skaih=s u(pe\r o)fru/os h)/lase xeiri/.
Quint. Smyrn. iv. 358:
to\n d' a)/ra *qhse/os ui(o\s e)u+frone/wn e)n a)e/qlw|
polla/kis e)s keneo\n kratera\s xe/ras i)qu/nesqai
qh=ke: kai\ i)drei/h|si diatmh/cas e(ka/terqe
xei=ras, e)s o)fru/a tu/yen e)pa/lmenos a)/xris i(ke/sqai
o)ste/on.
o)rqwqe/ntos gen. absol. with subj. unexpressed; cf. xiv. 18; Soph. O. T. 629 ou)/toi kakw=s g' a)/rxontos.

e)/cw…au)xe/nos, 'aimed blows at his breast and outside his neck.' Theocritus probably means the same as Homer, Odyss. xviii. 96 o( d' au)xe/n' e)/lassen u(p' ou)/atos: Ahrens reads i)cu\n (i)cu/a Meineke) au)xe/na t', but this is unnecessary, and is unsportsmanlike, not to be justified by Eurip. Iph. Taur. 1370:
kai\ kw=l' a)p' a)/mfoin…
e)s pleura\ kai\ pro\s h(=par h)konti/zeto.
(C. Hartung kai\ a)/cona au)xe/nos--a physical impossibility.)
a)eike/si Homeric; Iliad ii. 264.

sa/rkes d' ai( me/n 'haec scriptura defendi posse ita videtur ut sa/rkes de/ de utroque dictum esse statuamus, i.e. de Amyce et Polluce, atque ut postea poeta oratione translata a re statim ad ipsam personam utrumque distinxisse cogitetur per ai( me\n o( de/' (Ameis). The construction proceeds irregularly. We should normally have ai( de/ instead of o( de/.
e)k mega/lou cf. xxix. 24; Isocr. 16 D po/lin mega/lhn e)k smikra=s poih=sai.
o)li/gos cf. i. 47.

pa/ssona cf. Odyss. vi. 230:
to\n me\n )*aqhnai/h qh=ken…
mei/zona/ t' ei)side/ein kai\ pa/ssona.

a(ptome/nou…po/nou, 'in the grip of the fight.' A novel expression, but not unlike no/sos h(=ptai/ mou, Soph. Trach. 1009. This alone has an MSS. authority. a(pto/menos, which many read, would only be admissible if Amycus and Pollux fought in regular rounds, so that a(pto/menos po/nou would mean 'engaging in the fight again' (au)came/nou, conj. Meineke).

kai\ xroih=| a)mei/nwn (see Hiller, Beiträge, p. 45), 'better in colour too.' a)mei/nw, which Toup conjectured and most editors read, is less appropriate. It is not the limbs but the general aspect which is described. In the sportsman's phrase Pollux 'comes up smiling.'

116, 117 oi)=sqa e)gw/ cf. 7, 8, etc.: Index, s. v. Hiatus. The Muse (qea/) is invoked here at the crisis of the story; cf. Bacchyl. xv. 47 *meu=sa, ti/s prw=tos lo/gwn a)=rxen dikai/wn; The poet is the mouthpiece of the Muses uttering what they will; cf. Callim. iii. 186 ei)pe\ qea\ su\ me\n a)/mmin: e)gw\ d' e(te/roisin a)ei/sw: Ap. Rhod. iv. 1379 *mousa/wn o(/de mu=qos: e)gw\ d' u(pakouo\s a)ei/dw *pieri/dwn.
e(te/rwn, 'the mouthpiece of others,' i.e. of the Muses; see Hiller's note.
w(s e)qe/leis kai\ o(/ppws (Hiller, Beiträge, p. 52); cf. Iliad xiv. 337; Odyss. xviii. 113 o(/tti ma/list' e)qe/leis kai/ toi fi/lon e)/pleto qumw=|.

probolh=s. Liddell and Scott translate this word 'a lunge,' but when used in connexion with fighting it seems always to mean the 'guard position' (e)n probolh=| qeme/na ci/fos, A. Pal. vii. 433, etc.); cf. 'in procinctu' (Quintil. xii. 9. 21 'oratorem armatum semper et velut in procinctu stantem').
Tr. 'Amycus seized Polydeuces' left with his left swerving sideways from his guard, and attacking with the other hand swung round his broad forearm from his right side; ... but Polydeuces ducked his head, and struck straight from the shoulder': i.e. Amycus tried to hold down Polydeuces' guard arm and to deliver a side blow by swinging his arm round from his side on to his opponent's head. platu) gui=on is not the fist, but the whole forearm girt with the cestus. The Greeks used this swinging blow much more than the modern prize-fighter. Hence l. 45 Amycus is represented with his ears battered (see Badminton volume on Boxing, Introd.). For e(te/rh| Kiessling conjectures e(te/rhn, perhaps rightly.
a)po\ lago/nos. Ahrens' conjecture e)pi\ lago/nas, like Amycus' blow, is rendered futile by the fact that Pollux ducked his head.
w)/mw|, 'straight from the shoulder,' lit. with the weight of his shoulder; cf. xxv. 147.
laih=| (so *p). Amycus had released his hold on Polydeuces' left when met with the blow in the face.
puknoi/ Odyss. xii. 92.
e)pi\ gai/h| Odyss. xviii. 92.
a)llofrone/wn Iliad xxiii. 698.
Apollonius makes Polydeuces kill Amycus, but vid. Schol. Apoll. ii. 98 )*epi/xarmos de\ kai\ *pei/sandros fasi\n o(/ti e)/dhsen au)to\n o( *poludeu/khs.
o(\n pate/ra. Amycus was son of Poseidon and the nymph Melie, Ap. Rhod. ii. 2.

cei/noisi Ap. Rhod. ii. 5:
e)pi\ cei/noisin a)eike/a qesmo\n e)/qhken
mh/tin' a)postei/xein pri\n peirh/sasqai e(oi=o
pugmaxi/hs.

Theocritus now passes to the second part of the poem--the exploits of Castor. This has no connexion with the preceding save community of actors. In the Epic--the Cypria--Castor was killed by Idas, Lynceus and Idas by Polydeuces (Proclus, Chrestom. i). In Theocritus Lynceus is killed by Castor; Idas comes to his brother's assistance but is slain by the lightning of Zeus; Polydeuces takes no part in the fight. In Pindar (Nem. x) Castor is surprised by Lynceus stealing the cattle of Aphareus and is mortally wounded; Polydeuces slays Lynceus; Idas is killed by the thunderbolt. The detail that the sons of Aphareus were betrothed to the daughters of Leucippus and that the Dioscuri robbed them of their brides seems to be first found in Theocritus (see Legrand, Étude, p. 91), but is repeated by Ovid (Fasti, v. 699): vid. note on iv. 150.
o( kartero/s cf. xv. 48.
melloga/mw, 'soon to be bridegrooms.'
tu/mbon cf. Pind. N. x. 124 h)=lqe *lh/das pai=s diw/kwn: toi\ d' e)/nanta sta/qen tu/mbw| sxedo\n patrwi+/w|.
e)p' a)llh/loisin o)/rousan Homeric ending; Iliad xiv. 401.
e)pi\ nu/mfais…xalepoi/; 'why are ye sternly set to gain another's bride?'
e)pi/ cf. i. 49.

e)n o(/rkw| = o(/rkios: cf. Lucian, Tox. 22 e)n paidia=| to\ pra=gma e)poiou=nto: Evenus, i. 2 ou)ke/ti tou=t' e)n e)/qei. Cf. Thucyd. ii. 64; Hypereides, Eux. xxxvi. 25 e)a\n ta\ gegono/ta e)n a)dikh/mati yhfi/shsqe ei)=nai. So probably the difficult phrase, Eurip. Bacchae 860:
*dio/nuson o(\s pe/fuken e)n te/lei qeo\s
deino/tatos a)nqrw/poisi d' h)piw/tatos.
(e)n te/lei = te/leios.)

Meineke, Ahrens, and Ziegler reject the line altogether, regarding it as a weak supplement to dw/rois in l. 151 (bousi/ dat. instr. with paretre/yasqe); hardly necessary. The circumstances of the story as given here seem to be--the Dioscuri had made an expedition into Arcadia with Idas and Lynceus; a quarrel arising over the division of the loot the Dioscuri seized the portion which belonged to the sons of Aphareus, and offered it to Leucippus, who in return gave them his daughters previously espoused to Idas and Lynceus (Renier). According to the common version the Dioscuri were already married to the daughters of Leucippus, and being taunted by their cousins for giving no dowry stole the cattle of Aphareus and made a present of it to Leucippus (Schol. Lycophr. 548).
pollh/, 'large'; cf. Plato, Phaedo 78 a; Charito, g. vi. 2 pollh\ ga\r h( )*asi/a.
toke/essin. Theocritus uses the Epic and Ionic forms of nouns in -eus indifferently; cf. a)riste/es, xviii. 17; i(pph/essi, xxiv. 128; *dwrie/essi, xv. 93; basilh=es, xvii. 74, etc.
u(po/, 'under the dominion of'; Odyss. vii. 68 o(/ssai nu=n ge gunai=kes u(p' a)ndra/sin oi)=kon e)/xousi: Ap. Rhod. i. 270 u(po\ mhtruih=| bi/oton baru\n h(ghla/zei.
a)/nwqen cf. vii. 5.
pro\s te/los e)lqei=n, 'to come to completion'; Megara, 99 a)fi/keto pro\s te/los e)/rgou.

i)/skon, 'I said.' This verb (i)/skw, shortened form of e)i/skw) is among the many which the Alexandrian poets used in a new sense. In Homer it means 'to make like' (e.g. Odyss. iv. 279), or 'to conjecture.' In Ap. Rhod. frequently = 'he said,' after reporting a speech; e.g. ii. 240 i(/sken )*aghnori/dhs. 'So spake Ag.' Homer, Odyss. xxii. 31 probably = 'surmised.' See Buttmann, Lexil. p. 276 sqq.

w)/|xeto…pnoih\ e)/xous' cf. ii. 7, note; Odyss. viii. 408:
e)/pos d' ei)/ pe/r ti be/baktai
deino\n a)/far to\ fe/roien a)narpa/casai a)/ellai.
Statius, Achill. i. 285 'irrita ventosae rapiebant verba procellae'; Quint. Smyrn. xiv. 381:
eu)xwlai/ d' a)ne/moisi mi/gen kai\ a)po/proqi nhw=n
mayidi/ws nefe/essi kai\ h)e/ri sumfore/onto.
e)k patro/s, 'on our father's side.' Aphareus and Tyndareus were brothers.
nei=kos…o(moi/ion Iliad iv. 444.
e)/gxea lou=sai, 'to bathe our spears in blood'; cf. Simonides, 143 to/ca…*persw=n ai(/mati lousa/mena: Callim. iv. 95 taxino/s se kixh/somai ai(/mati lou/swn to/con e)mo/n.
o(/maimos e)mo/s, 'my kinsman.' Nothing is gained by the conjecture e(o/s.
w(/lloi the survivors of the fight.
qeo\s…qh/sein Homeric; Iliad iv. 363 ta\ de\ pa/nta qeoi\ metamw/nia qei=en.
e)s me/son cf. v. 83.
u(p' a)spi/dos a)/ntuga cf. Quint. Smyrn. i. 158 doiou\s ei(/let' a)/kontas u(p' a)spi/da. The shield is held to guard the body, while the spear shows under its edge.
po/non ei)=xon cf. vii. 139.

ei)/ pou/ ti cf. Hesiod, Scut. 334:
e)/nqa ke gumnwqe/nta sa/keus u(po\ daidale/oio
o)fqalmoi=sin i)/dh|s, e)/nq' ou)ta/men.
Theocritus may have had in mind the spirited account of the duel in Eurip. Phoen. 1356 foll.; cf. ib. 1382:
h)=|sson de\ lo/gxais: a)ll' u(fi/zanon ku/klois
o(/pws si/dhros e)colisqa/noi ma/thn:
ei) d' o)/mm' u(persxo\n i)/tuos a(/teros ma/qoi
lo/gxhn e)nw/ma sto/mati, profqh=nai qe/lwn.
e)ni/. For i_ lengthened in this position cf. Iliad x. 254.
a)/or. The singular should be retained against the conjectured a)/or' (Musurus); cf. vi. 2, note.
e)rwh/ the same ending, Iliad xvii. 761.

a)kribh\s o)/mmasi Ap. Rhod. i. 153:
*lugkeu\s de\ kai\ o)cuta/tois e)ke/kasto
o)/mmasin ei) e)teo/n ge pe/lei kle/os a)ne/ra kei=non
r(hidi/ws kai\ ne/rqe kata\ xqono\s au)ga/zesqai.
foi/nika d' o(/son, 'the point touched but the crimson crest.'

o(/son, 'just,' a developed meaning of the word. Originally it is used with words expressing distance or amount in a strictly comparative sense; cf. Arist. Thesm. 746:
*m. po/s' e)/th de\ ge/gone; trei=s xo/as h)\ te/ttaras;
*x. sxedo\n tosou=ton xw)/son e)k *dionusi/wn.
('as much as from the D. to now'); Iliad ix. 354 a)ll' o(/son e)s *skaia/s te pu/las kai\ fhgo\n i(/kanen ('as far as to the Scaean gates,' i.e. and no further): cf. Arist. Vespae 213 ti/ ou)k a)pekoimh/qhmen o(/son o(/son sti/lhn; ('just, just a wink'). So here. From this it acquires the meaning of 'as much and no more,' 'just,' and is used with less definite expression: Theocr. xxv. 73; Ap. Rhod. iv. 1269:
oi)o/qi d' a(/lmh
a)/ploos ei(lei=tai gai/hs u(/per o(/sson e)/xousa
'just covering the land'). So finally o(/son ou) (= 'all but,' 'just not'); o(/son h)/dh, Polyb. ii. 4. 4. Contrast the use noted in l. 45.
196, 197 tou= me/n. Construe tou= me\n e)pi\ skaio\n go/nu fa/sganon fe/rontos a)/krhn xei=ra e)ko/lousen.

to/qi, 'where'; Pindar and Alexandrian, not Homer (to/qi te, Mimnermus, xi. 5). Pindar has to/sson as relative (N. iv. 8). The Alexandrians use the t-forms freely: to/sson, to/fra, to/qen, Callim.; te/ws, Ap. Rhod.; to/te, Nicander, Alex. 608 (al. o(/te).
w)=se Pind. N. x. 131 e)formaqei\s d' a)/r' a)/konti qow=| h)/lase *lugke/os e)n pleurai=si xalko/n: cf. Iliad v. 80.

baru\s…u(/pnos Vergil, Aen. x. 745 'olli dura quies oculos et ferreus urget somnus'; Iliad v. 82:
to\n de/ kat' o)/sse
e)/llabe porfu/reos qa/natos.
to\n a)/llon (= to\n e(/teron, cf. vii. 36): Idas. Laocoossa is the mother of Idas and Lynceus.

sth/lhn…a)narrh/cas Pind. N. x. 125:
e)/nqen a(rpa/cantes a)/galm' )*ai+/da, cesto\n pe/tron,
e)/mbalon ste/rnw| *poludeu/keos.

keraunw=| Pind. loc. cit. 132:
*zeu\s d' e)p' )/*ida| purfo/ron pla=-
ce yolo/enta kerauno/n.
a(/ma d' e)kai/ont' e)rh=-
moi xalepa\ d' e)/ris a)nqrw/pois o(milei=n kresso/nwn.
e)n e)lafrw=| cf. v. 61, note.
xai/rete cf. xv. ad fin.; xvii. ad fin. Theocritus expands somewhat the formal ending to the old Homeric hymns, adding a more elaborate epilogue.
de/ te cf. i. 83.
pe/mpoite cf. v. 124.

pu/rgon a)uth=s, 'a pillar against the onset.' For the genitive cf. Soph. O. T. 1200 qana/twn pu/rgos a)ne/sta: Eurip. Medea 1322 e)/ruma polemi/as xero/s: Pindar, Ol. ii. 146, calls Hector *trw/|as a)/maxon ki/ona.

oi)=kos u(pa/rxei, 'as my store supplies' (w(s, cf. Odyss. xxii. 344). Gercke (Rh. Mus. 43) would read oi)=mos: cf. Bacchyl. v. 31:
e)moi\ muri/a panta=| ke/leuqos
u(mete/ran a)reta\n u(mnei=n.
Id. xix. 1 pa/resti muri/a ke/leuqos a)mbrosi/wn mele/wn.

div1.p: On authorship see Introd. § 2. It is difficult to understand how any critic could attribute this, worst of all poems, to Theocritus. Like xix, xx, xxi, it is preserved only in the *f group of MSS., and the text is exceedingly corrupt.

div2.p: polu/filtros, 'love-sick.' fi/ltron in late poets = love; Moschus, vii. 8 potamo\n dia\ fi/ltron e)/rws e)di/dace kolumbh=n.

ou)ke/q' o(moi/w. The force of ou)ke/ti is 'up to a certain point he was good, beyond that no longer ...': cf. Hesiod, Scut. 50 diduma/one gei/nato pai=de ou)ke/q' o(ma= frone/onte (Paley, ad loc.). Meineke compares Menander (Frag. Com. iv. p. 164):
ta\ dusxerh= te kai\ ta\ luph/sonta/ se
o(ra=|s e)n au)tw=| ta\ d' a)ga/q' ou)ke/ti ble/peis.
The line may be an imitation of Bion, x. (Herm.) 4 a)/grion a)/storgon morfa=| no/on ou)de\n o(moi=on.
potika/rdia adject. for adverbial expression; 'in the heart.'
tw=n pursw=n, 'love's fires'; Musaeus, 90 purso\s e)rw/twn.
a)ma/rugma, 'quiver.'

r(odo/malon (Vulg.) is a doubtful word, whether we take it as 'a rosy apple' (i.e. presents), or 'rosy cheeks.' r(o/da ma/lwn (Ahrens) neatly completes the description, 'there was no quiver of the lip, or bright flash of the eye, or roses blushing on the cheek.' Cf. Bion, i. 11 kai\ to\ r(o/don feu/gei tw= xei/leos.

10, 11 Cf. Callim. vi. 50:
ta\n d' a)/r' u(poble/yas xalepw/teron h)e\ kunago\n
w)/resin e)n *tma/roisin u(poble/pei a)/ndra le/aina.
The subjunctive u(popteu/h|si is used in simile according to Homeric syntax; Monro, H. G. § 285. 3 (a); Iliad v. 161.

ou(/tws pa/nt' e)poi/ei, 'so he acted in all things towards the man'; but this can hardly be right. pa/nta poiei=n = to leave nothing undone. The sense would require ou(/tws ei)=xe. No satisfactory emendation has been proposed (ou(/tw u(po/pteuen pa/nta broto/n, Graefe; paptai/nei potiw\n broto/n, Keibel; a)ntw/pei poti/, Meineke; ? ou(/tws pa/nt' e)no/ei poti/, 'so was he minded in all things').

ei)=xe ga\r o)/gkon, 'for he possessed self-conceit'; cf. o( tw=n u(peroptikw=n o)/gkos, Isocr. 8 d. The MSS. ei)=xen a)na/gkwn could only mean 'he suffered constraint,' and is senseless. Meineke, followed by subsequent editors, reads ble/pos ei)=xon a)na/gkas, hardly translateable. Ahrens commends this because the translation of Divus (1539) has 'oculi gravem visum habebant necessitate,' and Ahrens held that Divus used a now lost MS. of good character: but see Hiller, Beitr. p. 15, note 3. Divus obviously took ble/pon as a noun and made what he could of a)na/gkan (ei)/pot' a)pa/nth, Fritzsche). o)/gkon prepares the way for xola=| in l. 13.
13, 14 'His colour fled clothed in angry insult.'
ta=s o)rga=s is defining genitive.
perikei/menos vid. Liddell and Scott; and add A. Pal. xi. 38 pi=ne kai\ e)/sqie kai\ perikei=so a)/nqea.

Cf. A. Pal. v. 255:
u(/bris e)/rwtas e)/luse: ma/thn o(/de mu=qos a)la=tai:
u(/bris e)mh\n e)re/qei ma=llon e)rwmani/hn.

Apparently imitated by Ovid, Met. xiv. 701:
'Postquam ratione furorem
Vincere non potuit supplex ad limina venit';
and ib. 716:
'Non tulit impatiens longi tormenta doloris
Iphis et ante fores haec verba novissima dixit.'

ou)ke/ti pa\r se\…e)qe/lw, 'I will not move to you'; sc. badi/zein. Others read ga/r se (from Junt.), construing e)qe/lw with direct accus., a late use: A. Pal. vii. 98 (Meleager) ou)k e)qe/lw *xari/damon.
lu/phs kexolwme/nos, 'enraged by reason of my grief' (not 'propter iniurias tuas' as Meineke). The genit. lu/phs is causal as th=sd' a)pa/ths kote/wn, Iliad iv. 168 (Krüger, ii. 47. 21).
a)lla\ badi/zw, 'but I go where the story holds there is a common road (of death), where there is that medicine for love--forgetfulness.'
fa/rmakon cf. A. Pal. v. 220 fa/rmakon a)mfote/rois ci/fos e)/ssetai.
xo/lon referring back to l. 22 kexolwme/nos. The Juntine reading po/qon has been too readily accepted.

Haupt rejects this line and the preceding. The couplet is certainly a mere tautology of ll. 28, 29. The expression of the lines is clumsy at the best: 'White is the lily, it fades when it falls (droops?); white is the snow, and melts when it has sprinkled' (pa/ssw). For the meaningless paxqh=| of l. 31 Boissonade conjectures flegxqh=|: J. A. Hartung pi/pth| with e)panqh=| in l. 30, 'alii alia.' The line seems to be modelled on Odyss. xix. 206 xiw\n h(/nt' *eu)=ros kate/thcen e)ph\n *ze/furos kataxeu/h|.
o(pani/ka…fila/seis cf. xxiv. 85.
e)pispei/sas A. Pal. viii. 192 a)ll' e)re/w ge da/kru' e)pispe/ndwn: ib. vii. 220.
to\ d' au)= pu/mato/n me fi/lason from Bion, i. 45.

ou) du/namai lupei=n se, 'I cannot vex you: you will reconcile me with your kiss.' A syllable is lost in the MSS.: Paley's lupei=n is perhaps the best of many conjectures: Ahrens' si/nein would be a perfect emendation if the active voice for si/nomai were ever found, *c*i*n*e*i*n by haplography becoming *e*i*v. misei=n (Madvig) is also possible.

xw=ma de/…, 'and pile me up some mound that shall hide my love.' koi/lanon (the Vulgate lectio) is quite absurd. Possibly kh/deue to/ is the original; vid. crit. note. The corruption oi--h is common in late texts, the two sounds being pronounced alike. The text of Theocritus affords a good number of cases of this itacism and consequent corruption; vid. xxiii. 16; v. 129 ke/ontai, p; ke/onti, k; kai/onti, c: xxv. 80 ei) oi(--ei)/h, c: xxiii. 52 e)koi/lisen, *f.

There is possibly an imitation of this passage in Charito, E. x; Chaereas, about to hang himself, loquitur: ai)tou=mai/ se xa/rin teleutai/an: o(/tan a)poqa/nw pro/selqe moi tw=| nekrw=| kai\ ei) me\n du/nasai klau=son, ei)pe\ de\ prosku/yasa th=| sth/lh|: oi)/xh| *xaire/a nu=n a)lhqw=s.
o(doipo/re. Addresses to the passer-by are of constant occurrence in Greek sepulchral inscriptions; Theocr. Epig. ix. 19; A. Pal. vii. 452, etc.

49, 50 li/qon ei)=lken, k.t.l. 'he dragged a stone and leaning it--the dreadful stone--against the wall, high as the middle of the doorway, fastened therefrom the fine cord, and placed the noose about his neck.'
ou)dw=n properly the threshold, here the doorposts and lintel.
a)p' au)tw=n sc. ou)dw=n.
a(/pteto cf. Odyss. xi. 278 a(yame/nh bro/xon ai)pu\n a)f' u(yhloi=o mela/qrou.
[For li/qon in l. 50 Ahrens conjectures li/non, unnecessary. For a)p' au)tw=n or a)p' au)tou=, Voss a)/nwqen.]
ou)d' e)lugi/xqh so one MS. corrected; e)tuli/xqh, *f; neither is very likely. ?stufeli/xqh, 'was amazed'; Nicet. Eugen. v. 286 e)stufeli/xqh th=| qe/a| tou= satra/pou.
ne/on fo/non 'caedes modo patrata' (Wuestemann).

a)ll' e)pi\ nekrw=| ei(/mata, k.t.l. Paley keeps this, and explains 'defiled his robes by touching the corpse'; so Wuestemann. But it is not the garment but the man that is defiled by such contact, and the text is undoubtedly corrupt. Meineke conjectures ou)d' e)pi\…ka/l' e)pi/alen, referring to v. 39 (possibly e)pi\ nekrw=| ai(/mati pa=s e)miai/net').
e)pemai/eto, 'made for'; o)re/wn e)pemai/eto, Aratus, 127.
to\n qeo/n sc. )/*erws, i. e. a statue of the god standing by the bath.

i(/stato, 'he stood on the stone base looking to the water.' The construction is defended by Iliad xiv. 154 sta=s' e)c *ou)lu/mpoio a)po\ r(i/ou, 'standing looking from Olympus'; Soph. Antig. 411 kaqh/meq' a)/krwn e)k pa/gwn u(ph/nemoi.

div1.p:
This poem narrates the story of the infant Heracles strangling the serpents which were sent by Hera to destroy him. As in the other narrative poems the setting is domestic rather than heroic (see Introd. p. 29; Legrand, Étude, p. 185). The story was well known in literature (cf. Pindar, N. i), and supplies a frequent subject to art. The device of Heracles and the serpents appears on the coins of (1) Thebes; (2) the alliance of Samos, Ephesus, Rhodes, Cnidus, etc.; (3) Croton and the South Italian league; cf. note on Id. iv. 32. In painting the best known is a fresco of Pompeii; on the right is Zeus; in the centre Alcmene, terror-struck; on the left a slave; Heracles is a well-grown child, and is represented not in his cradle but kneeling (see Journ. Hellen. Studies, vol. xvi. p. 143 sqq.). There was a painting by Zeuxis on the same subject, Pliny, N. H. xxxv. 63 'magnificus est et Iuppiter eius in throno adstantibus deis et Hercules infans dracones strangulans, Alcmena matre coram parente et Amphitryone.' The dialect, Doric with a few Epic forms intermixed (po/ka 1, fame/na 10,
a)=mos 11, etc.; but tou/s 10 not tw/s, etc.). On authenticity see Introd. § 3.

div2.p: *pterela/ou king of the island Taphos. He was destined to be deathless so long as he kept from hurt his strange gold hair, but being robbed of this by his daughter Comaetho--the Delilah of the story--fell an easy victim to Amphitryo in war.
a(ptome/na…kefala=s, 'laying her hand on their heads.'

e)ge/rsimon u(/pnon, 'sleep to wake again'; contrast iii. 49, and eu)= ma/la makro\n a)te/rmona nh/greton u(/pnon (Epit. Bion.). Observe the beautiful melody of these three lines; the crooning sound of the open vowel in the first two, the rounded refrain of the last with its repeated o)/lbioi and rhyming halves.
a)w= is accus. of 'motion to'; cf. i. 140.

a)mos de/, 'when the Bear swings to his midnight setting opposite to Orion, who just shows his mighty shoulder in the sky.' Orion's shoulder is just above the horizon at midnight in the middle of September (in Lat. 35° N.); cf. Aratus, 584:
w(s oi( me\n (Corona, Piscis, Bootes) du/nousin, o( d' a)nti/os ou)de\n a)eikh\s
a)ll' eu)= me\n zw/nh| eu)= d' a)mfote/roisi faeino\s
w)/mois )*wri/wn ci/feo/s ge me\n i)=fi pepoiqw/s,
pa/nta fe/rwn potamo\n ke/raos paratei/netai a)/llou.
Where Aratus is speaking of the cosmical setting of Corona in June-July.
kata/; cf. i. 30; Herod. i. 76 kata\ *sinw/phn po/lin (over against).

u(po/, 'bristling with the motion of their azure coils.' Join u(po/ with spei/raisi not with w)=rsen as tmesis. u(po/ with the dative is used instead of the simple dative to express 'under the power of,' 'under the influence of'; and so instead of the dative of means, cf. Ap. Rhod. iii. 3 e)s )*iwlko\n a)nh/gage kw=as )*ih/swn *mhdei/hs u(p' e)/rwti. The whole description follows Pindar, N. i. 59:
kai\ basi/leia qew=n
sperxqei=sa qumw=| pe/mpe dra/kontas a)/far:
toi\ me\n oi)xqeisa=n pula=n
e)s qala/mou muxo\n eu)ru\n e)/ban, te/k-
noisin w)kei/as gna/qous
a)mfeli/casqai memaw=tes: o( d' o)r-
qo\n me\n a)/nteinen ka/ra, peira=to de\ prw=ton ma/xas,
dissai=si doiou\s au)xe/nwn
ma/ryais a)fu/ktois xersi\n e(ai=s o)/fias:
a)gxome/nois de\ xro/nos
yuxa\s a)pe/pneusen mele/wn a)fa/twn.
e)k d' a)/r' a)/tlaton be/los
pla=ce gunai=kas, o(/sai tu/xon )*alkmh/-
nas a)rh/goisai le/xei:
kai\ ga\r au)ta/, possi\n a)/peplos o)rou/s-
ais' a)po\ strwmna=s, o(/mws a)/munen u(/brin knwda/lwn.
……
e)n xeri\ d' )*amfitru/wn koleou= gu-
mno\n tina/sswn fa/sganon
i(/ket' o)cei/ais a)ni/aisi tupei/s.

koi=la. Paley understands 'postes qui latebras serpentibus praebuerunt,' but the serpents in question are at least big pythons. It seems better to change the feeble oi)/kou of l. 16 to ei)=ken (Stadtmüller), and explain koi=la as Soph. O. T. 1262 e)/kline koi=la klh=|qra. Tr. 'where the posts gave way and bent inwards.' The huge snakes do not come through an open door--as in Pindar's narrative--but force their way in.
a)peilh/sasa, 'threatening that they should eat.'
kako\n pu=r. Bacchyl. 9 has canqoderkh/s, of a snake; cf. Hesiod, Theog. 826 (of Typhoeus) e)k de/ oi( o)/sswn qespesi/h|s kefalh=|sin u(p' o)fru/si pu=r a)ma/russe.
fa/os cf. v. 39.

o(/pws, 'when he saw.' There are isolated instances of this use in Homer, Odyss. xxii. 22 toi\ d' o(ma/dhsan mnhsth=res kata\ dw/maq', o(/pws i)/don a)/ndra peso/nta. It is common in Herodotus; cf. also Callim. Dian. 51 o(/pws i)/den ai)na\ pe/lwra.
e)nanti/os, 'facing the snakes'; 'standing up to them' as we might say.
u(po\ trofw=|, 'that never cried while nursed.'
u(po/, 'under the power of'; cf. xxii. 159; Ap. Rhod. i. 270 u(po\ mhtruih=| bi/oton baru\n h(ghla/zei.

a)ka/nqas belongs both to die/luon and moge/oien, 'loosening their coils in their agony'; cf. Ap. Rhod. iv. 150:
au)ta\r o(/ g' h)/dh
oi)/mh| qelgo/menos dolixh\n a)nelu/et' a)/kanqan
ghgene/os spei/rhs mh/kune de\ muri/a ku/kla.

34, 35 The speech of Alcmena is introduced abruptly without any prefatory kai\ fa/to mu=qon or the like; cf. l. 48. Ahrens' e)pe/krage is an unnecessary change for e)pe/greto. The v. l. e)pe/drame (MS. c)--strangely adopted by Ziegler--is worthless.
a)/nsta = a)na/sthqi (Krüger, ii. 36. 1. 11); cf. para/sta = para/sthqi, Menander.
qei/h|s Epic subjunct. 2 aor., Krüger, ii. 36. 1. 7.
e(oi=s = teoi=s (soi=s).

o(/ti nukto/s, 'that it is the dead hour of night, while the walls stand clear with light, as it were in the brilliant dawn'; cf. Odyss. xix. 37. The house is filled with a strange unnatural light, presaging some miraculous event.
a)wri/ cf. xi. 40; sc. e)sti/: cf. tri/xa nukto\s e)/hn, o)ye\ h)=n th=s h(me/ras, etc.

h)rigenei/as gen. of time. The word is an adjectival epithet of h)w/s in Homer, except only Odyss. xxiii. 347 (xruso/qronon h)rige/neian w)=rsen). It appears as a substantive in Ap. Rhod. iii. 823, and frequently in later poets.

kaqara=s cf. Aratus, 469:
nukto\s kaqara=s o(/te pa/ntas a)gauou\s
a)ste/ras a)nqrw/pois e)pidei/knutai ou)rani/h nu/c.
new/teron, 'something strange.'
meta\ ci/fos, 'to get his sword.'

o(/ oi( cf. the scansion of Iliad xxii. 307 to/ oi( u(po\ lapa/rhn te/tato me/ga te stibaro/n te: Odyss. ix. 398; xxi. 136. The line resembles closely Antimachus, frag. 74 to/ r(a/ oi( a)gxilexe\s kre/mato peri\ pa/ssalon ai)ei/.

dmw=as, k.t.l. Note here as at the beginning of the poem how homely the description of Theocritus is as compared with Pindar (above on l. 14). Theocritus' heroes would hardly let you believe that they belong to that past which was never present. In Theocritus the sleepy, snoring servants are hardly roused by the master (au)to/s) and the mill-slave, and then come crowding in a throng of frightened domestics; for Pindar there must come at this moment of the adventure *kadmei/wn a)goi\ xalke/ois su\n o(/plois dramo/ntes.

For e)kfusw=ntas cf. Verg. Aen. ix. 326 'toto proflabat pectore somnum,' where Servius has 'periphrasis est ne verbo humili stertentem dicat'; here the 'humile verbum' is not intended to be concealed.
o(/ti qa=sson Arist. Probl. 866 a 25 o(/pws o(/ti qermo/teros h)=|.

mu/lais e)/pi cf. Odyss. xx. 105:
fh/mhn d' e)c oi)/koio gunh\ proe/hken a)letri\s
plhsi/on, e)/nq' a)/ra oi( mu/lai ei(/ato poime/ni law=n.
l. 49 has a Homeric ending (Odyss. xxi. 47); l. 52 resembles Iliad xviii. 525 oi( de\ ta/xa proge/nonto.

sumplh/gdhn apparently = 'in panic' not 'conplosis manibus' (see Meineke's note)--a new word, but formed like e)mplh/gdhn (Odyss. xx. 132). Similar words in -dhn, -da, -do/n are coined with great frequency in the poets: a)nami/gdhn, a)na/migda, e)mpela/dhn, dra/gdhn, i)lhdo/n (for Homeric i)lado/n), e(lkhdo/n, etc.
deikana/asken, 'showed'; vid. Liddell and Scott.
kourosu/na| a new coinage of the Alexandrian poets.
ba/le Callim. Del. 265 a)p' ou)/deos ei(/leo pai=da e)n d' e)ba/leu ko/lpoisin.
chro\n u(pai\ dei/ous, 'paralyzed with fear'; Arist. Lysist. 385 a)ll' au)=o/s ei)m' h)/dh tre/mwn.
u(pai\ dei/ous cf. A. Pal. vi. 220 a)/naudos e)/meine de/ous u(/po.
a)kro/xloon, 'deadly pale.'

tri/ton the third cock-crow. 'Noctis enim tempus quemadmodum in tres partes erat divisum, ita tertia pars, quae a gallicinio (a)lektorofwni/a) nomen habebat, in tres particulas erat subdivisa. Sic Id. xviii. 56 o( pra=tos a)oido\s de primo gallicinio ponitur indicatque primum mane' (Wuestemann).

*teiresi/an cf. Pind. N. i. 90:
gei/tona d' e)kka/lesen
(Amphitryon) *dio\s u(yi/stou profa/tan e)/coxon,
o)rqo/mantin *teiresi/an: o( de\ oi(= fra/ze kai\ panti\
stratw=|, poi/ais o(milh/sei tu/xais, k.t.l.

e)/mellen the imperfect is correct here. Oratio Recta would use e)/melle--a thing is fixed from of old in destiny--not me/llei. Odyss. ii. 156 w(/rmhnan d' a)na\ qumo\n a(/ per tele/esqai e)/mellon: Arist. Vesp. 460 a)=r' e)me/llome/n poq' u(ma=s a)posobh/sein tw=| xro/nw|.

ai)do/menos Odyss. iv. 326:
mhde/ ti/ m' ai)do/menos meili/sseo mhd' e)leai/rwn,
a)ll' eu)= moi kata/lecon, k.t.l.
kai\ w(/s, 'even thus.' We should expect ou)d' w(/s as the sentence is negative.

klwsth=ros, 'spindle'; Odyss. vii. 197:
pei/setai a(/ssa oi( *ai)=sa kata\ *klw=qe/s te barei=ai
geinome/nw| nh/santo li/nw|.
A. Pal. vii. 14:
w)= trie/likton
*moi=rai dineu=sai nh=ma kat' h)laka/tas.

*eu)hrei/da Teiresias appears by this name in Callim. v. 81. The MS. version of this line is hardly tolerable, though we find such scansion as gerai^ous (Tyrtaeus), zhtrei^on (Herond.), ui^os (Odyss.), a)rai^os as well as oi^o/s te, toi^au=ta, etc. ma/nti is an obvious gloss.
frone/onta dida/skw the emphasis is on the participle; 'thou knowest all I tell thee.'

a)ristoto/keia cf. Megara, 27 ai)noto/keia. The sense there is obviously 'most wretched of mothers,' so here 'noblest of mothers' not 'mother of noblest sons'; Eurip. Rhes. 909 a)ristoto/koio ge/nnas, 'noblest of children.' See Kenyon on Bacchyl. xi. 106.
mello/ntwn de/, 'and treasure in thy heart the happier turns of fate.'
76, 77 pollai/, 'many a dame of Greece, while she rubs the soft thread about her knee at eventide, shall sing of Alcmene by name.' The important word is a)ei/doisai--the participle.

peri\ gou/nati cf. A. Pal. vii. 726 (Leonidas):
h)\ r(iknh\ r(iknou= peri\ gou/natos a)/rkion i(stw=|
xeiri\ stroggu/llous' i(mero/essa kro/khn.
The use of katatri/yonti (-ousi) is rather far-fetched, but expresses the careful twisting and rubbing smooth of the thread before weaving, Verg. Georg. i. 390 'nocturna carpentes pensa puellae.'

e)s ou)rano/n cf. the prophecy in Pindar, N. i. 105:
au)to
 ma
 e)n ei)ra/na kama/twn mega/lwn e)n sxerw=|
a(suxi/an to
 a(/panta xro/non poina
 laxo/nt' e)cai/reton
o)lbi/ois e)n dw/masi, deca/menon qalera
 (/*hban a)/koitin
…pa *dii\ *kroni/da| semno)n ai)nh/sein do/mon.
a)po\ ste/rnwn platu/s, 'broad of breast'; cf. xiv. 68.
platu/s cf. Simon. Epig. 108 ou) plate/i+ nikw=n sw/matos a)lla\ te/xna|.
*traxi/nios Soph. Trach. 1191 sqq.: Bacchyl. xvi.
gambro/s cf. xviii. 18.

e)/stai (o(/te) : cf. xxiii. 34; Iliad xiii. 817; Odyss. xviii. 272. Teiresias seems to prophecy a new golden age on earth as the
result of Heracles' labours; cf. Verg. Ecl. iv. 24. The idea is unusual in this connexion, but there is hardly ground for suspecting the verses as an interpolation.
eu)= ma/la pa=san cf. xxv. 19.
u(perou/rion, 'out of the land.' The adject. = u(pe\r tou\s o(/rous; cf. xiv. 55, etc.
e)s pe/tras the ashes are to be cast on to a desert spot. The 'correction' r(wga/dos e)k makes nonsense.

a)/streptos Verg. Ecl. viii. 101:
'Fer cineres, Amarylli, foras rivoque fluenti
Transque caput iace, nec respexeris.'
Soph. O. C. 490:
ai)tou= su/ t' au)to\s kei)/ tis a)/llos a)nti\ sou=,
a)/pusta fwnw=n mhde\ mhku/nwn boh/n.
e)/peit' a)fe/rpein a)/strofos.
Note the use of the nominative with the infin. here in command. According to the usual use the accus. is employed when the person to whom the command applies is not present in person. As here Quint. Smyrn. xii. 29 laoi\ d' a)po\ no/sfi ne/esqai: Hesiod, Op. 459 dh\ to/t' e)formhqh=nai o(mw=s dmw=e/s te kai\ au)to/s.
e)stemme/nw| qallw=|, 'wreathed with wool'; cf. Soph. O. T. 3 i(kthri/ois kla/doisin e)cestemme/noi.
w(s tele/qoite, 'that ye may ever be lords over your enemies.' The optative is used in primary sequence as in x. 45 (note)
baru/s cf. Soph. O. T. 17 su\n gh/ra| barei=s.

ne/on futo/n. The simile is as old as Homer, Iliad xviii. 56:
o( d' a)ne/dramen e)/rnei+ i)=sos:
to\n me\n e)gw\ qre/yasa, futo\n w(\s gounw=| a)lwh=s, k.t.l.
Cf. Quint. Smyrn. vii. 645 o( d' a)/r' w)=ka qew=n e)rikude/i+ boulh=| e)/rnos o(/pws e)riqhle\s a)e/ceto.

keklhme/nos )*amfitru/wnos Eurip. H. F. 31 ou(= tau)to\n o)/noma pai=s patro\s keklhme/nos. The remainder of the idyll is occupied with a brief account of the training of the young Heracles; it is somewhat bald and has little connexion with the preceding narrative. It is probable that here for once Theocritus yields to the learned tendency of the Alexandrian school, and introduces mythology for mythology's sake alone, especially as the majority of the legends here alluded to are scarcely known elsewhere, or not at all. An additional motive may however be that already noticed; to glorify Heracles as the last ancestor of the house of Ptolemy, and to glorify him by giving him as pupil to a group of heroes.

e)pi/skopon ei)=nai, 'to be a marksman with the arrow'; e)pi/skopos is the adjective, vid. Liddell and Scott. The genitive stands after it as after e)pisth/mwn or the like (a)frodisi/wn duse/rwtes, Xen. Oec. xii. 13). Most editors now read e)pi\ skopo\n ei(=nai o)isto/n, but this is an unnecessary alteration.
e)k pate/rwn cf. xvii. 13.

a)fneio/s with the dative here and xxv. 119, and Hesiod, Op. 120; elsewhere with genitive. Eurytus named with Heracles as the greatest of archers in Odyss. viii. 224 oi(/ r(a kai\ a)qana/toisin e)ri/zeskon peri\ to/cwn.

eu)/molpos MSS. *eu)/molpos, but 'tres Eumolpos habet Schol. Soph. O. C. 1046, quorum nemo erat filius Philammonis. Lege *fila/mmwn eu)/molpos = Philam. cantu peritus, et intellige de Thamyri (Iliad ii. 595) Suidas: *fila/mmwn e(/teros o(\n a)/|dousi *qamu/rou tou= *qra|ko\s pa/tera gene/sqai.' Taylor quoted by Briggs.
Join o(/ssa a)po\ skele/wn sfa/llonti, 'all the tricks of foot wherewith the nimble Argive wrestlers throw each other in the bout.'
a)po\ skele/wn cf. vii. 6 e)k podo/s (note).
e(drostro/foi, 'with a quick twist.' Theophrastus peri\ o)yimaqi/as: kai\ palai/wn e)n tw=| balanei/w| pukna\ th\n e(/dran stre/fein.
pa/mmaxoi Heracles is trained (1) in wrestling; (2) in boxing; (3) in the combined exercises of the Pancratium: see note on xxii. 66.
*fanoth=i of Phanotè or Phanoteia a town of Phocis. This Harpalycus is not elsewhere known in connexion with Heracles.

su/rigga Soph. Electra 720, describing the chariots coming close round the turning-point of the course (nu/ssa):
kei=nos d' u(p' au)th\n e)sxa/thn sth/lhn e)/xwn
e)/xrimpt' a)ei\ su/rigga, decio/n t' a)nei\s
seirai=on i(/ppon ei)=rge to\n proskei/menon.
Amphitryon appears as a great charioteer in Pindar, P. ix. 81.

e)ch/rato Odyss. xiii. 137:
o(/s' a)\n ou)de/pote *troi/hs e)ch/rat' )*odusseu/s,
ei)/per a)ph/mwn h)=lqe, laxw\n a)po\ lhi+/dos ai)=san.
die/lusan i(ma/ntas 'Commendatur Amphitryonis peritia ea eo quod nondum fractos currus servaverat usque dum lora eorum prae vetustate soluta essent' (Briggs).
probolai/w| cf. xxii. 120.

w)=mon cf. Tyrtaeus, ii. 23:
mhrou/s te knh/mas te ka/tw kai\ ste/rna kai\ w)/mous
a)spi/dos eu)rei/hs gastri\ kaluya/menos.
The nw=ton of the MSS. would only be possible if Heracles were pictured retreating like Ajax in Iliad xi. 545 (o)/piqen de\ sa/kos ba/len e(ptabo/eion); or the shield was slung on the back when not in use; Ap. Rhod. iii. 1320, of Jason ploughing--o( d' a)/r' au)=tis e(lw\n sa/kos e)/nqeto nw/tw| e)co/piqen.

(*ippali/das (1) son of Hippalus; then this Castor is not the brother of Pollux, but another not elsewhere known: (2) i(ppali/das is read by some as a by-form of i(ppeu/s: then the story of the next two lines does not suit Castor; besides, though we have drapeti/dhs = drape/ths, and a number of comic formations, klepti/dhs, grammodidaskali/dhs, etc., i(ppali/das would necessitate a form i(/ppalos or i(ppa/lhs: and there is no such word.
It is best therefore to admit here the existence of Castor son of Hippalus.
a)sfale/ws…kore/ssai another homely, if not comic, touch.
a)sfale/ws A. Pal. v. 182 xou=s ga\r e)/neisi du/o a)sfale/ws, 'for certain.'

kore/ssai not e)ko/ressen as the possibility is regarded as still present; Odyss. xiii. 86:
h( de\ ma/l' a)sfale/ws qe/en e)/mpedon: ou)de/ ken i)/rhc
ki/rkos o(marth/seien, e)lafro/tatos petehnw=n.
e)p' a)/mati in the day, as opposed to his square meal at evening (dei=pnon).

The poem closes abruptly on the picture of the barelegged Heracles, but these abrupt endings are fully in the manner of Theocritus, and not the slightest attention should be paid to the notice of the Juntine edition a)tele/s, or that of Callierges, lei/pei to\ te/los. See the next idyll, Megara, and Introd. p. 29.

div1.p: On this poem see Introduction, p. 29. It falls into three divisions: (1) ll. 1-84 the meeting of Heracles with an old labourer; his inquiry concerning Augeas; their journeying toward the stables. (2) The meeting with Augeas is not described, but we have a sudden transition to the cattle stalls, and description of Heracles felling a bull which attacked him. (3) Another sudden transition, l. 153: Phyleus and Heracles are found going to 'the town,' the reason for the journey is not given. In the course of the walk Heracles tells his companion the story of the Nemean lion.

The title of the poem, (*hraklh=s *leontofo/nos, is therefore incomplete. The poem rather describes a day in the life of Heracles, ending with his personal narrative. There is no direct evidence that any part of the poem has been lost, or that additions were contemplated by the author; nor is it necessary to hold such a view; the abrupt beginning and transitions leave no obscurity, and are therefore unobjectionable. On the MS. see Introd. pt. ii. There are striking diversities of reading due probably to the fact that the original archetype was in places illegible. I have followed the *p tradition generally (cf. Ahrens) save where its readings are due to mere guesswork (e. g. l. 1). The best collation is given by Hiller, Beiträge, p. 96; cf. ib. p. 47 and 80 foll.
The dialect is Epic; the vocabulary is chiefly Homeric, but contains many words unknown to the old poetry, and not a few a(/pac lego/mena.

div2.p: The speaker and the question put by him are learned from the labourer's answer, l. 7 sqq.

ei)nodi/oio, 'the god of the roads.' For this attribute of
Hermes, cf. Soph. Philoct. 133 )*ermh=s o( pe/mpwn do/lios h(gh/saito nw=|n: hence the erection of the statues of Hermes at the street corners.
kexolw=sqai. Hiller quotes Diphilus (in Athenaeus, 238 F) a)gnoei=s e)n tai=s a)rai=s o(/, ti e)sti\n ei)/ tis mh\ fra/sei' o)rqw=s o(do/n.

na/ontos…)*elisou=ntos, 'of the flowing Elisus.' This was a river of Pisatis (Elis). a)mfi/ adverbial; 'on either side.' *bouprasi/ou (l. 11) is in N. Elis. *mh/niou (l. 15) is the stream which Heracles diverted into the stables of Augeas to clean them.
xwri\s…shkoi/. The sheepfolds are scattered in the different districts of Elis where the flocks are; the cattle stalls (l. 18) are all together and the herds are massed in one place.

qale/qousi poi/hn. The verb is not causal, but intransitive; and mel. poi/hn is cognate accusative: cf. v. 154; Nonnus, Dion. vii. 346 droserou= leimw=nos a)ne/bruon a)/nqea toi=xoi ('burst into flower'); Herond. i. 52 i)/oulon a)nqeu=ntas: Pind. Ol. iii. 23 kala\ de/ndre' e)/qallen xw=ros.
ei)amenai/, 'meadows.'
e)pi\ decia\ xeiro/s, 'on thy right'; Isocr. 65 b e)pi\ ta/de *fash/lidos, 'on this side of Phaselis.'
eu)= ma/la pa=sa xxiv. 94. The stable is all in one place not divided like the sheepfolds.
e)phetanai/, 'in close groves.'
eu)qu/s, 'hard by' of place; cf. Thucyd. vi. 96; vii. 22.

polu\n kai\ a)qe/sfaton conjoined like makro\s kai\ a)nari/qmhtos, Soph. Ajax 646; pollh\ a)pei/rwn, Odyss. xv. 81; polu\s o)/mbros a)qe/sfatos. Iliad x. 6. See Lobeck in Ajax, loc. cit.; and cf. Idyll vii. 15, note.
tripo/lois see xvi. 94, note.

ou)/rous = o(/rous: the boundaries of the domain. The labourer has been describing the various divisions of Augeas' domain: the sheep lands, the cattle pastures, the corn lands (l. 25), and labourers' cottages. The sense of the present line, 'the boundaries are known by the gardeners (? vine-dressers),' seems to be 'the fourth part of the domain--on the hills about hollow Elis (l. 31) is vineland, with which we here have nothing to do, but only see the labourers when they come to annual festival and wine-treading (lhnoi/, cf. vii. 25).' ou)/rous i)/sasi therefore is equivalent to e)n o(/rois oi)kou=sin. Meineke gives this sense but reads nai/ousi. Hiller's translation, 'si scire cupis ubi tandem termini ditionis sint interroga fossores, hoc est, "latissime patent fines,"' seems greatly forced and unnatural.
kakw=n e)/c cf. xxii. 56, note. The line echoes Iliad xiv. 472 ou) me/n moi kako\s ei)/detai ou)de\ kakw=n e)/c, k.t.l.

oi(=on not exclamatory, but = e)pei\ toi=on: cf. xv. 146; Odyss. xviii. 74:
h)= ta/xa =)*iros )/*ai+ros e)pi/spaston kako\n e(/cei,
oi(/hn e)k r(ake/wn o( ge/rwn e)pigouni/da fai/nei.
Odyss. iv. 611 ai(/mato/s ei)s a)gaqoi=o, fi/lon te/kos, oi(=' a)goreu/eis.
For e)pipre/pei cf. Pind. P. viii. 64 fua=| to\ gennai=on e)pipre/pei e)k pate/rwn paisi\n lh=ma.
h)/gagen xreiw/ cf. Odyss. iv. 312.

kri/nousi Iliad xvi. 387 ei)n a)gorh=| skolia\s kri/nwsi qe/mistas. The king with the elders of the people sits in judgement (in Ap. Rhod. iv. 1175 Alcinous e)n xeiri\ skh=ptron e)/xen xrusoi=o dikaspo/lon w(=| u(/po laoi\ i)qei/as a)na\ a)/stu diekri/nonto qe/mistas--diekri/nonto is passive--were judged with righteous judgment). In the Homeric age the king would hardly have coadjutors; cf. Hesiod, Theog. 85 pa/ntes e)s au)to\n o(rw=si diakri/nonta qe/mistas. 'These qe/mistes refer to men's rights which may have become a subject of dispute and require the decision of an authorized judge' (Paley).

a)/llon, 'for God makes man dependent upon man.' (Eurip.) Rhesus 106:
a)ll' ou) ga\r au(to\s pa/nt' e)pi/stasqai brotw=n
pe/fuken: a)/llw| d' a)/llo pro/skeitai ge/ras.
di=os Odyss. xiv. 413 di=os u(forbo/s.
