bi/h| *fulh=os a well known Homeric periphrasis, i)erh\ i)\s *thlema/xoio: i)\s )*odush=os (Iliad xxiii. 720); bi/h (*hraklhei/h, l. 154 of this Idyll; Odyss. xi. 601, etc.
h)/masi polloi=s, 'after many days'; as xro/nw|: dia\ xro/nou, 'after long time.'
w(/s pou, 'since even kings I take it think their household will be surer for their own care.'
i(/na, 'where.' ken belongs to the verb.
te/tmoimen, 'find.'
mh/ ti/ oi(, 'lest perchance his word should be out of season, in his fellow's haste.'
sperxome/nou genit. absol. without subject after dative. Vid. Index.
oi( cf. vii. 25.

ku/nes cf. Odyss. xiv. 29:
e)capi/nhs d' )*odush=a i)/don ku/nes u(lako/mwroi.
oi( me\n keklh/gontes e)pe/dramon…
a)lla\ subw/ths w)=ka posi\ kraipnoi=si metaspw\n
e)/ssut' a)na\ pro/quron,…
tou\s me\n o(moklh/sas seu=en ku/nas a)/lludis a)/llon
puknh=|sin liqa/dessin.
to\n de\ ge/ronta, 'but fawned about the old man with aimless yelping.'
a)xrei=on because the dogs are barking not at any one, as is their proper work, but out of sheer high spirits; cf. Odyss. xviii. 163 a)xrei=on d' e)ge/lasse.
peri/ssainon cf. Odyss. xvi. 4 *thle/maxon de\ peri/ssainon ku/nes u(lako/mwroi.

kla/zonte dual participle with plural subject and verb (more than two being meant); cf. xxv. 137. This use becomes not uncommon in late authors, Oppian, Cynes. ii. 165:
oi(=a/ te laxnh/entes a)riprepe\s ei)=dos e)/xousi
canqo/komoi blosuroi\ qhrw=n mede/onte le/ontes.
Aratus, 1023 o)ye\ bow=nte koloioi/. The instances quoted from
Homer are all doubtful, Iliad i. 567; v. 487 (a couple are addressed); vid. Monro, Hom. Gram. 170, 173.
a)po\ xqono\s o(/sson, 'just lifting from the ground'; cf. xxii. 195, note.

Cf. Odyss. xiv. 527:
xai=re d' )*odusseu\s
o(/tti r(a/ oi( bio/tou perikh/deto no/sfin e)o/ntos.
Odyss. xvii. 200:
tw\ bh/thn, staqmo\n de\ ku/nes kai\ bw/tores a)/ndres
r(u/at' o)/pisqe me/nontes.

w(s e)pimhqe/s Liddell and Scott give 'thoughtful,' but this does not suit the context and is doubtful; the word naturally suggests )*epimhqeu/s, 'the man who thought when it was too late.' In Herondas, iii. 94 (the only other place where the word is used), Metrotima, after having her boy thrashed, says e)re/w e)pimhqe/ws tw=| ge/ronti, *la/mpriske, e)lqou=s' e)s oi)=kon tau=ta. Buecheler translates 'de industria,' but a better sense is got if we take it to mean 'I will get the boy thrashed first, and tell the old man about it casually afterwards.' Here then it will mean 'the dog is quick to fly at any one (l. 80 sqq.), but slow to think whether it be friend or foe.' Recent editors 'emend': e)pipeiqe/s, Ahrens; e)pikhde/s, J. A. Hartung; but we evidently want something in contrast to ei) fre/nes h)=san of l. 80, cf. Plato, Rep. 376 a o(
 a)
 i)/dh| a)gnw=ta xalepai/nei ou)de
 de\ kako
 propeponqw/s.
za/koton, 'savage.'
a)rrhne/s --apparently an onomatopoeic word--'snarling.'
The second episode begins here. Heracles is come to the stalls; the cattle are described coming in thousands over the plain, like the clouds packed and driven by the south-west storm.
met' au)li/a te_ for scansion cf. Iliad xi. 10 me/ga te deino/n te.
meta/, 'into'; cf. vii. 24; h. hymn Demet. 338 meta\ dai/monas, 'to be among the gods.'
a)riqmo\s ou)d' a)/nusis, 'no count nor end.'
a)/nusis, 'power of ending'; cf. prh=cis, Odyss. x. 202 ou) prh=cis e)gi/gneto murome/noisin.
meta/ cf. i. 39.
stei/nonto de/, 'the rich fields were too narrow for the host.'

mukhqmw=| goes with e)rxome/nhs, 'as they wound along lowing.' For the structure of the line cf. Hesiod, Theog. 157 pa/ntas a)pokru/ptaske (kai\ e)s fa/os ou)k a)ni/eske) gai/hs e)n keuqmw=ni: Odyss. viii. 475 nw/tou a)poprotamw\n (e)pi\ de\ plei=on e)le/leipto) a)rgio/dontos u(o/s.
e(/khlos, 'idle'; a post-Homeric meaning.
kwlope/das, 'clogs' or 'thongs about the leg' to keep the cow from kicking the pail over.
peristado\n e)ggu/s an instance of the same redundancy of expression as was noted in vii. 142 peri\ pi/dakas a)mfi/: xiii. 24 a)f' w(= to/te: cf. xxv. 147, 126 suna/ma: xi. 65.
ga/laktos partit. genit. after pine/menai, cf. ii. 152.
baru/fronos, 'deeply pondering.'
112, 113 qumo\n…a)rhro/ta a modification of the Homeric fresi\n h(=|sin a)rhrw/s (Odyss. x. 553).

ou) ga/r ken, 'for none had counted or thought that so great would be the spoil of one man, no nor of ten besides'; cf. Odyss. xiv. 96:
ou)/tini to/ssh (zwh\)
a)ndrw=n h(rw/wn ou)/t' h)pei/roio melai/nhs
ou)/t' au)th=s )*iqa/khs. ou)de\ cuneei/kosi fwtw=n
e)/st' a)/fenos tossou=ton.
polu/rrhnes the wealth is counted in sheep according to the practice of the patriarchal age.
pa/ntwn e)k basilh/wn, 'from a line of kings.'
peri\ pa/ntwn, 'surpassing all men'; a Homeric use of the preposition; cf. Iliad v. 325 *dhipu/lw|…peri\ pa/shs ti=en o(mhliki/hs, etc.

121, 122 nou=sos…ai(/t' the relative is here used in the generic plural after singular noun; cf. Eurip. Orest. 918 au)tourgo\s oi(/per kai\ mo/noi sw/zousi gh=n: Id. Supp. 867 fi/lois a)lhqh\s h)=n fi/los parou=si/ te kai\ mh\ parou=sin, w(=n a)riqmo\s ou) polu/s: Odyss. v. 438 ku/matos e)canadu/s, ta/ t' e)reu/getai h)/peiro/nde.

knh/margoi, 'white-legged.' e(/likes, generally taken here to mean 'black' on the strength of Hesychius' assurance e(/lic me/las. In Homer e(/likes bou=s means either 'with rolling gait' or 'with twisted horns.' In Hesiod, Theog. 298 e(likw/pida nu/mfhn may be 'black-eyed maiden.' Black obviously suits the context here.
a)rghstai/, 'white'; cf. Ap. Rhod. iv. 974 of the oxen of Helios, ou)de/ tis h)=en kuane/h meta\ th=|si de/mas, pa=sai de\ ga/lakti ei)do/menai xruse/oisi kera/asi kudia/askon.
progenoi/ato (proge/nointo) : optative of general time in historic sequence.
leu/ssonte dual for plural; see above, l. 72. For the phrase cf. Odyss. ii. 152 o)/ssonto d' o)/leqron: Eurip. Alcest. 773 ti/ semno\n kai\ pefrontiko\s ble/peis;
sqe/nei+ w(=| Iliad v. 71 po/sei+ w(=|: xvi. 542 sqe/nei+ w(=|, etc.
xaropoi=o, 'tawny.'
e)dra/cato…ke/raos, 'gripped him by the left horn'; cf. iv. 36.
w)/mw|, 'throwing the weight of his shoulder on the thrust'; cf. xxii. 124.

muw/n, 'the muscle'; cf. xxii. 48. The passage seems to be imitated by Quint. Smyrn. vi. 236:
a)po/proqi d' e)/pleto tau=ros
pu/rpnoos o(/n r(a kai\ au)to\n a)maima/keto/n per e)o/nta
gna/mpte bi/h| krateroi=o kera/atos: oi(= de/ oi( a)/mfw
a)ka/matoi muw=nes e)reidome/noio te/tanto.

Here the poet passes to the third episode. Phyleus tells Heracles how a man of Achaea had come among them with a wondrous tale of the killing of the Nemean lion by an unknown hero; surely the unknown can be no one than Phyleus' present companion. Is it so, and will he tell how the deed was done? Heracles acknowledges his identity, and tells
in a modest but spirited narrative how he slew the beast. The transition is as abrupt as at 84, and we are left to supply a number of details at our pleasure.
e)stixe/thn note that while in Homer the dual never has the augment, later Epic adds it.

The two had left the stalls by a narrow path through the vineyards where there was not room for both to walk abreast. Phyleus therefore defers his questioning until they reach the broader road (laofo/ros ke/leuqos).
o(/qi is answered by th=| min a)/ra, 159.
-158. e)canu/santes, 'when they had reached the end.'
a)mpelew/n a rarer form for a)mpelw/n.

xlwra\ qe/ousa, 'a line of green among the trees.' xlwra/ is cognate accus. (= adverb). So Hesiod, Scut. 147 o)do/ntes leuka\ qe/ontes: poi/hn leuka\ qe/ousan, Herod. Att. v. 24: potamoi\ keladeina\ r(e/ontes, Ap. Rhod. iii. 532 (see Lobeck on Ajax, p. 71 sqq.). I have altered Meineke's qeou/sh| to qe/ousa since the greenness of the wood would not make the path less clear. Theocritus surely means a narrow grass-grown path, scarcely distinguishable in the green wood. Ap. Rhod. i. 546 e)leukai/nonto ke/leuqoi a)trapo\s w(\s xloeroi=o dieidome/nh pedi/oio.

162, 163 The reading of these lines as it stands in the MSS., though awkward, is not incapable of defence. Tr. 'But now, as it were, am I giving mind to a tale which long time since I heard of thee' (lit. having heard a tale of thee long ago I am now as it were giving mind to it). w(sei/ per qualifies e)ni\ fresi\ ba/llomai, and gives a hesitating tone to the assertion. He is not quite certain yet of the correctness of his conclusion; w(sei/ per therefore = 'quasi,' and ba/llomai remains the main verb. In 162 join pa/lai pa/gxu. sfete/rh|si here = e)mai=s.
e)ni\ fresi/ cf. Iliad i. 297 a)/llo de/ toi e)re/w, su\ d' e)ni\ fresi\ ba/lleo sh=|si.

w(s me/sos a)kmh=s, 'in the middle of his prime.' For the genitive cf. Herod. i. 170 *te/wn ga\r ei)=nai me/son th=s )*iwni/hs: St. Matt. xiv. 24 to\ de\ ploi=on h)/dh me/son th=s qala/sshs h)=n, 'in the midst of the sea.' More usually the genitive denotes the extremes between which a thing lies, not the whole in which a central point is taken. [Similar are Anacreont. xii. 16 me/sos de\ kardi/hs meu e)/dune: Iliad vi. 118 puma/th qe/en a)spi/dos o)mfaloe/sshs.]
ai)nole/onta = ai)no\n le/onta: cf. xxiv. 73, note. So mounole/wn (Leonidas, 65) = mo/nos le/wn: mono/lukos, Aratus; ai)no/lukos, A. Pal. vii. 550.
ei)/t' e)tu/mws. This clause depends on i(/na gnw/w. The following ei) su/g' e)kei=nos depends on ei)/p' a)/ge.
a)kouo/ntessin = a)kou/ousi: cf. v. 16; Odyss. i. 352; xii. 311 klaio/ntessi. The form is especially common in Pindar.
ou(c (*eli/khqen cf. xxii. 11. Note that Theocritus even in the Epic idylls uses the article in the post-Homeric manner.
)*api/da Peloponnesus; )*api/a gh=, Aesch. Ag. 257.
187, 188 'And some said he told them traveller's tales, scattering the words of an idle tongue among the throng.'
xarizo/menon cf. Eurip. Orest. 1514 deili/a| glw/ssh| xari/zei ta)/ndon ou)x ou(/tw fronw=n: Hesiod, Op. 709 yeu/desqai glw/sshs xa/rin: Odyss. xiv. 365 mayidi/ws yeu/desqai.
kata\ sta/qmhn, 'aright,' Odyss. v. 245 e)pi\ sta/qmhn i)/qunen.
ta\ e(/kasta Iliad xi. 706 and often.
tou=de pelw/rou the genitive depends loosely on ta\ e(/kasta, all the circumstance concerning this monster.

leli/hsai. Homer has the participle only lelihme/nos: we find not infrequently in the Alexandrians verbs used in parts in which they are defective in earlier writers. Thus Ap. Rhod. i. 765 has a)ke/ois (as if from a)ke/w, cf. Homeric a)ke/wn): Nicand. Alex. 13 pnuqei/hs (akin to pepnume/nos).
no/sfi/n g' h)/, 'save only whence he came.' nosfi\n h)/ does not occur elsewhere.
i(rw=n mhni/santa, 'in wrath with us for (neglect of) sacrifice.' The genitive stands after verbs expressing emotion--anger, envy, or the like.

*forwnei/dh|sin Meineke quotes Steph. Byzant. le/gontai de\ )*argei=oi patrwnumikw=s--(*hraklei=dai, pro\ d' (*hrakle/ous *persei=dai, pro\ *perse/ws de\ *lugkei=dai, pro\ de\ *lugke/ws *danai+/dai pro\ de\ *danaou= kai\ *forwnei=dai.
potamo\s w(/s the syllable before w(/s is lengthened in Epic verse, Callim. Del. 193 a)nqe/rikos w(/s, etc.
pish=as (piseu/s), 'dwellers in the meadows,' 'lowlanders.' The word is a new formation from pi=sos: cf. stadieu/s (sta/dion), a)lweu/s (Alexandrian writers) from a)lwa/.
*bembinai/ous *bembi=na kw/mh th=s *neme/as, o( poli/ths *bembini/ths…*panu/asis e)n (*hraklei/as prw/th| de/rma de\ qh/reion *bembinh/tao le/ontos, Steph. Byzant.

a)gxo/moroi (governing e(/qen), 'nigh on his borders.' The word is simply a more picturesque form for a)/gxi, being formed from a)/gxi and o(/moros: cf. a)/gxouros, proso/mouros, a)gxi/domoi (see Hiller, Beiträge, p. 81). In the MS. reading the lengthening of the syllable (nai=on) in the fourth arsis is unusual except when the verse has weak caesura.
For paqo/ntes we should have pa/sxontes.
u(gro/n, 'supple'; cf. i. 55.

au)to/floion, 'with its bark complete'; = au)tw=| tw=| floi/w|, a good example of the flexibility of the Greek compound adjective. Cf. the word au)toboei/: au)to/culon, Soph. Phil. 35 (= made of wood alone).
o(/qi_ li=s the i_ is lengthened before the liquid -l- according to Epic use; cf. xxii. 121; xxv. 241, 73, 257; xi. 45; Odyss. i. 56 ai)ei\ de\ malakoi=si, etc.

neureih/n a collateral form for neurh/: cf. e)gxei/h. Oppian has ou)rai/h| for ou)rh=| (Hal. v. 479). So we find karxaro/dwn (xxiv. 87); meledwneu/s (xxiv. 106); a)muxmo/n (xxiv. 126); khdemoneu/s (Ap. Rhod.) for khdemw/n, etc.
ei)/…e)saqrh/saimi, 'if haply I might see him'; cf. Iliad xiii. 760 foi/ta…dizh/menos ei)/ pou e)feu/roi: Ap. Rhod. iii. 113 bh= r(' i)/men ei)/ min e)feu/roi, etc.: Sonnenschein, Syntax, § 357.

h)/matos, 'it was now midday, and nowhere could I mark his tracks nor hear his roar.' ou)de/ ph| a)qrh=sai duna/mhn, Odyss. xii. 232. The reading ou)d' o(/ph| is indefensible here, pace Meineke. The sense so yielded, 'I could not mark where his tracks were,' is clumsy, and the order would naturally be frasqh=nai i)/xnia o(/ph|.

o(/ntin' e)roi/mhn, 'whom I could ask.' This use of the
optative is Homeric; Iliad ii. 687 ou) ga\r e)/hn o(/stis sfin e)pi\ sti/xas h(gh/saito. In primary sequence Homer uses subjunctive with or without ken: Iliad ix. 165 klhtou\s o)tru/nomen oi(/ ke ta/xista e)/lqwsi: ib. xxi. 103 ou)k e)/sq' o(/stis qa/naton fu/gh|. In Attic we should here have the aorist indic. with a)/n: o(/ntina h)rw/thsa a)/n. Cf. Plato, Phaedo, ad init. ou)dei\s a)fi=ktai o(/stis a)\n h(mi=n a)ggei=lai oi(=o/s t' h)=n. The abnormal instances in Soph. Philoct. 691, 280 o(rw=n ou)de/na o(/stis a)rke/seie, are due to the influence of the deliberative construction ou)x ei)=xon o(/stis a)rke/seie.
xlwro/n Odyss. xi. 43 e)me\ de\ xlwro\n de/os h(/|rei: ib. xxii. 42.

sqq. Imitated from Odyss. xxii. 401:
eu(=ren e)/peit' )*odush=a meta\ ktame/noisi ne/kussin,
ai(/mati kai\ lu/qrw| pepalagme/non w(/s te le/onta,
o(/s r(a/ te bebrwkw\s boo\s e)/rxetai a)grau/loio:
pa=n d' a)/ra oi( sth=qo/s te parh/i+a/ t' a)mfote/rwqen
ai(mato/enta pe/lei, deino\s d' ei)s w)=pa i)de/sqai.

dedegme/nos o(ppo/qe, 'waiting for his coming.' Theocritus uses dedegme/nos for the Homeric de/gmenos: Iliad ii. 794 de/gmenos o(ppo/te nau=fin a)formhqei=en )*axaioi/. The clause o(ppo/q' i(/koito is a prospective time clause (Sonnenschein, Syntax, 347).

thu+si/ws, 'in vain'; Bacchyl. v. 81 mh\ tau+/sion proi/ei traxu\n e)k xeirw=n o)i+sto\n yuxai=sin e)/pi fqime/nwn: ib. xiii. 17 ou) ga\r damasi/mbrotos ai)/qwn xalko\s a)pla/tou qe/lei pei/rein dia\ sw/matos: e)stre/fqh d' o)pi/ssw fa/sganon refers like Theocritus to the impossibility of killing the bear with ordinary weapons.
a)nemw/lios au)/tws see v. 40 (note).

per' i)gnu/h|sin, 'and lashed his tail about his flanks'; Iliad xx. 170, of a lion:
ou)rh=| de\ pleura/s te kai\ i)sxi/a a)mfote/rwqen
masti/etai, e(e\ d' au)to\n e)potru/nei maxe/sasqai,
glaukio/wn d' i)qu\s fe/retai me/nei, h)/n tina pe/fnh|
a)ndrw=n, h)\ au)to\s fqi/etai prw/tw| e)n o(mi/lw|.
Note the elision of per(i), cf. Pind. Pyth. iv. 265 didoi= ya=fon per' au)ta=s, and the verbs peri/axe, peroi/xetai.
'And his back bent like a bow as he gathered himself together, sides and flanks, for his spring.'
e)/fugen gnomic aorist; 'flies from his hand.'

su
 o(rmh=|, 'with one bound.' The use of the preposition makes the phrase more picturesque; cf. ii. 136: Soph. Antig. 135 mainome/na| su
 o(rma=|: Pind. N. x. 48 dro/mw| su
 podw=n xeirw=n te nika=sai sqe/nei.
a)qro/os cf. xiii. 51.
ko/rshs, 'swinging the seasoned club over my head'; cf. Eurip. H. F. 992 u(pe\r ka/ra balw\n cu/lon kaqh=ke paido\s e)s canqo\n ka/ra, e)/rrhce d' o)sta=.
pri\n e)/m' i(ke/sqai, 'before he reached me.'

neusta/zwn kefalh=| cf. Odyss. xviii. 239:
=)*iros…
h(=stai neusta/zwn kefalh=|, mequ/onti e)oikw/s,
ou)d' o)rqo\s sth=nai du/i atai.
Theocr. xxii. 98.
i)ni/on the back of the neck.

h)/lasa with his broken club or with his fist? The reading is however doubtful: h)/lasa is given by *p, but *f has e)/fqasa profqa/s, and it is possible that profqa/s is wrong, not e)/fqasa: and we should substitute such a word as pni/cas, or xri/myas. C. Hartung conjectures e)/spasa profqa/s which is attractive.

pro\s d' ou)=das, 'and I pinned his hind legs (po/das ou)rai/ous) firmly to the earth with my heels, and held down his sides with my thighs' (not 'guarded against,' this would require e)fulasso/mhn). Heracles gets behind the lion, gripping his throat and throttling him, while he holds his back firmly with his knees, and treads on the beast's hind legs.
For ou)rai/ous cf. Aratus, 145 ou)rai/ois u(po\ gou/nasi.
me/xri, 'until I had stretched out his fore-limbs (braxi/onas ) and lifted him lifeless.'
tmhth/ the syllable remains long in hiatus, as in Iliad xxiv. 52 e(/lkei: ou) mh/n, etc.

ou)de\ me\n a)/llh|, 'nor in any way besides.' This is Wordsworth's conjecture for the meaningless u(/lh| of the MSS., but is weak and unsatisfactory. Meineke's h(/lw| is not likely to find supporters. The corruption probably goes deeper than the single word.
e)pi\ fresi/, 'set the thought in my mind'; Odyss. xviii. 158 th=| d' a)/r' e)pi\ fresi\ qh=ke qea\…mnhsth/ressi fanh=nai.
au)toi=s…o)nu/xessi, 'with my nails unaided.'

i)wxmoi=o here = 'battle,' a new sense of the word; cf. o)cei/as a)u+/tas, Pind. N. 9. 84. The *p reading o)/fra moi ei)/h is hardly right. The rare i)wxmoi=o would never have been substituted for it.

div1.p: This poem tells in a few rapid strokes the story of Pentheus, his spying on the mysteries of Bacchus, and death at the hands of the Maenads. The description follows that of Euripides in the Bacchae with few unimportant variations. The motif of the poem is hard to determine. Herr Maass, writing in Hermes, 1891, holds that the poem was written as a hymn to Bacchus for performance at a Coan festival. The end certainly suits this view (l. 33 xai/roi me\n *dio/nusos, k.t.l.). Others hold that it is inspired by a painting; in this case the ending lines will express merely the thoughts suggested by the picture. The story was certainly taken as a subject by painters with great frequency, but no existing representation quite tallies with the description here. Lastly it is possible and by far most natural to regard the poem as a simple narrative like Id. xxii; the search for ulterior motives is a weakness among critics of the Alexandrian period, and the obvious is set aside too often.

div2.p:
malopa/rauos cf. vii. 117 w)= ma/loisin )/*erontes e)reuqome/noisin o(moi=oi: the word is possibly chosen as an intentional refinement
of Hesiod's )*agauh\n kallipa/rh|on (Theog. 975). See generally Eurip. Bacch. 679:
o(rw= de\ qia/sous trei=s gunaikei/wn xorw=n,
w(=n h)=rx' e(no\s me\n *au)tono/h, tou= deute/rou
mh/thr )*agauh\ sh/, tri/tou d' )*inw\ xorou=.
ka/mon, 'made.'
tw\s trei=s. The article is used regularly in Greek in mentioning a part or fraction of a larger number already given.
eu)fa/mws, 'in holy silence'; cf. the use of the verb: eu)fhmei=n xrh\ ka)ci/stasqai toi=s h(mete/roisi xoroi=sin (Arist. Frogs 353).
neodre/ptwn of new-plucked branches, as described above.

e)quma/rei, 'was pleased.' Bacchus himself was the founder of the Bacchic worship; see Eurip. Bacch. 21:
e)kei= xoreu/sas kai\ katasth/sas e)ma\s
teleta\s i(/n' ei)/hn e)mfanh\s dai/mwn brotoi=s.

e)ta/race, 'dashed to pieces all the sacred things' (Hiller); o)/rgia includes the altars and sacred vessels, etc. The motive is explained by the following words: ta\ d' ou)x o(re/onti be/bhloi ('on which the unhallowed look not').
mai/neto, 'raged'; cf. Ajax 81 memhno/t' a)/ndra.

me/n te…de/ expresses with the anaphora of mai/nonto a very close connexion of the two actions; see Liddell and Scott, s. v. me/n B. ii. 3; Iliad v. 139 tou= me/n te sqe/nos w)=rsen, e)/peita de/ t' ou) prosamu/nei: Theocr. xxv. 92.
e)ru/saisai Aeolic form of participle, = e)ru/sasai.

Note the extraordinary abruptness of the style here and in the preceding lines. Each detail of the action is sharply expressed in disjointed sentences, each of a single line or couplet, without any subtle use of conjunction.

Compare the account in Eurip. Bacch. 1125:
labou=sa d' w)le/nais a)ristera\n xe/ra,
pleurai=sin a)ntiba=sa tou= dusdai/monos,
a)pespa/racen w)=mon, ou)x u(po\ sqe/nous,
a)ll' o( qeo\s eu)ma/reian e)pedi/dou xeroi=n.
)*inw\ de\ ta)pi\ qa/ter' e)ceirga/zeto,
r(hgnu=sa sa/rkas, *au)tono/h t' o)/xlos te pa=s
e)pei=xe bakxw=n: h)=n de\ pa=s' o(mou= boh/.

kreanome/onto intentionally ghastly, like R. Kipling's--
'When wounded you lie on Afghanistan's plains,
And the women come out to cut up what remains.'

pe/nqhma (*penqh=a) : an instance of the fondness of the Greeks for seeing ominous significance in names; Eurip. Bacch. 367 *penqeu/s--pe/nqos: Aesch. Agam. 686 (*ele/nan…e)pei\ prepo/nt??s e(le/nas, e(/landros, e(le/ptolis ('Helen ship's Hell, man's Hell, city's Hell'--Browning). So Shakespeare, Rich. II, ii. 1 'Old John of Gaunt and gaunt in being old,' though here there is less thought of the name as ominous.
ou)k a)le/gw, 'I care not, nor let another give heed to him that is hated of Bacchus, nay, not if he suffered a harder fate than this.'

a)pexqome/nw we may take this to refer to Pentheus, or to any other who offended the god; such as was Erysichthon who to/ssa *diw/nuson ga\r a(\ kai\ *da/matra xale/ptei kai\ tw=| ga\r *da/matri sunwrgi/sqh *dio/nusos (Callim. vi. 70), and was punished with insatiable hunger.

ei)/h the subject must be a)/llos of l. 27: 'Let not another care, but let him be a child of nine years or entering on the tenth.' The only passage which gives any key to the meaning seems to have been overlooked by the commentators. In Callim. iii. 14 Artemis asks her father: do\s de/ moi e(ch/konta xori/tidas w)keani/nas, pa/sas ei)nae/teas pa/sas e)/ti pai=das a)mi/trous. Artemis' attendants are to be novices of nine years old. Add to this the fact often noticed that children were initiated into the Bacchic mysteries (A. Pal. xi. 40) and we get a possible explanation. 'But let him be as a young novice of Dionysus, as one nine years old or entering on his tenth, and let me too be pure and pleasing to the pure.'
deka/tw cf. xv. 129.
eu)age/oimi cf. Callim. Del. 98 eu)age/wn de\ kai\ eu)age/essi meloi/mhn.
ai)eto/s cf. Iliad xii. 243 ei(=s oi)wno\s a)/ristos a)mu/nesqai peri\ pa/trhs. The present passage shows a curious specialization of use.

div1.p: On the authorship of this see Introd. § 3. The poem gives in dialogue a rustic wooing between one Daphnis and an unnamed girl. Style, language, and tone are alike un-Theocritean.

div2.p: The beginning is abrupt, but there is no necessity to suppose anything lost. The girl tempts Daphnis on by a coy reference to 'another neatherd,' and the prize he won by daring, and accompanies her words apparently with a kiss.
'Rather Helen has captured the neatherd with her kiss, unforced.'
mh\ kauxw= refers to the words a)/zuga kw/ran, 'you will not always be able to boast that you are a young girl.'
w(s o)/nar Theognis, 985 ai)=ya ga\r w(/ste no/hma pare/rxetai a)glao\s h(/bh.

a. Granted that this line stands where the author intended, and as he wished, it would seem to mean 'and if I do grow old, then life at any rate is milk and honey to me.' Then after this line one must be lost in which Daphnis reiterates his warning of the shortness of youth (a(du/ ti ghr. conj. Ribbeck).

The girl objects, 'the grape becomes the raisin, and the dried rose shall not perish,' i. e. I too may change, but I shall
retain something of my sweetness and still shall please. For the mode of expression cf. A. Pal. v. 303:
o)/mfac ou)k e)pe/neusas: o(/t' h)=s stafulh\ parepe/myw,
mh\ fqone/sh|s dou=nai ka)\n braxu\ th=s stafi/dos.
Nicet. Eug. vi. 635:
so\n fqino/pwron krei=tton (h)\ poi=os lo/gos;)
e)/aros a)/llhs so\s de\ xeimw\n kalli/wn
o)pwrofuou=s eu)kraou=s a)/llou qe/rous.
o)izu/on partic. of o)izu/w, 'no lovesick tune.'
li/non Ibycus, fr. 2 e)/ros e)s a)/peira di/ktua *ku/prido/s me ba/llei.

This verse stands before 17 in the MSS.; it is obviously out of its place here. Hermann with some probability sets it after l. 2, dividing it between the girl and Daphnis, but marking a lacuna of two half-lines and reading a)me/lcw. I should prefer xei/lea mi/cw. If it belongs wholly to the girl a line of Daphnis must be lost. Warton proposes kai\ ei)/ g' e)/ti, 'and if you do, I will scratch your lips.'
zugo/n, 'you ever bear his yoke.'

no/mon, 'no one sings my marriage-song'; cf. l. 25; Nonnus, xlvii. 323:
a(bro\s e)/hn u(me/naios a)eidome/nhs )*aria/dnhs
kai\ xoro/s.
Musaeus, 274:
h)=n ga/mos a)ll' a)xo/reutos: e)/hn le/xos a)ll' a)/ter u(/mnwn:
ou) *zugi/hn (/*hrhn tis e)peufh/mhsen a)oido\s…
ou)de\ poluska/rqmw| tis e)peski/rthse xorei/h|:
ou)x u(me/naion a)/eise path\r kai\ po/tnia mh/thr.
r(e/caimi the use of the plain optative in questions occurring in Homer (Iliad xi. 838) becomes very common in Alexandrian and later writers, Herond. v. 76 ti/s ou)k e)mptu/oi; etc.
ne/on fa/os i. e. you will renew your beauty in your children; so Oppian, Hal. v. 89 patri/ ge ghra/skonti ne/on sqe/nos ui(=es.
o)/mnue on these forms see Dr. Rutherford, Babrius, 50.
diw=cai, 'even if you wish to chase me.' Perhaps we should read ge for me, 'I swear not to leave you, and I swear if you like even to pursue you.'

div1.p: This graceful little lyric accompanies a present of an ivory distaff to Theugenis, wife of Theocritus' friend Nicias, now practising as a doctor in Miletus; see Introd p. 34. The metre is Asclepiad: oo -uu- -uu- -uu- uU

The dialect in 28-30 is Aeolic. The chief peculiarities of this are: (1) the absence of the spiritus asper in almost every case (l. 4 i)=ron = i(ero/n): (2) the shifting of the accent far back on words, e.g. 6 i)/dwn, 23 a)/ei, 25 ti/mata, etc.: (3) the doubling of consonants, a)/mmin, ce/nnon, xe/rras = xei=ras, *mi/llaton, 16 a)mmete/ras: (4) in conjugation of verbs; a large number of verbs appear in the -mi form instead of -w. Thus xxviii. 3 qe/rseis' = qarsou=sa (qe/rshmi). Some have u(ma/rth, xxviii. 3--u(ma/rthmi for u(marte/w: ai)th/meqa, xxviii. 5: poth/mena, xxix. 30: doki/moi, xxx. 26 (doki/mwmi): fi/lh, xxix. 20 (fi/lhmi): e)qe/leisqa or e)qe/lhsqa (e)qe/leis), xxix. 4. In the -w conjugation the participle is formed in -oisa (xxviii. 19); the 2nd pers. sing. -hs for -eis (xxix. 14); infin. -hn for -ein (xxix. 35); ei)mi/ has participle e)/ssan (xxviii. 16): (5) in nouns note the accus. plur. -ois for -ous (xxviii. 20); gen. sing in -w (xxx. 1, etc.).

As with the Doric used in the other idylls the Aeolic here is not a pure dialect, but contains an admixture of forms which are not Aeolic at all [xxviii. 6 o(/pws: kaleu=ntos, xxix. 39 (Aeolic would be kale/ntos): noe/onta, xxix. 31]. Others which are Aeolic but quite obsolete, bra/kh (= r(a/kh), xxviii. 11; a)pu/ for a)po/, brai+di/ws, xxx. 27; vid. Legrand, Étude, p. 252. How much is to be attributed to Theocritus and how much to faulty transmission is not to be determined with certainty; the restoration or not of Aeolisms must depend on the taste of each individual reader.

div2.p: gu/naicin dative after dw=ron cf. Soph. Trach. 668 tw=n sw=n (*hraklei= dwrhma/twn: Eurip. I. T. 387.

*nei/leos po/lin Miletus; Callim. iii. 225:
xai=re *xitw/nh
*milh/tw| e)pi/dhme: de\ ga\r poih/sato *neileu\s
h(gemo/nhn o(/te nhusi\n a)nh/geto *kekropi/hqen.

kala/mw…u(papa/lw. I have left the Vulg. lectio, although the last word is in the highest degree uncertain. No satisfactory emendation is forthcoming, and the only plausible suggestion is that the word conceals u(p' + the name of a hill (Meineke). It is just possible, however, to keep to the MS. and explain the word as a compound of u(po/ and a(palo/s, like u(po/suxnos, etc., the u(po- giving the sense of 'somewhat.' It is, however, then necessary to suppose that the first -a- is counted long on the analogy of such Aeolic forms as e(/n(n)eka, ce/n(n)on, su=n o)li/gw| (xxviii. fin.). In that case translate 'where is the shrine of Cypris of tender reeds.' There was a temple of Venus at Samos called to\ e)n kala/mois or to\ e)n e(/lei: cf. Theocr. vii. 115, where the name *bubli/s is probably connected with bu/blos and derived from these rush-beds.
te/ryomai cf. Odyss. xvi. 25 nu=n ei)/selqe fi/lon te/kos o)/fra se qumw=| te/ryomai ei)soro/wn.
i)/eron fu/ton cf. Iliad ii. 704 *poda/rkhs, o)/zos )/*arhos: Theocr. vii. 44.
polumo/xqw, 'wrought with toil.'
gegenhme/nan, 'made'; the passive of poie/w as in Isocr. ii. 27 toi=s pra/gmasi toi=s mh\ dia\ sou= gegenhme/nois, etc.
o)lo/xw = a)lo/xou.
xe/rras = xei=ras.
pe/plois acc. plur. = pe/plous: cf. ll. 12, 16.
fore/ois' = fore/ousi (forou=si).
bra/kh (r(a/kh), 'raiment.' The b represents the digamma at the beginning of words in Aeolic; so brodopa/xees is restored in Sappho; and we find brai+di/ws, Theocr. xxx. 28, and bradino/s in Sappho.

u)da/tina Callim. fr. 295 has u(da/tinon kai/rwma. The sense is probably 'flowing,' not 'water-coloured' or 'transparent.' That was at any rate the sense understood by Antipater in A. Pal. ix. 567 u(dati/nous fore/ousa braxi/onas.
pe/cainto, 'would get shorn.' The use of the middle is curious; cf. Pseudo-Phocyl. 166 a)/rourai lh/ia keira/menai.
au)toe/nei, 'in one year.'
e)bollo/man = e)boulo/mhn.
a)ki/ras, 'idle.'
a)mmete/ras…xqono/s see Introd.
)*efu/ras Corinth; cf. xvi. 83. Syracuse was a colony from Corinth.
sqq. o(\s…a)palalke/men, 'he knows many a skilful healing art to keep disease from men.'
no/sois is acc. plur. a)palalke/men, infin. dependent on fa/rmaka e)da/h. The form is Epic rather than Aeolic.
peda/ = meta/: cf. xxix. 38.

kh=no = e)kei=no, tw)/pos = to\ e)/pos: 'thus shall one say who sees thee: truly a little gift, but great the love; and love makes all things precious'; cf. A. Pal. vi. 227 o)li/ghn do/sin a)ll' a)po\ qumou= and the Homeric do/sis d' o)li/gh te fi/lh te (Odyss. vi. 208).
su/n cf. a)su_ne/thmi tw=n a)ne/mwn sta/sin, Alcaeus.

div1.p: This and the following idyll are the most purely personal in the collection, and together with xii show Theocritus in the light of a love-poet. While however xii was conventional in form and feeling, these open the poet's heart more unreservedly. They show a pure and tender feeling of chivalrous attachment constant in disappointment, not without self-condemnation for entertaining hope, but still hopeful of a consummation of pure friendship. The tone is reserved but breathes sincerity, and seems to show that Theocritus knew nothing and would know nothing of the abuses to which these friendships led in Greek society.

The metre is -V -uu -uu -uu- uU, glyconic expanded by two dactyls.
Cf. Alcaeus, 25 a)ntre/yei ta/xa ta)\n po/lin: a) d' e)/xetai r(o/pas.

div2.p: a)la/qea = a)lh/qeia: '"wine and truth" runs the proverb, lad'; cf. the proverb 'in vino veritas,' Theogn. 500 a)ndro\s d' oi)=nos e)/deice no/on: Alcaeus, 53 oi)=nos ga\r a)nqrw/pois di/optron: Schol. Plato, Sympos. 218 e e)/sti de\ a)/|smatos )*alkai/ou a)rxh\ oi)=nos w)= fi/le pai= kai\ a)lh/qeia.
The order is kh)/gw me\n e)re/w ta\ ke/at' (= kei=ntai) e)n muxw=| frenw=n.
e)gw\ me/n with personal pronouns me/n is not infrequently used where no de/ clause follows; cf. vii. 50; similarly Iliad i. 234, etc.
e)qe/lhsqa 2nd sing. pres. indic. from e)qe/lhmi. Aeolic adds -qa to the termination; Ahrens (Dial. Aeol. p. 139) would write e)qe/leisqa, fi/leisqa (Sappho, 22), e)/xeisqa (Theogn. 1316), etc.

file/ein is no Aeolic form. The line is imitated by Nicet. Eugen. v. 35:
sou= mh\ filei=n qe/lontos e)k yuxh=s me/shs
dokw= poqeinh=s h(/misu zwh=s e)/xein.
Cf. Callim. Epig. 41.
za/ = dia/: so za/dhlos = dia/dhlos, *zo/nnucos = *dio/nusos. Cf. the formation of fra/zw from fra/d-j-w.
i)de/an, 'beauty.'

maka/ressin i)/san cf. Sappho, 2:
fai/netai/ moi kh=nos i)/sos qeoi=sin
e)/mmen w)/nhr, o)/stis e)nanti/os toi
i(za/nei.
e)n sko/tw| Lucret. 5 'in tenebris vita ac maerore iacebat.'
o(/ta = o(/te.
ou)k the negative attaches inseparately to the verb and forms a single notion, 'when you refuse.' Hence ou) is allowed in spite of the subjunctive.
di/dwn = dido/nai, Ahrens, op. cit. p. 141; cf. vii. 124 na/rkaisi didoi/h.
'Make thee a single nest in a single tree where no poisonous thing shall come.'

kali/a Leonidas, 91 (A. Pal. vii. 736):
mh\ fqei/reu, w)/nqrwpe, peripla/nion bi/on e(/lkwn,
a)/llhn e)c a)/llhs ei)s xqo/n' a)lindo/menos:
mh\ fqei/reu: keneh\ se periste/yaito kalih/,
h(\n qa/lpoi mikko\n pu=r a)nakaio/menon, k.t.l.
o(/pph| mhde/n, 'where it shall not come.' The sentence is final; cf. Soph. O. T. 1412 e)kri/yat', e)/nqa mh/pot' ei)so/yesq' e)/ti, etc.
ma/ths 2nd sing. pres. ma/thmi, 'to search for.'
e)ge/neu cf. xii. 25, note.

tri/taion sc. fi/lon, 'thou makest him a friend of three
days' standing,' in contrast to trie/ths fi/los above, 'a friendship three years old.' Cf. the complaint, Theognis, 1311:
e)mh\n de\ meqh=kas a)ti/mhton filo/thta,
ou) me\n dh\ tou/tois g' h)=sqa fi/los pro/teron:
a)ll' e)gw\ e)k pa/ntwn s' e)do/koun e)/ssesqai e(tai=ron
pisto/n: kai\ dh\ nu=n a)/llon e)/xeisqa fi/lon.
a)ll' o( me\n eu)= e(/rdwn kei=mai, k.t.l.

a)/ndrwn…pne/ein the only way to explain this is to understand pneu=ma from pne/ein so that a)/ndrwn shall depend on pneu=ma not on the verb; 'you seem to breathe the spirit of swelling pride.' It is possible that a)/ndrwn is a gloss and has displaced an accusative, e. g. u(/brin (so Meineke). Fritzsche joins pne/ein with a)/ndrwn, etc., and compares Arist. Knights 437 sukofanti/as pnei=, but the genitive of a concrete expression like a)/ndrwn tw=n u(pe/r- could not be so used.
a)kou/seai, 'thou shalt be called'; cf. xvi. 30.
kh)/me 'and has changed my iron heart to yielding.' For e)c cf. xxii. 112; Soph. O. T. 454 tuflo\s e)k dedorko/tos, etc.
pe/r = u(pe/r, Ahr. Dial. Aeol. p. 151; Alcaeus, 18 pe\r me\n ga\r a)/ntlos i(stope/dan e)/xei: cf. Theocr. xxx. 3. 'I beseech thee by thy soft lips to remember.'
pede/rxomai = mete/rxomai: so peda/ (l. 38) = meta/. For the sense of the verb cf. Herod. vi. 68 e)gw\ w)=n se mete/rxomai tw=n qew=n ei)pei=n to\ a)lhqe/s.
o)mna/sqhn = Attic a)namnhsqh=nai (so a)mna/seie, Pind. P. i. 47 = a)namna/seie, Ahrens, Dial. pp. 141, 149). Both in pe/r and pe/rusin the vowel before the liquid is counted long.
fo/rh 3rd pers. sing. pres. indic.; but these forms in -h are doubtful. Ahrens would write fo/rei (Dial. Aeol. p. 92).

bardu/teroi, 'we are too slow to seize a winged thing'; the full form of the construction is bradu/teroi h)\ w(/ste sullabei=n. Similarly Thucyd. ii. 61 tapeinh\ u(mw=n h( dia/noia e)gkarterei=n a(\ e)/gnwte for tapeinote/ra h)\ w(/ste e)gkarterei=n.
a)ne/moisin cf. xxii. 167.
e)n q??mw|, 'say in your heart,' Odyss. xix. 209 au)ta\r )*odusseu\s qumw=| me\n goo/wsan e(h\n e)le/aire gunai=ka.
e)no/xlhs see note on 29 (fo/rh).

nu=n me/n. There is no need for any transposition of the lines. The apparent confusion arises merely from the paratactical structure of the Greek, where we should use a subordinate clause: 'If thou shouldst cast these words to the winds and say in thy heart "why troublest thou me?" then, while now for thy sake I would go to fetch the golden apples or to fetch back Cerberus the watcher of the dead, then I would not stir to thy doors even if thou didst call me, but would cease from the burden of my sickness.'

xru/sea ma=la suggest both an heroic exploit as of Heracles, and a journey to the limits of the world; cf. Callim. vi. 11 e(/st' e)pi\ dusma\s e(/st' e)pi\ tw\s me/lanas kai\ o(/pa| ta\ xru/sea ma=la.
bai/hn not a wish, but as in xvi. 67; hence ou)de/ not mhde/ in the following line.

div1.p: On the authenticity of this see Introd. § 3. The poem was only discovered in 1864 by Ziegler, and first published by Bergk in 1865. Yet the MS. in which alone it is preserved was thought to have been thoroughly collated more than once. The metre is as in xxviii. The person addressed is in all probability the same as in Id. xxix.

div2.p: tw= xalepw= cf. ii. 95; and for the genitive iv. 40.

tetortai=os, 'like a quartan-fever'; w(s is omitted as in xiii. 24, etc. The point of the simile is explained by l. 5. The fever comes and goes, and so his love as yet holds him for a day and lets him go, but soon will give him no rest.
3, 4 The text is here too corrupt to admit of convincing emendation; and no one's proposal has yet been accepted by another. I can hardly hope for better success.

ka/lw me\n metri/ws of the MS. is hardly defensible. It would not mean 'fair in due proportion,' but 'fair enough,' somewhat disparagingly, and this is not a place for disparagement. Both sides of the antithesis being doubtful we can hardly expect to reach certainty in restoration; but granted that ma=kos me\n metri/w g' is the sense intended, if not the actual words, the following clause as given in the text makes good sense. 'Not very tall is he, but all his height above the earth, all this is gracefulness.' Cf. A. Pal. xii. 93:
o(/ste kaq' u(/yos
ou) me/gas ou)rani/h d' a)mfite/qhle xa/ris:
and comically in Arist. Acharn. 909:
*b. mikko/s ga ma=kos ou(=tos. *d. a)ll' a(/pan kako/n.
perre/xei = u(perre/xei: cf. xxix. 25.

tw= pe/da, 'with the height he has.' peda/ (meta/) gives the accompanying conditions; cf. Xen. Symp. ii. 15 kalo\s o( pai=s w)\n o(/mws su\n toi=s sxh/masin e)/ti kalli/wn fai/netai. (For the conjectures of others, see Ziegler and Hiller; that of Maehly is the most attractive, but fails to make a good antithesis.)

tai=s sc. h(me/rais: a strange ellipse and not found elsewhere, the nearest being Theophr. Char. 30 tai=s teta/rtais, 'on the fourth of each month.' The end of the line is however very uncertain. tai=s d' e)/ai (= e)a=|) a(me/rais (Maehly).
ta/xa, 'but soon there will be no rest, not enough for sleep.'
o(/son…e)pitu/xhn consecutive = tosou=ton w(/ste e)pituxei=n. Soph. O. T. 1191 tosou=ton o(/son dokei=n: Thucyd. i. 2 o(/son a)pozh=n: A. Pal. v. 138 ou) d' o(/son a)mpneu=sai baio\n e)w=si xro/non.
e)xqe/s, 'for yesterday in passing he stole a glance at me sidelong, ashamed to look me in the face, and flushed red.'

di' o)fru/gwn (= o)fru/wn), 'with head bent and looking from under the eyebrows.' o)fru/s has not here of course any notion of 'pride' or scowling (superciliose, Fritzsche), but simply forms the antithesis to poti/dhn a)nti/os. They say in Russian, gljadîtj iz podlobja, 'to glance from under the brow'; opp. 'to look boldly in the face.'
le/pt' a quick passing glance: kle/pt' (Kreussler) is pretty but not necessary. Cf. Ibycus, fr. 2 e)/ros au)=te me kuane/ois u(po\ blefa/rois take/r' o)/mmasi derko/menos.
w(/'ros = o( e)/ros.

ei)skale/sas, 'calling my heart before me.' Theocritus gives a new and quainter turn to such addresses to one's own heart as the Odyssean te/tlaqi dh\ kradi/h. Theognis, 1029 to/lma qume\ kakoi=sin o(/mws a)/tlhta peponqw/s: Archiloch. 66, etc. Cf. A. Pal. v. 23:
yuxh/ moi prole/gei feu/gein po/qon (*hliodw/ras
…fhsi\ me/n: a)lla\ fugei=n ou)/ moi sqe/nos: h( ga\r a)naidh\s
au)th\ kai\ prole/gei kai\ prole/gousa filei=.
ti/ e)/sxaton, 'what will be the end of this thy folly?' We should probably scan ti/ 'sxaton rather than ti/ e)/sxaton.
w(=ra, 'time to bethink thee whether thou art no longer young to look on. ...'
frone/ein takes the same construction as a verb of fearing here; cf. Xen. Cyrop. i. 1. 3 metanoei=n mh\ ou) tw=n a)duna/twn h)=| to\ a)nqrw/pwn a)/rxein.
, 'Thou doest all that the young in years would do.' a)/rti gegeu/menoi, cf. A. Pal. Append. 238 mh/pw geusa/menon h(/bhs: ib. vii. 76 a)/rti d' a)ro/trou geuo/menon.

bi/os e(/rpei, k.t.l. 'For his life speeds on swift as a roebuck, and to-morrow he will loose his sails for a voyage to another port, nor yet does the flower of his youth remain among his fellows.' Three warnings are contained in the three metaphors: first, that the lad is active of mind and body as a deer, and therefore no companion for an older man; secondly, that he changes his affection from day to day (cf. xxix. 14 sqq.); thirdly, that his prime of youth will soon be past (cf. vii. 120).
o)mmimnaskome/nw| = a)namimnhskome/nw|.

o)/rh (o)/rhmi) : o(ra=|. Hiller compares aptly Horace, Odes iv. 1. 37:
'Nocturnis ego somniis
Iam captum teneo, iam volucrem sequor
Te per gramina Martii
Campi, te per aquas, dure, volubiles.'
He makes the subject the same as tw=| de/. Is it not rather o( po/qos personified?

e)memya/man, 'this charge did I make against my heart.' me/mfesqai pro/s tina elsewhere = 'to lay a complaint before a judge': Xen. Oec. xi. 23 h)\ me/myomai/ tina pro\s tou\s fi/lous h)\ e)painw= (cf. le/gein ei)s dikasta/s).
doki/moi (doki/mwmi) = 'thinks.'

toi/s acc. plur. 'He thinks to discover easily how many nines of stars there are above our heads'; cf. Nicet. Eugen. iv. 411:
dokei= de/ moi/ tis a)\n pare/lqh| kai\ fu/gh|
)/*erwta to\n tu/rannon e)pterwme/non
kai\ tou\s e)f' u(/yous e)kmetrh/sein a)ste/ras.
o(ppossa/kin = o(posa/kis.

e)nne/a the form of expression is chosen because of the mystic nature of the number nine. Plato's tyrant is 729 times as unhappy as the perfect citizen (729 = 93). Nicias, retreating from Syracuse, has to wait twenty-seven days (33) because of an eclipse of the moon. Ausonius (Id. xi) 'ter bibe vel totiens ternos: sic mystica lex est.'
to\n a)/mfena = to\n au)xe/na.
makro\n sxo/nta, 'stretching out my neck,' like a horse pulling a heavy load. Nonnus, D. xiv. 265 ei)s zugo\n au)toke/leuston e(kou/sion au)xe/na tei/nas (Hiller).
31, 32 'But me, the leaf of a day, that needs but a breath of wind (to make it fall), it carries where it listeth.'
o)ne/mwn = a)ne/mwn.
deu/menon not for deuo/menon, but contracted from deo/menon--a Doric rather than Aeolic form. For the contraction, cf. Herond. v. 19 tw=n se gouna/twn deu=mai.

body.head: Commentary: Epigrams
body.p:
The epigrams given here are those which are preserved in the MS. of Theocritus, as well as in the Anthology. Two more are ascribed to the poet in A. Pal. vii. 262:
au)dh/sei to\ gra/mma ti/ sh=ma/ te kai\ ti/s u(p' au)tw=|:
*glau/khs ei)mi\ ta/fos th=s o)nomazome/nhs:
and A. Plan. 253:
a)/nqrwpe, zwh=s perifei/deo, mhde\ par' w(/rhn
nauti/los i)/sqi: kai\ w(\s ou) polu\s a)ndri\ bi/os.
The latter appears also in A. Pal. vii. 534, under the name of Automedon, with four more lines added:
o\ei/laie *kleo/nike, su\ d' ei)s liparh\n *qa/son e)lqei=n
h)pei/geu koi/lhs e)/mporos e)k *suri/hs,
e)/mporos w)= *kleo/nike: du/sin d' u(/po *pleia/dos au)th\n
pontoporw=n au)th=| *pleia/di sugkate/dus.
The authenticity of these two is more than doubtful. Of the others Nos. 15, 7, 9, 11, 16, 20, 21 are ascribed in the Anthology to Leonidas of Tarentum or to 'Leonidas or Theocritus.' How
they came to be confused, whether Leonidas is the author of any of them, who is responsible for their insertion in the Anthology, are questions beyond the compass of this book. I must refer the student to Geffcken's Monograph (Leonidas von Tarent, Teubner, 1896, p. 10 sqq.) and the authorities there referred to. It is possible that a collection of epigrams by Theocritus and Leonidas (and others?) existed before the compilation of the Anthology, and a confusion of pages led to the error (Geffcken opposes this). It is curious that Meleager in his preface to the Anthology does not mention Theocritus, unless, contrary to all evidence, we see our poet's name and not that of Asclepiades concealed in the pseudonym *sikeli/dhs, v. 46 *sikeli/dew/ t' a)ne/mois a)/nqea fuo/mena. Did Meleager insert any of Theocritus' epigrams in the collection?

div1.p:
The Anthology gives no name, but there is no reason to suspect the authenticity. The style is strikingly like that of Leonidas in his dedicatory epigrams; cf. A. Pal. 82 (Leonid. 82, Geffck.):
*qh=ris o( daidalo/xeir ta=| *palla/di ph=xun a)kamph=
kai\ tetano\n nw/tw| kampto/menon pri/ona:
kai\ pe/lekun r(uka/nan t' eu)page/a kai\ periage\s
tru/panon e)k te/xnas a)/nqeto pausa/menos:
another indication of close connexion between Theocritus and the Tarentine.

div2.p: e)malofo/rei cf. Id. ii. 120.
ph/ran Id. i. 49.

div1.p: To Daphnis sleeping.

div2.p: kaqapto/menos kisso/n, 'with ivy bound about his head.'
kw=ma katagro/menon the gathering drowsiness (?); but katagei/rw does not occur elsewhere; ? katerxo/menon, 'coming upon thee.'

div1.p:
A description of a rude figure of Priapus to whom the speaker will offer sacrifice if the god grant him relief from his sorrowing. Possibly Leonidas refers to this epigram in his lines (A. Plan. 261):
fu/lac e(/sthka *pri/hpos
…ei(/sato ga\r pisto/n me *qeo/kritos…

div2.p: a)poste/rcai cf. xiv. 50.
*da/fnidos…po/qous, 'love for Daphnis.'
keu)qu/s, 'and promise that I will sacrifice'; the idea of saying is given by eu)/xeo.

h)\n d' a)naneu/sh|, 'but if he refuses, if I win my quest I will sacrifice thrice as much.' The prayer for deliverance from the love is but half-hearted; the real wish is to continue in the love and win.
khrode/tw| pneu/mati, 'the breathing of his wax-bound reed'; cf. ix. 19 puri\ drui/nw|, 'fire of oak logs,' and note on that passage.
to\ ple/on, 'what is thy gain?' cf. viii. 17.
diglh/nous w)=pas the adj. contains a word of same meaning, as the subst. w)=pas: cf. A. Pal. v. 196 eu)plo/kamon ki/kinnon, etc.
o)sti/on ou)de\ te/fra, 'neither bone nor ash'; the first negative being omitted: Aesch. Agam. 532 *pa/ris ga\r ou)/te suntelh\s po/lis, etc.

div1.p: The epigram refers to a statue of Aesculapius set up by Nicias and carved for him by Eetion, but it obviously was not intended to be engraved on the pedestal.

div2.p: i(knei=tai, 'entreats him with sacrifice.'
glu/yato, 'got carved.' Note the use of the middle voice, cf. Dem. 520. 2; Hdt. ii. 135.
polla=s patri/dos, 'instead of the wide fields of my native land I lie in a narrow robe of foreign soil.'
e)fessa/menos Ap. Rhod. i. 691 o)i/omai h)/dh gai=an e)fe/ssesqai: Soph. O. C. 1701 w)= to\n a)ei\ kata\ ga=s sko/ton ei(me/nos.
e)pi\ cei/nhs ce/non cf. Soph. Philoct. 135 e)n ce/na| ce/non.
u(mnoqe/ths, 'the poet'; a)oidoqe/ths, A. Pal. vii. 50. I should prefer au)tw=| for au)toi=s.
pa/ntwn depends on khdemo/nas.
qew=n as monosyllable; 'common in tragedy, never in comedy,' Shilleto.

to
 h(/diston qew=n prose would require to
 h(/diston tw=n qew=n, since of two nouns thus dependent if one has the article both would have it; cf. Pind. Is. vii. 8 to
 fe/rtaton qew=n.
e)k se/qen a)rxome/nois cf. xvii. 1.
tra/peza, 'money-changer's table,' 'bank.'
qei\s a)nelou=, 'take up your deposit when the account is reckoned up'; cf. A. Pal. v. 180 fe/re to\n lo/gon: e)lqe\ labou=sa *fru/nh ta\s yh/fous.

div1.p: In the Anthology the first couplet of the epigram is erroneously attached to the preceding epigram. A. Pal. 657 (Leonidas). Hence possibly the ascription of this epigram to Leonidas in the Anthology (see Geffcken, op. cit. p. 11).

div2.p: polloi=s h(likih=s, 'fullness of years' = pollw=n e)te/wn: cf. Agathias, A. Pal. vii. 734 ou)/pw th=s nomi/mhs e)/mpleon h(liki/hs. The explanation of Hiller (pollw=n h(li/kwn) is very unsatisfactory.
e)n e(toi/mw|, 'in promptu'; cf. xxii. 61.

w)= ce/ne cf. xxiii. 47; A. Pal. vii. 544:
ei)pe\ poti\ *fqi/an eu)a/mpelon h)/n poq' i(/khai
kai\ po/lin a)rxai/an w)= ce/ne *qaumaki/an
w(s…ei)=des *la/mpwnos to/nd' e)pi\ paidi\ ta/fon, k.t.l.
Cf. Idyll vii. 4.
The metre of the epigram is alternately iambic trimeter and hendecasyllable.

div1.p: On a statue of Epicharmus, the first writer of comedy.

The meter is a four-line stanza, in which the second and fourth lines are the same. The first line is trochaic tetrameter catalectic: -u-- -u-- -u-- -u-. The second and fourth lines are a reizianum whose base may be resolved: W -uu- -. The third line is iambic trimeter: --u- u-u- u-u-.

div2.p: eu(rw/n cf. Isocr. 24 c tou\s prw/tous eu(ro/ntas tragw|di/an.
xa/lkeon…a)ne/qhkan cf. Idyll x. 33, and the lines of Hermesianax (Athenaeus, 597 a) quoted in Introd. § 1, p. 11.

toi\…pedwristai/, i.e. 'oi(\…meqomilhtai\ a pedaori/zein quod in pedwri/zein abiit. Dativus po/lei pendet ab ipso illo pedwristai\ quasi dicas toi=s poli/tais meqomilou=ntes' (Meineke). The statue is erected by natives of Cos resident in Syracuse.
oi(=' a)ndri\ poli/ta|, 'as if to their own fellow-citizen.'
swro\n ga/r, 'for a store of language had he to requite those that remember him. For many an utterance did he make to help the life of men.'
memname/nous of the MSS. could only be kept if we joined it to telei=n as a command, and put a stop at r(hma/twn, 'remember and pay him his due.'
ei)=pe_, not ei)=pe^.

div1.p: On the iambic poet Hipponax, noted for his bitter satiric verse.
The metre, like that of Hipponax himself, is the scazon iambic.

Epigrams on Hipponax are frequent in the Anthology, but all
make a different point--the danger of approaching the poet even in death; cf. Leonidas, 40 (A. Pal. vii. 408):
a)tre/ma to\n tu/mbon paramei/bete mh\ to\n e)n u(/pnw|
pikro\n e)gei/rhte sfh=k' a)napauo/menon.
…ta\ ga\r pepurwme/na kei/nou
r(h/mata phmai/nein oi)=de kai\ ei)n )*ai/dh|.
The metre is alternately Phalacean hendecasyllable and Archilochian, the system of the latter being -W -W -W -W = -u-u -- i. e. four dactyls or equivalents in first half, then an ithyphallic.

div2.p: *qrai+/ssa cf. Herond. i. 1 *qre/issa a)ra/ssei th\n qu/rhn tis: Theocr. ii. 70.
o(dw=| the last syllable of the first half of the line may be long instead of short.
guna\ a)nti/ synizesis.
a)nti\ th/nwn w(=n e)/qreye = a)nti\ th/nwn a(\ e)/qreye, or in ordinary idiom a)nq' w(=n e)/qreye, 'in return for her nursing.'

div1.p: On a statue of Archilochus.
The metre is ll. 1 and 4 Archilochian (cf. Epig. 20), ll. 2 and 5 iambic trimeter, ll. 3 and 6 iambic trimeter catalectic.

div2.p: sta=qi kai\ ei)/side the first verb is interposed in the construction, Xen. Hellen. vii. 3 u(mei=s tou\s peri\ )*arxi/an ou) yh=fon a)nemei/nate a)lla\ e)timwrh/sasqe.
nu/kta…a)w= west and east.

div1.p: On a statue of Peisander, an Epic poet of the seventh century B.C. He wrote a Heracleis in two books, of which barely a fragment survives. The metre is hendecasyllabic.

div2.p: e)pa/nwqe cf. vii. 5.

div1.head: Megara.
div1.p: See Introd. § 3, etc. The poem consists of a dialogue between Megara, the wife of Heracles, and Alcmene. The former asks the cause of Alcmene's pallor and appearance of grief, and in the course of her conversation tells briefly the story of Heracles' murder of his children. Alcmene in answer tells of a dream foreboding fresh suffering to Heracles and woe to herself.

div2.p: a)ndro/s sc. Eurystheus.
fae/essin e)moi=sin, 'my eyes.'
sfete/rh|sin, 'his.'
sxe/tlios exclamatory nominative; cf. xii. 34, note.

*khrw=n…be/lemna, 'dread weapon of some Fury or Spirit of Death' (A. Lang); cf. Musaeus 308 of Hero's lamp, *moira/wn a)ne/faine kai\ ou)ke/ti dalo\n )*erw/twn. Hercules received his arrows as a gift from Apollo, his sword from Hermes, his breastplate from Hephaestus.
to\ d' ou)d' o)/nar, 'such a thing as has come on none other even in his dreams.'
kat' au)tou/s, 'near them'; Iliad xvii. 732 a)ll' o(/te dh/ r(' *ai)/ante metastrefqe/nte kat' au)tou\s stai/hsan.
h)= r(a MSS. h)= ga/r oi(: cf. xv. 112, note, but probably in all places where ga/r precedes oi( and a short syllable is required we should read r(a. Cf. Iliad ii. 665; xi. 339; xxiii. 865; xxiv. 72.
ai)noto/keia, 'most miserable of mothers'; cf. xxiv. 73, note.
pollo\n…do/mon, 'the wide halls,' 'ampla domus'; cf. xxii. 156 pollh/ toi *spa/rth: Epig. ix. 3 polla=s patri/dos.

a. Some such line as that supplied by Hermann seems necessary. Without it )/*artemi, k.t.l., becomes quite a pointless address to the goddess; with it Megara expresses a double wish either that she had been slain by Heracles or had died at the hands of Artemis. This accords well with what follows, 31-35.
o(/qi sc. 'in Thebes.'
oi( me/n sc. tokh=es.
pe/trhs…sidh/rou cf. Idyll x. 7; xiii. 5.

lei/betai cf. v. 28, note, and for the expression, Iliad ix. 14:
i(/stato dakruxe/wn w(/s te krh/nh mela/nudros,
h(/te kat' ai)gi/lipos pe/trhs dnofero\n xe/ei u(/dwr.
Psalm xxii. 15 'I am poured out like water; all my bones are out of joint.'

h)/maq' o(po/ssa, 'every day'; cf. 'quotquot eunt dies'; 'quot annis,' etc.: but h)/mata is nominative not accusative, e)sti/ being supplied: see Odyss. viii. 214 pa/nta ga\r ou) kako/s ei)mi, met' a)ndra/sin o(/ssoi a)/eqloi.
mh/lwn cf. xiv. 38.
daimoni/h pai/dwn cf. Odyss. xiv. 443 daimo/nie cei/nwn. The sense here is rather 'poor child'--in pity--than 'noble child.' The latter meaning is always employed somewhat formally; cf. xxii. 62.
to\ deu/taton ai)ei/…, 'continually to the last day of our lives.'

sqq. 'In love with sorrow would he be who would count them'; namely the sorrows oi(=s e)xo/mesqa. The vulgata lectio here yields no sense at all, nor has any emendation of single words proved at all satisfactory (a)riqmh/sein e(\n…qarsoi/h, Hermann, Ahrens, Meineke, which is beyond the understanding of any but themselves). I conjecture the missing hemistichs to be something like a)riqmh/seien a(/ per qeo\s a)/mmin e)/qhke a)/lgea: ti/s de/ ken
ei)/poi e)f'…, 'Who could count the sorrows God has laid upon us? And who would bid us have courage in this our woe? Not such is the destiny laid upon us' (i.e. not such as to be able, qarrei=n).
mhde/n, k.t.l. dependent on i)/stw, 'that I love thee no less than if ...'
h)\ ei) for the synizesis cf. xi. 81.
tw=|, 'therefore.'
h(/pat' = h(/pati: the 'i' of the dative is occasionally elided in Epic Greek: Iliad v. 5 a)ste/r' o)pwrinw=| e)nali/gkion.

e)/rdoi cf. x. 45, note. The kind of personification whereby the vision is said to do the hurt (e)/rdoi) is curious, but such confusions between a premonition and a cause are not hard to parallel in popular lore.

dedegme/nos, 'having received the task.' It is noticeable how much stronger and vivid the verse becomes from this point to the end. The weaker strain of the opening of the poem nowhere gives the impression of easy workmanship. Possibly this is an evidence of early date, but there is no real evidence.
ou)k e)qe/lonta a touch of quite Homeric simplicity!
ma/ntis 'and may my foreboding prophesy ill to him, and may God bring nought to pass besides.'
